HEADLINE: PATH IS CLEARED FOR CUTS IN FEES FOR LONG DISTANCE

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 31

 BODY:
The federal government and many of the nation's leading telephone companies agreed today to a reshuffling of phone rates that would reduce the bills of tens of millions of less-affluent consumers.
The reductions, described by officials of the Federal Communications Commission as the largest rate cut in the history of federal telephone regulation, should lead to less-significant cuts for other consumers and businesses. And the changes could ultimately lead to a flat rate for long-distance service, much like fees paid by mobile phone users. 
 Government officials said they had a commitment from the long-distance companies to pass on to consumers the benefits of $3.2 billion in savings from a reduction in the payments they make to local telephone companies to connect calls to customers, known as access charges.
Officials said the cuts would have the biggest effect on the poor and those who use their phones the least. Rates would be reduced as much as 50 percent -- to $4.68 from $9.39 a month in a typical case -- for Americans who make few or no long-distance calls.
For consumers and businesses that make more long-distance calls, the government predicted reduced costs, though some consumer groups and Wall Street analysts disagreed with the government's estimates, suggesting they were too rosy.
The consumer groups and analysts questioned whether the significant savings recognized by the long-distance companies would ultimately be passed on to consumers. They also said that the government could not force the companies to pass the savings on to the consumers, who would have to rely on the good faith of the long-distance companies.
But officials said that when access charges were last reduced three years ago, the long-distance companies began engaging in a price war that drastically lowered overall phone rates.
The critics and analysts said, however, that long-distance companies had been slow to pass on all of the savings when the access charges were cut and that the benefit to consumers from the price wars was offset by new fees tacked on to their bills.
Critics and officials agreed that today's action would fundamentally reshape the economics of the telephone industry and that it was another big step toward deregulation. It is also part of an evolution toward a price structure in which long-distance rates will ultimately be like wireless and Internet service rates -- either a flat monthly fee or a fee that entitles the customer to a bundle of minutes.
"Today's announcement is a giant step forward in rationalizing pricing," said William E. Kennard, the chairman of the F.C.C. "This is the most dramatic reduction in telephone service prices in the history of this agency."
Mr. Kennard said the price changes would take effect in July. He said the commission's action was an effort to accelerate competition by ending several implicit subsidies.
Today's moves involved an agreement and an order by the F.C.C. They were the products of more than a year of intense negotiations among local and long-distance companies and federal regulators on issues that have divided the local and long-distance providers from the moment they were created with the breakup of AT&T 16 years ago.
Telephone executives from most of the nation's top companies applauded the order.
"When the results of today's action start showing up on customer bills in a month or so, consumers will see that the total cost of local and long-distance telephone service will be down," said Duane Ackerman, the chairman and chief executive of BellSouth.
"At the same time," he said, "those customers who live in rural areas that are expensive to serve and those people who need help paying their phone bills will be ensured affordable service well into the future."
Officials said that the companies had ultimately reached an agreement with one another and regulators because of several important trends, including the blurring of the lines between local and long-distance companies, the competitive threats posed by the emergence of telephone service on the Internet and the heavy pressure put on regulators by a Republican Congress to reduce regulations and let the marketplace play a greater role in setting prices.
As part of the agreement, AT&T said it would eliminate the $3 minimum monthly fee that it charges to millions of customers who make few or no long-distance calls.
Combined with other changes announced today, a typical monthly bill for an AT&T customer who makes no long-distance calls would be cut in half. For a customer who made 10 minutes of long-distance calls, total monthly charges would decrease 27 percent, to $6.87 from $9.39.
The order simplifies telephone bills by folding two separate charges -- one for the cost of telephone lines and the other a special access charge -- into one. It reduces an earlier announced rate increase for the combined items by 66 cents a month.
The centerpiece of the agreement, spelled out in the summary of the order that will soon be issued by the commission, reduces by $3.2 billion the access charges that long-distance companies like AT&T and Sprint pay to local telephone companies like Bell Atlantic to use their lines at the beginning and end of a call. The reduction amounts to a cut of about 25 percent in access fees paid to the local companies.
Commission officials said they could not precisely quantify the reduction for heavy users of long-distance services, and some analysts and consumer groups said they doubted that many of the savings would result in significantly lower bills.
"We hope that the F.C.C. will monitor this process to ensure that the $3.2 billion in long-distance company savings are translated into demonstrable price reductions for consumers," said Gene Kimmelman, co-director of the Washington office of Consumers Union.
"Today's decision is a clear benefit for people who make few or no long-distance calls," he said. "But it still leaves consumers paying inflated monthly charges."
Scott C. Cleland, a telecommunications analyst at the Legg Mason Precursor Group, said that experience had shown that the companies had not passed on savings from reductions in access charges.
"The companies have a fiduciary responsibility to their shareholders to not necessarily pass them on," Mr. Cleland said. "To the extent that prices don't fall, these savings increase long-distance profits. The companies may pass them on, but it will be over time."
Industry executives said the decision was part of a trend that will lead to long-distance fees' resembling the fees charged by Internet companies and cell phone providers.
"The pricing structure that these rules permit allows us to move more in the direction that will ultimately lead to Internet pricing or wireless pricing in the long-distance market," said John Nakahata, a former top official at the F.C.C. and spokesman for the coalition of telephone companies that signed the agreement.
As a result of the fee changes, local telephone companies stand to get a short-term shortfall of as much as $500 million over the next year. But industry executives and analysts said that lower prices should increase demand more than enough to offset the shortfall.
"This industry is growing at a rapid rate, and we're all realizing significant cost reductions," said Frank Gumper, vice president for regulatory and long-range planning at Bell Atlantic.
Traders on Wall Street shrugged off the announcement of the rate changes. There was no uniform movement in the stock prices of telephone companies, and changes were modest.
In a partial dissent to today's order, a commissioner accused the F.C.C. staff of making improper side deals with the telephone industry to gain its support for the order.
The commissioner, Harold Furchtgott-Roth, said that in exchange for the industry's support, the staff had agreed to waive certain onerous depreciation rules and rule favorably in a separate access fee proceeding. Both proceedings involve billions of dollars for the companies.
"To be clear, I do not believe that any employee of this agency acted in bad faith" Mr. Furchtgott-Roth wrote. "But I cannot escape the conclusion that the process by which this notice has been promulgated falls short of certain fundamental principles that govern the behavior of administrative agencies."
Both industry lobbyists and staff officials denied that any separate deals had been reached.

HEADLINE: Most Editorials Endorse Florio

 BODY:
Jon Corzine is easily winning the spending race, but former Gov. Jim Florio is emerging as the clear choice of newspaper editorial writers in the race for New Jersey's Democratic nomination for the United States Senate.
The Star-Ledger, New Jersey's largest daily newspaper, endorsed Mr. Florio's candidacy yesterday, calling him a "first-rate congressman and a gutsy governor." 
 The paper said the $2.8 billion tax increase that enraged voters was "probably" necessary at the time, with the state facing a $600 million deficit and the state constitution requiring a balanced budget.
Last month, Mr. Florio received endorsements from The New York Times, The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Chatham Courier, a weekly Morris County paper.
Thus far, his opponent, Jon Corzine, has been endorsed by The Times of Trenton, a Central New Jersey daily. Yesterday, the paper praised Mr. Corzine for business acumen, ability to work constructively with others and courage to campaign as a liberal.
"He sees government the way F.D.R., Truman, J.F.K., L.B.J. and Humphrey saw it: an instrument for addressing what he calls 'the great unfinished business of social and economic justice,' " the editorial said.

HEADLINE: Once and Again a Republican, but Always Libertarian

SERIES: IN THE RUNNING: Last of four profiles of the Republican candidates for the Senate in New Jersey.

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN 

DATELINE: TOTOWA, N.J., May 31

 BODY:
Murray Sabrin is waving a maroon-bound pocket-size version of the United States Constitution to make a point.
"This is our contract with the people," he said. "This is my agenda, if you will, to restore the principles here, to put a fire wall around the Bill of Rights." 
 Try as he might, Mr. Sabrin still sounds like a Libertarian, even though he is running for the United States Senate as a Republican.
He wants to eliminate the federal income tax, and while other politicians decry urban sprawl, he sees no problem with it. He has had it with demands for political correctness and affirmative action and gun control.
Mr. Sabrin, 53, ran for governor three years ago on the Libertarian Party ticket, raised enough in contributions to qualify for public funds, and picked up more than 100,000 votes, something that no other third-party candidate for statewide office in New Jersey had ever done. He still came in a distant third, but not before worrying Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, who won a narrow re-election victory, that he was taking away some of her more conservative constituents.
And now he is back, in a new incarnation as a Republican, but sounding very much like the old Murray Sabrin.
"The theme of this campaign is that we want to end political correctness," he said recently. "The government shouldn't be establishing or mandating preference programs."
Mr. Sabrin, a professor of finance at Ramapo College in Mahwah, may have changed parties, but he is clearly still the odd man out in this race, a crowded one with four candidates vying in Tuesday's primary. The other Republicans are State Senator William Gormley, United States Representative Robert D. Franks and the Essex County executive, James W. Treffinger.
If the outcome is determined in part on ties to party leaders, it is clear that this will be a party to which Mr. Sabrin was not invited.
"I don't consider Murray Sabrin a Republican," said Chuck Haytaian, the chairman of the state Republican Party, practically sputtering.
"I think he's a Libertarian with some very outlandish views. He should not be running in this primary," Mr. Haytaian said.
But party rules say anyone who gathers 1,000 names on a petition can run in a primary, and Mr. Sabrin did just that.
Mr. Sabrin may have won 114,000 votes in the 1997 election for governor, but that was less than 5 percent of the total, said Tom Wilson, Mrs. Whitman's campaign manager then. Mr. Wilson said Mr. Sabrin remained a fringe candidate with no real chance of winning the nomination.
"New Jersey Republicans are, for the most part, open-minded, inclusive, progressive, mainstream, middle-of-the-road, moderate type Republicans," he said. "Will he get some votes? Of course he will. There are people who choose to use their vote to send a message to the establishment or whoever that they don't like the status quo."
So far, Mr. Sabrin has raised $328,000, but that is small compared with what his opponents have raised. One of them, Mr. Gormley, has raised $2.4 million. Mr. Wilson said that was another strong indicator of the limited support for Mr. Sabrin.
"Murray Sabrin is the Lyndon LaRouche of New Jersey," Mr. Wilson said. "He can put his name on the ballot any time he wants, but he's making a joke of the whole electoral process."
Mr. Sabrin says the Republican Party needs the kind of agenda he is offering. "Last time around, the Republican candidate didn't get that marginal voter that's going to elect a Republican in the state, the pro-lifers and the Second Amendment voters," he said. "That's who will vote for me."
His supporters tend to sound a lot like he does.
"He's developed a following of people like me who are just fed up to their ears with what's going on in Washington," said Frank Reick, an inventor and businessman in Washington Township who, along with his wife has donated about $15,000 to Mr. Sabrin's campaigns since 1997. "I'm a firm believer in the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, and so is Murray."
Mr. Sabrin has been endorsed in this race by New Jersey Right to Life and by the Association of Rifle and Pistol Clubs. He wants to legislatively overturn the Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion, and is very much against any gun controls. But he is not, he insists, anti-government. If he must be reduced to a label, he said he was for limited government.
"If I were truly anti-government, I would be in the hills somewhere opting out, and I'm not," he said recently, sitting in his campaign office in a shopping mall here, an American flag behind him, and an autographed photograph of Rush Limbaugh in front of him on his desk. "I am the only candidate who has true conservative grass-roots support. "
Mr. Sabrin was born in Germany to parents who were the only ones in their family to survive the Holocaust. He grew up in the Bronx and attended the Bronx High School of Science and Hunter College. His first job was as a teacher in New York City.
He went on to get his Ph.D. in economic geography from Rutgers University, and worked as an analyst and economist. He has taught at Ramapo College since 1985.
Mr. Sabrin bristles at criticism that while he calls for limited government and low taxes and no social safety net, he has benefited from attending a tuition-free college, and he works for a public college.
"To criticize me is extremely mean-spirited," he said. "I went to college before I had read anything about Libertarian ideas. It was an opportunity that was available." The public college he teaches at, Mr. Sabrin adds, raises a significant part of its budget from tuition.
He also said he was not surprised that many of his opponents were criticizing his change of parties after he lost as a Libertarian. He is merely returning to the party he belonged to in his youth, he said.
"I joined the Republican Party in 1969 with the views of freedom and individual liberties and free enterprise and an adequate national defense," he said.
"Those were my core beliefs then, and they haven't wavered one bit. I was a Republican long before I even heard the term Libertarian."
He is stung that he is sometimes the only one of the four candidates not invited to take part in some of the debates or forums that have been held throughout the state. And he knows the Republican Party leaders would rather he not be running under their banner.
"This is part of the process of the people in the Republican establishment wanting to make sure that the Republican Party is not much different than the Democratic Party," he said.

HEADLINE: New York and New Jersey Are Said to Be Nearing an Accord on the Port Authority

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, May 31

 BODY:
Negotiations to end an impasse between Gov. George Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman that has blocked major new projects by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey are nearing a successful conclusion, associates of both officials said today.
Charles Gargano, New York's chief negotiator and the vice chairman of the agency, would not discuss details of the talks, but said, "We are at the point of submitting something to the two governors." 
 Lewis Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority board and New Jersey's chief negotiator, would say only that "we are close to a comprehensive agreement." While none of the negotiators for the two states would confirm that a final agreement was set, many who have been close to the efforts to end the 18-month logjam said in private that the final details were being worked out, paving the way for a long-sought meeting between the two governors. That largely symbolic meeting would be followed within days by a board meeting to ratify the accord.
At stake in the long dispute is the fate of a proposed 30-year lease to Maersk-Sealand, a major container cargo company at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal, that New Jersey insists is necessary for the port to remain competitive with other East Coast ports.
New York representatives on the Port Authority board, charging that the deal would amount to a deep subsidy for New Jersey, have refused to approve it, and New Jersey representatives have retaliated by refusing to approve two projects New York covets: privatization of the World Trade Center and the leasing of air rights over Manhattan's Port Authority Bus Terminal.
But all of those projects would get a go-ahead, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity, if the details of the emerging agreement were approved.
Six elements of that evolving agreement would appear to provide something for everyone. In an effort to assuage New York's concerns that New Jersey disproportionately benefits from agency spending, a $250 million pool of money, or "development bank," would be set aside for New York to spend on port- and transportation-related items over the next three years.
New Jersey would also agree to let the Port Authority lease space in, and thus help finance, the transportation and office center proposed for Manhattan's main post office building. In addition, New Jersey would end its opposition to a study of an increase in the $1 PATH fare, which New York has long considered to be unfairly subsidized by the Port Authority. Sources in both states conceded that this was likely to mean a fare increase by year's end.
They said the Port Authority would also invest development funds in South Jamaica, where a new terminal is planned to connect subway and commuter trains to a Kennedy International Airport rail link.
The deal being hammered out would provide New Jersey with the $120 million it had planned to spend to dredge major port channels, and with other concessions in the much-disputed valuation of the Maersk-Sealand lease. And it would require that guidelines be set to distinguish subsidies from investments in the region's transportation and commercial infrastructure -- a clarification that both governors have sought.
Kayla Bergeron, a spokesman for the agency, said it would have no comment on the ongoing talks.
The reports of a possible settlement come just a week after the agency's monthly board meeting, in which commissioners unanimously approved a $3.9 billion budget for this year in what Mr. Eisenberg and Mr. Gargano conceded was a sign of progress in the effort to end the impasse.
At the previous month's meeting the board failed to even vote on the budget, a sign that talks were faltering. Then as now, officials had suggested privately that an agreement was imminent.

HEADLINE: Hope and Fear on Social Security

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Campaigning on Social Security" (editorial, May 29):
You say the comparison of the projected returns on private Social Security accounts versus the return on money deposited as taxes in the trust fund is "highly misleading" because the "economy is expected to slow over the next several decades." But predicting large swings in the economy is as uncertain as guessing how the Mets will do in 20 years. 
 Second, changing the law to allow the government to invest in the stock market is a horrendous idea. With the amount of money that flows through Social Security, the trustees of such enormous accounts could destroy companies that rely on the capitalization of the stock market. Furthermore, one of the government's main responsibilities is to regulate corporate America to ensure a fair playing field. A stake in the game would erode that ability.
 
JAMES COOK
Stanford, Calif., May 29, 2000

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: By Anthony Ramirez

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: FILMING MOVED
A commercial scheduled to be filmed yesterday at Rikers Island using nonunion actors was canceled by Bernard Kerik, the head of the Correction Department, after the correction officers union raised concerns about crossing picket lines. The Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists have been on strike against commercial producers since May 1 over pay issues. A spokesman for Southwestern Bell Communications said its commercial would still be produced, but not at Rikers. Tina Kelley (NYT) 

MANHATTAN: GUN CONTROL BILL
Representative Jerrold L. Nadler said yesterday that he would introduce an amendment to the federal criminal code next week to bar the sale of guns in kit form through magazines and the Internet. Mr. Nadler, a Democrat whose district includes parts of Manhattan and Brooklyn, said his plan would change the definition of firearm in federal statutes to include components of guns like barrels, stocks and actions, thereby barring their sale across state lines. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)
 
BROOKLYN: PORNOGRAPHY PLEA
A Brooklyn man pleaded guilty yesterday to running a worldwide child pornography club on the Internet in which members traded pornographic images of prepubescent boys and girls. The man, Peter Giordano, 37, admitted in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to having created the online club named '#wOnderland' after "Alice in Wonderland." Prosecutors said Mr. Giordano operated the site from March 1997 to September 1998 and restricted membership to people who had at least 10,000 pornographic images. Alan Feuer (NYT)
 
NEW YORK CITY: MORE JOBS
New York is second only to Atlanta in the number of jobs created in the last year, according to figures on employment in metropolitan areas released yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Employers in New York added 90,500 positions in the year ended April; Atlanta added 103,000 and Los Angeles had an additional 88,200. But unemployment in New York City, at 5.1 percent, is the third highest among big cities, after Miami (5.6 percent) and Los Angeles (5.2 percent). Leslie Eaton (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: EAST SIDE ATTACKS
Two women were attacked within 10 minutes on the Upper East Side, but the police said no evidence thus far linked the attacks to an East Side rapist sought in assaults on at least 16 women. The first attack occurred Tuesday at 11:59 a.m. at East 92nd Street and Lexington Avenue, and the second at 12:08 p.m. at 93rd Street and Fifth Avenue, four blocks away. In both cases, the attackers fled when the women screamed. (AP)
 
MANHATTAN: HOSPITAL REVIEW
Beth Israel Medical Center has begun an outside review prompted by the case of Dr. Allan Zarkin, the obstetrician who carved his initials into a patient's abdomen after delivering her baby. The hospital has hired consultants from the Greeley Company, to recommend improvements in quality control and employee screening, as required under sanctions from the State Department of Health. Beth Israel must make improvements within a month of getting the consultants' reports. Edward Wong (NYT)
 
MANHATTAN: INVESTIGATION SOUGHT
Asian-American groups demanded yesterday that the federal government look into possible violations of civil rights laws in an attack on Asian students at the State University of New York in Binghamton on Feb. 27. The assault left a student with a fractured skull. The three suspects are white members of the school's wrestling team. The Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund began a letter-writing campaign yesterday to urge the Justice Department to open an investigation. (AP)
 
SARATOGA SPRINGS: PLAN FOR HUDSON
An independent panel of scientists last night endorsed the Environmental Protection Agency's conclusion that industrial chemicals in the upper Hudson River pose a cancer risk to people who regularly eat fish caught north of Poughkeepsie. The decision clears the way for the agency to decide how to clean up the river's last substantial form of pollution by the end of the year. The contamination consists of tons of polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, chemicals that were dumped from two General Electric factories 200 miles upriver from Manhattan until 1977.
 Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
MONTVALE: PRANK GOES AWRY
Senior Prank Day at Pascack Hills High School started last Thursday with a joke and ended with an ambulance when the principal was hospitalized with chest pains. Just before 10 a.m., a group of seniors, prompted by a secret cue over the school intercom, released hundreds of rubber balls, about 50 crickets and about a dozen mice and rats, students said yesterday. Officials questioned a senior girl about the intercom cue and some students walked out in protest. Two false fire alarms then sounded within an hour, prompting the school's 600 students to evacuate. After the alarms, the principal, Manual Ferreira, was taken to a hospital and underwent angioplasty for a clogged artery. Robert Hanley (NYT)
 
PATERSON: SCHOOLS PLAN
Paterson's public school system on Tuesday unveiled a five-year plan to build 11 schools for $570 million. Several of Paterson's schools are more than 100 years old. (AP)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
GREENWICH: DEMOLITION PLAN
The town has granted a permit to raze a house where a teenager was slain 25 years ago. Michael Skakel, a nephew of Ethel Kennedy, has been charged in the murder of 15-year-old Martha Moxley, who was beaten to death. The move ends uncertainty over whether lawyers would seek to delay demolition so that eventual jurors might view the crime scene. It was not known why the current owners of the 18-room house want to tear it down. (AP)
 
STORRS: NEW LAW DEAN
Nell Jessup Newton, a leading authority on American Indian law, will become the first woman to be dean of the University of Connecticut School of Law. Ms. Newton, dean of the University of Denver College of Law, will succeed Hugh Macgill, dean for 10 years. Theresa Crapanzano (NYT)

HEADLINE: Schools Chief Hears Parents' Concerns Firsthand

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
In his first major attempt to communicate with parents, Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy held a town meeting in Queens last night and fielded questions on standardized testing, sex education, summer school and other topics.
Several hundred parents, grandparents, teachers and others filled the auditorium at Francis Lewis High School in Flushing to hear the new chancellor speak. Mr. Levy, who became the permanent chancellor just two weeks ago, stood in front with a microphone as dozens of people waited in two long lines to ask questions. 
 Mr. Levy did not always give the answers they wanted to hear. When one mother asked if her son's school district could get better after-school programs, Mr. Levy replied that continuing training for teachers was more important. "It's a finite pool of money," he said. "If we had more, we'd do more."
And when another mother, Debra Artis of Flushing, complained about the new requirement that every student pass the State Regents exams to graduate, Mr. Levy vigorously defended the requirement. "If you can't read and you can't do math, there's not going to be a place for you in the new economy," Mr. Levy told her.
Afterward, Ms. Artis said she thought Mr. Levy's comments were insensitive and short-sighted.
"His attitude was like, 'You're stuck with it and you have no option,' " Ms. Artis said. "It's unfair because kids like my daughter are getting frustrated and it's causing them to drop out."
But Ms. Artis and another mother, Maxine Kupersmith of Flushing, praised Mr. Levy for allowing parents to vent their frustrations to him in person.
"It's very nice of him to take the time to do this," said Ms. Kupersmith, who has a son in the ninth grade. "He's not giving definite answers but at least he's listening."
New York City chancellors have long weathered criticism from parents for not involving them enough in policy decisions. Mr. Levy said last night that it would be an enormous challenge, but promised to make it a priority. He plans to hold one town meeting a month, starting in September, and to communicate with parents on talk radio shows.
"What I take away from this," Mr. Levy said after taking questions for two hours, "is a great sense of frustration with the inability to get the message across."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Minimum-Wage Rise Gets Pataki Support

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he supports the idea of increasing the minimum wage, as long as doing so does not negatively affect some economically disadvantaged areas of New York.
"I think it's the right thing to do, but it has to be done in such a way that it doesn't hurt the economic competitiveness of New York State," Governor Pataki said in Albany. 
 The governor said he was not sure whether regions with high unemployment rates, like the Catskills and the Adirondacks, would benefit or be harmed by legislation providing for a minimum wage increase.
Both houses of the State Legislature are considering bills that would increase the minimum wage to $6.75 from $5.15.

HEADLINE: In Bayonne, Blue-Collar Backlash Over Corzine's Spending

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: BAYONNE, N.J., May 30

 BODY:
The crash of bowling pins. Fifty-cent Budweisers. The Jersey Devils on the big television beating the pants off their Stanley Cup rivals.
Life doesn't get much better at the Knights of Columbus lounge, a dark and smoky cocoon where generations of stevedores, crane operators and refinery workers have drunk away their daily aches. 
 During a break in the hockey game, it was time again for the politicians to sell their wares. Like clockwork, the guy with the bold ideas and the bottomless bank account appeared on the bar's half-dozen screens.
Lou Rodrique, 75, drained his glass of beer as Jon S. Corzine, the Wall Street multimillionaire, took over the room. Through the din, an announcer could be heard saying something nasty about former Gov. Jim Florio, Mr. Corzine's opponent in next Tuesday's Democratic primary for the United States Senate. Mr. Rodrique, a World War II Navy veteran who worked at the Exxon refinery until it followed the other oil companies out of town, turned away and nearly spat with disdain.
"I just don't get it," he said. "I don't trust a guy who's spending this kind of money for a job that pays so little. There's gotta be something in it for him."
In a few short weeks, Mr. Corzine's $30 million juggernaut has transformed him from an obscure hopeful into a household name who, recent polls say, is the man to beat. But if the diehard Democrats in this fraying blue-collar town are any indication, Mr. Corzine may be overdoing his lavish spending campaign, one that is quickly making this Senate race the most expensive in American history.
There is little love expressed for elected officials here in Bayonne, and many residents still curse the tax increase championed by Mr. Florio a decade ago when he was governor. But even though Mr. Corzine bills himself as the independent outsider, his relentless advertising blitz and bottomless war chest are spurring a quiet backlash in some quarters.
Despite the support Mr. Corzine has won from Bayonne's Democratic leadership and the state's largest labor unions, many voters here say they will cast their lot with Mr. Florio, a man some now see as an embattled underdog, someone who might understand what it's like to be frustrated by a changing world.
"They're all a bunch of lying crooks," said Mr. Rodrique with the swat of his hand. "But I go for the little guy."
Then there is Joe Paszek, 44, a local postal worker who admits he is not following the race but is sure of one thing: "I'm sick of all those Corzine ads."
Sipping a beer at the Big Apple, a popular sports bar studded with 30 television screens, Mr. Paszek did not have to wait long before his gripe was borne out. "You see, you can't avoid the guy," he said. "Yuck."
In interviews, it was not hard to find those enchanted by Mr. Corzine and his commercials, although many confessed they had little sense of what the former Goldman Sachs executive stood for.
For some, it is enough to cheer on the person who is not Mr. Florio, a man many blame for the $2.8 million tax that was enacted while he was governor. For others, like George Bowe, 66, Mr. Corzine's self-generated wealth is to be admired. "It's not like he robbed a bank," said Mr. Bowe, a truck driver. "Either way, he's coming from nowhere, so he's got to get his name out there."
And then there are those like Tommy Akel, 40, a shaggy-haired longshoreman, who says Mr. Corzine's riches make him a free man. "No one can tell him what to do," said Mr. Akel, who plays the drums in a heavy-metal band called Attacker. "If he wins, they can't hold nothing over his head."
Still, up and down Broadway, the town's ailing commercial strip, most people held little hope that either candidate would have any impact on their two-square-mile peninsula.
Once a working man's paradise, Bayonne has lost nearly all of its big employers in recent years, from Texaco, which left behind 40 acres of tainted land, to the Army, which last year abandoned the Military Ocean Terminal, a huge complex that once employed 2,500 people.
Despite all the changes, Bayonne has weathered its economic traumas relatively well. Taxes are high, but crime is low and the schools are still among the best in Hudson County. The city of 61,000 has always been cushioned from the outside world by the water on three sides.
Unlike most of urban New Jersey, and especially its closest neighbors, Newark, Jersey City and Elizabeth, Bayonne is still dominated by ethnic whites, mostly the children of Polish, Italian and Irish immigrants. It is the kind of town where American flags flutter on every other porch. Democrats here outnumber Republicans 10 to 1, although voters will gladly cross party lines for the right candidate.
Leonard P. Kiczek, a former mayor who produces and is the host of a cable program called "Bayonne Today," predicted that few residents would vote in Tuesday's primary. "Folks here are busy working," he said. "Unless there's a burning issue, they're not going to the polls."
Robert Bailey, an associate professor of public policy at Rutgers University at Camden, said that he, too, sensed widespread apathy among working-class voters. He said he believed that the indifference would only grow as more people learned about Mr. Corzine's $400 million personal fortune and unprecedented spending habits.
"I think it reinforces the perception that the entire political process is a money game, not a political game," he said. "I think this really busts the scale."
Mr. Corzine's strategists might be heartened to meet Mark Minski, a refinery worker and part-time student who was hanging out with some friends in front of Showcase Hairstyling on Broadway. At 25, Mr. Minski hasn't seen too many Senate campaigns, but he knows a thing or two about life in Bayonne. Jobs are scarce, taxes are high and politicians rarely speak the truth, he said. Although he hasn't been following the race, he said he had seen a few of the Corzine commercials on television.
"I saw the one that said Florio's tax hikes hurt the middle class," he said, as his friends nodded in agreement. "Well, we're all middle class. So I guess we're getting hurt. I'll probably support the other guy."
Down the block at Steve's Comet Shoe Repair, the owners, Jean and Steve Attardi, were sitting in the shop's shoeshine chairs, talking politics with an upstairs neighbor, Margie Dorzdowski.
Only one customer had come in all day, but that didn't bother the Attardis, who own the building and get by on Social Security. These days the shop, which they opened 45 years ago, serves largely as a social club for the couple and their friends.
Shouting over one another, their voices growing increasingly agitated, the Attardis bemoaned what they called a new era of big money and empty promises. Mostly, though, they pitied Mr. Florio.
"Corzine has got all the money; it's just not fair," said Mr. Attardi, 85. "It's just not fair."
"The right man never gets elected," said his wife, who is 80. "The poor guy never wins."
Mr. Attardi shook his head and made a sour face. "It never used to be that way," he said. "Why does he have to steal the election?"
And so it went, until Mrs. Dorzdowski, 78, a retired factory worker, broke in. "What are you talking about?" she asked gruffly. "Politicians. Rich or poor, they're all the same. They promise you the moon, and they give you nothing in return."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: June 3, 2000, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Thursday about resentment among blue-collar voters in Bayonne, N.J., against Jon S. Corzine's record spending in the Democratic primary for United States Senate misstated the size of the state tax increase championed in 1990 by his opponent, Jim Florio, who was then governor. It was $2.8 billion, not $2.8 million.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Rambling Amid a Springtime of the Arts in a Garden That Was Bloomsbury

BYLINE: By JOHN RUSSELL 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN

 BODY:
"Bloomsbury" is the nickname never sought by those directly concerned -- for a group of friends and sometime lovers who began to see one another in or near Gordon Square in London in 1910. They included Virginia Woolf; her sister, the painter Vanessa Bell; Clive Bell, the critic and author of "Art" (1914); Roger Fry, the originator of two historic post-Impressionist exhibitions in London, in 1910 and 1914; the painter Duncan Grant, the economist J. M. Keynes and the essayist and biographer Lytton Strachey. They stayed together not as a self-promoting "group," but as people who never tired of one another's company.
"The Art of Bloomsbury" is the largest and most complicated loan exhibition ever mounted at the Yale Center for British Art here. What we see is a very large and tightly focused exhibition, but it is much more than that. In an almost subliminal way it gives us the freedom of a certain Britain in the first half of the 20th century. This was a time in which a handful of people provided the model of a civilization in which old ideas were called in question and new ones put quietly forward. 
 At the heart of it were three high Victorian families: the Stracheys, the Stephens and the Frys. Lytton Strachey, with his "Queen Victoria" (1921), pioneered the case for biographies that had something pertinent to say in every line but that did not go on forever. His brother, James, made the first translation into English of the complete works of Freud.
Their sister, Dorothy, married a French painter, Simon Bussy, and was for many years a close friend of Andre Gide. Henri Matisse, a former classmate of Bussy, was their friend and neighbor near Nice. Anyone who thinks that Bloomsbury lacked bite need only look at Bussy's little portrait of Lady Ottoline Morrell in the present show.
Duncan Grant, a pre-eminent figure in the Yale show, was a cousin of the Stracheys and went to school with the poet Rupert Brooke. Men and women alike fell for him on sight until he was well into his 80's.
The second Bloomsbury family were the Stephens. Virginia Woolf, the novelist, and Vanessa Bell, the painter, were the daughters of Sir Leslie Stephen, the first editor of the British Dictionary of National Biography.
Roger Fry's father, Sir Edward Fry, ended his legal career as a Lord Justice of Appeal and his sister Margery was principal of Somerville College, Oxford. He himself had been for a while at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, where he was responsible, among other things, for the purchase of Renoir's "Charpentier Family."
These were high Victorian families, but they were not at all stuffy. "Uncensorious" is the word for Lady Strachey's attitude to the often wayward antics of her children. Nor did her descendants forget her. Some 50 years ago, when I first went to the Stracheys' house in Gordon Square, I found that the name-board in the hall still bore the names of Sir Richard and Lady Strachey. Though long dead, they were simply marked "Out," as if they had just gone round the block.
And now, on the title page of the catalog for "The Art of Bloomsbury," we find Vanessa Bell, painter; Duncan Grant, painter; and Roger Fry, critic, painter, designer and mesmeric lecturer on the history of art.
More than 200 paintings, drawings and sculptures are on view. There are enough autograph letters (none of them perfunctory) to give an interested visitor a long and happy day's reading. (A magnifying glass will help.) There are photographs by the dozen, and not one of them is dull.
Anyone who knew Leonard Woolf as a widower, quietly fading away, will be amazed by the photograph that emphasizes the trenchant virility that he radiated at the time of his marriage to Virginia Woolf in 1911.
There are also headsets on which one can call up recorded memories by veterans of the Bloomsbury scene. There are relevant books and manuscripts by members or near-members of Bloomsbury: Virginia Woolf, above all, but also Leonard Woolf, E. M. Forster and Keynes.
We see the books published by Leonard Woolf under the imprint of the Hogarth Press. Unmistakable Bloomsbury book jackets (mostly designed by Virginia Woolf) also abound. And there are pieces of furniture made at the Omega Workshops, which were directed from 1911 to 1918 by Fry.
Almost everyone in Bloomsbury agreed with the philosopher G. E. Moore that "loving friendship" and esthetic enjoyment were "the supreme goods." From 1910 onward a "loving friendship" is clearly present in many of the portraits on view.
Beginning with Grant's portrait of Keynes (1908), a great many of them are clearly love-tokens. Same-sex love affairs ran throughout the history of Bloomsbury, though significant reversions to heterosexuality could happen at any moment and sometimes led to genealogical havoc.
And the art? To begin with, the dedicated organizer, Richard Shone, gives the lie to the long-running opinion that Fry's paintings are not worth looking at. Fry's paintings of French landscape in 1912-13, and even more his wonderfully lively and truthful portraits of Iris Tree (1915) and Edith Sitwell (1918), have a candor and a directness that still take us by surprise.
Bell and Grant were loving companions for half a century, and she had a daughter by him in 1918. But in their work, their selves remained separate. Grant always had surprises to spring, from the hauntingly beautiful abstract image that he painted in 1915 in memory of Rupert Brooke to the apotheosis of contentment that smiles out at us in his "Vanessa Bell at Charleston" (1917). Bell, by contrast, could always make something memorable out of plain things and plain places, even as early as 1912 with her "Monte Oliveto."
The art of Bloomsbury was a conversational art, in which high drama remained latent. (Grant put more drama into his "Parrot Tulips," from about 1912, than into any of the paintings that relate to his own life.) Nor were these artists competitive, either with one another or in the market. They did their own thing, in their own way, and they knew that it was part of a world of new books, new poems and new points of view in which they would always have a place.
 "The Art of Bloomsbury" is at the Yale Center for British Art, 1080 Chapel Street, New Haven, (203)432-2800, through Sept. 3. In conjunction with the show there will be a two-day symposium (June 16 and 17); performances of "Vita and Virginia," a play about Virginia Woolf and Vita Sackville-West written by Eileen Atkins (5:30 p.m. on June 20 and 21); and a program about the composer Ethel Smyth (5:30 p.m., June 22).

HEADLINE: Data Indicates Further Slowing of Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Two economic reports released yesterday pointed to a further slowdown in the economy, with growth in construction and manufacturing slackening this spring.
While the latest government figures added to evidence that six interest rate increases in less than a year by the Federal Reserve are having an effect, analysts said more rate increases were in store. 
 In one of the first major readings on May, an industry group said yesterday that growth of the manufacturing economy slowed considerably in May. The survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management also reported fewer price increases for raw materials, and an executive of the group said it appeared that such inflationary pressures peaked in March.
But economists say there is still reason to fear a surge in inflation, as oil prices once more are on the rise and as companies are pressed to raise wages to attract workers in an extremely tight labor market.
The monthly report on employment and hourly wages, scheduled for release today by the Labor Department, should provide clues on the labor market, where the unemployment rate last month fell to a 30-year low of 3.9 percent.
The government said yesterday that the number of Americans filing new claims for unemployment benefits rose a modest 1,000 last week, to 286,000. Economists view anything below 300,000 as a sign that employers will have trouble filling jobs.
In another government report, spending on construction projects, a sector sensitive to interest rates, fell 0.6 percent in April, the Commerce Department said. It was the biggest setback in almost a year. Analysts had expected no change.
The purchasing agents group reported its overall index of economic activity in the manufacturing economy fell 1.7 points, to 53.2 in May, the lowest reading since February 1999. Any reading above 50 indicates growth. Analysts had expected 55.2.
The index of raw materials prices dropped 10.2 points, to 65.8, indicating that manufacturers were still paying higher prices for supplies.
Taken together, the reports were consistent in pointing to modestly slower growth. But economists said the reports were not likely to change the Fed's stance on interest rates a great deal this summer. Fed policy makers next meet June 27 and 28, followed by an Aug. 22 session.
"You have some tentative evidence of slowdown, but unemployment is so low, and the Fed wants to be very sure they have their slowdown in hand before they back off," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at PaineWebber in New York.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Prudential Ponders Stake in Japanese Insurer

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, June 1

 BODY:
The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the largest life insurer in the United States, has tentatively agreed to take a stake in the Kyoei Life Insurance Company, one of Japan's many faltering life insurers.
The two companies announced this afternoon that they had signed a memorandum of understanding aimed at giving Prudential roughly a 20 percent stake in Kyoei, while the Japanese insurer will receive a cash infusion of up to 30 billion yen, or about $277 million at current exchange rates. 
 The deal is effectively a rescue package for Kyoei. Its ability to meet obligations and cover losses was rated among the lowest of Japan's life insurers as of November. At that time, there was a 70 billion yen gap between what Kyoei had promised to pay policyholders and returns it received on investments.
"Kyoei started having financial difficulties and came to us to see if we could help them," said Kiyo Sakaguchi, executive vice president of Prudential and head of its Japanese operations.
Japan's life insurance companies are all struggling, burdened by policies sold during the economic boom years that promised a high rate of return. With the economy mired in weakness for much of the last decade and interest rates at record lows, they cannot now make enough on their investments to cover those obligations.
Over the last three years, three Japanese life insurers have failed, and foreign companies have bought four others. On Wednesday, Japan's regulators forced Daihyaku Mutual, Japan's 15th-largest life insurer, to quit the life insurance business.
But while Prudential is acting as a white knight, its stake in Kyoei will not entitle it to a management role. "Our objective is not to take over Kyoei but to help them with financial support and technical support," Mr. Sakaguchi said.
Prudential would become Kyoei's largest shareholder, however, and as such, might even play a role in the nascent movement here to increase the awareness and influence of shareholders in corporate Japan. "I do see that trend developing, but it may take a little while before shareholders here really assert their position," Mr. Sakaguchi said.
The two companies will also form a marketing joint venture to sell a combination of their insurance policies as well as other investment products. Prudential's sales and training model will be used in hopes of making the sales force more professional. Traditionally, selling life insurance has been a part-time job for housewives in Japan.
Prudential will also lend an investment expert to Kyoei to help the Japanese insurer find strategies to improve its return on investments.
The companies said they hoped to cut costs and increase efficiency by eliminating redundant operations.

HEADLINE: Sales at Retail Stores Showed a Rise of 4.3% in May

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Retail sales climbed in May with consumers buying housewares, appliances and summer fashions, many of the nation's merchants reported yesterday, even as higher interest rates and gasoline prices threatened to crimp spending.
Sales in stores open more than a year, a crucial industry measurement, rose 4.3 percent in May, according to the Goldman Sachs retail composite index. Rising wages and consumer confidence and the lowest jobless rate in 30 years helped fuel spending. 
 Sales at Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the nation's top retailer, rose 7.4 percent, in line with forecasts. Limited Inc. had a better-than-expected 7 percent gain in same-store sales. Sales rose 4.2 percent at Federated Department Stores Inc., parent of Macy's and other chains.
Some retailers -- mostly those specializing in clothing -- reported disappointing results.
Gap Inc. said sales fell an unexpected 2 percent, led by declines at its Banana Republic and Old Navystores. Sales also missed forecasts at Pacific Sunwear of California, Abercrombie & Fitch and Ross Stores Inc.
Same-store sales are a leading measure of a retailer's business because they exclude results from new and closed locations.
Several department store companies met or topped forecasts. Sears, Roebuck & Company said sales rose 3.5 percent. Forecasts ranged from 1 percent to 3 percent. At the J. C. Penney Company, which is trying to emerge from a three-year sales slump, sales rose 1.1 percent at its department stores, beating projections for unchanged sales.
At May Department Stores Inc., sales rose 1.2 percent. Analysts had reduced forecasts from about 4 percent after the company, which owns Lord & Taylor, Hecht's and other chains, posted disappointing results for the final week of May.
Sales at the Neiman Marcus Group, which sells high-priced clothing, rose 6.6 percent.
Talbots Inc., the women's clothing retailer, said sales jumped 29.4 percent, nearly double forecasts. The company kept markdowns to a minimum as customers splurged on merchandise at full price.
The Ann Taylor Stores Corporation posted a 3.1 percent increase. Forecasts ranged from a gain of 1 percent to 3 percent.
Several stores reported slower sales toward the end of the month, said Thomas Tashjian, an analyst at Banc of America Securities.
"Was it a demand issue or a weather issue or a fashion issue?" he said. "It's a little bit of each one."
Abercrombie & Fitch, which sells apparel to teenagers and college-age consumers, reported a 14 percent drop in sales, steeper than forecasts for a decline of 6 percent to 8 percent.
Pacific Sunwear, which also sells clothing to teenagers, said fiscal second-quarter profit might miss forecasts because of slower-than-expected sales. Sales in May rose just 0.5 percent.
The Target Corporation's sales rose 1.5 percent, led by a 2.6 percent gain at its discount chain. That compares with a 6.3 percent increase in May 1999, when sales at Target stores jumped 7.4 percent. The company also owns the Mervyn's, Dayton's, Hudson's and Marshall Field's department stores.

HEADLINE: North Korean in China for 3 Secret Days

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, June 1

 BODY:
China and North Korea confirmed today that North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, was here this week for three days of secret meetings. The trip was the reclusive Mr. Kim's first journey abroad since he succeeded his father as leader in 1994 and his first visit to China since 1983.
Mr. Kim, 58, "the great leader," as he is called at home, took advantage of the trip to visit China's leading computer manufacturer, the Legend Group, as well as the imperial gate at Tiananmen Square, the Chinese reported. 
Occurring two weeks before Mr. Kim's scheduled meeting with President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, the trip appeared to be aimed at shoring up ties with China, the lone important ally of economically stricken North Korea.
China is eager to avoid serious instability in the region or a collapse of the Pyongyang government that might draw South Korean involvement or, perhaps, even American troops, to its border. China has encouraged the North to engage in peace talks and to open its economy to foreign trade and investment.
China fought alongside North Korea against the United States and South Korea in the Korean War and was long an ally in Communism. But relations became strained in 1992, when Beijing extended diplomatic recognition to economically thriving South Korea, and they have only slowly recovered.
On Mr. Kim's visit, from Monday to Wednesday, he was the guest of honor at a banquet given by President Jiang Zemin and met separately with other leaders, including Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, Vice President Hu Jintao and Li Peng, the former Prime Minister who heads the legislature. Mr. Kim was accompanied by top military and political officials.
The two sides reached an "important consensus" on bilateral and regional issues of common concern, a spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry, Zhang Qiyue, said this evening, declining to be specific. "Bilateral relations were raised to a new level."
China also made new promises of food and other aid for North Korea, Ms. Zhang said at a briefing.
A short announcement today from the official North Korean news agency -- as in the case of China's issued only after Mr. Kim had completed his overnight train journey and was safely back home -- described an "unshakable will" to develop friendship with China and said, "Consensus was reached on all matters discussed."
North Korea has tried to break out of its isolation, opening relations with Italy and Australia and holding talks with Japan and the United States.
In footage of their meeting shown on Chinese television tonight, Mr. Kim wore a gray Mao-style jacket, and Mr. Jiang wore a Western-style suit and tie.
Ms. Zhang declined to explain the extreme secrecy surrounding the trip, saying, "We think this is a normal visit."
But other Chinese officials said privately the North Koreans had insisted that the visit be kept secret until Mr. Kim's return to Pyongyang, and they suggested that he was concerned about his security or the possibility of a coup attempt.
In public, the Chinese were all smiles, stressing that the longstanding friendship between the two countries had been strengthened. Mr. Jiang told his guest that China welcomed the talks between North and South Korean leaders scheduled from June 12 to June 14 in Pyongyang, and "hopes the two sides improve their relationship," the New China News Agency reported.
Chinese officials have said in private they find the North Koreans unpredictable and frustrating, as well as too proud to accept openly Chinese coaching on economics or foreign policy. The official accounts today from China seemed intended to help the North Koreans save face, avoiding mention of issues that have strained relations.
Mr. Jiang was quoted as praising North Korea's economic achievements, even though it has suffered a severe decline and food shortages that have sent hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing to China.
China was angered last year when North Korea tested a long-range missile, frightening Japan and spurring stronger efforts by Japan and the United States to develop antimissile defenses, which China strongly opposes.
Ms. Zhang would not say whether the issue had been discussed, but restated China's hope to avoid any arms race in the region or any proliferation of weapons of mass destruction.
China has for years encouraged North Korea to begin opening its tightly controlled economy, which collapsed after subsidies from the former Soviet Union ended nearly a decade ago. Officials refused to say whether Mr. Kim had made any commitments on that. But according to official Chinese accounts, Mr. Kim praised the success of China's economic reforms.

HEADLINE: Clinton Finds Germans Critical of U.S. Missile Defense Plan

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: BERLIN, June 1

 BODY:
President Clinton arrived in Germany for a three-day visit today and faced immediate criticism of his administration's plans to build a limited missile defense system.
In a 90-minute meeting with Mr. Clinton in the official Chancellery, Chancellor Gerhard Schroder added his voice to the chorus of European allies criticizing the administration's plan, telling Mr. Clinton that it could touch off a new arms race. 
 Standing beside Mr. Clinton following their meeting, Mr. Schroder told reporters that the American president presented his views on his administration's position "in a very frank way." Mr. Schroder added, "I then went on and stated my concerns, concerns that we have to be very careful that any project does not re-trigger the process of a renewed arms race."
In an interview that will appear in Friday's Berliner Zeitung, Mr. Schroder was even more forceful, saying, "Neither economically nor politically can we afford a new round of the arms race. No one can dispute the Americans' right to develop what they believe is right for national defense. On the other hand, we are partners in a common alliance."
Other German officials have warned that the missile defense would weaken military ties between the United States and its European allies. And they have accused the United States of overstating the threat.
In his own remarks to reporters, Mr. Clinton did not respond to Mr. Schroder's assertions. But in briefing reporters later, the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, acknowledged the criticism.
"He expressed his concern that we proceed with due consideration for the impact on others, including Europe," Mr. Berger said in summing up Mr. Schroder's remarks.
A number of European leaders are concerned that a missile defense system could upset existing disarmament accords, particularly the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty with Russia, which must be amended to allow for the missile defense plan.
Neither Mr. Clinton nor any of his aides have made the point -- at least not publicly -- that the administration's plan is far less ambitious than one proposed by George W. Bush, the presumptive Republican nominee for president, who is ready to abandon the ABM treaty as a relic of the past.
But Mr. Berger stressed that the discord was "not at all sharp," adding, "It was a very intelligent discussion of a very complicated issue."
For his part, Mr. Clinton laid out the American conviction that it must find ways to counter dangerous emerging nuclear threats like North Korea.
"I'm concerned about how we proceed with Europe and their sense of comfort level with this," Mr. Berger paraphrased Mr. Clinton as telling Mr. Schroder. "But ultimately, I've got to make a decision in terms of national security."
Mr. Schroder's criticism slightly tarnished the opening of Mr. Clinton's visit to Berlin, the first by an American president since the city became the capital of a united Germany following the end of the cold war. On Friday Mr. Clinton travels to Aachen, the ancient capital of Charlemagne, to receive the Charlemagne Prize, awarded annually to a person who has worked toward European unity and prosperity.
On another area of contention between the United States and Germany, Mr. Clinton expressed concern over Germany's handling of child custody cases involving American parents.
According to the State Department, Germany favors German parents in custody cases and prevents American parents from gaining access to children living in Germany.
Two prominent cases involve Lady Catherine Meyer, the wife of Sir Christopher Meyer, the British ambassador in Washington, and Joseph Cooke, a New Yorker. Lady Catherine's two sons from a previous marriage were abducted by their German father; she has been allowed to see them for a total of 24 hours in the past six years.
Mr. Cooke has been fighting to regain custody of his two children, who were handed over to foster parents in Germany seven years ago after his wife, a German, fled there with them and declared she was mentally ill.
Mr. Schroder announced today that Germany would set up a working group of experts with the United States to investigate custody disputes involving American parents, but warned he could not interfere directly in the court system.
Mr. Clinton has recently come under pressure from an organized lobby of American parents who complain that Germany has violated conventions guaranteeing the return of kidnapped children.
Last week, the House of Representatives endorsed the effort in a resolution, voting 416 to 0.

HEADLINE: Chase to Lease Office Space In Jersey City

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
In the latest indication that the Jersey City waterfront has become a corporate haven, Chase Manhattan Bank, the second-largest bank in the country, is moving thousands of employees from Lower Manhattan to two new office towers at the Newport complex.
The Giuliani administration tried desperately to keep the bank from leasing space across the Hudson River, but the tax breaks offered by the city could not compete with a better deal in Jersey City. State officials in New Jersey dangled subsidies worth tens of millions of dollars, and Samuel J. LeFrak, the developer, promised to build an office tower within 18 months, according to real estate executives and local officials. 
 Chase's search for office space and bargaining for tax breaks recalls an earlier tug of war across the Hudson River, one that New York won. Twelve years ago, Chase had nearly closed a deal to move 5,000 technical jobs to a proposed 1.5 million-square-foot tower at the Newport project. At the last minute, Edward I. Koch, who was then mayor, got wind of the deal and persuaded Chase to remain in New York with the largest municipal tax break ever granted to a New York company: $235 million. The bank then moved the jobs and its computer operations to the Metrotech Center in Brooklyn.
The bank is joining Goldman, Sachs & Company, which recently announced plans to erect the tallest building in Jersey City, a 45-story, 1.6 million-square-foot tower at the former site of a Colgate toothpaste factory. Merrill Lynch & Company is building its own tower nearby, and Paine Webber, U.S. Trust and Lord, Abbett & Company have all taken large blocks of space in the past year.
Judy Miller, a spokeswoman for Chase, declined to comment, as did the bank's broker, Insignia/ESG, and Lloyd Kaplan, a spokesman for Mr. LeFrak, whose family owns the 600-acre Newport complex. But several executives said the two sides had struck a deal in which the developer would build two office towers totaling 1.1 million square feet for about 4,000 employees. Chase would move its staff from 55 Water Street and still have room to expand in Jersey City. The bank's headquarters would remain at 270 Park Avenue.
"We think Chase is an excellent fit," said Tom Gallagher, chief of staff for Bret Schundler, the Jersey City mayor, "and we welcome them as the latest Fortune 500 company to come to the Jersey City waterfront."
Michael Carey, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, did not return calls requesting comment, nor did a spokeswoman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Word of a pending deal was reported on Tuesday in The New York Post.
Chase's decision to move some jobs to New Jersey could renew criticism that the Giuliani administration has not developed alternative sites for less expensive back office space to house support staff in Brooklyn or Queens during the current real estate boom.
"This should be a signal to policy makers that New York needs an aggressive development policy to meet the growing demand by firms to do business in New York City," said Mitchell Moss, director of New York University's Taub Urban Research Center. "We can't afford to let other firms follow Chase across the river."
Rents for prime office space in Midtown and Lower Manhattan have soared to $50 a square foot and higher since the recession in the early and mid-1990's. And few large blocks of space are available.
Many corporate tenants, in turn, have hunted for cheap space in industrial areas of Manhattan, as well as in Jersey City and Hoboken. Metrotech, the back office complex that Mr. Koch promoted in the early 1980's, is practically full. While most economists said that it makes little difference to the regional economy whether a company is located in Manhattan, Stamford or Parsippany, local politicians have competed to lure companies with billions of dollars in tax breaks.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said he was concerned "that high rents are forcing companies to reconsider their presence in New York. We need to look into how we can create more affordable back office space in Manhattan, or the surrounding boroughs."
Only recently, real estate brokers said, have major corporate tenants been willing to cross the seemingly wide cultural and psychological gulf between Manhattan and Jersey City, which was regarded as a backwater. They were helped along by cheaper rents in Jersey City, enormous tax incentives and a quick ride via a PATH train or ferry. Jersey City is now referred to as the West Bank of Manhattan.
"The waterfront is extremely active right now," said Peter Eppie, executive vice president for SJP Properties, which is building office towers for Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in Jersey City and for John Wiley & Sons in Hoboken. "There are an awful lot of major companies looking at space, and the number of available sites is dwindling."
Last year, Chase announced that it was looking for one million square feet of office space in Manhattan and elsewhere. The bank talked to a number of developers about building a headquarters in Midtown and made what has become a corporate tenant's obligatory trip to Jersey City, if only to force New York into offering tax breaks.
But Chase changed its strategy earlier this year and abandoned its quest for a new headquarters as too expensive. Last month, the bank leased 14 floors, or 556,000 square feet, at 1166 Avenue of the Americas, which would allow it to move some employees out of the cramped headquarters building on Park Avenue.
Less than two months ago, Chase began negotiating in earnest with the LeFraks, who were starting construction of an 800,000-square-foot tower at Newport without a tenant. A confident Mr. LeFrak had already built and leased two other buildings last year and had bought the steel to construct a third. But executives who know him said he was wary of dealing with Chase because it had backed out of their deal in 1988. The developer told the bank that he already had a potential tenant, but whoever signed a deal first would get the building.
Chase also talked to officials in New Jersey, where the state offers new companies a rebate of up to 80 percent of the state income taxes the new jobs generate for 10 years. One person said the incentive package offered to Chase is worth about $100 million.
Meanwhile, the Giuliani administration offered Chase increasingly larger tax breaks if the bank would stay put. But, one real estate executive said, city officials were also slow to respond, in part because Mayor Giuliani was then engaged in the race for the Senate. The tempo picked up after the mayor dropped out of the race, but it was a lost cause by then. Chase had already decided to cross the Hudson, to where rents and other costs were 30 percent lower, and sign a deal for two buildings.
"Once they hurdle the river, you can't touch the economic benefits of Jersey," said one real estate executive involved in the talks. "No incentive package from New York could've mitigated the difference."
Mr. Koch said yesterday that he was saddened by the bank's decision. "I wish them well," he said, "but I can no longer refer to them as Chase Manhattan."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Jumps 5.34%, Its 7th-Best Percentage Gain Ever

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Technology stocks roared ahead yesterday, propelling the Nasdaq composite index to its seventh-best gain in percentage terms, up 5.34 percent. That performance followed Tuesday's record 7.9 percent rise.
The index surged 181.59 points, to 3,582.50, and cut the Nasdaq's losses on the year to nearly 12 percent. 
 After Wednesday's downturn, investors became re-enthused yesterday as the economic news of the day suggested that the economy was slowing markedly from the breakneck pace that had led the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates six times since last June.
"We're beginning to see the impact" of Alan Greenspan's slow-acting but powerful anti-inflation medicine, said Frank Cappiello of McCullough, Andrews & Cappiello in Baltimore. "We sense that he's gotten near the end of raising rates. And if that's the case, then these tech stocks are woefully underpriced."
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also posted a gain, up 28.21 points, or 1.99 percent, to 1,448.81, while the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 129.87 points, or 1.23 percent, to 10,652.20.
News of slackened industrial costs and construction spending left many analysts unpersuaded that rate increases were near an end and that this spring's stock slide was over.
"I'm skeptical," said Byron R. Wien, chief United States strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. He said the economic slowing was from a "very feverish" pace, suggesting that more Fed tightening might be needed, and that in any event corporate earnings growth was probably on the wane. "I would certainly have a defensive position" toward stocks, Mr. Wien advised.
In Atlanta, Robert M. Balentine, chief executive of the investment counselors Balentine & Company, took a similar view. "We're simply seeing some bounce off the lows," he said. "We would use the rally to raise cash for better buying opportunities ahead rather than think the worst is behind us."
And while the skeptics cited continued subdued trading volume as evidence that the rally lacked enthusiasm, there has been a clear improvement lately in the proportion of stocks moving higher. Yesterday, 2,061 New York Stock Exchange issues advanced while 927 declined, and new 52-week highs nearly doubled new lows, 68 to 35.
The ratio was even better for the S.& P. 500, where 353 stocks rose while 131 declined and 16 were unchanged.
Several Nasdaq issues posted double-digit gains, with the heavily weighted Cisco Systems up 4, to 60 15/16, having the biggest impact.
Hewlett-Packard, up 14 3/8, to 134 1/2, after a meeting that impressed security analysts, accounted for nearly two-thirds of the Dow's rise. Intel climbed 5, to 129 11/16.
Although the market for initial public offerings has been severely chilled of late, ONI Systems, a fiber optics company, attracted huge demand for 8 million shares it offered late Tuesday at 25. The stock started trading yesterday at 75, climbed as high as 86 and finished at 82 9/16.
 

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Climb
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury bond prices rose strongly yesterday after another economic report suggested that the nation's economy was slowing and interest rates might be near their peaks.
The report that manufacturing activity grew in May, but at its slowest pace in more than a year, followed similarly soft data on retail sales and orders for big-ticket items.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 30/32, to 104 11/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.94 percent from 6 percent on Wednesday. The price of the 10-year bond rose 21/32, to 102 11/32, while its yield declined to 6.17 percent from 6.26 percent.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Judge in Microsoft Trial Delays Ruling for U.S. Reply
The federal judge in the Microsoft antitrust case unexpectedly agreed to delay his final ruling for about a week, giving the Justice Department time to reply to Microsoft's proposal to water down the government's breakup plan. 
 Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson had planned to issue his final ruling, widely expected to call for a breakup of the company, by today. But Justice Department officials asked whether they could reply to Microsoft's comments on the government's remedy proposal, which were filed on Wednesday. Page C2.
 
Big Nasdaq Gain Leads Broad Rally
Technology stocks soared, lifting the Nasdaq composite index 181.59 points, or 5.3 percent, to 3,582.50. It was the index's seventh-best gain in percentage terms. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also rose sharply, up 28.21 points, or nearly 2 percent, to 1,448.81, while the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 129.97 points, or 1.2 percent, to 10,652.20. C10.
 
Retail Sales Increased 4.3% in May
Retail sales climbed 4.3 percent in May with consumers buying housewares, appliances and summer fashions, even as higher interest rates and gasoline prices threatened to crimp spending. Several department store companies met or topped forecasts. Sears, Roebuck said sales jumped 3.5 percent. Expectations ranged from 1 percent to 3 percent. Its shares rose 50 cents, to $37.4375. Sales at J. C. Penney stores rose 1.1 percent, beating projections for unchanged sales. C21.
 
In Online Auctions, Rings of Bidders
A close analysis of eBay art auctions reveals that the flourishing cyberauction world faces a deeper and more intransigent problem than people who bid on their own items to drive up the price: the prospect of rings of shill bidders, acting as partners. A1.
 
Fashionmall.com to Buy Boo.com
The remnants of Boo.com, the Web retailer that became insolvent last week when investors refused to give it more cash, were acquired by Fashionmall.com, a New York Internet company, for an undisclosed price. C4.
 
Alcan Wins Algroup With Higher Bid
Alcan Aluminium of Canada agreed to buy Algroup of Switzerland after an influential Swiss shareholder group threw its support behind a sweetened deal worth $4.7 billion. C4.
 
Advertising That's All About Luck
Advertisers and media magnates are celebrating the concept of good fortune with a lengthening list of products, publications and pitches centered on the word "lucky," including a magazine named Lucky, a character called Mr. Lucky who promotes the Excite Web site and the venerable Lucky Strike cigarette brand, which is being reintroduced with a big advertising push that plays up the name. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.
 
Prudential to Buy Stake in Kyoei Life
The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the largest life insurer in the United States, has tentatively agreed to take a stake in the Kyoei Life Insurance, one of Japan's many faltering life insurers. C4.
 
Manufacturing Index Edges Lower
The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its overall index of economic activity in the manufacturing economy fell 1.7 points, to 53.2 in May, the lowest reading since February 1999. A separate report showed that spending on construction projects fell 0.6 percent in April. C2.
