HEADLINE: Mayor and Council Near Agreement on Budget

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration and City Council leaders are close to reaching an accord on a $37 billion budget for the 2001 fiscal year, although the proposed settlement could still be disrupted by state legislators in Albany, who might add as much as $1 billion in extra expenses, city officials said.
Representatives for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council want to try to resolve remaining differences on the budget package by today, city officials said, with a vote by the Council to adopt the spending plan perhaps as soon as Tuesday. The new fiscal year starts July 1. 
 The talks between the administration and the Council have focused on differences in the tax-cut plans, as well as some relatively small differences in spending plans for certain city agencies. As of late yesterday, the two parties were considering adding $150 million to $200 million in spending to the budget over the mayor's April proposal to supplement programs like recycling and day care.
As of yesterday evening, the negotiators had agreed to include a reduction in the commercial rent tax in the budget package, which, according to the mayor's April budget plan, would save businesses $16 million in the next fiscal year. And both sides are supporting cutting a surcharge on the personal income tax to 7 percent from 14 percent. For a taxpayer who earns $60,000 to $99,999 a year, that cut would save an average of $123, assuming the tax rate structure is not changed.
The budget negotiations this year have been relatively stress-free, because the city economy is booming, meaning there is a surplus in the current fiscal year of as much as $3.1 billion, which can used to help balance the 2001 fiscal year budget.
But the talks have been complicated because of legislation under consideration in Albany that could require changes in pension benefits for retired city workers that would cost as much as $1 billion in the coming fiscal year. City officials have asked the state to pick up all or part of the cost of this program, which would give retirees automatic cost-of-living increases in their pensions.
The city is also asking the state for the authority to borrow an additional $4 billion over the next four years, although so far it looks as though the Legislature is moving toward approving only $2.5 billion for the next two years.
Depending on what actions are taken by the State Legislature and governor, the city may not be able to afford the tax cuts that the mayor and City Council are advocating, officials said.

HEADLINE: Auto Sales Declined 2% Last Month

BYLINE: ByKEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 1

 BODY:
Auto sales dropped 2 percent last month from May of last year, the first year-to-year drop since the summer of 1998. Dismal results at DaimlerChrysler and General Motors entirely accounted for the decline as other manufacturers posted record sales, leaving it unclear whether a long-expected decline in sales had begun.
Only one in five buyers of new family vehicles pays cash; the rest rely on loans or leases, for which the monthly payments vary with interest rates. As a result, the auto industry is usually one of the first to feel the effects when the Federal Reserve starts pushing up interest rates, as it has done in recent months. Many economists, including Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, have long watched for weak auto sales as an early indicator that the American economy might be slowing. 
 But if auto sales fell because of a slowing economy, many automakers would be expected to post lower sales figures. Instead, Ford Motor, Toyota, Nissan, Honda and Mitsubishi announced increases in sales, with Toyota and Mitsubishi reporting their best months ever. Industry experts suggested this meant that the overall decline in sales in May was linked at least as much to specific problems at DaimlerChrysler and G.M. as to the pace of economic growth in the United States.
While the 2 percent decline in sales last month was the first since August 1998, when a strike crippled G.M., sales were still very strong last month by historical standards. Ward's Auto Infobank, a market data service in Southfield, Mich., calculated that the seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales last month was 17.1 million vehicles. That put last month's sales above the average pace for last year, the industry's best ever, with 17 million vehicles sold.
DaimlerChrysler's sales plunged 16.8 percent last month after the company tried to reduce its rebates and other discounts in May. The company announced on Wednesday that it was increasing its rebates and eliminating most low-rate auto loans as part of a new sales-incentive campaign intended to match the more generous discounts offered by its main rivals, G.M. and Ford.
May of 1999 was also the best month ever for DaimlerChrysler. "That is a tough benchmark," James P. Holden, the president of DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler unit, said in a statement.
G.M.'s sales fell 5.8 percent, as the company, the world's largest automaker, struggled to stay ahead of Ford in total sales. Paul Ballew, G.M.'s executive director of market analysis, attributed the G.M. drop to shortfalls in three specific segments of the auto market, rather than an overall weakening of the market in response to the Federal Reserve's six increases in short-term interest rates or rising gas prices.
G.M.'s sales of luxury cars suffered as Cadillac ran short of the new DeVille sedan, for which G.M. is still ramping up production after redesigning the vehicle, Mr. Ballew said. The overall pickup truck market weakened in May, while Korean automakers continued to expand their share of the small-car market, which G.M. once dominated.
"I don't think you can declare May some watershed of industry moderation" in the pace of sales, Mr. Ballew said in a telephone conference call with reporters this afternoon, adding that G.M. still expected sales to slow somewhat later this year.
But Haig Stoddard, the manager of industry analysis at Ward's, was more concerned about the industry's short-term health. "We're definitely heading at least into a stop in the growth we've had," he said. "But June should be a good month because now we've got all this excess inventory they've got to get rid of."
G. Richard Wagoner Jr., G.M.'s president, added the title of chief executive today, replacing John F. Smith Jr., who remains chairman.
Ford's sales crept up 1.4 percent, which still allowed the company to say that it had just enjoyed its best May ever. Toyota's sales inched up 2.7 percent to break a record set last year. Honda's sales rose 3.6 percent, Nissan's increased 11.5 percent and Mitsubishi's were up 31.3 percent.
The most recently introduced models sold best, the latest sign that American shoppers are becoming more conscious of the latest styles when it comes to cars. William J. Kirrane, Nissan's vice president and general manager of Nissan brand cars, said that his company's Sentra small car and Xterra sport utility vehicle were the most recently introduced models and had sold especially briskly even without incentives.
"The new products have really done well for us," Mr. Kirrane said.

HEADLINE: With Loophole, Carmakers Post Mileage Gain

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, June 1

 BODY:
A soon-to-be- released government report shows a slight increase in the fuel economy of family vehicles in the 2000 model year. But the rise is mostly thanks to a loophole that gives carmakers extra mileage credit for vehicles that can run on ethanol, even though virtually no one uses that fuel.
Ethanol is sold by only 108 of the nation's 178,000 service stations. Nonetheless, General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler are producing roughly 750,000 dual-fuel minivans, small pickup trucks and cars this year at an extra cost of up to $300 each. These vehicles are counted by the government as getting roughly triple the gas mileage that they actually achieve, allowing manufacturers to sell more full-sized sport utilities and pickups while still meeting federal standards for average fuel economy. 
 The government report, produced by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, calculated that the average fuel economy for all new family vehicles sold in the 2000 model year would be 24.7 miles per gallon, after including the special treatment of dual-fuel vehicles. That is up slightly from 24.5 in the 1999 model year and the same as in the 1998 model year, but still well below a peak of 26.2 miles per gallon in the 1987 model year.
Without the benefit from the special treatment of ethanol, the overall number would be up very slightly from 1999, when many dual-fuel vehicles were also sold, and down from 1998, when automakers were just starting to build the dual-fuel vehicles.
The growing popularity of large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks that are far less fuel efficient than cars has lowered the average fuel economy of the nation's vehicles in recent years. Automakers have made the big vehicles a bit more fuel efficient for this model year. But there are so many of them being sold that they have dragged down the average.
Fuel economy has become a political issue again this year because of rising gasoline prices, the possibility of shortages of certain types of gasoline in the Midwest this summer and growing criticisms of large family vehicles by environmentalists and safety advocates.
Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who unsuccessfully sought his party's presidential nomination earlier this year, has used his position as chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee to order Congress's General Accounting Office to perform a broad review of American fuel-economy policies.
At Senator McCain's request, the review is focused on the safety, environmental and energy conservation issues raised by the fuel-economy standards for sport utilities and other so-called light trucks -- standards that are more lenient than those applied to cars. Pia Pialorsi, a spokeswoman for the Commerce Committee, said today that the report should be finished by August.
The 12-year-old law that gives special treatment to automobiles that can burn ethanol or gasoline also requires the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to prepare an extensive report of the legislation's effectiveness by the end of the government's current fiscal year, on Sept. 30. The law will make the fuel-economy calculations for dual-fuel vehicles less favorable for automakers in 2004, and manufacturers have already begun lobbying for an extension of that deadline. An auto executive who insisted on anonymity said that the industry was counting on support for an extension of the law from the farm lobby and from politicians who might want to impress voters in Iowa, which holds the first presidential caucuses.
Samuel Leonard, General Motors' policy director for fuel economy and air pollution, said the fuel-economy credits for dual-fuel vehicles were needed as an incentive for automakers to build vehicles that could burn ethanol, a type of alcohol made from corn, sugar cane or even waste paper. For many years, automakers refused to build vehicles for which alternative fuels were not available while the oil industry refused to distribute fuels that few vehicles could burn. The fuel-economy credits could break the standoff, Mr. Leonard said.
Environmentalists have long been skeptical of ethanol, mainly because there have been conflicting studies on whether it takes more fossil fuels to grow corn and turn it into ethanol than would be burned by gasoline-powered vehicles. Oil companies do not like to sell ethanol because it is so corrosive that it cannot be shipped in steel pipelines, requiring costly trucks, barges, and rail cars instead, said John Felmy, the director of policy and statistics at the American Petroleum Institute in Washington.
There have also been predictions of a coming ethanol shortage. The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed the elimination of a popular gasoline additive, MTBE, which accounts for almost 3 percent of the volume of gasoline, and the use of ethanol instead. The ethanol industry says it can increase production.
The average fuel economy of new cars has inched up to 28.4 miles per gallon from 28.3 in the 1999 model year, the report said. But the average for light trucks -- sport utilities, pickup trucks and vans -- jumped to 21.2 miles per gallon from 20.7 a year earlier. Almost all of the automobiles being produced with the capacity to burn ethanol are minivans and small pickup trucks, like Ford Rangers with 3-liter engines and Dodge and Chrysler minivans with 3.3-liter engines, as automakers have struggled to comply with federal standards.
Safety agency officials estimated that labeling vehicles as capable of burning ethanol or gasoline had allowed Ford and DaimlerChrysler to increase the calculated average fuel economy of their sport utility vehicles and other so-called light trucks by about 0.8 mile per gallon in the 2000 model year. The benefit for G.M. is 0.4 mile per gallon in the current model year. G.M. has indicated that it plans to step up production.
The government's rules require each automaker to produce cars with a so-called corporate average fuel economy of at least 27.5 miles per gallon and light trucks with an average fuel economy of at least 20.7 miles per gallon. Gasoline prices have recently increased but over the last decade, adjusted for inflation, they have been among the lowest ever, and this has helped create demand for light trucks with poor gas mileage.
Auto executives have called repeatedly for Congress to repeal the corporate average fuel economy rules (known as CAFE) and replace them with higher gasoline taxes, but there has been no enthusiasm in Washington for such a move. "A philosophy of CAFE that doesn't have a corollary of fuel policy doesn't work," said James Holden, the president of DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler unit, in an interview earlier this year.
The giant Ford Excursion sport utility vehicle and a growing number of full-size pickup trucks are not included in the fuel-economy averages at all, because they exceed the maximum weight that regulators set in the 1970's for consideration as a family vehicle. G.M. and Ford told regulators at the time that they could not envision selling family vehicles weighing as much as their current models do.
Senator McCain's review and the safety agency's report on dual-fuel vehicles in September are unlikely to result in legislative action this year. The Republican majority in the House approved a transportation budget two weeks ago that for the sixth year in a row, bans the spending of federal money to revise federal fuel-economy rules. House Democrats organized an effort to remove the ban but then backed away from introducing the necessary amendment, fearing an election-year split between environmentalists, who favor stricter standards, and labor unions, which worry that American automakers depend on big gas guzzlers for their profits.
The Senate is tentatively scheduled to vote in two weeks on a nonbinding resolution calling for an end to the ban. Senator Slade Gorton, Republican of Washington, a state with no auto assembly plants and high gasoline prices, said that he hoped to do better than last year, when the Senate defeated a similar resolution, 55 to 40.
"I'm convinced we'll get more votes than last year, and we've got a 50-50 chance of winning it," Senator Gorton said.

LENGTH: 1085 words

HEADLINE: Lazio Tending to Stray From Strategists' Script

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 1

 BODY:
As Representative Rick A. Lazio set out from the Republican convention in Buffalo, the immediate concern of his Senate campaign was not what he said, but how he was photographed. Everywhere Mr. Lazio went -- a vineyard in the Finger Lakes yesterday, a suburban schoolyard here today -- his staff members vigorously stage-directed the candidate and the news media, seeking the best photographs of Mr. Lazio's inaugural bus tour.
Most important, Mr. Lazio was advised to refrain from attacks on Hillary Rodham Clinton, because they might distract from these carefully arranged images. 
 That restraint lasted for all of five hours. Just past noon on Mr. Lazio's very first day out, at a small sidewalk rally in Watkins Glen, the candidate's high-minded and deliberately low-octane discussion of education and the economy gave way to a mocking jab at Mrs. Clinton's book "It Takes a Village."
By dusk, he was heartily attacking the first lady as a cloistered carpetbagger, suggesting that she was using the Secret Service to shield her from the press and the public. "We're not going to have a bunch of bodyguards to hide behind," he pledged.
The new Republican candidate for United States Senate has presented a conflicted message during these opening days of his campaign. At one moment, he has condemned negative campaigning and promised New Yorkers a candidacy grounded in his values and "mainstream ideas," a campaign drawn in a series of settings chosen to encourage picturesque, and not particularly weighty, coverage of his first official swing as a candidate for Senate.
But at the next, Mr. Lazio has gone after Mrs. Clinton with as much spirit as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani ever did, before he quit the race for health reasons. "Being a New Yorker is more than moving into a multimillion-dollar house and putting on a Yankee cap," Mr. Lazio said at a rally by a golf course in Binghamton. Some of these discordant moments have even come within the space of a few lines in a speech.
Ideally, according to aides, it is the first Mr. Lazio that voters should be seeing for now. The strategy, one Republican said, is for Mr. Lazio, a Suffolk County Republican, to keep his guns holstered for the time being, allowing New Yorkers to get to know him for what he is and what he stands for, rather than as a harsh carrier of attacks on Mrs. Clinton.
To that end, he is intending to be somewhat vague and studiously noncontroversial, relying on carefully arranged pictures -- like eating a sandwich today at Katz's Deli on the Lower East Side -- rather than words to get himself known.
That this task has turned out to be more than a little difficult is, in part, a reflection of the aggressive nature and relative inexperience of the 42-year-old candidate the Republicans have chosen to send up against Mrs. Clinton.
Mr. Lazio, as Mr. Giuliani discovered when Mr. Lazio threatened to run a primary race against him, has a taste for political combat. But this is only his first race for statewide office, and a key skill for any successful politician is knowing when not to say something, a lesson that often comes only with time.
Beyond that, the conflicting signals out of the Lazio camp suggest the difficult terrain that the candidate confronts as he enters this complicated race. If this contest is going to be about Mrs. Clinton's shortcomings -- and that is, to a large extent, what his aides want it to be about -- he needs to make Mrs. Clinton the issue, and one way is by raising questions about her credentials, philosophy and character.
The problem is time. In a more traditional campaign, Mr. Lazio would have had months to quietly establish his credentials, biography and record in the minds of voters, giving him the foundation from which to attack his opponent come the fall. But Mr. Lazio is getting a relatively late start, because of Mr. Giuliani's delayed departure from the race. Mrs. Clinton has been campaigning for a nearly a year.
And the candidate is facing conflicting pressures from inside and outside his campaign on how quickly to proceed, which no doubt accounts for the different faces he has shown in the early days of the campaign.
Mr. Lazio has surely noticed that the applause lines that he uses in more high-minded campaign moments -- "We don't want to export any more of our children out of state, do we?" for example -- do not get quite the response from his audience (or the reporters covering him) as when he lashes out at the first lady as an opportunist.
And senior Republicans are expressing impatience with Mr. Lazio's emphasis on image over political substance, and are urging him to dispense with his slow wind-up.
"This is about connecting with the voters and identifying the candidate with the voters, as opposed to showing up in a nice picture on a daily basis for 30-seconds on the national news," a senior New York Republican said today as part of a generally unhappy assessment of Mr. Lazio's first run out. "There's a legitimate need to talk about Hillary's record and her stand on the issues."
Mr. Lazio and his advisers, in particular his chief strategist, Mike Murphy, are not known for being shy about going on the attack. But they are constrained by the history of candidates who have squandered their credibility by starting off on the attack, and this concern has been evident in the Lazio camp in the last few days. Mr. Lazio has chastised reporters who have suggested in their questioning that he is attacking Mrs. Clinton. And Mr. Lazio's aides were upset with newspaper headlines that portrayed Mr. Lazio as going on the attack.
Mrs. Clinton's advisers are not strangers to tough campaign tactics and, sensing the Republican candidate's discomfort, have thrown marbles in his path.
"It sounds like Congressman Lazio's bus took a wrong turn off the high road today, offering New Yorkers more insults instead of ideas," Howard Wolfson, the campaign spokesman, said moments after Mr. Lazio made some critical remarks about the first lady.
For now, Mr. Lazio's aides said that he would continue to steer away from engaging Mrs. Clinton as much as possible, hoping that with experience comes restraint. And they are not even trying to conceal their intentions.
When Mr. Lazio was posing with workers at a milk processing factory in Syracuse early this week, one of his aides noticed that reporters were spilling into the picture and shooed them to the back of the room.
"We're doing this for the cameras," he declared."

HEADLINE: Governors End Port Authority Rift That Blocked Billions in Projects

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman settled an 18-month standoff at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey yesterday, clearing the way for long-blocked projects worth billions to both states.
In a flurry of late-afternoon telephone calls, the two governors -- who had refused appeals from their political colleagues to speak to each other about the impasse -- put the finishing touches on a deal their negotiators have hammered out over the last several months. 
 The agency's 12-member board is expected to ratify the agreement at a meeting today, where, one member said, "the floodgates will open" when members vote on previously stalled projects and other deals reached in the negotiations.
In the governors' talks yesterday, Mr. Pataki agreed to end New York's opposition to a 30-year lease for the Maersk-Sealand shipping line to expand its operations at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal. The proposed lease had been the major cause of the disagreement, which has all but stymied an agency created 79 years ago to end bickering between the two states over transportation and port commerce.
Mrs. Whitman, in turn, ended New Jersey's refusal to approve two projects dear to New York: selling or leasing the World Trade Center to private interests and leasing air rights over the Port Authority Bus Terminal.
As part of the deal, Mrs. Whitman also agreed to a study that is likely to lead to an increase by the end of the year in the $1 fare on the PATH rapid transit line -- a step New York had long sought. The governors, who each control half of the votes on the Port Authority board, had been locked in a dispute over which state received more financial benefits from the agency, which built and operates all of the bridge and tunnel crossings between New Jersey and New York City, manages airports and seaports in both states, operates the PATH system and owns the World Trade Center.
In a joint news release, Mr. Pataki and Mrs. Whitman presented dueling encomiums to the agreement, which they said would serve commuters, shippers, travelers, the global marketplace and the long-term stability of the region. Their statement gave details on 18 specific actions that they had agreed upon.
"This agreement will ensure the Port Authority moves forward with important projects that will help spur economic growth for the entire region, creating more jobs and opportunities for hard-working New Yorkers," Mr. Pataki said in the statement.
For her part, Governor Whitman added, "It will guarantee the lasting prominence of our shared port in the global marketplace and will provide a foundation for the long-term stability of the port region."
New York officials have long contended that New Jersey, which is smaller and contributes less to the region's economy, has benefited disproportionately from agency spending.
Some items in the agreement that seemed aimed at addressing New York's concerns included the creation of a $250 million "development bank" for New York transportation projects over the next three years and the allocation of agency money for economic development efforts in South Jamaica, Queens, where a new terminal is planned to connect subway and commuter trains to a Kennedy Airport rail link.
New York would also benefit from the agreement's call for approval of measures to improve Howland Hook and Red Hook port and barge operations and its promise that the Port Authority will lease space in the proposed main post office and Pennsylvania Station renovation in Midtown Manhattan.
The agreement also calls for agency approval of the northbound connection of the Staten Island Railroad to CSX Transportation's Chemical Coast Line.
Among the gains for New Jersey in the agreement are the allocation of $120 million in agency funds for dredging operations that New Jersey had previously planned to finance on its own, and the sale of cranes to help modernize several cargo terminals.
The agreement also gives the go-ahead to the purchase and development by the port agency of a Jersey City site for port use, the privatization of the Newark Legal Center and a study of the feasibility of extending the PATH line to Newark Airport monorail connections.
While the impasse had not completely hobbled the agency, it had blocked the authority's major initiatives and spawned furious philosophical debates between the two states' representatives over whether Port Authority investments benefited the region, or just one state.
Differences over these issues had thrown the agency into tumult, threatening the agency's reputation as a can-do and efficient builder.
As part of the agreement, the governors have directed the agency board to begin two studies to try to bridge those philosophical differences and set clear criteria for projects. One study would modify how the Port Authority evaluates a project's cost, return on investment and regional benefit. The other would study the financial and operating structure of the agency and more throughly examine the allocation of resources between the two states.

HEADLINE: Plan for New Intelligence Post Is Shelved

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 1

 BODY:
An ambitious plan to create a post to oversee the government's spy-catching efforts has been shelved by the Clinton administration, largely because of strong opposition from Attorney General Janet Reno, federal officials said today.
The job of a national counterintelligence executive was proposed to answer widespread criticism of the government's efforts to combat espionage. 
 The official would have been asked to develop and oversee a strategy to protect the nation's secrets, trying to stay a step ahead of foreign spies by identifying what information -- in government and in industry -- would be the most enticing to other governments.
The proposal, the product of a yearlong interagency review, gained support from Louis J. Freeh, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation; George J. Tenet, the director of central intelligence, and John J. Hamre, who until recently was deputy secretary of defense, officials said.
But Ms. Reno blocked the proposal, and some officials said they believed that her opposition was the product of her feud with Mr. Freeh, whose agency is charged with overseeing domestic counterintelligence.
In letters and conversations with other officials, Ms. Reno indicated that she believed the agency needed to solve its own internal problems with counterintelligence instead of adding a new layer of bureaucracy.
Ms. Reno and Mr. Freeh have been at odds over a wide variety of issues over the past few years, most notably Mr. Freeh's recommendation, which she rejected, that she appoint an independent counsel to investigate campaign fund-raising abuses by Democrats in the 1996 presidential election.
Opposition to the counterintelligence plan, called CI-21, also surfaced within the F.B.I., where some senior officials were said to fear that it would erode the bureau's authority over spy-hunting operations.
And some Clinton administration officials said they believed that the interagency panel, formed last summer, had gone too far by calling for major changes in the counterintelligence structure without adequately consulting with other officials throughout the government.
"The idea of a new counterintelligence executive is probably not going to work the way it was proposed," a senior administration official acknowledged.
Still, officials said, many of the panel's ideas for changing the direction of counterintelligence may be incorporated in more a modest reorganization plan in the future.
A high-level review of counterintelligence is still under way within the administration, they said.
"It's clear that the CI-21 initiative has succeeded in focusing attention, and what will emerge from that is still evolving," said the Defense Department spokesman, Kenneth H. Bacon.
Despite the debate over the proposed reorganization, there is widespread agreement among senior officials that the government has failed to keep pace with the rapidly changing espionage threats faced by the United States in a post-cold-war, information-age era.
Critics agree that the F.B.I., the Central Intelligence Agency and the Pentagon have found it difficult to shift gears after decades spent keeping tabs on traditional adversaries, like K.G.B. agents working out of the Soviet embassy in Washington.
Today, as the sole remaining economic and military superpower, the United States faces a wider range of espionage threats than ever before, from both allied and unfriendly nations eager to steal information not just from the C.I.A. or the Pentagon but from corporations and research institutes.
France, Israel, China, India, Russia and other countries are believed to have turned their focus on the United States to obtain sensitive and economically significant scientific and technological information, as well as traditional military and national security secrets.
Intelligence officials made some changes after the 1994 arrest of Aldrich H. Ames, the C.I.A. officer who spied for the Soviet Union. But several officials said they believed that the National Counterintelligence Center, established at the agency after the Ames case, had largely failed to provide coordination for counterintelligence. The center would have been abolished under the proposed restructuring.
Flaws in the government's handling of some high-profile espionage cases, including the investigation of Wen Ho Lee, the former government scientist accused of mishandling government secrets, have underscored the need for counterintelligence reform, officials say.
In the Lee case, an 800-page classified report by the Justice Department has just been completed detailing the mistakes made both at the F.B.I. and at the Justice Department in the way they handled investigation.
The report is said to offer an even-handed critique of the government's failures in the Lee case.
The report criticizes the F.B.I. for its failure to aggressively investigate evidence that China may have stolen American nuclear weapons data, as well as its decision to focus on Dr. Lee early in that investigation. But it also is critical of the Justice Department for its failure to approve F.B.I. requests to wiretap Dr. Lee.
While he was never charged with espionage, Dr. Lee was accused of mishandling classified material after investigators found that he had downloaded large amounts of sensitive nuclear weapons design information and then copied it onto portable computer tapes. Some of those tapes are now missing. Dr. Lee has said he is innocent of the charges.
The reorganization proposed in the new initiative would not have altered the F.B.I.'s authority to handle criminal investigations into spy cases.
But it would have created a board made up of senior officials from the C.I.A., F.B.I. and Pentagon and advised by other agencies like State and Treasury. Its executive would have set the broad direction of counterintelligence strategy, and would had access to information about ongoing espionage cases.
"It's terribly unfortunate that the attorney general has seen fit to torpedo this, because the concept is very good and absolutely necessary as we face counterintelligence threats that are as great as ever," said Paul Redmond, a former chief of counterintelligence at the C.I.A.

HEADLINE: Factory Turnaround Reflects Economic Glimmer in Russia

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: VOLOGDA, Russia

 BODY:
Don't look now, says Viktor Petukhov, but that Russian economy the world wrote off as a basket case two years ago is roaring back to life.
He is certainly right about the roaring part. 
 Inside a peeling salmon-colored stucco building near the center of this otherwise quiet town, Mr. Petukhov, the director of the Vologda Textile Enterprise, stood one recent day and surveyed the ear-splitting success he has wrought. Around him, a hundred mechanical looms clack-clacked in deafening unison, spitting miles of linen onto spools as big as car axles.
He said linen sales leapt by 50 percent last year and would grow by a third or so more this year. This from a company that was bankrupt and rudderless just four years ago.
"There's growth everywhere," he said. "All we need now is stability and some government understanding of the problems."
This is Russia's not-quite-open secret: the crash of 1998, the meltdown that wiped out Russia's middle class and turned the Kremlin into a global deadbeat, is over.
Its devastating aftereffects -- a sharply devalued ruble, the disappearance of imports, a government cut off from addictive foreign loans -- turned out to be fuel for an economy that had simply run out of gas. A landscape littered with bankruptcies two years ago now sprouts hundreds of Vologda Textiles.
The question is whether that comeback is real and gaining strength, or will run out of steam.
The Kremlin casts it as real, if shaky, and the numbers look promising. Industrial production through April was 10.3 percent greater than the same period in 1999. Russian exports jumped 50 percent. The average worker's salary, a meager $73 a month, nevertheless was up 7 percent in March over a year ago.
Companies and the government have begun to pay workers months and even years of back wages. Inflation this year is expected to run about 13 percent, far below the 1999 rate. Investment in new equipment and buildings is rising for the first time in a decade.
Most promising, Russia's budget now runs a primary surplus -- that is, it has money left after domestic spending to pay some of its foreign debt. In Washington in May, President Vladimir V. Putin's chief economic adviser told President Clinton that the Kremlin no longer needed to secure new foreign loans just to pay its old ones.
Mr. Putin now announces the good news personally, as in April when he disclosed a higher-than-expected increase in economic growth in the first quarter. By recent Russian standards, he boasted, "this is enormous growth."
He cautions, and experts agree, that it cannot last absent basic economic reforms. He already has proposed wholesale changes in taxes, including a flat income tax and corporate tax cuts, and despite concerns that the wealthy would benefit most, the changes appear to have strong support. Mr. Putin promises to announce equally sweeping changes in June. If they become law, his advisers say, Russia's economy should grow by roughly 5 percent a year, and inflation should fall steadily.
Other top government forecasters are less cocksure. They agree that the economy is reaping the economic windfall of the 1998 crisis. The problem, they say, is that the windfall has now been more or less exploited, and there is little to take its place.
"In the second part of this year, the positive influences will mostly be over," said Aleksandr Frenkel, the chief macroeconomics forecaster at the Russian Academy of Sciences' Economics Institute. "And the influence of negative factors -- low investment, a foreign payments crisis, a low standard of living -- may significantly influence economic growth."
Eduard F. Baranov, the first deputy chief of the government's Economic Research Center, says Russia's boomlet has been confined mostly to raw-materials exports and light industries like food processing and textiles. Major industries have mostly been left behind.
Companies like Vologda Textiles "are like little plants that give us hope," he said. But they are not the architects of basic reform that the economy needs.
"We still have the mentality of the old Soviet plan, when we didn't have to think about sales or quality or lowering expenses," he said. "We have to rebuild our organization at the molecular level. And it's going to take a long time."
The bears say the glowing statistics look a lot different when Russia's performance is compared with the months before the August 1998 crash instead of the depressed months after it. Investment so far this year is surely greater than last, they allow, but it still is only 92 percent of that during early 1998. Workers' real income is substantially higher than a year ago. But it remains barely 77 percent of what is was in 1998, and that translates into a lower standard of living.
"Wages haven't returned yet to their pre-crisis level," Mr. Baranov said. "And while salaries have increased, they have risen at a lower rate than prices."
A Russia that poor is hard put to generate enough domestic demand to make the economy grow. The statistics bear that out, Mr. Frenkel says: exports are driving the recovery, accounting for more than $8 of every $10 of growth in the gross domestic product.
Russian exports have boomed because the fallen ruble has made them exceptionally cheap while economic growth elsewhere has driven up demand. But most are raw materials -- timber, chemicals and especially high-priced oil. Exporting consumer goods is unrealistic; most remain too shoddy or poorly marketed. Some of those same goods have prospered at home because of another crisis-borne opportunity: the chance to fill the gaps on store shelves after the ruble's crash made foreign products too expensive.
But those gaps have been largely closed. To keep growing, companies now must attract new buyers -- no easy task in a nation whose products are not ready for export, and whose citizens are too poor to buy anyway. In fact, exports have slowed this year, and industrial output fell in April. So did the measure of business managers' confidence in the future.
All that seems at odds with the brimming orders at Vologda Textile and its kin. But in more than a few ways, Vologda Textile epitomizes the economy's two-steps-forward, one-step-back quality. Like the rest of Russia, this place has come a long way in the last few years, yet still has miles to go.
For 38 years after its founding in 1953, Vologda Textile was a worry-free place. Its 5,000 workers had state-guaranteed jobs. The bottom line was no concern: the state bought the output, too. In its heyday, the factory churned out 22 million square meters of linen a year.
But when Communism fell in 1991, Vologda Textile followed the rest of Russian industry into a black hole. The government hastily privatized it. Harebrained schemes that followed included a switch from making textiles to making jeeps. By the mid-90's, the company was bankrupt.
Vologda's regional government finally intervened, and in 1998 it dispatched Mr. Petukhov, a dour furniture-factory manager to clean up the mess. A mess it was, too. Workers had gone unpaid for three years. With a crippled factory for their product, farmers had stopped growing flax, and cultivation had plummeted to a paltry 6,000 acres in 1998 from 200,000 in the early 90's. Exports were a fantasy: the ancient looms produced only 100-centimeter linen in a world market that bought only cloth 150 centimeters wide.
That said, Vologda Textile had some advantages. For one, Russia was posed to prosper in the world textile business, if only it could control costs.
"In Europe, the textile industry is shutting down," Mr. Petukhov said. "Labor costs are very expensive in Europe, and fabrics produced in Europe are very expensive." The centers of textile production, he said, have been moving east to Russia, Ukraine and elsewhere.
Also, the region's government was already pushing the sorts of economic reforms that Mr. Putin is pressing on Parliament. The region's new governor, Vyacheslav Y. Pozgalev, exempted businesses from all taxes, provided they poured the savings into their companies. He lent flax farmers money and equipment. And he gave Vologda Textile a break on electricity prices, and a hefty order of linen to get it back on its feet.
It also helped that clothing is one of life's essentials. "When people's income fell after the crash, lots of them became poor," Mr. Frenkel said. "And when you're poor, all you can afford is food and clothes."
The crash of '98 solved Vologda Textile's competitiveness woes: almost overnight, the ruble's plunge made its linen four times cheaper to foreign buyers. Nationally, textile production shot up 20 percent in 1999, even as other industries struggled.
But none of that might have helped had the factory not bootstrapped itself into profitability. The work force was slashed to 1,300, ending the featherbedding that was a staple of Soviet factory life. The government shut the monolithic trade agency that marketed textiles abroad, so Mr. Petukhov began hawking his wares at trade shows in Milan, Paris and New York.
As in most Russian industry, new equipment was too expensive. So over a year, workers rebuilt 400 looms to produce 150-centimeter fabric and fired up a foundry to make hard-to-get spare parts.
The result of all the changes: Vologda Textile will sell six million meters of linen this year -- well below its totals of old, but enough to make a profit. Next year, the goal is eight million meters.
Exports have rocketed to 80 percent of sales, with Italy and the United States the primary customers. Mr. Petukhov also has paid off back wages. That helped workers, who make 31 to 46 cents an hour -- $50 to $70 a month -- for mind-numbing and unhealthy work. "American workers would never work for such wages," Mr. Petukhov grumbled.
On the assembly line, 37-year-old Tatyana Naidyonova, an apron covering her Harley-Davidson T-shirt, paused from cleaning a machine with kerosene and agreed. "It's not much money," she said. "But where else can you get any more?" Raises will have to wait until the plant can sell more and better linen.
Governor Pozgalev says private investors -- this time with experience -- could buy the factory by year's end. His eventual goal, and Mr. Petukhov's, is to move from a supplier of basic cloth to a producer of more profitable dyed and refined fabrics, and eventually to make and export clothes.
"We have only to solve the problem of the quality of our material and little by little increase the volume," Mr. Petukhov said. "What's needed is that in Russia we produce as much as possible, and buy as little as possible abroad."
That is a long way away. The factory still faces basic problems and Soviet mind-sets at every turn. One example: linen production is severely crimped by the supply of local flax, which is in turn limited by the state's utter failure to replace Soviet-style collective farming and sound management. So Vologda Textile has been forced to buy higher-priced flax from Belgium, France and the Netherlands -- which, in turn, is slapped with a 15 percent customs duty. That raises Vologda Textile's costs, and lowers sales.
The factory also has to navigate the Gordian customs office, which inexplicably follows the factory's processing of imported flax into cloth even after the duty is paid and the reedy plant is made into thread.
The factory is peppered with tags on various machines reserving them exclusively for imported flax under customs supervision. Asked why, Mr. Petukhov said drily: "We have a bureaucracy in this country. You probably have one in America, too." That may be solved soon; local flax production should jump by two-thirds, to 25,000 acres, next year.
For now, though, Vologda Textile must import some 40 percent of its raw material from Europe. That lifts costs. But it is a change that Mr. Petukhov savors.
"For once," he said, "we're importing our raw materials from the West, instead of the other way around."

HEADLINE: The Patterns Hidden In Market Swings

BYLINE: By EDWARD ROTHSTEIN 

 BODY:
In recent years, the craggy peaks and sharp precipices of the common stock chart have redefined the American landscape. Charts flash on television screens and computer monitors, inspire animated debate and wild expectations, and become minor obsessions. Anyone who follows charts cannot follow them casually; too much is at stake. But anyone who follows them closely can be baffled by their vast swings, unexplained moves and dizzying plunges.
Of course, professional commentators would argue, these movements are hardly arbitrary. Among the reasons they offer for the ups and downs: changes in interest rates, shifts in foreign policy, technological innovations. And theories abound for how to predict the fate of a company's stock chart. 
 Some investors have championed "value" investing, in which a company's cash flow, future earnings and assets are rigorously analyzed; stock prices are expected to reflect a rational analysis of value.
One interpretation of stock market behavior, known as the random walk theory, has less faith in reason: prices randomly stumble around a perceived value like a drunk looking for a lost coin; no past price can tell us anything about the future.
Other theories argue that the future can indeed be anticipated by examining past activity through computer analyses of the rate of stock sales, or calculations of the averages of stock prices over the last 200 days, or examinations of seasonal price patterns.
Meanwhile, though, another set of techniques appeals to the hope that a deeper order can be revealed in the bewildering movements of the market. It is known as "technical analysis." As the Internet has turned the market into a mass market, this discipline, once the domain of professional traders, has entered the mainstream.
Software programs like Omnitrader and Internet sites like www.barchart.com bring the approach home. Television discussions of "support levels," and "consolidation," "breakouts" and "corrections," have made the vocabulary as familiar as a weatherman's references to low-pressure systems, pollen count and wind-chill factors.
According to the theory of technical analysis, nothing needs to be considered aside from a chart showing price movements and volumes of trades. Forget profit statements, business plans and inflation figures; ignore whether the company makes widgets or lays fiber optic cable. Investors, the theory believes, have already come in contact with all these bits of knowledge, reacted to them, judged their impact on other investors, and acted upon them. The result is a stock's price; commitment to that price is measured in the volume of trades.
Technical analysts examine charts, draw geometric shapes, connect points and mark off familiar patterns. Each pattern has a meaning in the analyst's lexicon, providing a glimpse of what might happen next. Some technical analysts, having seen a promise of pictorial order, go further, arguing that there are even more basic rules governing these shapes, rules that grow out of what they consider basic laws of nature and geometry; some get even more fantastical, invoking the principles of astrology. These latter hypotheses do not seem to have a major following, but few traders work without using some of the techniques of technical analysis.
In one classic text, "Technical Analysis of Stock Trends," (seventh edition, 1997, St. Lucie Press), Robert D. Edwards and John Magee trace technical analysis to ideas first advanced a hundred years ago by Charles H. Dow, a founder of Dow Jones & Company. The market, they explain, moves in long-term trends in which stocks rise or fall; those trends are subdivided into secondary or tertiary trends in which retreats and advances also take place.
The entire effect, they suggest, is like the ebb and flow of the tides, punctuated by individual waves washing against the shore, whose own surfaces are, in turn, shaped by more chaotic ripples. The goal of analysis is to identify places where the tide will change.
Charts can help, analysts argue, if their pictorial language is properly understood. These patterns tend to have geometric names like a "right-angle broadening formation" or pictorial names like "falling wedge." A chart might, for example, create a "head and shoulders formation," which is composed of three jagged hills, the central one (the head) reaching the highest point. These patterns and scores of others can best be understood as maps of human behavior, revealing ways in which investors act and react.
Consider one example: the "head and shoulders" pattern. When a stock's price is rising, analysts argue, the pattern is almost always followed by a reversal. Why? Imagine a stock moving from $10 to $12 and back, forming a "shoulder." It then rises again to $15 before falling again to $10, forming a "head." Finally another shoulder forms, resembling the first. Why should this mean the stock will fall from $10?
Well, think of the behavior this pattern portrays. The first rise is energetic, with heavy volume, but the fall back from $12 reveals some doubts. Some owners cautiously sell off a bit, but others may hold on as the first shoulder is formed. The head represents yet another burst of support. But though the stock reaches higher, the trading has less volume. Conviction is limited and the stock drops again.
Two such rises and falls might be thought inconsequential, but by the time the stock rises yet again, worry becomes palpable. The faith in the stock cannot be supported. Finally, the stock begins its extended fall, plunging below $10, which is picturesquely called the "neckline."
The uncertainty shown in this pattern might be affected by a company's fortunes, or the state of the economy, but according to the theory, interpreting the pattern requires no knowledge of any of this. "Head and shoulders" is a pattern caused by conflict; it reveals a gradual defeat of bullish optimism. And the pattern has the same meanings for any stock.
The theory of analysis then goes even further: rules not only predict broad patterns, they also provide guidance about the extent of a rise or fall. For analysts, charts almost seem to follow aesthetic principles. For example, analysts suggest that in the "head and shoulders" pattern, the second shoulder will tend to mirror the first, and the rise of the "head" will tend to be matched by the extent of the fall after the stock drops below the "neckline." There is something uncanny about such assertions; they are much more difficult to justify. But they reveal a determination to find order in the midst of seeming chaos.
Critics argue that these sorts of rules have so many exceptions they can hardly be relied upon; that patterns are best seen in retrospect, when they are no longer helpful; that analysts' ideas can becomeself-fulfilling prophecies. And indeed, while investment banks have technical analysts on staff, strict analysis is generally tempered by considerations of other factors.
But the effort to find pictorial order seems almost universal. The Japanese, for example, have used a 300-year-old method of charting known as "candlesticks," made familiar in the West after the analyst Steve Nison examined them in books like "Beyond Candlesticks: New Japanese Charting Techniques Revealed" (1994, Wiley). Instead of just marking the range of a day's trading with a single vertical line, as on Western charts, the Japanese create candlesticks: small rectangles whose ends represent the stock's opening and closing prices. If the price fell during the day, the candlestick is darkened (and is called a "long black body"); if the price rose, it is left unshaded (and is called a "long white body"). In candlestick charts, technical analysis becomes almost poetic, with patterns named "morning star," "hanging man" and "falling window."
But if charts reveal hidden patterns, some believe there are even deeper esoteric patterns guiding them. In "The Psychology of Technical Analysis" (1993, Irwin), which The Financial Times of London said would "entertain and intrigue keen investors," Tony Plummer, a British trader, argues that the ebb and flow of human activity actually follow a pattern that resembles the curve of the Nautilus shell. That curve, which expands outward without changing its shape, recurs throughout the natural world in various organic forms (pine cones, sunflowers, tree leaves). It is an image of a certain form of growth that, Mr. Plummer suggests, also applies to the large-scale actions of the marketplace. He argues that a properly drawn Nautilus curve -- and it is by no means easy to find the proper curve -- will intersect with the stock's highs and lows.
Major turning points in stock charts, other theorists have also argued, occur at intervals determined by the Golden Mean -- a ratio approximately equal to 1.618 that also determines the shape of the Nautilus curve. Similar arguments are made in "Fibonacci Applications and Strategies for Traders" by Robert Fischer (1993, Wiley) and are regularly described in survey texts like "Technical Analysis of the Financial Markets" by John J. Murphy (1999, New York Institute of Finance). The quest for order would now seem complete: charts not only are rife with symmetries and patterns, but they also reflect a ratio that is considered one of the most beautiful in the natural world.
It is perhaps too much to believe, that the cumulative effect of individual decisions to buy and sell would create such hidden patterns. In fact, push the notion of hidden pattern a bit further and chart reading can even turn religious: the analyst Perry J. Kaufman devotes 10 pages to financial astrology in a scrupulous theoretical text, "Trading Systems and Methods" (1998, Wiley), a method few analysts would probably confess to using.
Of course, these assertions are not widely accepted; they are extensions of the theory, not exceptions to it. Technical analysis has its believers and detractors, but it is an unusual attempt to make sense of an exceedingly mysterious phenomenon.
After all, the market may be created by its participants but it is also independent of them; it reflects their will but also affects their will; its participants believe they are free, but their actions fall into familiar patterns. The chart is not just the record of a company's share price; it is the record of attempts to guess the future. It is a trace of human behavior. So what are we seeing when we examine these charts? Images of ourselves.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Unemployment Rate Rose To 4.1 Percent Last Month
In the strongest signal yet that the booming economy is finally slowing, the Labor Department reported that the nation's private sector employers shed 116,000 jobs in May. It was the largest drop in more than eight years and the first decline since the economy began to soar in the mid-1990's. 
 The unemployment rate edged up to 4.1 percent from 3.9 percent, with blacks and Hispanics absorbing most of the loss. Wage increases, which had accelerated in the early spring, eased in May, reducing concerns about inflation. Jobs disappeared in almost every sector of the economy, except government, where the hiring of 357,000 census takers for the once-a-decade population count offset the decline in business jobs. Page A1.
 
More H.M.O.'s Are Exiting Medicare
More health maintenance organizations, including Cigna and Aetna, will soon pull out of Medicare or curtail their participation, disrupting insurance coverage for thousands of elderly people, according to federal officials, independent experts and managed care executives. Despite pledges by the Clinton administration to slow the withdrawal, the exodus may actually accelerate this year, a White House official and several experts said. A1.
 
F.A.A. May Ground Alaska Airlines
The Federal Aviation Administration threatened to shut down major maintenance operations at Alaska Airlines, which would ground the airline within months. The agency, its attention drawn to the airline by a fatal crash last January and a federal grand jury investigation, said that the carrier had a persistent problem in keeping track of whether required maintenance had been done, and that managers had not noticed the problem. A7.
 
Oprah Magazine Editor to Resign
The editor of O: The Oprah Magazine is resigning for personal reasons, forcing the owners of the top-selling women's glossy to find a new leader after just one issue went on sale. Ellen Kunes, a longtime editor of women's magazines, said her decision was prompted by "work-family issues" and had nothing to do with the way the magazine was run. C15.
 
Brazilian Pension Fund Controversy
In a political race that was major news in Brazil but little noticed abroad, a radical-left coalition now controls all three elected seats on the six-member board of the nation's largest and most influential pension fund. Two radical leftist candidates who won seats in an election last month began their terms Thursday, joining an incumbent colleague on the board of the fund, known as Previ. That gives them unprecedented power to block decisions that require a majority vote. C2.
 
Another Loss for Soros Hedge Fund
The hedge fund empire of George Soros continued to shrink as Duncan Hennes, left, who was hired last summer to be chief executive of Soros Fund Management, announced his resignation. "I was brought in to do one thing, and George doesn't want to do that anymore," Mr. Hennes, 43, said. That thing, he said, was to build a larger hedge fund business. Mr. Soros announced in April that his two top fund managers, Stanley Druckenmiller and Nicholas Roditi, were leaving and that the fund that made Mr. Soros famous, the Quantum Fund, would be renamed the Quantum Endowment Fund and changed in emphasis to reduce its risk. C15.
 
F.T.C. to Sue to Halt Kroger Deal
The Federal Trade Commission announced that it would sue to halt Kroger's proposed purchase of 74 Winn-Dixie Stores supermarkets in Oklahoma and Texas. The F.T.C. voted 5 to 0 to seek a preliminary injunction in a Federal District Court in Dallas. A Kroger spokesman said the company would explore its legal alternatives. Kroger has more than 2,300 stores in 31 states. C4.

HEADLINE: JOURNAL;
We All Pass Go. They Collect $200.

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH 

 BODY:
At long last: Schadenfreude dot-com.
This has been a great spring not only for those rooting for the comeuppance of Bill Gates, but for anyone who has had quite enough of New Economy New Millionaires and their irritatingly unostentatious brand of ostentation. Just a short list of recent flameouts includes boo.com (a fashion site that burned through $135 million in months), den.net (a "digital entertainment network" panting haplessly after the demographic Holy Grail of Generation Y), and RedRocket.com (toys from Nickelodeon). Among the countless former high-fliers in a Wall Street tailspin are Drkoop.com and Michael Saylor's MicroStrategy, whose shares have dropped from $333 in March to around $23 today, amid investigations for alleged accounting irregularities. 
 Most of these sites rode in on a wave of hype as excessive as those that herald Hollywood's bigger bombs. (On the Web, as in show business, the big hits are often sleepers.) Mr. Saylor was being canonized in the press as a Medici -- for underwriting a dubious, if free, online university -- just as his stockholders fell on his sword. Now that these start-ups are in peril or ruin, their press is almost as apocalyptic as the initial buzz was celebratory. When Disney bought a 60 percent interest in Toysmart.com back in August, an expert at Forrester Research gushed to The Associated Press, "There's nothing bad in it for Disney." When Toysmart went belly-up last week, another Forrester analyst authoritatively told The A.P. it was "the wrong company selling the wrong product at the wrong time." Now you tell us!
You have to wonder if these pundits visit the sites they initially tout. I found from personal experience five months ago that den.net was nearly impenetrable even on a fast connection and that no one in its office would come to the phone to explain why. If anyone wonders whether Barnes & Noble has mastered online bookselling, just try, as I did this week, to order from its not-ready-for-e-time "same-day delivery" service. With competitors like this, no one at Amazon need go sleepless in Seattle.
Emotionally satisfying as these rags-to-riches-to-rags dot-com sagas may be, however, they are often irrelevant to the long and looming future of the Internet. Like some other favorite story lines of the past few years -- the kiddie-porn scare, the "Blair Witch" craze, the day-trader menace -- tales of the Nasdaq bubble are transient sideshows in the Web's early gold-rush phase that may look like quaint olden-days phenomena once the Internet is seamlessly integrated into our lives. As with the original California gold rush's prospectors, it's inevitable that more dot-com prospectuses are going to pan fool's gold than pay dirt. The disasters won't slow the progress of this new technology any more than earlier economic setbacks did the spread of the railroad and electricity.
The truly illuminating Internet stories are sometimes less visible than the morality plays of hubristic e-celebrities and evanescent I.P.O.'s. That may be because they are buried in the very architecture of a technology few of us laymen understand -- or because they involve the media's own selfish interests. Or both.
Into this category fall the newest corporate marriages in the increasingly intertwined Internet-cable-entertainment-telecommunications industry: AT&T-MediaOne and AOL-Time Warner. These mammoth couplings have been dissected as stock-price stories and captains-of-industry personality profiles, to be sure. But if it hadn't been for the divine intervention of another corporate giant last month -- Disney -- even a hint of the worst-case scenarios possible in this new media landscape would have been invisible to most Americans. Few still understand how these new powerhouses could make our current cable and phone companies look like kindly mom-and-pop operations by comparison.
What Time Warner did to Disney, throwing ABC off its cable in 11 cities until a public outcry forced a retreat, is just a tiny window into how these corporations can behave in their even more powerful future, when cable TV service will be inseparable from Internet service. There is nothing to stop one of these new megaliths from exerting a larger and more surreptitious chokehold on all the electronic services that their cable wires will speed by the bundle into our homes tomorrow, from chat rooms to e-shopping to movies. Even in the few weeks since the Disney fiasco, when you might think Time Warner would be too chastened to risk more censure, it has been caught misbehaving in Texas, where its cable company offered its employees bounties to place bogus orders for a rival Internet service offered by Southwestern Bell.
Time Warner has since apologized for its recent transgressions, but if it can try to squelch Disney (itself described by The Wall Street Journal as "one of America's most aggressive corporate bullies"), imagine what it can do to smaller companies and consumers once Disney and the other giants inevitably make deals to secure their pieces of the pie.
Not unlike Windows, which blackballed Web software not made by Microsoft, or the most recent edition of AOL, which snaked into its users' computer settings to override competing programs, the future AOL-TW threshold into the Internet/TV can be engineered for nefarious purposes. It could make its own products, like Time and CNN, come on screen easily and fast while slowing down (or blocking) the alternatives, whether Newsweek or Drudgewannabe.com. It could do the same with merchants, TV channels or non-AOL Internet service providers.
In other words, it could control the entertainment and even the news grid on your computer/TV screen much as the movie studios (including Time Warner's ancestor, Warner Brothers) limited Americans' entertainment choices in cities until antitrust action ended such restrictive practices in 1948. The result wouldn't be the democratic, go-anywhere-you-want Internet of yore but a more elaborate version of cable TV, in which your cable company adjudicates both your programming choices and cyber-activities (and could monitor all of them).
It would be like "someone constantly dealing the deck and knowing every card and shuffling at will, but never letting you know if you're being dealt every card or not," says Jeffrey Chester of the Center for Media Education. Gerald Levin, of Time Warner, and Steve Case, of AOL, have pledged not to be naughty, but even if we take them at their word, they'll not be running their company forever. What's more, what they say already fails to square with what they do. This week USA Today persuasively charged AOL with foot-dragging on last summer's promise to open up its instant-messenger system to all non-AOL Internet users.
The antidote to any possible future misbehavior is not necessarily to stop the merger -- a non-starter anyway -- but for regulators to set simple rules of the information highway (and build them into its construction) so that all comers have equal access to its various lanes. Yet most of the political pressure on Washington comes from the media giants, not the spottily informed public. TV news, the main news source for most Americans, is mum about this part of the merger story, in which so much is at stake for its corporate parents; it's easier to talk about Mr. Levin going tieless.
Nor do politicians want to take on media corporations whose news divisions cover them and whose donations increasingly support them. At my request, the Center for Responsive Politics broke down total campaign contributions by industry over the past decade, and the result shows a rapid increase of total donations by media, communications and electronics companies since the explosion of the Internet -- a stiffer increase than even those made by the health care industry. The parties more or less split the loot.
The Clinton administration has taken a "do-nothing attitude" about ensuring fairness for the millions who will connect by cable into the Internet, according to Lawrence Lessig, the Harvard law professor who has more than anyone framed this issue. Nor is there any Teddy Roosevelt Republican in sight to ride to the rescue. Still, some public-interest advocates are hopeful that voters will be provoked into anger over time, if only because media companies arrogant enough to pull the plug on Regis Philbin may, like Microsoft before them, eventually overplay their hand. But it may take something as startling as a totalitarian new voice saying "You've got mail" -- Charlton Heston's, perhaps -- to wake the country up.

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's Weekend in Moscow

 BODY:
Meetings between American presidents and their Russian counterparts pack less drama than they used to. But they still matter. Bill Clinton's meetings with Vladimir Putin, the first since Mr. Putin became Russia's president, provide a timely opportunity to discuss issues ranging from nuclear arms control to market reforms and human rights. Mr. Clinton should use his public appearances, including a radio call-in show and an address to Parliament, to hail Mr. Putin's steps toward reform and criticize troubling signs of authoritarianism.
Mr. Putin's leadership personality is still unfolding. The theme of his presidency so far has been the reorganization of the central government. That is a reasonable response to the catastrophic breakdown of services over the past decade. But there are concerns that Mr. Putin, who was a K.G.B. officer in the Soviet era, means to reassert Kremlin powers at the expense of Russia's nascent civil liberties. Last month's raid on Media-MOST, a leading private media company, was troubling in this regard. So is Moscow's continuing military brutality in Chechnya and Mr. Putin's legislative drive to override the power of elected regional governors. 
 More encouraging are the economic goals reflected in his cabinet appointments and proposals to reform the income tax code. Higher oil prices and the consequences of earlier ruble devaluations have spurred a modest economic revival in Russia. But this windfall must now be sustained by a coherent set of government policies including further simplifications of the tax code and improvements in property and bankruptcy laws.
No breakthroughs on nuclear arms cuts or missile defense are expected this weekend. But in an interview with NBC News Mr. Putin acknowledged that he, too, recognized a potential threat from small, unpredictable nuclear powers. He said he intended to propose a joint defensive system to counter it. The details of Mr. Putin's ideas have yet to be filled in, but they are likely to be quite different from the national missile defense system currently being tested by the Pentagon. Mr. Clinton should listen carefully to any new Russian proposal. It could ease the path to an eventual agreement. As for offensive warheads, both sides have strong reason to move ahead with deep new cuts.
Mr. Putin's presidency is just beginning, while Mr. Clinton's is drawing to a close. But the remaining seven and a half months during which their terms overlap should not be wasted. Mr. Clinton has full authority to negotiate on nuclear issues through next January. As leader of the world's foremost democracy he also has the moral authority, and obligation, to speak out in defense of human rights and Russia's newly won freedoms.

HEADLINE: Measuring the Progress of Women

 BODY:
Next week at the United Nations, representatives of nearly every country and thousands of non-governmental groups are meeting to talk about what the world has done to improve the lives of women. The delegates will evaluate what has happened since the 1995 World Conference on Women in Beijing, when 187 nations endorsed a wide range of goals and promised specific actions.
The subject of women's needs is, of course, a broad one, encompassing poverty -- 70 percent of the poor are female -- health, domestic violence, armed conflict, political representation and other issues. One achievement of the Beijing conference was its acknowledgment that women need to be heard in debates on just about every kind of policy. 
 The Beijing conference was the fourth U.N. conference on women, but more than the others it established concrete targets -- such as abolishing laws that discriminate against women economically or increasing the number of women in public administration -- and set timetables for measuring progress. Activists have found these benchmarks crucial to holding governments accountable.
In 1998 the Women's Environment and Development Organization, a New York-based network of groups, did a survey of progress. It found that most of the governments represented at Beijing had drawn up plans to keep their promises, and 64 countries had changed laws. The growth of local women's groups has been the most important reason for these advances. Some 30,000 activists attended the Beijing conference, and they have used its platform to organize women and to press governments to keep their commitments.
But most of what governments call action is still just lofty talk, and is not yet affecting women. The inaction stems partly from cultural resistance and partly from lack of money to finance new programs. Governments argue, persuasively, that they are overwhelmed by AIDS, debt payments and budget cuts demanded by the International Monetary Fund. But women's issues have never been a priority, even when progress, as with educating girls, would benefit the nation as a whole.
In addition, many governments are not even changing egregious laws, which costs nothing. In several countries women may not inherit property. In much of Latin America, a rapist goes free if he marries the victim. In several Islamic countries, a man may kill a female relative who has disgraced the family. In Pakistan, women's testimony has no value in rape cases. In Kuwait, women still may not vote. "We have prepared people to ask their government: 'Did you do what you said you would do?' " says Litha Musyimi-Ogana, a Kenyan activist, who could be speaking for women's groups everywhere. This is a big achievement, but the answer in too many places is "no."
