HEADLINE: Streetscapes/Readers' Questions;
Building's Name, Gallery's Photo, Complex's Origin

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:

A Wall Street Skyscraper
Q I have been tracing my family ancestry and know that Helena Gillender Asinari built the Gillender building in memory of her father. But who was he? . . . Katey Gillinder, Cambridge, England.
A Her father was Eccles Gillender, born in New York in 1810, a millionaire tobacco merchant who made his fortune during the Civil War and died in Paris in 1877. Although his obituary spells the name Gillender, earlier directory and census records sometimes render it with the spelling you use in your signature. The 19-story Gillender Building, an unusually thin skyscraper designed by Berg & Clark, was built in 1896-1897 at the northwest corner of Wall and Nassau Streets. It was put up in a hurry to beat contemplated legislation to outlaw tall buildings, although serious regulation did not come until 1916. The $500,000 structure was demolished only 13 years after completion, replaced by the Bankers Trust Company skyscraper at 14 Wall Street. 
 Although no period sources definitely indicate how Helena Asinari named the structure, it does seem more likely that she would have named it for her father than her mother, Augusta Gillender. In 1884 Augusta Gillender had disinherited her daughter in favor of her Italian son-in-law, the Marquis of San Marzano, from whom Helena had separated in 1883. Helena Asinari had already inherited the land at Wall and Nassau.
Helena Asinari sold the Gillender skyscraper in 1909, and she was able to purchase the newly built Norman-style apartment house at the northwest corner of 82nd Street and West End Avenue. It was apparently she who gave it the name still in use -- the Umbria. She died there in 1932.
 
A Fifth Avenue Gallery
Q For a new edition of "The Golden City," my book about classical versus modern architecture first published in 1959, can you locate an old photograph of the Duveen art gallery at the northwest corner of 56th Street and Fifth Avenue, designed in 1911 by Horace Trumbauer and Rene Sergent? . . . Henry Hope Reed, Manhattan.
A The oldest good photographs apparently available were made after World War II, long after the building was completed in 1913 and only a few years before its demolition in early 1953. Joseph Duveen was one of the top old-master dealers, closely associated with the collections of Henry Clay Frick, Paul Mellon and others.
The design for this richly sculptured structure was apparently not published in a contemporary architectural journal (such publications are frequently sources for photographs). At the time of construction, Duveen had just pleaded guilty in federal court to art smuggling. The federal prosecutor, Henry A. Wise, described Duveen's company in 1910 as "low down swindlers." Duveen barely escaped prison, and the company paid more than $1 million in fines for evading customs duties by framing valuable paintings underneath lesser works and "mistakenly" shipping furniture to the United States with antique tapestries inside.
The Duveen building was the first of three powerful family-run art galleries to open near 57th Street and Fifth Avenue. They included Durand-Ruel's eight-story gallery and residence at 12 East 57th Street, in 1913, and the richly modeled Knoedler palazzo at 14 East 57th Street, in 1925. Both were designed by Carrere & Hastings, architects of the New York Public Library at 42nd Street and Fifth Avenue, and both have since been demolished.
The Duveen gallery is generally described as having been based on the Ministry of the Marine in Paris, but the building merited only minor notices in Architectural Forum and Architectural Record, both in the 1920's and long after completion. The 1924 Architectural Forum article noted that "the style of Louis XVI has been so closely followed that one might almost imagine the address to be Rue de la Paix instead of Fifth Avenue."
The successor building, an office structure completed in 1954, was designed by Emery Roth & Sons in the "ribbon window" style popular at the time.
 
The East River Homes
Q My daughter lives at 517 East 77th Street, a complex that appears at one time to have been a hospital. On every other landing there are built-in seats, presumably for patients to rest, since there are no elevators. Can you tell me the genesis of the buildings? . . . Bernice Foege, Newtown, Conn.
A The complex was not built as a hospital, but it was supposed to be healthful. The East River Homes -- four connected buildings covering the west side of Cherokee Place from 77th to 78th Streets -- were built in 1912 by Anna Harriman Vanderbilt, who sought to develop a more healthful kind of working-class housing. Mrs. Vanderbilt was following the advice of Dr. George Shively, who was researching the high rates of tuberculosis in crowded urban housing.
Near the East River and facing a public park, the tenements were laid out by the architect Henry Atterbury Smith with sitting areas exposed to sunlight and fresh air, including wide central courtyards, rooftops and the stair landings.
The open stairwells were a reaction against the dark, fetid hallways of traditional tenements. Apparently the lack of elevators was purely an economic issue. According to research by Virginia Kurshan at the Landmarks Preservation Commission, the apartment interiors were also designed with health in mind.
Radiators were mounted on the walls to prevent dust from collecting underneath; flooring material was curved up to the walls; and the unusual triple-sash windows, extending all the way to the floor and leading out to the extensive balcony system, provided more than the usual interior ventilation. The buildings are landmarks.
According to the 1915 census, residents' occupations included electrician, chauffeur, druggist, brakeman, cigar packer and telephone operator. Most apartments held two or three people.
When first rented, one quarter of the apartments were let to tuberculosis patients. In 1924 the buildings were sold to the City and Suburban Homes Company, which already operated the more extensive group of model tenements just to the north. The buildings are now co-ops.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
Helping 10-Year-Olds Find Common Ground

BYLINE: By COREY KILGANNON 

DATELINE: MAMARONECK

 BODY:
AT first it might seem just delightfully precocious: 10-year-old children onstage in sneakers and oversize black T-shirts, bringing smiles to parents' faces by reciting lines from "Romeo and Juliet."
But the performance at the the Murray Avenue School here last month was not just a school play. It was also a closely monitored pilot project involving two classes from very different backgrounds. 
 A fourth-grade class from the Chatsworth Avenue Elementary School in Larchmont, where most students are from upper-income neighborhoods, staged the Shakespeare play with a fifth-grade class from the Mamaroneck Avenue School, where many students (white, black, Hispanic and Asian) are from lower income areas and are the children of immigrants.
The elementary schools in the Mamaroneck district have some of the widest disparities in the county, from the upscale white neighborhoods of Larchmont to poorer immigrant neighborhoods. And the need to bridge this gap, especially before students are thrown together in junior high, has long been a concern, said Steven Bluestone, the teacher of the Chatsworth class.
"These two groups of kids would probably never even meet, much less work together, at this age if not for this," said Mr. Bluestone, who conceived the project.
In 1998 he applied for a grant from the Mamaroneck Schools Foundation to buy six computers and five laptops to help students make classroom presentations. Then the district superintendent, Dr. Sherry King, had computers put into Ken Taylor's fifth- grade classroom at the Mamaroneck Avenue school, so the two classes would learn technology together.
For a subject, Mr. Bluestone suggested staging "Romeo and Juliet." Before going to Chatsworth Avenue three years ago, Mr. Bluestone had worked in the New York City schools for 12 years and long wanted to involve students of diverse backgrounds in performing Shakespeare. The classes began discussing the play online in chat rooms and by e-mail before meeting for rehearsals in May.
"I always wanted to bring students of different backgrounds together, but I never knew exactly how that would occur," Mr. Bluestone said. "I hoped the technology would prepare and support, finally bringing the kids together."
A consultant from the Educational Development Center for Children and Technology in Manhattan monitored the project for the district. The Murray Avenue school was chosen as a neutral site for rehearsals and performances to make the children more comfortable, Mr. Bluestone said.
"Most of my students come from upper-middle-class or wealthy neighborhoods, and Ken's students are a real mix, with a good deal of lower income and immigrant families," Mr. Bluestone said. "And to have them working together and getting along, blind to any differences, that stuff just doesn't happen much here."
The average academic achievement of Chatsworth Avenue students, based on fourth-grade tests, was significantly higher last year than that of Mamaroneck Avenue students. Demographic information was unavailable, but 17.5 percent of Mamaroneck Avenue students are eligible for free lunch, compared with none at Chatsworth Avenue.
For school officials hoping to use fair Verona as a sociological petri dish, here is what they saw: any gaps stemming from ethnic and economic differences were nonexistent onstage. Students quickly dropped their guard and began cooperating enthusiastically, helping one another deliver dialogue from the diaphragm, and trading high-fives afterward.
Riding the bus to rehearsal, Aron Baigelman sat with two Chatsworth classmates, Nathaniel Lowenthal and William Moore, all of whom are white. They said they rarely ride their bikes out of their neighborhood, so they did not know Mr. Taylor's students.
But in the auditorium, Aron rehearsed the role of the prince along with two Mamaroneck Avenue students, Marcus Rohim, 11, who is black, and John Pierre Hohl, who is Peruvian. Between scenes, they discussed television programs, the New York Knicks and even the Montague-Capulet feud.
Floyd Rumohr, artistic director for the Chekhov Theater Ensemble in Brooklyn and the acting coach for the project, said that Shakespearean drama "lets students from different backgrounds meet on new turf."
"All the children are dealing with language that's 400 years old," he said. "It's almost a foreign language, so no child has all the advantages."
At the actual performance, Inocencio Arias and his wife, Beatrice, sat in an otherwise empty balcony. Mr. Arias, who works on a truck collecting recyclables in town, watched his 11-year-old daughter Daisy play the part of Benvolio.
Speaking in broken English, Mr. Arias said he left school in Mexico after sixth grade. He said he was unfamiliar with Shakespeare's plays but hoped his daughter would learn them.
Regardless of their income, ethnic background or fluency in English, most parents said they had enjoyed their children marching around the house reciting lines of iambic pentameter and answering questions with words like cometh and goeth.
Julie Spielvogel, 9, a Chatsworth student, can recite lines from several plays.
"I mean, most of Shakespeare's plays are pretty well known," said Julie, who along with a blond-haired classmate, William Moore, shared the role of the Nurse with two Mamaroneck Avenue students, Elena Reyes, 11, and Yajaira Gonzalez, 10.
Julie's mother, Lisa Spielvogel, said her daughter never stopped reciting lines since the Shakespeare project started, even appointing her cat, Kitty-O, as a stand-in for Romeo. Julie was enrolled in a children's Shakespeare theater troupe when the family spent a year in London last year. Mrs. Spielvogel and her husband, a doctor, rented Julie a cartoon version of "Romeo and Juliet" and recently took her to see the New York City Ballet perform a dance version.
For Jonathan Brewton, however, a student in the Mamaroneck Avenue School, Shakespeare was less accessible. At first, Jonathan, 11, resisted learning the play, Mr. Taylor said, but after a few rehearsals, he became fascinated with it and pestered his mother to find books and a videotape of it.
Mr. Taylor said his students were hesitant about embracing Shakespeare, but were challenged by discussions and rehearsals with the Chatsworth students.
Naomi Lowenthal's son, Nathaniel, is a Chatsworth student who played Friar Laurence. She and her husband, Daniel A. Lowenthal, a lawyer in Manhattan, said students from different elementary schools in Mamaroneck need to mingle more before junior high.
"There's Little League," she said, "but things like this also help neighborhoods from being too insular."
Beth MacErlen, whose son Ryan goes to Chatsworth and played Friar Laurence, agreed, calling Shakespeare a common language to bring them together.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS;
Higher Profile for a Little-Known Foundation

BYLINE: By CAITLIN KELLY 

 BODY:
IT took a Nobel prize-winning Austrian economist to turn a New Orleans' welder's son on to the joys of free-market capitalism. But once Donald J. Boudreaux discovered the work of Freidrich von Hayek, co-winner of the Nobel prize in 1974, there was no going back. "This is my greatest hero," Mr. Boudreaux said of the man whose photograph is one of several pictures of free marketers lining the mantelpiece in his office at the Foundation for Economic Education, a libertarian nonprofit educational group in Irvington.
"I love his depth, his erudition, his seriousness," said Mr. Boudreaux, a friendly, down-to-earth 41-year-old who left a tenured professorship in economics at Clemson University in South Carolina in 1997 to take over as head of the foundation. "A lot of people on both sides of the debate are facile, but he thought about their arguments seriously. He didn't dismiss them." 
 For years, the group, founded in 1946 by a Westchester County business executive, Leonard E. Read, has remained little known and low profile -- drivers whizzing south on Broadway might have noticed its small sign stuck high up on a roadside tree trunk. But the foundation never advertised, gave few seminars, was rarely quoted in the press.
No more, thanks to Mr. Boudreaux, whose passion for the dismal science could illuminate the Manhattan skyline. His plans for the foundation include fund-raising, Web sites, remaking its monthly magazine, creating new educational programs and distributing their materials nationwide to high school debaters and teachers.
Mr. Boudreaux recently hired Nicole Gray, formerly with Steve Forbes's presidential campaign, as his development director. Ms. Gray, who has also worked for the Cato Institute, a conservative think tank in Washington, intends to create and nurture new relationships with members in one region of the country that has, historically, provided the foundation with relatively little support -- New York.
One local fan is John Stossel, the ABC "20/20" correspondent who describes himself as "libertarian leaning." Mr. Stossel discovered the foundation through its magazine. "I had read it and found it really stupid and boring," he said. "Then these new people came in. I was skeptical, as it had always been tedious, but the articles now are often original and well written. It's a jungle gym for the brain."
A longtime Westchester resident who appreciates the foundation's point of view is Sheldon Jacobs, editor and publisher of The No-Load Fund Investor, a monthly newsletter in Irvington. Mr. Jacobs admits that, even after living in Irvington for five years, with the foundation blocks away, "I'd only heard vague references to it." Eventually, a colleague, a fellow investment newsletter publisher in Florida, introduced Jacobs to the group and its activities, including seminars and lectures. Those wanting more information about the foundation can visit its Web site at www.fee.org.
"My attraction to them is that they stand for smaller government," said Mr. Jacobs, who reads the foundation's monthly publication, attends its seminars and hopes, someday, to write for the foundation. The organization puts out a quarterly newsletter, called FEE Today and the 64-page monthly magazine, called Ideas on Liberty. "The thing that really impressed me about them was their 50th anniversary dinner," he said. "It was a huge event at the Waldorf-Astoria, with Bill Buckley as the host and Margaret Thatcher as their keynote speaker. People came from all across the country."
Herb Grossman, who teaches mathematics in Oradell, N.J., but who taught at Roosevelt High School in Yonkers from 1968 to 1985, has, for many years, handed out the foundation's literature to any student he thinks might find it useful. "The materials they get are very inadequate," he said. "I feel the period dealing with the robber barons is terribly portrayed. They were major benefactors. They also learn that the Depression was a failure of the free-enterprise system and the government bailed us out. What I object to is that the kids never hear anything to the contrary."
Only 5 percent of the foundation's 5,000 contributors are from New York, although the group has been based here since it was founded. Members, most of them older and male, traditionally come from Wisconsin and Michigan, Washington State, Texas and California because the last time the Foundation for Economic Education was on the radar screen, fund-raising was strongest in these areas, Mr. Boudreaux says.
The group's annual budget of $2 million comes exclusively from private individuals and a few foundations. Given that its credo is libertarian -- "We're skeptical of state power, no matter what its use," Mr. Boudreaux said -- it would never consider accepting government funds.
"We're looking for local libertarians," Ms. Gray said. "It's just a matter of connecting with them. They just haven't seen us lately."
The group is definitely graying and needs new blood, Mr. Boudreaux said. "Most of our members are in their 60's. When they became interested in free markets they were in college or even in high school." Back then, he says, the foundation was well-known, and Mr. Hayek was a celebrity on a par with his fellow economist Milton Friedman.
But Mr. Hayek's theories, popular from the 1930's through the 1950's, fell out of favor in the 1960's and the age of government expansion, Mr. Boudreaux says.
He has little illusion that the group's work and ideas, filtering slowly through its small and relatively invisible network of supporters, will change the world overnight, or even in his lifetime.
"What FEE does is not going to have an effect on the world tomorrow -- Cato will," he said.
But he went on confidently to say: "I'm out to make people more suspicious of collective political action. I do think ideas matter longterm, but our time horizon is very long. It's not a hard sell because the ideas we espouse are esoteric or out of this world. They're not weird or bizarre. But because the ideas making up an ideology are deeply rooted you can't change them easily."
Mr. Boudreaux, who studied at Nicholls State University in Thibodaux, La., received his law degree at the University of Virginia and his Ph.D. at Auburn University in Alabama, enjoys his own subsidy of sorts -- he and his wife, Karol, and their 2-year-old son, Thomas, live rent free in a carriage house on the foundation's property.
The foundation is currently struggling, he admitted, to define itself. Legally, it is a nonprofit educational organization, and he rejects the term think tank. Instead, he said, "We're more abstract, and focus on the fundamentals."
The trustees, who meet twice a year, "judge us on our inputs" -- seminars, the monthly magazine, with a circulation of 14,000, lectures and summer programs for college and graduate students.
The group does not take positions or create policy like the Cato Institute, with whom it shares trustees and information. This, Mr. Boudreaux said, has kept its profile low. When reporters call, as they often do on deadline seeking a sound bite on economic issues, Mr. Boudreaux doesn't offer them prepackaged answers.
"Some headline," he said with a laugh. "Economist says 'I Don't Know.' "

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Upscale Rentals Finding a Ready Market in Suffolk

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

 BODY:
REFLECTING the continuing popularity of upscale rental housing, Trammel Crow Residential has started construction on almost 800 luxury apartments in central Suffolk County.
The development, called Alexan Brookhaven, will have 795 apartments and will occupy 117 acres in South Yaphank between Woodside Avenue and Horse Block Road, east of Station Road-Bellport Avenue. When completed in 2002, the development will be one of the largest rental projects on Long Island. 
 Trammell Crow's entry into the Long Island market is another indication that this area is increasingly attracting upscale rental housing that offers many, if not all, of the features of for-sale units, along with extensive recreational amenities.
The increasing popularity of upscale rental apartments can be traced, in part, to the region's growing number of young professionals, many of them working at high-technology companies, who may be too busy, or too unsure of their next move, to put down permanent roots.
Rental housing is also attracting older people, former homeowners who have raised their families and sold their houses and who want someone else to attend to all the details, even those as minute as fixing a leaking faucet in the bathroom.
Developers say that these two groups also don't want to be locked into homeownership at a time when house prices are high and could turn downward if the economy weakens.
"Rentals offer a very flexible lifestyle choice," said Joseph S. Torg, the development partner in the Northeast division of Trammell Crow's MidAtlantic/Northeast Group, which has offices in Fairfield, Conn. The MidAtlantic side of the partnership has its headquarters in Rockville, Md. Each of the five groups that constitute Trammell Crow Residential, which has its headquarters in Atlanta, is an independently owned partnership.
"There are plenty of people who can afford to purchase a house but choose not to," Mr. Torg said. "Many people now feel they don't want equity tied up in a house because they can get much better returns on the stock market."
The tenant mix in South Yaphank, he said, is also expected to include couples, with or without children, who have not yet saved up enough money to buy a house in today's costly market.
The biggest difficulty on Long Island, developers say, is not in finding tenants, but in finding land. Preapproved sites like the 117 acres that Trammell Crow bought from Horseblock Associates, an investor group, "are very hard to find," said Paul K. Gruber, the president of PKG Associates of Woodbury, the broker for the $17 million deal.
The property's apartment zoning dates back to the mid-1980's and might not be granted today. Felix Grucci Jr., the Brookhaven town supervisor, has gone on record several times saying he opposed any housing on the site because the surrounding area is largely industrial.
But Mr. Torg said the location was a very convenient one. The State University of New York at Stony Brook, the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, county offices in Riverhead and large employers like Computer Associates International in Islandia and Symbol Technologies in Holtsville are all close by.
To attract the different groups of renters, Alexan Brookhaven, designed by the Lessard Architectural Group of Vienna, Va., will have a variety of layouts. The choices include one- and two-bedroom flats in two-story town-house-style buildings; two- and three-bedroom two-story town houses, some with the master bedroom on the ground floor to accommodate older couples who do not want to climb stairs, and some ranch-style units for tenants who want all the living space on one level without having anyone above them. Each of the units will have direct access to a one-car garage.
Rents will range from $850 for an 825-square-foot one-bedroom flat to $1,400 for a three-bedroom, 1,250-square-foot town house. The two-bedroom, 1,150-square-foot flat will rent for $1,200 a month, and the three-bedroom 1,300-square-foot ranch-style unit will rent for $1,400. Rents will not include heat or utilities. Leasing for the first phase of 549 apartments is expected to begin at the the end of the year, with the first apartments to be ready for occupancy early in 2001. When complexed, the complex will have as many as four pools, tennis courts and an 8,000-square-foot clubhouse.
Trammell Crow Residential, which was founded in 1978, is the second national builder to build luxury rentals on Long Island.
THE other is AvalonBay Communities, a real estate investment trust traded on the New York Stock Exchange. It started out as the Trammell Crow Mid Atlantic/Northeast Group until it went public in 1995 as Avalon. Avalon took the AvalonBay name after a merger in 1998 with a West Coast apartment builder called Bay Communities. A new Trammell Crow Mid Atlantic/Northeast Group was set up in 1997.
Until 1997, when Avalon opened a 312-unit rental complex in Smithtown called Avalon Commons, the rental stock in Suffolk, where most of the new rental complexes are springing up, consisted largely of brick garden apartments built after World War II.
Companies like Trammell Crow were building luxury rentals in the Southeast and Southwest long before the idea was brought to the Northeast, said Gary Steinfield, AvalonBay's vice president for development for the New Jersey and Long Island regions. "The Northeast was a little slower in understanding that people are willing to pay for a better-quality, better-amenitized apartment community," he said.
At Avalon Commons, the apartments are in two-story town-house-style buildings with clapboard exteriors. They range in size from an 862-square-foot one-bedroom to a 1,527-square-foot two-bedroom with a loft. Some of the apartments have two bathrooms, and some have fireplaces. Rents range from $1,499 to $1,949. The complex has a clubhouse, a fitness and business center, a pool and an indoor half court for basketball. Prices do not include heat or utilities.
Avalon now owns and operates four complexes on Long Island with a total of 915 apartments. In addition to Avalon Commons in Smithtown, two are in Melville and one is in Long Beach. The most recent to come on the market, the 340-unit Avalon Court North in Melville, opened in April and is already fully occupied, Mr. Steinfield said. Rents there range from $1,600 for a 740-square-foot one-bedroom to $2,299 for a 1,390-square-foot three-bedroom. Seventy-five percent of the apartments have direct access to their own garages. In addition to the pool, tennis court, clubhouse and fitness center that have become standard for these complexes, Avalon Court North also has a putting green and a jogging trail.
Local developers are also aggressively entering the luxury rental market. Fairfield Properties of Commack had been buying and upgrading older apartment complexes for 27 years, amassing a portfolio of 40 rental properties with a total of 4,000 apartments. It has now begun building new apartment complexes, with almost 300 units either completed or under construction and another 411 in the planning stages.
Its first new project, the 169-unit Fairfield Hills in Farmingville, opened last summer. Like the AvalonBay projects and the Trammell Crow development, it offers a choice of apartments to suit different groups of renters. Sizes range from a 1,207-square-foot one-bedroom flat renting for $1,485 to a 1,575-square-foot three-bedroom two-story town house renting for $1,835. There is a 7,000-square-foot clubhouse with a fitness and business center, a pool, a playground and courts for tennis, volleyball and basketball. The complex is fully rented and has a waiting list.
Last month, Fairfield began leasing its newest project, Setauket Gables, and it took deposits on 37 of the 64 apartments on opening day, said Mark A. Broxmeyer, one of the principals in Fairfield. The Setauket development has five floor plans; a 1,150-square-foot one-bedroom with a loft rents for $1,750, a 1,195-square-foot two-bedroom for $2,000 and a 1,150-square-foot three-bedroom for $2,200. Each apartment has direct access to a private garage. Of the 64 apartments, 28 are town houses, and a third of the apartments have fireplaces. There is a clubhouse with a fitness and business center, a pool and an electronic gatehouse.
"Many of our tenants have combined incomes of $150,000 or more," Mr. Broxmeyer said. "They have chosen to rent because they don't want to worry about maintenance. They're retired, or they work long hours, and they just want to turn the key in the door and be done."
Fairfield's third project, which has not yet been named, is under construction in the Village of Port Jefferson. It will have 66 apartments. Another complex with 202 apartments will start construction this summer across the street from Fairfield Hills, and yet another, for people 55 and over, is planned for Port Jefferson.
Ross C. Cassata of Babylon, who with a partner, Glenn D. Feldman, is building a 402-apartment rental complex in Holtsville called Victorian Gardens, said the 300 apartments completed there so far are all rented. Rents range from $1,250 for a 1,000-square-foot one-bedroom to $1,450 for a 1,200-square-foot two-bedroom. Mr. Cassata said he has three more projects with a total of 800 apartments in the planning stages. All three will be for people 55 and over.
Demand for these rentals is so strong, Mr. Cassata said, that "we paint our apartments in the morning, and by afternoon people are already moving in."

HEADLINE: Apartments, Finally, for Downtown Los Angeles

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
AN upscale rental project that will eventually fill three city blocks and have 658 apartments is rising at the edge of the central business district here, where no market-rate housing has been built for nearly a decade.
The $100 million development, known as the Medici, is one of a number of recent projects in downtown Los Angeles that have brought -- or will bring -- a new sports arena, a new museum, a new concert hall, a new cathedral and new housing to a business district that formerly had little but high-rise office buildings and hotels. 
 The first phase of 92 apartments is expected to be completed in July, and all have been leased, with the exception of two penthouses, said Geoff Palmer, the Medici's developer and the president of G. H. Palmer Associates of Los Angeles.
As an entirely private development with no public subsidies, the Medici is an anomaly in an area where nearly all housing in recent years has been subsidized, low-income apartments.
"It's a major turning point to have a private developer take the initiative to build housing downtown on his own," said Donald R. Spivack, the deputy administrator of the Los Angeles Community Redevelopment Agency, the leading builder of low-income housing downtown.
Mr. Palmer said, "I'm ahead of the curve," but he added that his project was a response to a demonstrable demand. Downtown has a vacancy rate of only 2 percent, he said, and rents are rising sharply.
The Medici project is currently under construction immediately west of the Harbor Freeway, an elevated 10-lane road that serves as the unofficial western boundary of the central business district.
The project's only neighbors are office buildings and busy streets, although two or three restaurants are within 100 yards of the project, and the Staples Center sports arena is within easy walking distance.
Mr. Palmer said his rents would be about 15 percent higher than those of other market-rate apartments downtown. In the first phase, rents will range from $1,280 for a 641-square-foot one-bedroom to $2,608 for a 1,208-square-foot two-bedroom, two-bath apartment. A small number of penthouses will also be available; $8,200 a month will rent the largest, with 2,200 square feet.
Mr. Palmer, who developed an apartment building in downtown Los Angeles in the 1980's but has spent much of his career putting up rental apartments in the suburbs,said that downtown living has found a new cachet in Los Angeles, and that, along with a growing frustration over traffic congestion, helped him sell his project.
LOCATION was the overriding concern of Loren Stassart, one of first tenants to reserve an apartment at the Medici.
"I figured I was driving 19 hours a week," said Mr. Stassart, who owns a produce company and drives 65 miles from Riverside County to his company on the southern edge of downtown. "I had to buy a new truck every two years just to go back and forth to L.A."
Mr. Stassart said he was looking for "a nice, clean place that was well secured." He is pleased with the view from his fourth-floor apartment and is looking forward to moving in. "There are city lights at night," he said. "It's almost like coming home to a resort."
Marketing for the Medici makes note of the Italian marble vanities in the bathrooms, the black granite counter tops and maple cabinets in the kitchens, the solid oak front doors, the nine-foot ceilings and the double-paned windows. The complex also has an outdoor pool with a 24-foot waterfall and a rubberized running track and a golf driving range, both in a one-acre private park. About 17,000 square feet will be devoted to retail space, with a coffee bar, a juice bar and a convenience store.
The Medici's second phase, with 133 apartments, including some studios, is scheduled to open in August, and the third and final phase is to open next year.
The new apartments are part of a larger change in the development patterns downtown. In the 1970's and 80's, the city's redevelopment agency aggressively promoted office development, in the attempt to make downtown into a traditional city center. That created a forest of high-rise office buildings on Bunker Hill and in the financial district a few blocks west of City Hall.
Critics contended that the enormous public investment in downtown was inappropriate for a nontraditional city like Los Angeles, which has many business centers. By one estimate, the city and state governments have spent $2 billion on downtown in the last two decades, $1 billion of that from the redevelopment agency alone. Office development boomed during the economically confident early and mid-1980's, and between 1979 and 1992, developers built nearly 20 million square feet of office space downtown.
The recession of the early 1990's halted the construction of speculative office space, and vacancy rates remained in the 20 percent range for much of the decade.
In recent years, developers have concentrated on entertainment and cultural projects, not office buildings. Two recent projects -- the Medici and a set of six motion-picture sound stages completed last year -- were both built on sites originally zoned for high-rise office buildings.
The Japanese-American History Museum in the Little Tokyo District on the east end of downtown has expanded. Last month, the Southern California Institute of Architecture, a private professional school, announced that it would relocate from Santa Monica to a building on the east end of downtown. And the long-delayed Walt Disney Concert Hall, designed by Frank O. Gehry, resumed construction in December after a five-year fund drive.
THE new Roman Catholic Cathedral of Los Angeles is rising at the north end of downtown, between the Los Angeles Music Center and the Hollywood Freeway.
The east end of downtown has a growing number of artists' lofts in aging warehouses. Loft conversions are continuing on Fourth Street in the historic district just east of City Hall; the Bank District development, by Gilmore Associates of Los Angeles, will have 250 rental lofts.
But the venture that will possibly have the biggest impact on downtown is the $350 million Staples Center, a basketball and hockey arena that doubles as a concert hall. It was completed last October.
Mr. Spivack, the redevelopment official, credited the popularity of Staples Center with reviving interest in downtown itself. "Staples is bringing people into downtown on evenings and weekends who otherwise might not have come," he said. "A lot of people are pleasantly surprised when they come down here that downtown is a fairly attractive place to be."
Mr. Palmer, the Medici developer, said that the construction of the sports arena was "an added consideration" in his own decision to build upscale housing nearby. "I knew that with Staples Center coming, there would be an exodus back to the city," he said. "I knew it would generate a lot of activity, just as the stadiums in Denver and Baltimore did."
The further revival of downtown will depend on building a base of full-time middle-class residents, Mr. Palmer said. So far the area has only a few thousand residents, although about 375,000 people commute into downtown daily.
"You can't get downtown moving again just with low-income housing," Mr. Palmer said. "You need to bring in middle-class, working people, and that is what we are doing. A lot of professional people work downtown in beautiful buildings with glass and marble, and they are used to a certain level of quality. I could not see them coming home to Formica and linoleum."

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
Building for High-Tech Tenants in the Meadowlands

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
HOPING to capitalize on the expansion of technology companies, a small group of developers in the Hackensack Meadowlands are constructing buildings or converting warehouses for new-economy tenants.
For decades low-slung warehouses, mostly manufacturers' distribution centers, have dominated the Meadlowlands, a 32-square-mile region that stretches through 14 communities in Bergen and Hudson Counties. But with dot-com companies and Internet service providers pushing into areas like the garment district in Manhattan and the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City, the Meadowlands offers an alternative, commercial brokers said. The draws are its proximity to transportation, access to fiber optics and lower rents. 
 "The shift is real," said Richard Fritzsky, the president of the Meadowlands Chamber of Commerce.
Frank Lopriore, a managing director in the Saddle Brook office of Insignia/ESG, the national commercial brokerage company, said, "The issue is that there is a demand but no inventory."
Some developers, like Penhorn Construction of Secaucus, are responding by putting up high-tech flex buildings, as they are called, because they can be used for offices or for distribution or assembly operations. The company recently completed and leased two buildings totaling 100,000 square feet on Penhorn Avenue in Secaucus, drawing e-commerce companies as tenants. Now it is advancing plans for two more buildings.
And on Meadowlands Parkway at Castle Road in Secaucus, M. Rappaport Real Estate of Englewood Cliffs recently completed leasing a 145,000-square-foot building. It had rebuilt 55,000 square feet of office space there and turned the remaining 90,000 square feet of retail space into office space for high-tech tenants. The company is selling 10 acres nearby, also on Meadowlands Parkway, to Hudson Development L.L.C. of Brooklyn, which is planning a high-tech building as big as 225,000 square feet to appeal to similar tenants.
Meanwhile, Whitehall Industrial Properties of Edison bought a 170,000-square-foot industrial building in Carlstadt last month and plans to reconfigure it into smaller spaces for technology companies. Young Woo & Associates of Manhattan is buying a 200,000-square-foot warehouse, also in Carlstadt, and plans to turn it into a telecommunications center, a so-called "telco hotel," with a number of technology and telecommunications tenants under one roof.
Such businesses, including companies that provide Internet data centers, which manage Internet sites for businesses, are scouring the Meadowlands for space. Last month, Gift Certificate.com of Manhattan leased a 100,000-square-foot warehouse in Carlstadt and plans to transform it into an order-fulfillment center. In February, Webvan Inc., an Internet grocer, leased a 348,885-square-foot warehouse in North Bergen from Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus, among the largest property owners in the Meadowlands. It plans to use the warehouse as a distribution center.
Tenants requiring over 500,000 square feet of space are still in the market, said Jonathan S. Meisel, an associate director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the national brokerage company. "We see the Meadowlands as the next hotbed of activity for Web-centric businesses," he said.
From 1994 to 1999 the number of high-tech jobs, including telecommunications and computer software development and related services, grew in New Jersey by 59,000 to 295,0000 jobs, according to state figures. A report released last month by Nasdaq and the American Electronics Association ranked New Jersey seventh in the nation in the number of such jobs.
While the presence of high-tech operations in the Meadowlands is growing, such companies are not completely new to the area. Mr. Fritzsky of the Chamber of Commerce said that over a decade ago Ernst & Young and Salomon Smith Barney set up data centers in the Meadowlands.
COMDISCO, an international technology management company based in Rosemont, Ill., is consolidating four operations in the region into a 302,000-square-foot building under way on Central Boulevard in Carlstadt. Next door, Chase Manhattan Bank is developing a 176,000 square-foot check-processing operation
Brokers say the presence of such tenants is one of the reasons the Meadowlands will appeal to high-tech companies. In addition, it is close to Newark and Teterboro airports and to Manhattan, where many clients have offices, Mr. Lopriore of Insignia/ESG said. And, he added, the tight commercial market in Manhattan is pushing companies to seek space elsewhere, and one of those places is the Meadowlands.
The Meadowlands will also be more accessible once transportation improvements are made. Construction is under way on the $448 million Secaucus Transfer rail station, which will link several rail lines to provide direct train service to Manhattan from Bergen and Passaic Counties. The project, which will allow employees to commute more easily from New York City, is to be completed by 2002.
The vacancy rate in the 72-million-square-foot Meadowlands industrial market is 3.25 percent, Mr. Lopriore said. That translates to 2.3 million square feet, much of it in obsolete industrial buildings, he said, adding that such buildings can be converted to suit the needs of technology companies. The average annual asking rents in the region are $6.50 a square foot, he said, compared with asking rents in Manhattan of $30 to $40 a square foot.
That price difference makes the Meadowlands "a competitive alternative," said Mr. Meisel of Cushman & Wakefield. The area also has access multiple sources of electric power and a fiber-optic network, he added.
Those factors encouraged Gift Certificate.com to lease the Carlstadt building at 190 Jony Drive, said Alan J. Desino, a senior managing director in the Manhattan office of Insignia/ESG, who represented the company. It had looked at space in Manhattan, he said, but in terms of price and access to labor, the Meadowlands was more favorable. He said the company would occupy 77,000 square feet initially and would reconfigure it as an order-fulfillment center.
To meet this sort of demand by high-tech tenants, Hari Bhasin, the president of Penhorn Construction, was prompted to to develop two high-tech buildings in Secaucus. The $8 million buildings at 501 and 601 Penhorn Avenue contain 100,000 square feet, 70,000 square feet at 501 and 30,000 at 601. Each building is divided into blocks of 5,000 to 20,000 square feet to draw start-up as well as expanding companies needing office and distribution space. The project was completely leased even before it was finished in March, he said. Annual rents average $8 a square foot triple net, meaning that tenants pay taxes, common-area charges and utilities.
One tenant is Vitamin Shop.com, part of Vitamin Shop Industries of North Bergen, which took 20,000 square feet at 501 Penhorn. "As our Internet business grows, we need to expand our distribution capability," said Steven Linn, the director of operations. The building has the telecommunications capacity, including high-speed Internet connections, that the company will eventually tap for its online business, he said.
Mr. Bhasin said he was seeking approvals to develop two additional buildings on 12 adjacent acres, which he would lease at slightly higher rents. Construction of those buildings, totaling 175,000 square feet, is to start this fall. They are expected to be completed in 12 months at a cost of $14 million, he said.
Smaller companies are the tenants that Hudson Development expects to draw to Castle Industrial Park, the high-tech building with a maximum of 225,000 square feet the company plans to build on the 10 acres it is buying in Secaucus. "The activity in Manhattan feeds Secaucus, and we are seeing an overflow," said Daniel P. Gleich, a principal in Hudson Development. His company plans to divide the $12.5 million building into blocks of 7,500 square feet.
Mr. Gleich said he expected to start construction this summer; the building is to be completed next year. In Carlstadt, Whitehall Industrial Properties L.L.C. plans to carve the 170,000-square-foot warehouse it bought at 401 Washington Avenue into 50,000- to 60,000-square-foot spaces. "Traditional companies are changing to e-commerce and doing more business over the Internet, but they still need production and distribution space to get their products out," said Michael Nachamkin, the president of Whitehall, an affiliate of Goldman, Sachs.
The Whitehall Street Real Estate Fund committed $75 million to the company, which was formed last November to acquire, develop and redevelop industrial properties in the Northeast. The Carlstadt project, valued at over $5 million, is the company's first in New Jersey.
Mr. Nachamkin said he expected to start work in June on the exterior of the building, which the seller still occupies. Annual rents are expected to be $7 to $10 a square foot, triple net.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

HEADLINE: Battle Lines Drawn on New Zoning Plan

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
BY a margin of almost 2 to 1, the 26 speakers at the City Planning Commission hearing last month offered their support for a zoning proposal that would reshape development, neighborhood character and architectural innovation in every corner of New York.
But that consensus in favor of the plan may have been misleading. Several fathoms below the level of public review, a battle is being fought over the proposal, called the Unified Bulk Program, which is to go to the City Council later this year. Though no one predicts that the measure is headed toward defeat, it faces high hurdles. The debate over key aspects of the rezoning package is believed to be going on within the Giuliani administration itself. 
 Asked on Thursday whether the Unified Bulk Program had the unqualified support of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Deputy Mayor Anthony P. Coles replied simply, "The mayor has an open mind."
As proposed by Joseph B. Rose, the chairman of the City Planning Commission and the director of the City Planning Department, the Unified Bulk Program would be the most thorough revision to zoning rules since they were entirely rewritten 40 years ago. These are some of the provisions of the program:
*It would impose height limits for the first time in neighborhoods citywide.
*It would effectively restrict transfer of development rights.
*It would eliminate bonuses for plazas at new apartment towers.
*It would create a review panel that could recommend waiving restrictions in the interest of better design.
*And it would eliminate complex zoning formulas that are understood only by a few technicians.
Leaders of the real estate industry do not like the proposal and are making their displeasure known through public testimony and private communiques to politicians. They have a formidable ally in nonprofit institutions that fear new limits on their ability to transfer development rights, known as air rights, or to build what the law calls "community facilities": schools, hospitals, medical offices, nursing homes and houses of worship. The Greater New York Hospital Association has spoken out against the rezoning, and New York Presbyterian Hospital has raised concerns about a project it plans on West 165th Street. The Archdiocese of New York is in talks with city planners but will wait to comment until the matter comes before the City Council, a spokesman said.
On the other hand, community planning boards, professional organizations like the American Institute of Architects and American Planning Association, and civic groups like the Municipal Art Society, Citizens Union and Civitas generally support the program, with qualifications. They see it as a rare opportunity to clear out a regulatory thicket that confounds the public and benefits only skilled manipulators.
Though the proposal is often portrayed as a weapon against out-of-scale projects like the 856-foot Trump World Tower at First Avenue and 47th Street (the new height cap on that site would be 495 feet), the height limits would also be felt in medium-density districts, including residential zones known as R6, R7 and R8 that are mapped broadly through Brooklyn and the Bronx, the Lower East Side and Harlem, and the M1-5 manufacturing districts found in Lower Manhattan and elsewhere.
Even as developers chafe at the proposed height limits of 55 to 140 feet in medium-density districts, neighborhood leaders are asking planners to draw the limits lower yet, to curb the liberally regulated community facilities and to tune zoning more closely to the prevailing physical context.
All of which goes to a broader issue: Is the goal of a municipal land-use regimen to preserve the context of older neighborhoods or to provide enough flexibility that neighborhoods can change, and new neighborhoods can emerge, as economic and social trends dictate?
Mr. Rose believes it is possible to do both, to ensure that a neighborhood's prevailing scale is not violated without straitjacketing design and development. Critics of his proposal believe it will stymie construction in areas that could most benefit from an infusion of new housing and usurp the architect's role, forcing the production of predictable, unwieldy building types.
Reacting to comments and suggestions, city planners have proposed 76 possible modifications. In response, Mitchell J. Silver, the president of the New York chapter of the American Planning Association, told the commission at its May 23 hearing that "on the whole, we're very enthusiastic about the direction of this proposal."
But the modifications do not go nearly far enough to persuade the Real Estate Board of New York to drop its blanket opposition.
"This is still a totally objectionable proposal," Steven Spinola, the president of the Real Estate Board, said last week.
Before the proposal is sent to the Council, it is likely to undergo further overhaul.
Mayor Giuliani has made no public comment on the proposal, and a spokesman said on Wednesday that he would have none at this time. (In contrast, the mayor personally announced a rezoning of the theater district in December 1997 from the stage of the Lyceum Theater. It was adopted by the Council eight months later.)
It may be that Mr. Giuliani is not ready to place his imprimatur on a proposal that is still very much in flux. As Mr. Coles said, "City Planning is going through a process where it's listening to different constituencies." Or as opponents of the proposal hope, the mayor may seek to distance himself from the undertaking.
AS to the proposal's prospects before the City Council, Speaker Peter F. Vallone was noncommittal. "If this improves the quality of life for the people of the City of New York," he said on Wednesday, "it will be very favorably reviewed.
"If not, forget about it."
Mr. Rose has embarked on a difficult political maneuver, since the proposal enjoys qualified support from some quarters but faces implacable antagonism from others, all of this against a backdrop of relative public indifference.
It is a paradox of land-use issues that the broader they are, the less popular attention they claim. The landmarking of a single building or the rezoning of several blocks might draw hundreds of people to City Hall, since the impact is so evident. But the rezoning of an entire city is a far more abstract undertaking. And the Unified Bulk Program is a long and complicated document that defies easy categorization.
"I see in place dynamics that could result in defeat as well as success," said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens, who heads the zoning subcommittee. "There is strong support for this though, and I don't think that general principle should be trivialized in any way, shape or form. This is an aggressive, strong approach to the zoning text, and Joe does deserve credit for that."
Height limits are a key hurdle, according to Mitchell L. Moss, the director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University, as is the opposition of hospitals. "Once landowners outside Manhattan are concerned about height limits," he said, "the consensus becomes more fragile."
Mr. Spinola said the rules would foreclose the construction in medium-density R6, R7 and R8 zones of buildings ranging from 180 to 240 feet, or about 18 to 24 stories.
"The city's future is going to be in neighborhoods that are emerging or neighborhoods we haven't even thought about," he said. "To propose height limits of 55 or 75 or 140 feet just is counter to what New York City is all about."
But Mr. Rose said that on normal sites in medium-density districts, "there isn't that great a disparity between what is currently permitted and what the Unified Bulk Program would allow."
The New York State Association for Affordable Housing, an organization of for-profit builders, has appealed directly to Deputy Mayor Coles, saying in a letter dated May 25 that the Unified Bulk Program "will impede new housing construction, thwart neighborhood revitalization and undermine the economic resurgence initiated by this administration."
Donald Capoccia, the founder and vice president of the builders' association and a principal in BFC Partners, said the rezoning would penalize those who had taken risks investing in areas like Upper Manhattan and the Lower East Side against the hope that there would one day be a market strong enough to attract large-scale, unsubsidized, private development.
"Very big players are not interested in getting involved in small six-story and eight-story endeavors," he said. "If they can't build big buildings, it just isn't worth their while. When you find neighborhoods reaching a critical mass where the next logical step is higher density, the Unified Bulk Program stops this from happening."
But one person's critical mass is another's critical injury. In Kew Gardens, Queens, the relief promised from oversized development cannot come quickly enough, said Sylvia Hack, the chairwoman of Community Board 9, which includes Woodhaven, Richmond Hill and South Ozone Park.
"We care desperately in Queens about the height of buildings," she said. "There are tremendous monstrosities sitting on tiny lots that overwhelm the buildings around them." She said current controls are too complicated and too open to interpretation.
"Unified Bulk sets a definite height," Ms. Hack said. "It says, 'This building shall be 21 feet high.' You don't have to figure it out. You know where the top of the floor is supposed to be. We're so pleased that there is a height regulation."
The Unified Bulk Program would also change the rules governing building sites that straddle more than one zoning district, a perennially vexatious land-use issue. Ms. Hack praised the proposal for limiting the application of medium-density R7 controls on adjacent low-density R2 lots. "That's a tremendous protection," she said. "The sooner this gets passed, the better for us."
Another issue stirring the neighbors in medium-density zones involves community facilities, which can in some districts produce a structure with almost twice as much floor area as a residential buildings on the same site.
Height limits directly affect institutions that need higher-than-normal floors for auditoriums, operating rooms, gymnasiums and the like. Mr. Rose has said that limits placed on community facilities, "especially in a campus-type environment, may warrant greater latitude."
At the same time, neighbors worry about the potential disruption caused by such institutions. "You buy a house next door to another family and suddenly you're living next door to 200 people," Ms. Hack said.
Councilwoman June M. Eisland of the Bronx, who heads the Land Use Committee, said the failure of the proposal to tackle the community-facility issue in greater detail was "one of the main sticking points."
Another element of the plan that has drawn skeptical reaction is the proposed design review panel, made up of seven members appointed by the planning director who would have "knowledge and experience in the areas of architecture and urban design," in the language of the zoning amendment. This group could recommend waiving height limits, lot coverage requirements and setback rules for a building that "exhibits superior design quality."
Bruce S. Fowle, co-chairman of the zoning task force for the New York chapter of the American Institute of Architects, told the commission on May 23 that the chapter had "serious questions whether or not the proposed panel will encourage design excellence on a meaningful scale." Allowing that it might provide a greater opportunity for innovative design in unique situations, he urged city planners to adopt the program on a five-year test basis.
It is possible, of course, that the whole idea of a design review panel could be withdrawn, although city planners might still try to devise a process under which aesthetic quality could be used as a criterion to allow the development of buildings that do not conform to standard zoning rules.
Another serious point of contention is grandfathering; that is, just where will the cutoff be set between projects governed by the old and new zoning? Mr. Rose has said that projects under construction would be unaffected. But what about a project that has not begun to dig foundations but has all of its building permits in place? Or a project that has just obtained its financing? Drawing this line will be a challenge.
One significant obstacle seems to have been cleared. In January, city planners proposed a requirement that a tower occupy at least 33 percent of the merged zoning lot from which it draws air rights. This was intended to prevent the harvesting of air rights up and down a block and piling them on a single building site, as was done at Trump World Tower, which occupies only 13 percent of the merged zoning lot.
Developers were understandably upset about this provision, but they were not alone in criticizing it. In April, the A.I.A. expressed concern that the result would be "bulkier, poorly proportioned" buildings that "create darkness for more hours of the day; provide long, dark interior corridors and like many of the least desirable developments in the last several decades, will be characterless and flat-topped."
Since then, planners have proposed adjusting the minimum to 25 percent. "It creates greater flexibility," Mr. Rose said. "That's the essence of the proposal: to come up with a set of rules that are clear; that allow for as-of-right, economically viable development; that have some relationship to neighborhood scale; and that end the elaborate series of zoning manipulation, loopholes and inconsistency."
THE readjustment of the tower coverage provision was endorsed by the A.I.A. and the Municipal Art Society, which said it would "allow the as-of-right construction of slimmer towers that allow more light and air to reach the street." Even Mr. Spinola of the Real Estate Board said it was a "meaningful change."
But he also said there had been no progress in resolving the board's objection to height limits in the medium-density R6, R7, R8 and M1-5 districts and the high-density M1-6 manufacturing district that is found around the Hudson Square area in Lower Manhattan.
"There's little reason to believe that some kind of compromise is going to be worked out," Mr. Spinola said. "That's not to say that one can't be worked out."
"I don't believe in taking on fights that are impossible to win," he said, "so I believe there's a chance that this process will lead to its not being enacted. But on the other hand, it's probably an uphill battle."
That battle is waged on many fronts. According to records compiled by the New York City Campaign Finance Board, Mr. Vallone, a potential mayoral candidate, has received $72,125 from 25 members of the board of governors of the Real Estate Board since 1999. Eight of these contributors, including Bernard H. Mendik, the chairman of the Real Estate Board, gave $4,500, the maximum permitted for a citywide contest under the public financing law.
Mr. Spinola said contributions do not "buy us anything other than the ability to have a direct conversation and make our point."
And Mr. Vallone dismissed the notion that any contribution -- much less such small contributions -- could affect a vote. "No respectable elected official is going to be influenced solely by campaign contributions," he said. Moreover, he added, he hears "a lot of conflicting real estate opinions."

Chart: "Zoning Change as Work in Progress"
REZONING AS FIRST PROPOSED
To limit the use of development rights, the Unified Bulk Program originally required that a new apartment tower occupty at least 33 percent of the merged zoning lot used to calculate its floor area. The example shows a 10,000-square-foot corner site that makes use of development rights - know as air rights - from five adjacent properties, creating an overall zoning lot of 19,000 square feet. A tower that covers 33 percent of that merged lot could rise 25 stories, with 173,000 square feet of floor area. This virtually mandates a bulky building type that covers most of the corner site.
 
REZONING AS MODIFIED
In response to objections from the real estate industry and organizations like the American Insititute of Architects, planners are considering a requirement that a tower cover 25 percent of the overall zoning lot. In this example, that would permit the addition of a sixth property to the assemblage, creating a 20,000-square-foot zoning lot. A tower that covers 25 percent of that merged lot could rise 32 stories and still not exceed the 360-foot height limit for the area, with 181,000 square feet of floor area. The benefit for a slight increase in floor area is much greater flexibility in design.
(Source: Zoning Task Force of the American Institute of Architects New York Chapter)

(In fact, they do not even apply to the mid-Manhattan and Lower Manhattan zoning districts.) They would also cover medium-density zones like the R6, R7 and R8 residential districts and M1-5 manufacturing districts, part of the citywide patchwork shown in this map. (pg. 1)

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY;
Americans Aren't in the Market for Freedom

BYLINE: By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
EVERYWHERE you turn nowadays, somebody is trying to sell you something. And why not? The American economy is churning out unprecedented prosperity, and consumers (the creatures formerly known as "people") are snapping up vacation houses, fancy cars and other nifty appurtenances of the good life.
Folks are entitled to enjoy their earnings, after all. And why should anyone attend social critics who, from their tasteful vacation houses in Amagansett, berate the masses for buying his-and-hers Barcaloungers? 
 Unfortunately, the one thing nobody is insisting you rush out and buy is freedom. Ever hear of it? I don't mean freedom of speech or religion, which we enjoy in spades. I mean the freedom to do what you want -- including, if necessary, telling your boss to drop dead. For non-lottery winners, it's the kind of freedom that comes of thrift, and maybe also self-knowledge.
What I'm suggesting, in other words, is to forget that big new professional-quality range or $40,000 sport utility vehicle and buy yourself some freedom; you really can, because it's a commodity just like any other.
In a two-earner household, for instance, maybe one of you can quit and go back to school, or even see the kids once in awhile. Save enough and perhaps live a little more modestly, and you might be able to ditch that lucrative but unworthy gig you've been slaving at all these years and do something you believe in -- teach school, start a business, move to the country, join the Elks. Read a book, for Pete's sake.
The current boom comes at a steep price. Cell phones, pagers, e-mail and other technological tethers keep us on our toes at all hours. Those who hand out Internet freebies insist that you pay with your privacy. Even the dot-com elite find themselves bound by so-called golden handcuffs: They can't leave until their options vest, and now that investors are showing signs of coming to their senses about Internet valuations, it may all be for naught anyway.
At a time when more people than ever have the opportunity to do what they want in life, many lack the imagination to do anything but accumulate possessions. Freedom is losing market share to stuff.
Why? One possibility is that freedom has a marketing problem. All the other stuff is hawked day and night in commercials suggesting that a product will somehow make you more free rather than less. Yet freedom itself goes unpromoted.
This woeful lack of advertising for America's very best product means relatively few people know about it, at least judging by consumer behavior. Easy credit and record-high personal indebtedness mean that, despite rising affluence, lots of people still owe their souls to what amounts to the company store. "Money is coined liberty," Dostoyevski rightly observed long ago.
People who make pronouncements like that are usually well-fixed in the things department; the poor regrettably don't have the option of blithely giving up some of their income to change their lives. Besides, Americans really like all the stuff they buy, even deriving a sense of identity from it. Yet many of us are so rich that we need not give up much material well-being to become a whole lot freer to do what we want to do.
Perhaps Americans aren't in the market for more freedom because they already enjoy an extraordinary degree of personal liberty, by global and historical standards. It's odd that we aren't any happier, though. Maybe we have too much of some kinds of freedom and too little of others.
Recognizing that money buys freedom (if not love) might change the way you look at all you make and spend. If you're smart, it will induce you to save more. It might also challenge you to think about what you're doing with your life. Then again, money has always heavily taxed the imagination. In this day of unbacked currency and electronic balances, the whole concept requires a leap of collective faith.
Maybe that's the reason there's so little call for more material freedom in this country. More than anything else you buy, freedom demands that you do something with it. It's not something to tuck away in the garage or unload a few years later on ebay. When someone asks, "Free to do what?" the answer doesn't always come easily. But when you're lucky enough to live in a time and place like this one, perhaps that's your real job -- not making the money, but figuring out what you ought to achieve with it.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 3; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 831 words

HEADLINE: COPING;
Doing God's Work Where Hope Is Rare

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
HOW do you find God in a place of faded glory, far from home? The question haunts Amira Hernandez. Ms. Hernandez, who recently graduated from college, works in Bedford Park, the Bronx, near the part of the Grand Concourse that is no longer grand, with its drug-dealing side streets and ground-down life stories.
Ms. Hernandez, 23, came to New York last summer from Spartanburg, S.C., to volunteer with a nonprofit group called Part of the Solution, which provides poor people with food, housing and legal services. Ms. Hernandez's spiritual faith made her want to change the world, and her idealism has not faded. But her search for God in the Bronx has been far harder than she ever imagined. 
 "Something's out of sync when you've got so many women and children and men being abused and neglected in some way in a world that should be able to feed everyone," she said, explaining her mission. "I didn't want to participate in the injustice. "
But justice can be a mighty big concept to wrestle down to human size and parcel out. Ms. Hernandez would organize meetings so people could deal with the bad things in their lives, like dilapidated housing, but often they would not show up. Sometimes it was because of a long wait at a clinic to treat a sick baby. Sometimes it was because of too many drinks the night before.
Ms. Hernandez, a thin woman with a curtain of bright red hair, also felt the heartbreak of seeing suffering up close, day in and day out. Homelessness. Unemployment. Addiction.
"You come in with these great, idealistic intentions," she said. "Grass roots all the way. Work from the bottom up. On a practical level, sometimes it's hard to get everybody to go to a meeting they're supposed to go to."
"It's a challenge to remain respectful and at the same time try to demonstrate the importance of follow-through," Ms. Hernandez said. "There are days that I am so frustrated, I'm not convinced this is the level on which I'm supposed to be working. The flight response is huge."
"I am angry not just about the disproportion of wealth but also the simplicity of what people ask for," she said. "Some days, all they want is someone to talk to."
Ms. Hernandez is part of an effort called the Jesuit Volunteer Corps, a Roman Catholic organization that sends recent college graduates to volunteer in poor communities. They work in exchange for food, board and a small stipend. In New York City, the volunteers are in every borough, working at organizations like New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition and the Urban Justice Center. They are teachers, counselors and health workers, among other vocations.
Like the other volunteers, Ms. Hernandez was recruited from college. She is a 1999 graduate of Sweet Briar College, which has a 3,600-acre campus in Sweet Briar, Va. She was not especially keen on coming to New York, she said, but was attracted to Part of the Solution because it offered so many services and seemed so engaged with the community. She was heartened when she found that many people in the neighborhood were eager to share their lives with her.
Many of the smells and sounds of the neighborhood were familiar, Ms. Hernandez said, from the trips she took to Colombia with her father, a college professor who is a native of that country. She speaks Spanish.
"I guess the greatest surprise has been how much of their lives they want to share with you," she said. "In detail many of us out of fear of embarrassment or judgment would not divulge to anyone. The honesty is beautiful and humbling. There's not a lot of surface you have to go through to get to the real person. That's the greatest gift."
Ms. Hernandez lives in a long, narrow house with five other volunteers. White and well-scrubbed, they do not exactly resemble their neighbors, who are mostly poor black and Latin people.
If nothing else, the volunteers seem well intentioned, and no one in the neighborhood bothers them. Sharing the same values for the most part, they support one another through those dark nights of the soul.
"A lot of my personal anguish this year has been over women," Ms. Hernandez said. "The cycles of abuse they seem to be stuck in or the presence of drugs and alcohol in their lives.
"At the end of the day, someone will say let's go and have a beer, and I flip out. I can't hear it without seeing the face of someone here and seeing the loss of life and the loss of independence because of alcohol."
Ms. Hernandez's tour of duty ends early in August. She is not certain what she will do next. But even if her search for faith in the Bronx has been met with silence sometimes, she has seen a God with a different face, the face of the people she has tried to help. They have endured in the absence of answers.
"They're homeless and they're housed," Ms. Hernandez said. "They're addicted and they're clean. They're men and they're women.
"I'm grateful to them. If it wasn't for them, I don't know if I would have survived."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
$5 Billion Benefit Seen From LIPA Rate Cut

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
Reductions in electricity rates by the Long Island Power Authority have expanded the Long Island economy by $5 billion in the past two years, making it a $100 billion economy for the first time, an economist, Irwin Kellner, said last week.
Dr. Kellner, a professor of economics at Hofstra University, made the estimate at ceremonies attended by Gov. George E. Pataki and Richard Kessel, the utility's chairman, held on Tuesday for LIPA's second anniversary. 
 Mr. Pataki, who led the authority's partial takeover of the former Long Island Lighting Company, said the rate reductions, averaging 20 percent, "benefited all Long Islanders, but especially small-business owners, who are the backbone of the local economy." He estimated direct savings from lower rates at nearly $1 billion over the two years.
Dr. Kellner said the $5 billion figure took into account a multiplier effect that included new jobs and construction, business expansion and higher wages and disposable income. The unemployment rate on the Island is an extremely low 2.5 percent.
He said more than a million workers on the Island were employed by private businesses, and that 40,000 jobs were added last year, the highest figure since 1985.
Much of the savings in the partial takeover of Lilco resulted from refinancing of Lilco debt, including more than $4 billion for the Shoreham nuclear plant, which never opened, with tax-exempt state bonds.
Critics of the takeover said repayment of the bonds over the next 30 years would eventually drive electric rates higher. They also said the authority could act on its own to raise rates at any time, unlike private utilities, whose rates were regulated by the New York State Public Service Commission. JOHN RATHER

HEADLINE: From Tech Schools To Wine Cellars

 BODY:
It was cruel irony to have placed the article about the pressure to cede the building that houses the area's only technical high school to the town of Stamford on the same front page that describes the elaborate wine cellars being built in local homes ("House Wine Gets Its Own Room" and "A Tale of 2 Schools, but Only 1 Building," May 7).
The same population that spends lavishly on a home for liquor is too frugal to invest in the education of manual laborers -- the same population that does the sort of skilled carpentry work in such demand. 
 But, on second thought, it is probably true that both are reflections of the same economic phenomena. Stamford "needs" the tech school space in order to improve its schools, which in turn attract wealth and support real estate values. The wine cellars are "needed" in order to support fragile egos.
Fulfullment of such needs is shortsighted in the extreme, to the extent that they marginalize the very people we require to keep things in working order.
Instead, we need to do more to insure that all forms of talent are nurtured equally in our schools.
 
KATHY HARSANY CRUSOE
Greenwich
