HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Utilities Rally To Yield Some Powerful Results

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
NOTORIOUSLY vulnerable to rising interest rates, utility stocks fell 23.5 percent last year, their worst performance in a quarter-century, as the Federal Reserve made credit more expensive on three occasions, starting June 30.
So what has happened this year as the Fed raised rates another three times? The stocks have not only rallied but have performed better than any other group. The Standard & Poor's utility index has returned 20.6 percent through Friday while the S.& P. 500 has fetched just 1.1 percent. 
 What's to explain this turnaround? Several things, industry analysts and portfolio managers say, not least the fact that utilities are among the few sectors that pay handsome dividends, resulting in yields that are high even by historical standards.
Despite this year's rally, dividend yields for new investors in many utilities are flirting with 7 percent -- quadruple the 1.51 percent yield for the Dow industrials.
"Dividend income is one of the few real things you get from a company," observed William H. Reaves, president of a Jersey City money management company that specializes in utilities.
Unfashionable as such thinking has become in a technology-dominated investment world, it is clearly attracting some investors partial to equities but weary of the gyrations that have become commonplace on the Nasdaq and, all too often, for high-priced blue chip stocks as well.
"They're jumping into utilities," said Edward J. Tirello, who analyzes the group for Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. The appeal is not just high yields, he added, but that utility stocks are highly liquid and the companies in many cases offer prospects for growth in a newly deregulated environment.
Indeed, the industry is steadily, though slowly, shedding its traditional reputation as supersensitive to changes in interest rates. No longer do most utilities need to borrow huge amounts to build new generating capacity. Many of the companies are raking in so much cash that they have become lenders and investors themselves.
And many analysts say that after years of underperforming, utilities are bargains.
THE values are pretty compelling right now," said Daniele Seitz, director of equity research at UBS Warburg. She cited "hidden value" that deregulation is unlocking for many companies, such as from energy-trading and telecommunications, and the relatively friendly attitude that state officials have taken in awarding compensation for so-called stranded costs for plants that are no longer competitively viable.
With federal encouragement, half the states have facilitated some form of free market in electricity and natural gas, with consumers getting a choice of suppliers. This kind of deregulation is changing the risk-reward profile of the industry.
Although strategies differ, the industry is gravitating roughly into three camps -- those oriented toward generating power (such as Edison International, -- based in Rosemead, Calif.), those that distribute it (GPU of Morristown, N.J.) and those that follow the traditional route, doing both (Southern of Atlanta, Ga.).
Generation is considered riskier but distribution remains subject to price regulation, and analysts say it is too early to know the winning strategy.
"We don't know which plan's going to work out better," Mr. Tirello said.
Still, the companies do stand to benefit from strong growth in demand for power, which many believe will result in shortages in some parts of the country this summer. And there is little risk that fresh capacity will put downward pressure on rates anytime soon since independent "merchant" plants have become difficult to finance, analysts said.
Meanwhile, utility dividends, after a decade in which many companies cut payouts in response to Wall Street pressure to transform themselves into vehicles for rapid growth, seem relatively secure again.
Asked about favorite stocks, Ms. Seitz cited American Electric Power, -- a Columbus, Ohio, holding company yielding 6.93 percent with an energy-trading operation, good fuel diversification and the scale to be a major supplier. She also likes New Orleans-based Entergy -- (4.09 percent), the company that has the industry buzzing about its aggressive embrace of deregulation, and Duke Energy -- of Charlotte, N.C. (3.81 percent).
Mr. Tirello favors Atmos Energy, -- a Dallas-based gas distributor (6.12 percent); American Water Works, -- "a natural monopoly" in Voorhees, N.J., (3.63 percent); and such electrics as the Dallas-based TXU (7.07 percent) and New Jersey's Public Service Enterprise Group -- (5.90 percent).
AS FOR Mr. Reaves, who has been following the industry for some 50 years, the high-yield standout is the St. Louis-based Ameren, -- paying 7.04 percent and increasing its earnings 6 percent a year. He also likes Virginia's Dominion Resources -- (5.73 percent) and, for the patiently venturesome, the growth-oriented Peco Energy -- in Pennsylvania (2.30 percent).
"The stocks tend to do better when there's caution in the market" generally, Mr. Reaves said. But he said many investors were still inhibited by old notions about these suppliers of basic household services.
That is likely to change.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1296 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Rear Window;
What Are You Afraid Of? A Hidden Issue Emerges

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A HOT new issue is lurking just below the political radar, ready to explode onto the American electorate.
"It tests off the charts!" said Neil Newhouse, a Republican pollster. 
 Mark Penn, President Clinton's pollster, said, "Everybody's seen it in their surveys -- it's pretty hard to miss. It's a pretty powerful groundswell."
Senator Richard Durbin, an Illinois Democrat who held three hearings on the subject last week, gushed, "Boy, you prompt it with just a couple words and you're going to get a torrent of responses from people."
The issue is privacy. It encompasses far more than peeping toms, or even hackers invading Web sites or intercepting cell phone conversations. Not only are people frightened that information about their personal peccadillos could turn up in hostile hands, but also that thieves could cash in on their financial data.
Increasingly, people confess to pollsters, they are suspicious of companies that have access to their financial and health care records, and are frightened that the information will be used against them. They are no less wary of what the government could do with such data.
To many voters, that their movements and activities are being tracked on the Internet -- perhaps even by their bosses -- may not pose a direct danger. But the very idea of it is, well, creepy.
Spotting an opportunity, Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush have begun speaking out about protecting the dissemination of private information.
"Today, there is greater protection for your video rental receipts than for your most intimate medical information," Mr. Gore said in a speech at New York University two weeks ago. "I've seen cases where people's prescription drug histories are sold freely to direct mail companies without their permission; where hundreds of employees at an H.M.O. have access to patients' records."
Even Mr. Bush offered a nod, telling Business Week recently, "I'm a privacy-rights person. The marketplace can function without sacrificing the privacy of individuals."
In many ways, privacy seems like a sure-fire political issue: it touches day-to-day anxieties triggered when people are asked to divulge their credit card number over the telephone or when they retrieve cash from an A.T.M. machine. It is always a draw for press coverage. And as Internet useburgeons, so will fears.
But politicians face a challenge to convert privacy from a subliminal worry to something that will actually affect how people vote. Complicating that challenge,privacy is not, at first glance, a matter that would drive voters to one party or another.
DEMOCRATS have been the most aggressive in vying for the privacy niche. They are framing it as a tension between civil libertarians and consumers on one side and big business on the other. Already, in the House, Democrats have zeroed in on a vote taken last July, in which most Republicans opposed instituting rigorous privacy protection for customers' medical and financial records.
Although privacy comes up less among Republicans, they argue that it would not be out of character for them to seize the issue. After all, libertarians have always been big on privacy. And Republicans were the most outspoken in condemning the Census Bureau's long form, asserting that it was an infringement on privacy.
"This is a hill that nobody holds, and either party could seize the ground," said Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster who for months has been using flip charts to persuade his clients that privacy "is a huge issue waiting" for someone to grab. "The issue of privacy is very much in the place that health care was a decade or so ago," he said.
Acknowledging that either party could potentially become identified with privacy, Mr. Newhouse said the competition will be over who "can be there first and strongest and be the noisiest on it."
Indeed, a Gallup poll in March asked who would better handle protecting ordinary Americans against invasions of privacy. Mr. Gore drew 41 percent; Mr. Bush, 47 percent.
Privacy may be so potentially hot that some candidates did not want to publicly admit they were husbanding the issue for their fall arsenals. Who wants to tip off a rival to a fresh line of attack?
"My campaigns are reluctant about showing leg early on this," said Jim Jordan, political director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.
But candidates who face primary opponents do not have the luxury of holding off. Last week, former Representative Maria Cantwell, who is running for the Democratic Senate nomination from Washington state, began broadcasting a television commercial on privacy. Ms. Cantwell, who lost her seat after one term in the Gingrich revolution of 1994, went on to make between $25 million and $50 million in the Internet business.
Peering into the camera, Ms. Cantwell says in the 30-second spot: "What you do on your own computer should be your business and nobody else's. I want to make sure no child is left behind and that the Internet remains a tool for learning, not another way for government, banks or insurance companies to invade your privacy."
The campaign of another Democrat, Mike Ciresi, a trial lawyer who is seeking the Senate nomination from Minnesota, swamped potential supporters last week with thousands of glossy brochures featuring the headline, "Mike Ciresi Will Protect Your Privacy!"
When voters are asked what concerns them most, they seldom cite privacy right off the bat. Yet pollsters find that when voters are probed about issues that affect their lives, privacy shoots to the top -- or close to it.
"God gave me a couple of ears -- I just listen to people," said Brian Schweitzer, a peppermint farmer and soil scientist from Whitefish, Mont., who is running for the United States Senate. "Everywhere I go in Montana people want to protect their privacy. It's huge!"
Mr. Schweitzer, a Democrat who hopes to oust Senator Conrad Burns, accused his rival of co-sponsoring a bill that "would force the individual consumer to contact corporate America and beg them not to collate and sell your personal information."
For his part, Mr. Burns insisted that Mr. Schweitzer "mischaracterized the legislation" and was simply "trying to get his name in the paper." He is just as committed, he said, to guarding people's privacy.
No one knows whether this issue will truly rouse voters in the fall of 2000 to the same extent as health care and education. After all, even after the tax revolt of 1978 in California, it took years for cutting taxes to become a winning issue nationally. And despite stirrings about smog and dirty water in the 1970's, the environment did not emerge as a top-of-the-mind concern of American voters until years later.
The other challenge facing both sides is that there are no easy remedies for protecting privacy. Even if consumers clamor about their rights, no politician wants to be seen taking steps that could hobble the new economy -- or provoke the Internet industry, which has become increasingly generous in doling out contributions.
Candidates should also be mindful that there can be unintended consequences when they try to capitalize on a new issue.
Strategists for Representative Debbie Stabenow, a Michigan Democrat, said that in their drive to topple the incumbent Republican, Senator Spencer Abraham, they plan to castigate him as siding with big business -- and against consumers -- on privacy matters.
But Mr. Abraham shot back that he intends to play up that his campaign has an "Internet privacy policy on our Web site -- and she doesn't even have one."
"It would be interesting for Congresswoman Stabenow to make that an issue," he said. "We're explicit. We will protect the privacy of people who log on to our Web site."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1137 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS WORLD;
Eastern Europe's Foray Into 'M-Commerce'

BYLINE: By PETER S. GREEN

DATELINE: PRAGUE

 BODY:
THERE'S no need to fiddle in your pocket for loose change if you want a Coke on the streets of downtown Prague. Simply walk up to a Coca-Cola vending machine and point your mobile telephone at it.
Punch a few buttons on your phone and bang, a cold bottle clatters down the chute and 20 Czech Koruny, about 50 cents, is charged on your mobile phone bill. 
 As consumer spending in the former Communist bloc has risen, so has the use of mobile phones: in some countries as many as one in four households now owns one. But the creaky banking system inherited from Communism has left Central and Eastern Europe mostly cash economies. Credit cards and checks are seldom used, and both merchants and consumers are deeply fearful of losing their life savings to credit-card fraud.
Now, with the advent of sophisticated wireless technologies, improved data security and increasingly versatile handsets, Eastern Europe -- and the Czech Republic, in particular -- are at the forefront of a movement to put e-commerce in the hands of consumers. The result is m-commerce, for mobile. Moving far beyond the quick Coke, companies like Nokia and Citigroup want to turn mobile phones into virtual credit cards.
"People perceive mobiles as trusted personal devices," said Jari Paakkarinen, of Nokia Telecommunications, the Finnish mobile phone manufacturer, which is using the highly competitive Czech mobile phone market to test new technology. "You eat with it, you rest with it. It's an extension of your personality, so it's a very short step to trust it to pay with it."
M-commerce is likely to take off much more rapidly in Europe, especially the Czech Republic, than in the United States. Although some former Communist countries lack readily available wired telephones, most of Europe has mobile networks that are several generations more advanced and more secure than the older United States systems. And most European systems function across entire countries, not just several cities or states.
In the United States, the widespread use of checks and credit cards reduces the need for a new payment system. And Americans would be more likely than Europeans to see the spread of m-commerce as a threat to their privacy.
But Central Europe lacks the sophisticated database of consumer credit that card issuers require. Akshaya Bhargava, general manager of Citibank's Czech operations, says that the bank is instead arranging, by this fall, for retailers to accept payment by mobile telephone for goods sold on their Web sites.
The Czech Republic's 10.5 million people already own more than 2 million mobile phones and pay their bills religiously. But credit cards have hardly made a dent, with few Czech adults holding them.
Nor do Czechs use checks. Instead, most use A.T.M. cards to withdraw money, then pay their bills and make their purchases in cash. Czechs commonly pay for kitchen furniture, airline tickets and even new cars with wads of bills.
But merchants complain that cash transactions encourage theft and that customers often forgo purchases because they simply do not have enough cash in hand.
The prophets of m-commerce, here and around the world, therefore, see a double boon: The phone will replace or pre-empt the credit card, giving merchants authorization to immediately debit a shopper's bank account or add the charges to a phone bill. It can also become the prime means of gaining access to the Internet, allowing consumers to browse stripped-down Web sites especially tailored to small mobile phone displays. Only about 7 percent of Czechs have regular access to the Internet at home or work.
The m-commerce revolution depends on a series of technologies meant to bring information from the Web to screens not much larger than a watch face. The current technology, called Wireless Application Protocol, is seen as only the first step toward high-speed data transmission for mobile phones that will receive a constant flow of news bulletins, stock prices or suggestions for nearby restaurants, as determined by the nearest transmitter.
With an average monthly income of around $341, not many Czechs are likely to charge a new Lexus on their mobile phone. But Jack Schrantz, founder of Albumcity.cz, an Internet record shop, says he expects compact discs to sell well. "It matches the demographics here -- it's the young and tech-savvy who buy CD's," Mr. Schrantz said.
Several European airlines and banks are already making plans to extend m-commerce. Finnair and Lufthansa allow passengers to check for delays and change their reservations with Web-enabled telephones. Over the next two to three years, Lufthansa plans to offer everything from ticket purchases to check-in.
Banks in several European nations also are allowing customers to use telephones and the Internet to make transfers, check account balances and spend cash downloaded into an "electronic wallet." Others see the technology going even further. At Globopolis (www.globopolis.com), a collection of regularly updated city guides to major European cities, mobile phone surfers some time this year will be able to not only find a restaurant, cinema or nightclub, but to make a reservation and pay for tickets, and in some cases, even meal bills.
As with many an Internet business, however, it remains unclear how m-businesses will generate revenue and profits. Banner advertisements simply cannot fit on phones.
For now, the airtime that callers burn up while browsing is the main source of revenue for mobile phone operators. But competition and further generations of technology could replace charges by the minute with flat monthly rates, leaving the operators looking for a new model.
PROFITS from m-transactions are often small: hi-technology Coke machines will not make anybody rich. "The question with micropayments is how you split commissions: There's not much there," said Robert Chvatal, the marketing director of Radio Mobil, whose Paegas mobile telephone service, provided in a partnership with Deutsche Telekom, is the second-largest in the Czech Republic with nearly one million subscribers.
Both Paegas and its larger rival, EuroTel, whose partners are Bell Atlantic and Media One International, say they may eventually make their money much as Visa and American Express do, by charging merchants a percentage on every transaction.
EuroTel and Paegas count on Web traffic to be dominated by the mobile telephone, not the personal computer, or even palmtops. "Many of these customers simply cannot or will not invest in a home PC, so the ability to get to the content and applications of the Internet via the mobile is very attractive," said Mike Burns, EuroTel's marketing director. "What's in it for us is to be essentially the primary provider of Internet services in this country."

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1555 words

HEADLINE: The World: A Different Kind of Rogue;
When Democracy Runs Off the Rails

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS

 BODY:
FOR years the United States has classified some countries, like Iraq and North Korea, as "rogue states." Now, as the world becomes more democratic -- more than 60 percent of countries have elected leaders -- something more complicated enters the political lexicon. Call them "rogue democracies."
These are democratic governments that go off the rails, either in aggressiveness toward neighbors, cruelty to citizens or backtracking on the promise that democracy will foster liberty and equality. 
 How to deal with this new type of rogue, or to know when to recognize one, is not easy for established democracies. It is, after all, tempting to assume that when other nations choose to freely elect their leaders, good things automatically follow.
The case of Peru is the latest example. There an elected president, Alberto K. Fujimori, has rewritten the constitution, cut the power of his Congress and chipped away at political liberties, all in the name of social order. Now he is claiming a third term after an election so riddled with irregularities that the opposition boycotted it and the Organization of American States won't approve it.
What's the world to do? Shun Peru? Impose sanctions? When Austria's voters put the xenophobe Jorg Haider near the seat of power, Europe got together and forced his ostracism. But in Peru a similar outcome seems unlikely.
It has been obvious for some time that democracy no longer has one universally accepted definition, and so it is hard to say when a country ceases to be one. Consider the variety of forms in Peru, Russia, India, Zimbabwe, the United States, Austria and Japan. There is also a growing understanding that elections don't guarantee free expression or fair treatment of minorities.
Yet a nation's ability to call itself a democracy often buys it sympathy among voters in the West and among human-rights advocates everywhere. Elected leaders on almost every continent have, indeed, long used the forms of democracy as political wool to pull over the eyes of those abroad who would judge their legitimacy to rule.
Throughout Latin America, constitutions are routinely amended or rewritten to expand the terms and power of presidents.
In Zimbabwe, where parliamentary elections are now less than three weeks away, President Robert Mugabe has systematically attacked the opposition under the guise of a violent campaign to seize land from white farmers.
In Iran, lame-duck conservatives tried to block the newly elected reformist parliament; it was seated only with the suffrance of the Islamic republic's "supreme religious leader," who can veto such earthly procedures as elections.
In Singapore, and now Malaysia, elected Asian governments dominated by intolerant leaders have fashioned the most sophisticated, perfectly legal methods of destroying political opponents through the courts. The slow-moving prosecution on sex charges of Anwar Ibrahim, Malaysia's once-fast-rising deputy prime minister, is a prime example.
As for the component parts of the former Soviet Union, tidy definitions of democracy are surely confounded by the criminalization of the economy and, to some extent, political life, not to mention the tenacity of Communist-era and Communist-style political bosses who see elections pretty much as nuisances.
THERE have always been imperfect democracies; the very messiness of the political form invites imperfection. The United States has had segregation, internment of Japanese-Americans and repeated episodes of local police brutality. Europeans differ on the limits of free expression and how to treat minorities. But those can be seen as shortcomings in realizing democracy's ideals, not a negation of them. A more fundamental problem arises when institutions are too weak to provide eventual remedies for such flaws -- a role often played by elected legislatures and, in America, the courts.
Arguably, a democracy strays into rogue territory when a country cannot muster any checks on the power plays of an elected leader who chooses not to step aside and rewrites the rules accordingly. A corollary is almost always oppression of some kind, often beginning with the political opposition. And the mix becomes lethal, as it did in Yugoslavia, if race, ethnicity or religion are then used to inflame political passions.
Lorne W. Craner, president of the International Republican Institute, which is supported by the Republican Party, said that in some dodgy democracies, "a lot of people have figured out you can have a bad election and get away with it." So his organization and its opposite number in Washington, the National Democratic Institute, have been thinking for years that it might be better to concentrate more on what happens between elections. European democracy groups and the Organization of African Unity are making a similar shift, he said.
"It's very frustrating when there's no other reason why countries that have poor human rights and democracy records don't get sanctioned," he said.
Susan Kaufman Purcell, president of the Americas Society in New York, classifies the governments of Hugo Chavez in Venezuela and Mr. Fujimori in Peru as "imperfect democracies" -- adding that often "it is a hard call where to draw the line between imperfect democracies and fake democracies." A democracy, she says, "at the very least must have some basic defining characteristics, the most important being the ability to vote an incumbent out of power through the use of a functioning electoral process that allows competition."
Bengt Save-Soderbergh, who runs a new intergovernmental organization in Stockholm called the International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance, says even free and fair elections don't define democracy: "Deep down it's a culture, with values and also respect, tolerance -- all these things."
At Emory University in Atlanta, Robert Pastor, an expert on Latin America who served in the Carter administration and who has advised and monitored elections as far afield as China, draws a line at downgrading the essential role of national elections. There are those who say, for example, that building in voting experience from the village up, as China and Pakistan say they are doing (and as Americans did before 1789), may be more useful than imposing periodic national elections on an inexperienced people.
"There's been an argument that says democracy is more than elections," Mr. Pastor said. "I agree with that, but not when one takes the next step and says that elections are not that important for democracy. On that I completely disagree. Democracy should be more than free elections, but it can't be less."
And then there is the problem of a different kind of rogue: The democracy whose human rights record or foreign policies fall short of international standards but don't raise eyebrows. The contrast between attitudes in America toward India and Pakistan is instructive, one that human rights organizations often point to.
The State Department's annual international human rights survey is very critical of India for its treatment of women, minorities and people declared "untouchable" by the Hindu majority. In the disputed territory of Kashmir, which is under Indian military occupation, the report found significant abuses of the local Muslim population. Moreover, American officials say that India has only narrowly escaped being placed on the list of terrorist nations for its backing of unrest in neighboring nations, including bombings and perhaps assassinations in Pakistan.
But at Human Rights Watch in New York, Kenneth Roth, the executive director, said that Americans often overlook the record because most of India's governments have been freely elected, while neighboring Pakistan gets much closer scrutiny, having lurched in and out of military rule. "India has many attributes of a democracy," said Mr. Roth. "But it's too facile to embrace India as a democracy without recognizing the flawed nature of its political system when it comes to marginal populations or perceived security threats."
Ram Narayan Kumar, an Indian human rights leader, worries about the precedent. "Around India," he said, "the lesson other countries there will learn is that you just have to appear to be democratic."
E XAMPLES matter everywhere, said John L. Hirsch, a former American ambassador to Sierra Leone who is vice president of the International Peace Academy, a research organization with close ties to the United Nations. In Africa, he said, the two countries in which to hope for continued success are Nigeria and South Africa, both of which held open elections last year.
Michael Joseph Smith, a political science professor at the University of Virginia, said that strong democracies "haven't given enough thought to maintenance and sustaining of democracy." In the case of Peru, he added, the United States could have given stronger support to the Organization of American States. Instead, the Clinton administration first endorsed, then backed away from, an unusually bold O.A.S. judgment that the election was flawed. Professor Smith and Mr. Craner said that was a bad message to send to Latin America.
"We need to mobilize the multilateral organizations to a far greater extent," Mr. Smith said. "Democracy needs constant attention."

HEADLINE: The World;
2 Elections On an Island. So Close, So Far Apart.

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti

 BODY:
WILDA SEVERE carried the future in her mind and body as she waited to cast her ballot last month in Haiti's legislative elections. Though five months pregnant, she stood for hours on a slowly moving line, hoping that her vote would usher in a better life for her baby.
"I want the conditions of the country to change," she said. "The conditions are not good for anybody right now. People suffer and there is no work. And there is insecurity. The country is still not at peace." 
 More than five years after a United States-led military occupation restored democratic rule in Haiti, the civil serenity that she and many Haitians hoped for remains elusive. In the weeks before the elections, politically motivated violence had left 15 people dead, and in the slums the sense of poverty only deepened.
When the last American troops left Haiti this year, some policy makers saw it as the end of a successful mission to restore democracy. But the fact that the elections (in which former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide's party did well) found so many Haitians still pining for peace and progress belies any boast. It raises questions about why Haiti seems to stagger from crisis to crisis as it tries to embark on the path to democracy.
Part of an answer lies just a short flight away in the Dominican Republic -- a nation that shares not just the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, but also a history of dictatorship, violence and American intervention. It too has had an election in the last month.
But there, just over the border, the economy is expanding rapidly. New roads, modernized government agencies and investment have transformed the capital. Though many of the poorest Dominicans felt excluded from the boom times, they peacefully voiced their dissatisfaction at the polls, where a near majority elected Hipolito Mejia president on May 16. And then the ruling party abandoned its quest for a runoff and conceded defeat for the good of the country.
Like the border that separates the two countries -- where the lush green landscape of the Dominican Republic gives way to the barren, deforested soil of Haiti -- the contrast in political and social fortunes is sharp. Considering that Haiti was once the more prosperous and cosmopolitan of the two countries, and that the violence of Gen. Rafael Trujillo's dictatorship in the Dominican Republic 35 years ago ago rivaled if not exceeded that of the Duvalier family here, why do the two nations seem headed in opposite directions?
"A big part of the answer can be summed up in two words: 30 years," said Michele Wucker, author of "Why The Cocks Fight," a book exploring the relationship between the two nations. "Haiti is now where the Dominican Republic was not too long after the United States invasion in 1965."
Even within the shared experience of military intervention, however, there are differences. After the 1965 intervention, when Joaquin Balaguer came to power and ushered in years of repressive rule, the United States essentially kept a hands-off policy in the Dominican Republic, Ms. Wucker said. In Haiti, the United States restored President Aristide to power in 1994, but placed narrow constraints on the exercise of his power. Mr. Wucker said that the United States also contradicted itself, pressing for elections while cutting aid to help finance them. "They talk in pretty terms about democracy," Ms. said. "But deep down they are reluctant to let Haiti muddle its own way in that direction."
The legacy of dictatorship also played out differently. While some Dominicans still bear scars -- physical and psychological -- from Mr. Balaguer's early years, just as many recall benefiting from jobs, homes and other favors. So strong are those memories that nearly a quarter of the votes went to Mr. Balaguer, even though he is 93, blind and infirm. In Haiti, the experience of a former president running again is relatively rare, since most have gone into exile after enriching themselves. "They had Balaguer, we had Duvalier, but the histories are very different," said Raoul Denis, a record store owner in Port-au-Prince. "On our side, Duvalier destroyed the institutions and everything."
Those institutions, like the courts and the police, still struggle to maintain a semblance of law and order in Haiti. At the same time, other forces that could help bring pressure to bear lack sufficient experience to prove effective. In the Dominican Republic, public-interest advocates have played an important role in calling for clean elections and good government. Business owners, aware that tourists and factory jobs can flee unless there is social and political stability, also had a stake in the future and supported it with investment.
"Our problem is we in Haiti do not have an authentic bourgeoisie that has invested in Haiti," said Patrick Pierre-Louis, a law school professor. "All their money goes to the United States."
Dominican business leaders were a major force for their country's stability, said a diplomat who has worked there and in Haiti. When the United States worried about elections in the mid-1990's, such leaders were vulnerable to friendly pressure, since business owners wanted trade parity with the United States.
"In Haiti there isn't much tourism," said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. "The assembly sector is still not large. They weathered the embargo and other bad situations. I'm not sure the levers we had in the Dominican Republic could work here."
While Haiti's elections are the first step toward achieving a normal government, bigger obstacles remain in a country where winner-take-all has been a rule applied literally by victorious candidates. Haiti's political leaders have yet to understand that the power of the vote extends beyond election day.
"Dominican interests are the interests of their country," said Georges Sassine, a factory owner active in civic groups. "Here, you have people who come here, get rich and leave. We are still a colony of ourselves."

HEADLINE: RECKONINGS;
Green Cheese Rules

BYLINE: By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
Argentina is a faraway country about which most people in the United States know only what they learned from Andrew Lloyd Webber. And while the government of Fernando de la Rua is facing serious economic problems -- a weak recovery from last year's nasty slump, growing labor unrest -- "crisis" would be far too strong a word.
Yet Argentina has special symbolic importance in the battle among economic ideologies. The Latin nation has been a sort of poster child for the anti-Keynesian counterrevolution, for those who want to banish discretion and human fallibility from monetary policy. The nation's current difficulties won't cause the true believers to lose faith. But the contrast between the bad economic news in Argentina and good news elsewhere in Latin America is a reminder that green cheese has its virtues after all. 
 Puzzled? Let me explain. Until the 1930's, recessions were generally regarded as inevitable, and perhaps even desirable -- a sort of purging process that cleansed the economy after the excesses of the preceding boom. The government's job was to provide sound money and balance its own budget; a depressed economy would heal itself.
But in the face of mass unemployment some economists -- most notably the British theorist John Maynard Keynes -- concluded that recessions were neither healthy nor inevitable. They were, instead, an economic pathology that resulted when too many people tried to hoard cash instead of buying real goods and services. In a famous passage Keynes declared that "Unemployment develops . . . because people want the moon: men cannot be employed when the object of desire (i.e. money) is something which cannot be produced and the demand for which cannot readily be choked off." And he offered an answer: "There is no remedy but to persuade the public that green cheese is practically the same thing and to have a green cheese factory (i.e. central bank) under public control." In other words, the government could and should print money to stimulate a depressed economy.
For hard-money types this was and remains anathema. The dream of going back to an objective monetary standard -- preferably gold, but anyway something untouched by human hands -- has been kept alive by a small but well-financed group of enthusiasts. And in 1991 they got their wish: Argentina, desperate to regain credibility after decades of irresponsible policy, not only pegged its peso to the dollar but backed each peso with a dollar in reserves. In effect, the national green cheese factory was shut down.
In the years that followed, Argentina -- helped not only by the end of hyperinflation but also by the removal of many controls that had strangled business -- experienced an economic surge, and the hard-money enthusiasts took full credit. Only last year, as the currency of neighboring Brazil tumbled, an op-ed writer at The Wall Street Journal held up Argentina as a model: "No stimulating of the economy through inflation, no improving the 'competitiveness' of exports through currency devaluation. Just money that works." And she went on to express her ultimate wish: "Now if only America could make the dollar as good as gold."
But while Argentina's money may work, many Argentines don't, because they can't find jobs. The devaluation in Brazil was followed by a flight of manufacturing to Argentina's suddenly lower-cost neighbor. Although Argentina's government has insisted that slashing spending and raising taxes to balance the budget will promote recovery by restoring confidence, the actual effect -- as Keynes could have told you -- has been the opposite: with lower incomes, consumers are spending less, and recovery has been delayed.
And meanwhile Brazil has bounced back: that devaluation has turned out to be just what the doctor ordered. Chile and Mexico, with their floating exchange rates, are doing well. Right now Argentina has the worst, not the best, of Latin America's major economies.
I'm not saying that Mr. de la Rua should devalue the peso. Too many loans, even from one Argentine to another, are in dollars -- and anyway the political cost would be catastrophic. At least for the time being, I fear that Argentina is stuck. But its travails are a lesson for the rest of us, especially those who are nostalgic for the certainties of the gold standard: Keynes was right. Taken in moderation, green cheese can be good for your health.

HEADLINE: Race in America

 BODY:
A generation ago, after riots in several major cities, the Kerner Commission warned that the United States was in danger of becoming two nations, one black and one white. That has not happened. America is now an inescapably multiracial society from which there is no turning back for whites or blacks -- in its schools, its workplaces, its churches, its military and its cultural institutions. Yet divisions and frustrations persist on both sides, in minds and hearts if not in the laws of the land.
For various reasons, however, most Americans, especially white Americans, do not like to share their personal feelings on race. In 1997, President Clinton proposed a national "conversation" about race. A committee was appointed and town meetings were duly organized across the country. Most of those who showed up were civic activists interested in public policy. Almost no one dared to discuss private attitudes, a more subtle and potentially divisive subject. Yet these attitudes lie at the heart of the racial question because it is attitudes and feelings that determine how we actually interact with one another, and whether we get along. 
 Partly with that in mind, the editors of The New York Times's news department decided over a year ago to investigate the state of race relations in the United States, not with an eye to providing analysis or policy solutions, but simply to report in detail on the actual interplay of whites and blacks on a daily basis. The result was a series of a dozen or so articles that will be published over the next six weeks. The reporters who wrote these pieces spent as much as a year on their projects, returning again and again to the people who eventually came to inhabit their narratives, learning a bit more each time about their fears and frustrations and hopes.
In nearly every case, African-Americans were far more willing to talk about race, in large part because they have endured America's long history of discrimination and live with its consequences every single day. Yet in the end whites began to open up as well, sharing their thoughts about a subject that many would just as soon avoid and others do not think about at all. The fact that whites and blacks, as well as Latinos and Asian-Americans, were eventually able to address painful issues with great candor is one of the series' great reportorial accomplishments.
The first article appears today. It examines what happens in a Pentecostal church in Georgia when blacks begin to join an all-white congregation. In broadest terms, the piece is an examination of the struggle of two races to coexist in a world neither wants to leave, of the compromises accepted by both sides, of the narrowness of some parishioners and the bigheartedness of others. The struggle to coexist, in fact, defines most of the pieces in this series.
An article later this week, for example, will explore the daily tensions among white and black soldiers in the United States Army, an institution where the work force is fully and officially integrated and where racial resentments are usually thought to be a thing of the past. Another details the extraordinarily complex, painfully edgy relationship between the black producer and white writer who together created HBO's extraordinary documentary on Baltimore's drug culture.
In some cases there is evidence of progress, moments of growth and reconciliation, small epiphanies when one side comes to understand the motivations of the other and both come to understand that they need each other. In others, the divisions seem too great to bridge. The lifelong friendship between two Cubans, one white, the other black, loses its intimacy under the centrifugal strains of racial isolation in their adopted home of Miami. Whites, blacks, Mexicans and American Indians competing for rock-bottom wages on the factory floor simply cannot connect when racial animosities are sharpened by economic fears. White and black boys and girls, fast friends in a suburban elementary school, are tugged apart by seemingly irresistible cultural and academic forces by the time they begin high school.
Whether they chronicle success, failure or just plain inertia, these are stories that report race relations as they actually exist on a human scale in America. In a way, without deliberately trying to, the people who populate these stories provide the uncomfortably candid conversation about race that Mr. Clinton sought but never got. The stories hardly depict a perfect world, but they do depict a country in which citizens bring strong feelings, deep thought and, in a heartening number of cases, resilient spirits to one of the abiding issues of American life.

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
Fed's Moves Brighten The Outlook For Equities

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
REMEMBER the Goldilocks economy? The not too hot, not too cold, low inflation porridge beloved by Alan Greenspan and financial markets?
Although it's too early to say for sure, the latest numbers seem to indicate that what had been a steaming dish is beginning to cool. But there is little reason, at this point, to suspect it will turn stone cold. 
 Last week, purchasing managers said the manufacturing sector expanded in May, but not as fast as previously. And the government said the private sector actually shed some jobs last month, but not too many.
This sort of stuff is music to investors. The Nasdaq had its best week ever, rising more than 19 percent. The Dow and the S.& P. 500 also moved up briskly.
Christine Callies, chief United States market strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, took some time last week to talk about the economy and the stock market as spring begins to molt into summer. Following are excerpts from the conversation:
 
Q. The data suggests that the Fed's interest rate increases are beginning to slow the economy. Is that how you read these numbers?
 
A. We think economic growth is plateauing, and will gradually slow down over the next several quarters. But there is a lot of natural volatility in reports like retail sales and in housing data, and activity there is not weak. By the end of the summer, we will get more conclusive evidence that the Fed tightening is having an effect.
Recently, the stock market has assumed a bigger slowdown than is coming, a slowdown that will cause the Fed to ease. But we may be waiting for a while before we know for sure that the Fed has moved to neutral. I don't think we will know the Fed has reached that point until sometime next year.
 
Q. So you think the Fed hasn't yet finished tightening?
 
A. We see two more tightenings of one-quarter percentage point apiece, the first later this month and another in August. Then we think the Fed will be on hold. The Fed is trying to slow the U.S. economy to what is still a healthy growth rate against the backdrop of the first synchronized global expansion that we have seen in a dozen years.
The fact that every region of the world is in a reasonably healthy recovery mode will place some demand on the supply of goods and services.
The Fed is therefore operating in a situation where global growth is reinforcing itself. That will put a floor under global inflation, albeit at a low level.
We maintain this is potentially good news, because if the Fed is in a gradualist monetary mode that means it might tolerate a little inflation without going overboard.
 
Q. What does this mean for stocks?
 
A. All in all, this is a fairly benign environment for equity prices. We think the market is in a trading range, and will tread water until price/earnings multiples get down to the point where there is a little bit of headroom. We are almost there.
 
Q. How much cheaper does the market have to get? And what sort of a trading range are you talking about?
 
A. In order to support a major rally, we need to see multiples down another 10 percent or so. But that doesn't mean prices have to fall. If they stay at these levels, profits will catch up over the next couple of quarters. Trading range corrections are a substitute for faster, steeper corrections, where prices fall by 25 percent or so.
On the upside, the S.& P. 500 could go as high as 1,540 to 1,550 and the Nasdaq composite could go back to 4,000 or 4,100 and still not change the sideways trend.
 
Q. What are the risks to this forecast on the upside, and on the downside?
 
A. Bull markets need liquidity in the form of excess money. In order for the market to break out of the trading range on the upside, we would need to see a very substantial increase in liquidity, and we would need to see it over the next month or so.
On the downside, a major correction in the S.& P. 500 could only occur as a result of a major accident. And the economy, monetary, financial market and foreign exchange risks of this occurring are probably as low as they have been in many years. The one residual weak point in this scenario is that margin debt was not totally neutralized in the April correction. But in all, the environment is remarkably benign.
 
Q. It has been widely noted that while valuations in the aggregate are high, big chunks of the stock market are cheap, and have been for some time. Do you agree?
 
A. There are pieces of many sectors that look quite good.
The central concept is to identify companies that deliver growth at a moderate price. That is in contrast to last year, when the trick was to find the fastest-growing companies and buy them, because someone else would come in afterwards and pay more. You can find a lot of the companies I am talking about now in the capital goods area.
A lot of electrical equipment companies are developing new-economy growth rates and are trading at old-economy prices.
Three names we like are SCI Systems, Sanmina and General Electric, which is not overpriced relative to the top-line growth it is generating. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: The World;
Autocrat? Democrat? Well, Both.

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
THE year was 1991. Alberto Fujimori was Peru's newly elected president, and diplomats were rejoicing that every government in Latin America except Cuba's was now democratically elected. So President Fujimori joined the leaders of Peru's four Andean neighbors in proposing a radical plan: the Organization of American States would require all 34 member states to sever diplomatic relations with any government that took power unconstitutionally.
Nine years later, Mr. Fujimori must be happy his plan was never adopted. This week, the Organization of American States is to consider how to punish Mr. Fujimori for claiming a third five-year term after an election last Sunday that was tainted by dirty tricks and re-interpretation of the constitution, which limits Peru's presidents to two terms. His opponent, Alejandro Toledo, wound up boycotting the vote. 
 Still, Peru is probably safe from any drastic measures, in large part because the Clinton Administration is reluctant to punish a strong ally in the war against drugs and because Peru is not alone among its peers in slipping back into old authoritarian patterns.
The current president of Ecuador, a civilian, came to power in January by military coup. The elected president of Venezuela is a former military coup leader who has made all-out war on the Congress and the courts. Paraguay's civilian government is teetering.
Does this turn of events mean the man on horseback is coming back in Latin America? Or is it that Latin America never completely unsaddled him?
In fact, authoritarianism and democracy have long coexisted in Latin America, and a swing toward elections has never meant autocracy is dead. A pattern of generals replacing civilian presidents only to be replaced again by generals has been the rule from Panama to Argentina for the better part of a century. A variant on the theme, in places like Peru and Mexico, is a civilian leader who is elected and then rules by fiat, fraud or manipulation of the courts and congress.
"The box on the outside is labeled a democracy," said Piero Gleijeses, a professor of Latin American studies at Johns Hopkins University, "but inside you have an authoritarian system." A history of oligarchy, class division and racial conflict makes it hard to establish the social compacts on which liberal democracy is most often built.
Mr. Fujimori is not so much a model of a new kind of authoritarianism as an exemplar of something older. "Our military regimes were never that tough and our elected governments were never that democratic," said Carlos Tapia, a former Peruvian congressman and social critic. "Our coups were never initiated by the military alone. There was always a group of civilians ready to manipulate the military to jump in."
The model for the civilian strongman in Peru goes back at least to the 1919 election of Augusto B. Leguia, a businessman with a taste for top hats and thoroughbred horses, who served until a coup upended his rule in 1930. Like Mr. Fujimori, Mr. Leguia was a master builder of roads and ports who eagerly sought foreign investment. He also displayed little compunction about breaking democratic rules. He ordered the army to shut down the Congress, he closed down newspapers that opposed him, and his race horses had remarkable success at the track as soon as he took office.
As for governing Peru, neither the military nor the civilian strongmen have a stellar record. Most recently, the military regimes that ruled from 1968 to 1980 pushed through a radical land reform. But it ultimately failed, leading to a slump in agriculture and a chaotic peasant migration to the cities that created shantytowns that are still spreading. It did little for public confidence in military efficiency.
When civilians returned to power in 1980 the people were overjoyed. But the next 10 years were marked by hyperinflation, massive corruption and the eruption of terrorist violence. This ultimately discredited all the traditional political parties, leaving the public in despair about their hopes for order.
Finally the people turned to Mr. Fujimori, the ultimate outsider, a son of Japanese immigrants who belonged to no party and promised a clean break with the past. His popularity soared when he disbanded the Supreme Court and Congress in 1992, claiming that their corrupt ways were blocking his battle against terrorists including the Shining Path group -- whose leaders he then captured. In 1995, he won re-election in a landslide; it amounted to a democratic affirmation of authoritarianism and left advocates of democracy worried.
"A full democracy means more than elections," noted Carlos Ivan Degregori, an anthropologist at the Institute of Peruvian Studies. "It requires sturdy institutions: strong political parties, an independent judiciary and a Congress willing to vote against the executive branch." Most often, he said, "the boundary between democracy and authoritarianism is not so clear."
This is particularly true in the region's poorest countries, like neighboring Bolivia, where the democratically elected president is a former military dictator. But it is also true in Latin America's more economically and politically developed countries.
Chile is still governed under a constitution that was written when Augusto Pinochet was dictator; it gives the military independent powers over selecting its commanders and even senators. The new governor of Buenos Aires province in Argentina, when faced with a rising crime problem, selected as his police chief a former army colonel who had led a 1987 uprising to block trials against former junta leaders.
"Whichever way the pendulum swings," said Felipe Noguera, an Argentine political consultant, "it's not like the people overnight become perfect democrats and the next day become supporters of coups. People in this region are aware of both the weaknesses of democracy and the perils of authoritarian rule."
That may explain why in the days leading up to last Sunday's election, opinion polls showed that even though a majority of Peruvians said they thought the election process was tainted, they would vote for Mr. Fujimori.

PUB-DATE: June 4, 2000

SECTION: Section 4; Page 20; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 856 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Even a Worm Needs Love

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
LAST month a hyperactive computer program bearing the message "I Love You" ricocheted around the world's e-mail systems in less than 24 hours and infected tens of millions of computers.
The "I Love You" bug, allegedly launched by a computer student in the Philippines with too much time on his hands, touched off a cyber-flu season. More than 29 variants have emerged so far, including diabolical derivatives with names like "NewLove" and "Resume -- Janet Simons." Most of the mutants arrived without tidings of love, and some instead carried a software payload designed to erase victims' disks once the message's attachment was opened. 
 While "I Love You" was startlingly swift and effective, most of its imitators went almost nowhere. According to some computer security experts, the copycat cyberplagues should have spread just as rapidly as the worm (in computer entomology, worms propel themselves while viruses hitchhike on other documents) they were mimicking.
The question is, what's love got to do with it?
Quite a lot, perhaps.
Computer experts looking at the different contagion rates are divided about whether Internet users learned a hard lesson in computer hygiene or whether the world is actually a lonelier place than anyone realized.
"I've been told that men were much more likely to open the 'I Love You' worm than women," said George Cybenko, a computer scientist at Dartmouth University and a founder of the Institute of Security Technology Studies.
Indeed, the "I Love You" message was so simple and beguiling that in some cases it hoodwinked even the most sophisticated computer programmers.
Steven Capps, a senior Microsoft software designer, padded downstairs at 5 a.m. on the morning of the "I Love You" infection, poured himself a cup of coffee and sat down at his computer to read his e-mail. It happened to be his birthday, so as he scanned his mailbox he thought he saw a love note from his wife.
After opening the program Mr. Capps quickly realized his error and managed to delete the bug before it spread widely. "What I remember thinking was, "How did Marie manage to sneak downstairs late at night to send me a birthday note?" he said sheepishly.
Mr. Capps was not alone. Hewlett-Packard & Company acknowledged last week that its computers suffered more than 700,000 infections from the "I Love You" worm -- more than 500,000 in the United States.
The total damage -- primarily time spent restoring files and cleaning out clogged e-mail systems -- may reach $950 million, according to ICSA.net, a computer security company that tracks the cost of computer infections.
Two weeks ago, the far more lethal "NewLove" bug began infecting the address books of users of the popular Microsoft Outlook e-mail program, sending itself to every person on the list. But instead of delivering the endearingly named document LOVE-LETTER-FOR-YOU.TXT.VBS, NewLove cloaked itself by snatching a recent document name from its victim's hard disk and using that name in the subject line of all subsequent messages sent from the address list, destroying data on the hard drives of affected computers.
Last week, the "Resume" bug urged e-mail recipients to look at a job seeker's fabulous curriculum vitae, helpfully included as an attachment -- which, of course served as an electronic Trojan Horse.
Despite their cleverness, however, both "NewLove" and "Resume" were stopped in their tracks. "If 'NewLove' had come before 'I Love You' it would have spread more slowly but we would have had a bigger disaster," said Peter Tippett, chief technology officer of ICSA.
Mr. Tippett, who was trained as an epidemiologist before starting an antivirus software company in the 1980's, has long argued that computer viruses and infections closely mimic the biological world.
THAT might be another reason why the lethal "NewLove" was less effective than "I Love You." In the real world as well as in cyberspace, diseases that kill their hosts quickly tend to have limited success in spreading through large populations. "Viruses that kill their hosts never make it," Mr. Tippett said.
Whether it's the Darwinian imperative or the irresistible power of love at work, experts believe the current cyber-flu season will not be the last, especially as the millions of PC's of the 1990's are transformed into billions of cell phones, personal digital assistants and even toaster-connected Internet appliances by the end of the decade.
For each new device connected to the Internet there are dozens of new ways to spread infection. Even now, computer security experts are warning that the growing popularity of music and file-sharing programs like Napster, Gnutella, iMesh and Scour Exchange will virtually insure new vectors for diseases.
That will mean that disease in the cyberworld will become as routine as cold season is today.
"That's what concerns me," said Kevin Kelly, author of "Out of Control: The New Biology of Machines, Social Systems and the Economic World" (Addison Wesley, 1994). "These new systems leave us completely open to these infections and we may just have to learn to live with them."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2862 words

HEADLINE: Can Craig McCaw Keep His Vision Of Teledesic From Crashing?

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: KIRKLAND, Wash.

 BODY:
IT'S time for the latest installment of "Who Wants to Second-Guess a Billionaire?" In today's episode, Craig O. McCaw, the publicity-shy cable television and telecommunications entrepreneur with a fabled knack for anticipating the future, hits quicksand in his pursuit of a high-risk dream.
Mr. McCaw's investments include a maze of advanced wired and wireless services. But none presents a more formidable puzzle than Teledesic, his futuristic scheme to dot the heavens with a 288-satellite network for voice and data communications. 
 To most satellite experts, Teledesic's prospects have always seemed uncertain. But the outlook for attracting investors would appear to be considerably gloomier now that the spectacular bankruptcy of the Iridium phone system, problems in several other satellite ventures and the relentless advances of land-based competitors have confirmed Wall Street's worst fears about how tough it is to build a successful satellite business.
Teledesic is already scaled back from the mind-boggling 840-satellite system Mr. McCaw first announced in 1994 and the start of service has been delayed from 2001 to 2005. Still, the venture Mr. McCaw has referred to as "an Internet in the sky" remains by far the most ambitious commercial project in space.
Just last month, Mr. McCaw and his backers put up $1.2 billion to take control of bankrupt ICO Global Communications, a smaller satellite venture. But that hardly made the outlook any clearer. ICO could, as Mr. McCaw contends, be a steppingstone to Teledesic. Some experts, however, predict it will become the rationale for scaling back Teledesic into a more marketable venture.
For now though, Teledesic continues to grandly promise nothing less than a full array of high-speed video, data, and voice services to the vast portions of the planet beyond the reach of today's ground-based wired and wireless networks.
"He's thinking of tens of millions of customers for satellites," said Samuel A. Farrer Jr., a Reston, Va.-based satellite expert. "No one else is talking those numbers."
Perhaps no one else would dare to. In an age of singular entrepreneurs who have achieved unfathomable wealth by leading the charge into the Information Age, the 50-year-old Mr. McCaw has been among the boldest, repeatedly going deeply into debt to buy licenses and communications properties that soared in value as he improved them and new technology spread.
Associates say they have often talked of the need to be "90 percent" certain before embarking on a new investment or strategy. "But Craig's feeling of 90 percent was often Craig alone," said Wayne Perry, who was a young Seattle attorney helping an equally youthful Mr. McCaw buy cable television companies when he went to work full time for him in 1975. "It might be 40 percent to someone else."
To understand the complexity of the challenges facing Teledesic, consider the hurdles that were already in its path when Iridium collapsed last summer.
TO START with, rapidly evolving and expanding terrestrial services have been chipping away at the parts of the world for which satellites had been the only option.
Moreover, demand for satellite systems is certain to be fragmented among services already in orbit or soon to be there. Teledesic's focus is on computer users at fixed sites rather than mobile customers like ICO Global and other satellite phone companies. But those who might compete in certain segments range from international phone companies like Globalstar, a Vodafone Airtouch PLC subsidiary, and regional operators like the Asian Cellular Satellite System as well as proposed high-capacity satellite networks from consortiums led by Hughes Electronics, Alcatel and Lockheed Martin.
In addition, Teledesic's technical feasibility is still in question. The company has missed deadlines to settle specifications with Motorola, its prime contractor -- which is expected to be replaced by Hughes Space Systems, ICO's prime contractor.
The need for overseas phone companies to sell Teledesic services locally is another risk factor. "It's a mess trying to get your partners around the world working together when it's not their core business," said J. Armand Musey, who follows the industry for Banc of America Securities in New York.
But even assuming those hurdles could be completely overcome and the service launched for $10 billion, the lowest estimates around, what then? Teledesic has just two groups of potential customers that seem out of reach of the competition: computer users in remote lands and waters who will pay for the electronic equivalent of an all-you-can-eat buffet and users in the developed world who will pay to have a backup satellite Internet connection.
"I try to construct a business model with a $10 billion investment and I can't," said Mr. Farrer. "He clearly sees things I don't."
Preternatural far-sightedness, though, is part of Mr. McCaw's track record. "He's the billionaire whom even billionaires find interesting," said O. Casey Corr, whose biography of Mr. McCaw, "Money From Thin Air," is scheduled to be published next month by Times Books/Random House.
Mr. McCaw's admirers include Bill Gates, a childhood acquaintance and now a neighbor, who put $5 million into Teledesic in 1994 after reviewing the business plan on his honeymoon. (He has since added millions more.) Mr. Gates told Fortune magazine in 1996 that Mr. McCaw "understands the communications business and where it's going better than anyone I know."
Detractors tend to have more qualms than criticisms. "I'm not sure he's a visionary," said Michael Cleamon, a San Francisco consultant who has worked with Teledesic. "He's a gambler."
LOYALISTS say that perceptions of Mr. McCaw as an extreme risk-taker underestimate his fanatic attention to escape routes from his bets and his willingness to shift course when conditions change unexpectedly.
"He always knows where the back door is," said Robert Ratliffe, a long-time aide. "I don't know of a single time where conditions have changed so much that Craig couldn't morph his position into something useful."
And therein may be the clue to Teledesic's future. Mr. McCaw and his backers could have acquired Iridium for far less than the sum they are sinking into ICO. But ICO offered a big advantage: None of its 12 planned satellites is in the air yet, and that gives Mr. McCaw's engineers a chance to tinker with the design of both the satellites and the ground stations.
The McCaw group's stated goal when ICO goes into service in 2003 is not only to sell phone service to mobile customers, as its founders originally planned, but also to deliver email and data. The data capacity will be just an hors d'oeuvre compared to the Teledesic feast, but it will be a step in the direction Mr. McCaw wants to go.
His latest plan calls for merging the two ventures as soon as possible, generating revenue from ICO to help fund Teledesic, using ICO's connections to local phone companies around the world to market Teledesic, and tailoring Teledesic's satellite network to run traffic through ICO's ground stations, which have already been linked by a high-capacity fiber network.
Some analysts suspect, though that ICO -- even if it manages to become profitable -- will be less a steppingstone than a path of retreat for Mr. McCaw from his intentions to launch and operate a full-scale Teledesic network.
After getting ICO running, step two will be to move on to Teledesic, predicts Roger Rusch of Telastra, a consulting firm in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif., that advised bondholders in the ICO bankruptcy. "But step three," he said, "will be to cancel step two."
History suggests, though, that Mr. McCaw will not abandon his grand vision simply because everyone around him sees that as the sensible option. Many of his decisions have been described as intuitive, an attribute Mr. McCaw himself has often ascribed to his severe dyslexia. Unable to digest long documents, he has become a master at sizing up the interests of those he is dealing with and staying focused on fundamental questions, like how potential customers will perceive a new service.
When his intuitions harden into conviction, associates say, even his most trusted advisers cannot budge him.
One such occasion was Mr. McCaw's decision to acquire control of Nextel in 1995, according to Tim Donahue, a longtime McCaw executive who is now chief executive of Nextel, the digital wireless carrier based in Reston, Va.
UNLIKE other cellular phone systems, Nextel grew out of the radio dispatch sector and can easily tie many users into a single conversation. Five years ago, though, Nextel was burdened by debt and by the poor quality of its two-way radio equipment from Motorola, losing hundreds of millions of dollars annually and searching for billions to build out service in the cities where it had licenses.
Mr. McCaw plunged in anyway, relying in part on Motorola's commitment to improve the system if he became involved. By 1999, Nextel's customer base had more than doubled, its stock was up 600 percent, it was branching out into foreign markets and Microsoft had decided to invest $600 million to develop Nextel Online, an Internet service for Nextel customers. Today, Mr. McCaw and his fellow investors were sitting on a $3.4 billion gain on their investment.
"He loves big problems with big opportunities," said Peter Currie, a senior executive with McCaw Cellular Communications during Teledesic's formative days.
Even Mr. McCaw's charitable interests have a way of escalating into grand schemes. His effort to return Keiko, the killer whale featured in the movie "Free Willy," to the wild has become a multi-million-dollar project to vastly extend knowledge about the lives of the orcas of the North Atlantic where Keiko, then about 2, was captured in 1979.
Mr. McCaw's career began prematurely, in tragedy. The second of four sons of J. Elroy and Marion McCaw, a socially prominent and wealthy Seattle couple, it was Craig who, on a visit home from Stanford University, discovered his father dead from a stroke. Although only 19 years old at the time, Craig had been the son most interested in the family's financial affairs, including a small cable television business where he worked during the summer, and he was quickly accepted as the primary manager of the family's interests going forward.
Sorting out Elroy's estate was no simple task. The elder McCaw had been an avid dealmaker and borrower who loathed documentation and paid little attention to the actual operations of the businesses he owned. But Craig quickly set about expanding the family's cable investments as soon as the legal clouds lifted.
In 1974, Mr. McCaw began adding paging businesses to the portfolio. Seven years later, when the Federal Communications Commission licensed the first cellular phone companies, he was an active bidder.
MR. McCaw prided himself on beating industry service standards. Unlike his father, he concluded early on that happy customers produce more revenue, which helps support more rapid expansion. But he became best known for his willingness to borrow what seemed like astronomical sums to bid aggressively for new properties, confident that they would grow rapidly enough to cover his soaring debts. He was sure that latecomers to the cellular business would pay far higher prices.
Eventually, Mr. McCaw focused on building a nationwide network of cellular phone licenses, in the belief that customers would be attracted to any service that allowed them to roam freely at a reasonable cost with a minimum of trouble. The value of such freedom seemed obvious to a man who preferred flying, kayaking, sailing and camping in remote regions of western Canada to working in his office. (Water pistol wars tend to erupt when Mr. McCaw is stuck at work too long, according to Mr. Ratliffe.)
To build up a war chest for the increasingly expensive battles for cellular territories, he unsentimentally sold his family's cable television business for $755 million in 1986 and, with the help of Michael Milken, became a major issuer of high-yield bonds.
His reputation for making risks pay off was established by the wealth generated in cable television. It exploded into the realm of business legend when he sold McCaw Cellular to AT&T for $11.5 billion in 1996.
"He is like a great painter," said Steven Rattner, who as an investment banker at Lazard Freres was involved in many of Mr. McCaw's dealings. "He doesn't paint the same thing twice, but you can see similarities in the brush strokes."
Mr. McCaw's satellite plans provide the most obvious test of such skills, but they are hardly Mr. McCaw's only concern at the moment. Through Eagle River Inc., an investment firm based in this Seattle suburb, he has controlling interests in both Nexteland Nextlink, which provides businesses with high-capacity telecommunications and Internet services in the United States and Europe. In February, Mr. McCaw gathered $470 million to fund the expansion of Nextel's network into secondary and rural markets by spinning off Nextel Partners Inc. in a public offering; the 40 percent stake controlled by McCaw through Eagle River or Nextel is currently worth almost $1.9 billion.
Mr. McCaw has said there is no grand plan to link his telecommunications empire together, but associates like Mr. Donahue, Mr. Perry, and Dan Akerson, chief executive of Nextlink, look for ways the various companies can work with each other. Nextel uses Nextlink networks, and Mr. Perry foresees both companies promoting Teledesic's capacity as a backup service for their business customers.
Mr. McCaw acknowledged that the companies could end up competing against each other in some areas. "Our dream, however, is to find ways to make competitive situations more synergistic," he said.
Not that Mr. McCaw would announce a grand plan unless forced by some business need. Teledesic came to light when the company had to file a petition for radio spectrum with the Federal Communications Commission. Those in his inner circle say he is open with them, but often difficult to read. Russell Daggett, vice chairman of Teledesic, says associates have to "connect the dots" of McCaw commentary to come up with executable plans, and Dennis Weibling, president of Eagle River and a close financial adviser since 1982, says that Mr. McCaw's good ideas come interspersed with "things that will make you bankrupt."
These days, Mr. McCaw is so wealthy that he has a greater margin of error than early in his career. After remarrying in 1998 following a bitter divorce in 1997, then becoming a father for the first time, he also has less of his life wrapped up in making his business bets pay off. Where he once kept his aircraft, yachts and other toys deployed to make business and vacations as convenient as possible, he now juggles them to support family life, although not always with the same success.
"No amount of infrastructure can keep you on schedule with kids," he recently told a bemused Mr. Ratliffe.
BUT Mr. McCaw remains fascinated by the satellite opportunity and is unlikely to retreat drastically anytime soon. His interest began in 1986, when he explored putting satellites in orbit above the Indian and western Pacific oceans to serve Asia.
It was rekindled in 1990 when Ed Tuck, a pioneer in using satellites to pinpoint the location of boaters, hikers and others with handheld transmitters, suggested using satellites in low-earth orbits for a global phone system that would not suffer the disruptive delays that plagued calls using geo-stationary satellites in high orbits.
In Mr. McCaw's hands, the vision expanded to encompass a variety of computer applications that could benefit from eliminating that signal lag, known as latency. The devil was in the details: No one could see how Teledesic could afford, much less control, the 840 satellites in the original plan, which would be constantly shifting their positions in relation to the earth's surface. Beyond that, no one had ever secured permission from regulators around the world to use the broad swath of high-frequency radio spectrum Teledesic wanted for such communications.
Mr. McCaw handed the challenge to Mr. Daggett, a lawyer by training, and has yet to look back. Today, Teledesic has its regulatory approvals. It also has big name investors like Boeing ($100 million), Motorola ($750 million, including assets from Celestri, a planned network that was folded into Teledesic), and Prince Alwaleed bin Talal of Saudi Arabia ($200 million).
Teledesic's new headquarters in Bellevue, Wash., presents a thrifty facade: it is the back half of a warehouse abutting a railroad line in an industrial section of town. But inside is a confidently over-budget mixture of cool and whimsy, complete with an on-site coffee bar.
Before the ICO deal, the apparent prosperity could not quell reports that Teledesic's progress had stalled. Indeed, if anyone but Mr. McCaw had been involved, Teledesic would probably have been dismissed long ago.
"But McCaw is someone you never bet against," said Mr. Musey.
