Chart: "Evolving Vision"
Like many of Craig O. McCaw's businesses, his Teledesic satellite venture has gone through fundamental transformations.
 
1988 -- Venture capitalist Ed Tuck envisions a global satellite phone system. Two years later, McCaw teams with Tuck, expanding the vision to include high-capacity data services.
 
1994 -- The venture, now named Teledesic, is publicly disclosed. It calls for 840 satellites orbiting 435 miles above the Earth, plus 80 spares.
 
1997 -- Boeing is named prime contractor and announces it will invest up to $100 million in Teledesic. Satellite count is reduced to 288, at about 800 miles above the Earth.
 
1998 -- Motorola, investing $750 million, folds its proposed Celestri satellite network into Teledesic and takes over as prime contractor.
 
May 2000 -- McCaw-led investors gain control of ICO Global Communications, aiming to make its 12-satellite mobile phone system a stepping stone to Teledesic. (pg. 6)
 
Chart: "Risk Taker's Record"
Over the last 30 years, Craig O. McCaw has built a succession of businesses, all linked in some way to communications. His pattern has been to go deeply into debt to buy and develop undervalued assets, then cash out after their market value has soared to pursue other growth opportunities.
 
McCAW'S JOURNEY
 
CABLE -- When his father dies in 1969, McCaw, at age 19, becomes manager of the family's cable business. In 1986, he sells the vastly expanded holdings for $755 million.
 
PAGING -- In 1974, McCaw acquires the family's first paging licenses.
 
CELLULAR -- In 1980, forms Northwest Mobile Telephone to bid for cellular telephone licenses. In 1994, McCaw Cellular is sold to AT&T for $11.5 billion.
 
In 1995, gains control of Nextel, a digital cellular system, with a $315 million initial investment.
 
SATELLITE -- In 1990, forms Calling Communications, predecessor to Teledesic; gains control of ICO Global in 2000.
 
WIRED NETWORKS -- In 1994, creates Fiberlink to invest in fiber-optic networks. In 1997, Fiberlink, now named Nextlink, goes public.

Chart: "The Circle Game"
There are two basic approaches to using satellites in telecommunications systems -- low-Earth orbit, as planned by Teledesic, and geostationary orbit. Here is how they compare:
 
Geostationary Orbit
 
ALTITUDE -- 22,000 miles above the equator.
 
POSITION -- Orbit is synchronized with the Earth's rotation, so satellites maintain fixed positions in relation to ground stations.
 
ADVANTAGE -- Relatively easy to manage.
 
PRIMARY COMMERCIAL USE -- Broadcasting
 
COMPANIES -- Hughes Electronics, PanAmSat, Intelsat, Lockheed Martin
 
Low-Earth Orbit
 
ALTITUDE -- Within a few thousand miles of the Earth.
 
POSITION -- Constantly shifting, requiring more satellites to ensure uninterrupted service.
 
ADVANTAGE -- Because the satellites are closer to Earth, there is no delay in communications, so systems can be used for real-time applications like videoconferencing or telephone calls.
 
Low capacity
PRIMARY USE: Paging
COMPANIES: Orbcomm, Vita (Volunteers in Technical Assistance)
 
Medium capacity
PRIMARY USE: Cellular phone service
COMPANIES: ICO Global, Iridium, Globalstar
 
High capacity
PRIMARY USE: Full Internet service
COMPANIES: Teledesic, Skybridge (Alcatel)(pg. 7)

HEADLINE: Donald W. Davies, 75, Dies; Helped Refine Data Networks

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
Donald W. Davies, who proposed a method for transmitting data that made the Internet possible, died Sunday at a hospice in Esher, England. He was 75 and had been suffering from cancer, according to a spokesman for the British National Physical Laboratory.
Mr. Davies was a computer security expert and team leader of a group that created one of the first computer programs to translate Russian scientific papers to English, but the work for which he was most noted grew out of concerns that conventional telephone networks were poorly suited for carrying huge amounts of data in short bursts, the ideal for computers. 
 Mr. Davies suggested in 1965 that Britain develop a network that would allow data to follow a variety of pathways. To make the network efficient, the data would be broken into small packets, each carrying a code indicating where it came from and where it was supposed to end up so that a complete document could be compiled at the receiving computer.
Packets would wend through the network on the fastest available route. If any packets were lost because of breaks in the network, only those packets would have to be sent again. He called the concept packet switching.
The concept was similar to an approach advocated by Paul Baran of the RAND Corporation, a research concern in Santa Monica, Calif. Mr. Baran's goal was to devise a system for the United States government that would be less vulnerable to a nuclear attack.
But Mr. Baran's concepts went nowhere until Roger Scantlebury, a member of Mr. Davies's development team, described the British packet switching in a talk in 1967 in Gatlinburg, Tenn., to American computer experts. Mr. Davies's ideas caught the attention of Lawrence Roberts, program director for the Advanced Research Projects Agency. Mr. Roberts had been looking for a way to improve communications among the many laboratories and universities working on research financed by the agency.
Mr. Davies was able to build a demonstration packet-switching network within the National Physical Laboratory by 1969, but the power of his ideas was more fully displayed in the United States where Mr. Roberts melded them with work by Mr. Baran and others to create Arpanet, the forerunner of today's Internet.
Donald Watts Davies was born June 7, 1924, in Treorchy, Wales, just months before the death of his father, John, a coal mine clerk. His mother, Hilda, returned to her native Portsmouth, England, to work in the post office and raise her son and his twin sister. As a teenager, he experimented with radios and read technical books on telephony.
Mr. Davies was an honors student in physics and mathematics, gaining Bachelor of Science degrees in both subjects from Imperial College in London by 1947. His academic years included a break to work for Imperial Chemical Industries and as an atomic energy researcher at Birmingham University.
His career path was set, though, shortly before graduation when he attended a lecture about the National Physical Laboratory's effort to develop a British computer. Entranced by the new technology, he joined the small development team headed by Alan Turing, the cryptography expert who had become a computing pioneer while breaking German codes during World War II.
The device the team created, the Pilot ACE, ran its first program in 1950. Mr. Davies went on to become interested in a wide variety of applications, including traffic simulators and language translation programs. Displaying a rare combination of management skills and equanimity as well as technical expertise, he rose through a series of positions at the laboratory.
"His heart was with the technical side, but he was very skillful at dealing with people," said David Yates, a longtime colleague at the laboratory.
Mr. Davies quit his administrative work in 1979 to concentrate on data security research. The group he built ended up consulting on encryption and related issues for the largest British banks and other major computer users. He continued his consulting work after retiring from the laboratory in 1984. He became a visiting professor at Royal Holloway and Bedford New College in 1987.
Mr. Davies is survived by his wife of 45 years, the former Diane Burton of Sunbury-on-Thames; two sons, Paul, of Godalming, and Michael, of Bridgeport, and a daughter, Sarah, of Kingston-on-Thames.

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Troubling the Waters Of Nuclear Deterrence

BYLINE: By MICHAEL ORESKES

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR nearly half a century the cold war world's tense stability was built on a simple bit of political philosophy. Nicknamed, appropriately, MAD, for Mutual Assured Destruction, it held that the leader of a country advanced enough to build nuclear weapons would never actually use them if he was assured his nation would also be obliterated by his enemy.
Why call this a political philosophy? Because at its core, as at the core of every political philosophy from Plato to Marx, is an appraisal of human nature. MAD's view of human nature was, paradoxically, surprisingly sunny. It held that a leader, no matter how ambitious, ideological or even nutty, would never be so far gone (or allowed to be so far gone by his cohorts) as to risk the annihilation of his own people. 
 That was the heart of deterrence: America's belief that the Russians were rational and their belief that Americans were, too.
As nuclear technology proliferates, however, the nuclear equation is becoming more complicated, and a new view of deterrence is taking hold in the United States. That view was summed up by a bipartisan report last fall from a federal advisory commission studying national security in the 21st century: Threats to American security will be more diffuse, harder to anticipate and more difficult to neutralize than ever before. Deterrence will not work as it once did; in many cases it may not work at all."
Why? Because in the post cold war world, the new thinking goes, there are some countries and leaders who simply cannot be trusted to be rational about nuclear weapons.
The old line in the sand was between two ideologies, each held by people the other believed to be capable of acting sensibly. The new line is between people who can be counted on to behave like us and people who can't. Under the old thinking the best defense was the threat of an overwhelming offense. But in the new world, the new theorists suggest, the best defense in some cases is actually a defense.
George W. Bush embraced this view in a speech recently calling for a robust missile defense of the United States. And President Clinton is in Moscow this weekend to discuss the new thinking, and his own less expansive missile defense plans, with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who holds a treaty barring the United States (or Russia) from deploying a National Missile Defense (N.M.D.).
On his way to Moscow, President Clinton gave a glimpse of the new strategic view. The world, Mr. Clinton suggested during a stop in Lisbon, can be divided between "civilized nations," and "irresponsible new nuclear powers and their possible alliances with terrorists and other groups." Rest assured, Mr. Clinton said, America would share with the civilized the technology to defend against the irresponsible.
Who belongs in this second group? Mr. Clinton named neither the civilized nations nor the irresponsible ones, although there was a hint he was prepared to include Russia in the civilized category because the very phrase was one Boris Yeltsin had once used to describe a world protected by missile defenses.
But what of China, which is on the verge of modernizing and expanding its nuclear force and openly views a system defending the continental United States as a threat to that force?
The Americans say it's not China they're worried about, either, but what the Clinton administration calls "rogue states." North Korea, for example, would fall into this category. But why is Kim Jong Il of North Korea not likely to be deterred by the threat of national devastation, if he struck at America?
To be sure, North Korea is an isolated place, the last Stalinist state and so economically troubled that people flee to China for a better life. When Mr. Kim went on a secret state visit to Beijing last week pictures released afterward showed him wearing a Mao jacket, while China's president, Jiang Zemin, was attired in suit and tie. Certainly he is behind the fashion curve. But does that mean he would risk extinction?
Since the end of the cold war there has been only one real-world test of deterrence against a so-called rogue state, and it supports those who say it remains effective. It came on the eve of the Gulf War. In a variety of ways, including a direct meeting with Tariq Aziz, the Iraqi Foreign Minister, the American secretary of state, James A. Baker, warned Saddam Hussein that the use of chemical or biological weapons against allied forces would be met by "the most severe consequences."
THE Iraqis did not use these weapons and later said they understood the American warning to mean a nuclear response.
"Saddam Hussein may have been ruthlessly expansionist, but he did not act irrationally," writes Robert S. Litwak, a former member of the national security council staff at the White House, in his book, " Rogue States and U.S. Foreign Policy" (Woodrow Wilson Center Press, 2000).
Critics of America's emerging new strategic thinking, which is to say most of the rest of the world, seem to think that the new theories of deterrence have more to do with the mind of America than the mind of Saddam Hussein or of Kim Jong Il.
Americans have always seen themselves as self- reliant, and they have placed great faith in technology. Replacing MAD with N.M.D. relieves you of a dependence on the rationality of your fellow man, in favor of an independence granted by your homegrown radar, computers and missiles. America's allies are not convinced that is an improvement, but Americans seem to be.
While acknowledging that they do not know much about it, nearly 60 percent of Americans said in a survey last month that they favor trying to build a missile defense system against nuclear attack. Told that $60 billion had already been spent, opinion remained in favor. One American in four wants to try to build the system despite the cost, even if scientists conclude it probably won't work, according to the survey, conducted by The New York Times and CBS News.
What most Americans have not begun to consider is that an anti-missile system would represent a fundamental shift in how the nation thinks about nuclear war.
In 1945, the first year of the nuclear age, Albert Einstein described atomic energy as a "menace" and added: "Perhaps it is well that it should be. It may intimidate the human race into bringing order into its international affairs, which, without the pressure of fear, it would not do."
For a half century that is what happened, more or less. What frightens some analysts is that a shield against nuclear attack on the United States would make Americans believe they are safe and thus help lift from their leaders the pressure of fear, which helps motivate the world's one superpower to work for continued order and safety in the world.

HEADLINE: Living in the Shadow of Chernobyl's Reactors

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: CHERNOBYL, Ukraine

 BODY:
They are gardening again at Chernobyl.
Rounding the last corner on the road to the destroyed reactor of Unit No. 4 at the Chernobyl nuclear power plant, the most striking discovery at the site of the worst radiation accident in history was the two young women in white masks picking gingerly at the earth with hoes and rakes. 
 They were preparing a flower bed in the shadow of the "sarcophagus," the mammoth concrete and steel structure, riddled with leaks and cracks, that now encases the shattered reactor hall where nearly 200 tons of radioactive fuel lie melted and fused with sand, concrete and other debris from the explosion and fire that erupted on April 26, 1986.
"Ordinarily, we would have had flowers growing long ago," said Katya Premak, 33, explaining why nothing was coming out of the ground so late in the spring. "But we are going very slow," she added, leaning on her hoe.
"Last week, they found a hot spot over there," she said, pointing to where a scoop of earth had set off a radiation monitor during a routine sweep. "We wear these masks because we are stirring up the dust and it can be dangerous."
To any visitor, it seems more than unusual that thousands of people still come to work here every day, 14 years after a disaster that killed 28 people outright with high radiation doses and touched off a still accelerating epidemic of thyroid cancers among children who lived downwind of the plant.
Finally, something is to change.
President Leonid Kuchma has declared that Ukraine will close the last operating reactor at Chernobyl, Unit No. 3, sometime this year. He said he would announce a specific closing date during the visit to Kiev by President Clinton on June 5 and 6.
"We ourselves want to shut down the last remaining unit," Mr. Kuchma said in an interview in Kiev, Ukraine's capital, just 80 miles to the south. "So this is not a political game. We will shut it down."
But the shutdown is only the beginning of a new chapter in the life of the ill-fated power station, whose radioactive wastes and debris must be guarded for decades, if not centuries, to prevent them from further poisoning the environment. Not only do tens of thousands of Ukrainians depend on the plant for jobs and power, but Ukraine faces an acute energy crisis, even now, before Chernobyl is closed. Despite intensive medical investigations into the health effects of the huge amount of radiation released from the explosion and fire that ripped through reactor No. 4 in 1986 after an experiment went disastrously wrong, the overall health of the plant workers remains good, though more questions than answers remain about Chernobyl's long-term effects.
The biggest question is who will pay for what needs to be done here. Since 1986, Chernobyl's endgame has been marked by unceasing recriminations among Ukraine, the United States and the world's six other wealthiest industrial nations over financing for major decommissioning projects and the replacement of Chernobyl's electrical output.
Ukraine would like to complete two nuclear power plants that were under construction in western Ukraine before the Soviet Union collapsed, but the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, responsible for Western financing, has failed to offer lending terms Ukraine can afford, in the view of Mr. Kuchma and his government.
"The electricity deficit has been catastrophic in our industries, so if we just shut down a unit that has been producing one million watts," Mr. Kuchma said, referring to Chernobyl, "it will be a complete disaster for the Ukrainian economy because nuclear power is the cheapest."
As it is, controllers from Kiev enforce rotating blackouts for as long as eight hours a day in many parts of the country.
Even if Chernobyl closes, the costs of monitoring what happens inside the sarcophagus, and keeping radiation firmly encased inside, will run on. A permanent corps of safety engineers is needed. Moreover, a new sarcophagus costing as much as $750 million will probably have to be built, since the current one rests on potentially unstable foundations and suffers from intrusions of rainwater that create clouds of humidity in the radioactive darkness, corroding the maze of pipes and steel girders and increasing the risk of collapse.
A plant for processing radioactive waste will be needed, and a $100 million heating plant and new electricity supplies to run all the support facilities. Leaders of the seven wealthiest nations have pledged about $400 million of the money needed for the sarcophagus, but Mr. Kuchma said Western aid had been slow to materialize.
"It's not like closing a big door and putting a big lock in place and then forgetting about it," he said. "We have to continue servicing this plant."
In the interview, Mr. Kuchma indicated that Ukraine would seek Russian help if necessary to replace Chernobyl's electrical output, a step that would undermine the Western goal of reinforcing Ukrainian independence at a time when President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is emphasizing the "common roots" between his country and Ukraine.
"We will probably look for a compromise with Russia because 90 percent of the equipment in these plants was made in Russia and so economically and politically it's highly profitable and interesting to the Russians," Mr. Kuchma said.
His remarks may have been intended to put pressure on the West in advance of the July meeting of the Group of Seven leaders with Russia in Okinawa, but he nevertheless is under considerable pressure at home, where the energy sector is notoriously corrupt even as major industries go begging for electricity supplies.
Then there is the question of what to do about Slavutich, the city of 28,000 built in the 1980's to house Chernobyl's corps of engineers.
Units No. 1 and 2 of Chernobyl operated until the early 1990's. Unit No. 2 was shut down in 1991 after a fire swept through its turbine hall, causing extensive damage, though not to the reactor. And President Kuchma agreed to shut down Unit No. 1 in 1994 after pledges from the Group of Seven to help finance an overall plan to decommission the Chernobyl complex -- assistance that has been halting at times.
From Slavutich, Chernobyl's denizens ride an electric train 40 minutes to "the zone," the depopulated area of abandoned farms and villages where 135,000 people once lived within an 18-mile radius of the plant.
Where once there was farmland, weeds and brambles have taken over, enveloping houses and hiding earthen mounds where radioactive trucks and bulldozers are buried, and equipment yards where irradiated helicopters that dumped tons of sand and boron on the burning reactor still are quarantined. Some pilots died from the radiation.
In man-made canals that once carried cooling water to and from the reactor, hefty carp and catfish have taken over. And in the nearby forests the swelling deer population has attracted poachers who ply the trails of the zone at night.
In the aftermath of 1986, Chernobyl became a symbol of nuclear devastation that incited a numbing fear in Ukraine and Belarus, a fear that researchers suggest has so far been more destructive to public health than the huge release of radiation. The accident also laid bare industrial incompetence and a contempt for the environment that helped to fracture the Soviet edifice.
But for the 6,000 Chernobyl workers and their dependents today in independent Ukraine, the power station represents more than anything a paycheck and a guaranteed apartment when so many in the former Soviet Union are without both.
"I was a student in electrical engineering in Moscow and came here two years after the accident," said Irina A. Kolbich, who works for the plant administration. "Frankly I came for financial reasons because living here on 1,300 rubles a month with your own apartment was better than living in Moscow on 130 rubles a month with no apartment."
Vladimir A. Komarov calls himself "a patriot of Chernobyl" because he has worked here for 20 years. "If you talk to our experts, all agree that this plant could be operated until 2006 or maybe longer," he said.
The culture of safety still is not exactly pervasive. Neither Ms. Premak nor her co-worker, Natasha Poplegina, were wearing their radiation dosimeters while gardening.
"We are supposed to wear them all the time, but I keep mine in my locker," Ms. Premak said.
In the flower bed, the radiation, though low, was about four times higher than the naturally occurring levels in the environment. "Since you don't see it, who knows what to expect anyway?" Ms. Poplegina said.
On the deck that overlooks the sarcophagus, where Vice President Al Gore stood briefly during his visit to Chernobyl in 1997, the radiation goes from 4 times to 10 times the naturally occurring level, still not necessarily dangerous but not recommended for extended exposure.
Control Room No. 3 operates Chernobyl's last functioning nuclear dynamo. On a recent afternoon, Alexander N. Yelchishev, 46, a shift supervisor, monitored the reactor closely.
A veteran of Unit No. 4, Mr. Yelchishev lost a classmate and a neighbor to radiation poisoning in 1986. Still, he remains a believer in nuclear power, and laments that the closing of Unit No. 3 will constitute a waste of about $300 million in safety improvements financed by the United States and other Western donors.
The fixes are intended to prevent the reactor from surging out of control, as Unit No. 4 did during a low power test in 1986, setting off steam and hydrogen explosions that ripped apart the graphite reactor core, blew off the roof and spewed radioactive material into the atmosphere for days.
Mr. Yelchishev does not blame the West for the pressure to close Chernobyl as much as he blames Ukraine's leaders for allowing corruption and inept reforms to retard economic development.
In the accident, about 50 tons of radioactive dust and debris was carried by winds and rain to virtually every country in the Northern Hemisphere, but the worst contamination was in the areas near the zone, especially southern Belarus.
Thyroid cancer rates have increased tenfold in Ukraine and as much as 84 times in parts of Belarus. In 1996, about 800 thyroid cancers had appeared in Ukraine and Belarus, but the numbers have since risen sharply and continue to climb.
"As of today, we have operated on about 1,500 children in Ukraine alone," said Dr. Valery P. Tereshchenko of the Institute for Endocrinology and Metabolism in Kiev.
The health effects from other long-life radioactive elements, like cesium and strontium, have been difficult to measure. There have been no clusters of leukemia or other cancers in the fallout zones where the thyroid cancers have appeared, but the latency period for other health effects may be longer, experts say.
A United Nations conference on Chernobyl concluded in 1996 that the only clear change evident in health to date was a "highly significant" increase in thyroid cancer rates among people who were children in 1986 in the affected areas.
"To tell you the truth," said Dr. Mykola D. Tronko, director of Ukraine's thyroid cancer institute, "even 14 years after the accident, we have more questions than answers."

HEADLINE: All College Graduates, Please Apply

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The 1.2 million college graduates in the nation's class of 2000 are entering an unusually strong job market that is a result of a flourishing economy and, especially, the boom in high technology.
From Northeastern University in Boston to the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena, from the University of Michigan to the University of Texas, colleges, universities and professional schools are reporting a record number of recruiters competing to hire students in a time of low unemployment. 
 Engineering students from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and other universities in the East have been flown to Silicon Valley and Seattle for audiences with billionaire executives, while investment banks have flown Stanford University students to New York for high-priced dinners accompanied by job offers.
Some of the graduates have landed jobs paying more than $60,000 a year. With unemployment near its lowest level in three decades, despite the increase in unemployment announced on Friday, salaries overall for this year's graduating class are up 6 percent over last year's, job placement experts say.
"It's gangbusters," said Carol S. Lyons, dean of the department of career services at Northeastern University. "There are even more jobs now than last year. Obviously the hot market is high-tech, but if you're any kind of a business major, you're in fine shape. And even if you're a liberal arts major there are plenty of opportunities."
But those in computer sciences are doing best of all. Many technology companies are offering signing bonuses of $5,000, with stock options often added on top. One graduate of the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., has taken an $82,000-a-year job in Silicon Valley.
This year's computer science graduates have landed jobs averaging $48,500, while graduates in accounting average $37,200 and liberal arts graduates, $29,100, according to the National Association of Colleges and Employers, which represents employers and college job placement officers.
Emily Lowe, a senior at Stanford University who majored in product design engineering with a minor in computer science, said she will earn about $60,000 next year with a software company in San Diego, and that is before the $5,000 signing bonus and stock options.
"I had five job offers, including one from a company in Arizona that agreed to fly me to San Diego every weekend to visit my fiance," she said.
But some university officials see troubles behind this bright picture. A smaller percentage of students from this year's graduating class is planning to go to graduate school. At Columbia University, administrators say, about 20 percent of this year's graduating seniors said they would attend graduate school next year, down from a high of 70 percent in decades past, usually during recessions. This trend makes many college officials fear that a smaller, and possibly less capable, group will choose to become professors.
Another problem, university officials say, is that at a time when educators and government officials see an acute need for more -- and more talented -- teachers, the lavish starting salaries offered by the private sector are drawing away potential teachers.
"The problem isn't so much the high-tech salaries, but the level of teacher salaries," said Stanley O. Ikenberry, president of the American Council on Education, an association of 3,500 colleges and universities. "Can you imagine a high school teacher of physics or mathematics receiving a paycheck that might be $25,000 a year, as opposed to the $50,000 or $75,000 in a comparable role in business? It's a tough choice for a young person to make."
Some college officials say a bidding war between technology companies, investment banks and consulting firms has pushed salary offers to record levels, with average salaries jumping nearly 20 percent from three years ago.
In one unusual episode, several Columbia University students who had accepted $45,000-a-year jobs from a New York bank were delighted this spring when the bank, fearing it would lose them to competitors, announced that it was raising their starting salaries to $55,000.
"It looks as if the starting salaries for this year's college graduates are the same as that M.B.A.'s were receiving seven years ago," said Margaret O'Hara, a senior consultant with the Hanigan Consulting Group, which advises scores of companies on hiring college graduates. "What's happened in the past few years is we've gone from being employer-centric to being employee-centric."
At Northeastern University this year, there were 440 job recruiters, up from 400 the year before. At the University of Michigan, 170 employers made presentations selling themselves to students, up from 120 last year.
"There are just too many employers chasing too few students," said Patricia Rose, director of career services at the University of Pennsylvania.
Frustrated that there are not enough qualified college graduates, many high-technology companies have pressed President Clinton to nearly double, to 200,000, the number of annual visas for skilled foreign workers.
University officials say the high demand for skilled workers has created improper dealings. Some companies, eager to catch their prey, have made what are called "exploding offers" -- students are told they have 24 hours to accept a job offer or the offer disappears.
Pressured by such offers, students accept and, after continuing to look or after stumbling upon something more attractive, a few renege on those offers and take other jobs.
"There are some downsides to this wonderful market," said Robert Thirsk, director of career development services at Stanford University. "Exploding offers put students in a very precarious position. We tell these companies, 'You put the student in a difficult situation of having to make a decision like that. What do you think they're going to do?' When students renege on offers, it's usually because they haven't been given enough time to think about it."
Stanford has told employers that beginning this fall companies that recruit on campus must give students at least three weeks to respond to job offers.
The giddy job situation at colleges is giddier yet at business schools. There, $25,000 signing bonuses are common, and some companies fly not just prospective employees, but their spouses, cross-country.
Erin Cochrane, director of career services at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth, said the average base salary for this year's M.B.A. graduates is $90,000, up from $80,000 last year. She said overall median first-year compensation is actually $135,000, after adding in signing bonuses, a guaranteed first-year bonus and employers' paying a student's second-year business school tuition.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
For Corzine and Florio, Money Bags vs. Baggage

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 3

 BODY:
The state's newspapers are falling in behind Jim Florio. The party establishment is squarely backing Jon S. Corzine. The airwaves are full of nasty commercials about each of the Senate candidates. So what is a Democratic voter to do?
The New Jersey primary season, which culminates in Tuesday's election, has been the most competitive in a generation. The retirement of Frank R. Lautenberg left a Senate seat open for the first time in decades. And though the Republican primary drew four reasonably experienced but little-known contenders, the Democratic contest between Mr. Florio, the former governor, and Mr. Corzine, who spent tens of millions to gain name recognition, gave rise to a rarity in state politics -- a match between two household names. 
 "This is a singular story in New Jersey," said Clifford Zukin, a longtime political observer and director of The Star-Ledger/Eagleton Poll. "We've never had a marquee matchup like this between two people universally known by the citizenry."
Because the race has been so hard fought and so well publicized, it has confronted voters with an unusual number of important questions.
Mr. Corzine, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, arose as the answer to a search by Democratic officials for an anyone-but-Florio candidate. Even though Mr. Florio remains popular with many rank-and-file Democrats, he was considered by party leaders to be unelectable in November because of the memory of a $2.8 billion tax increase he pushed through the Legislature as governor in 1990.
Mr. Corzine's appeal to voters, not surprisingly, has been framed as a choice between an unhappy memory, embodied by Mr. Florio, and Mr. Corzine's own idealized vision for the future, with strict gun controls and ambitious new programs for health care, education and long-term care for the elderly and disabled. But to judge from the attack commercials Mr. Corzine has been running for more than a month, it remains, at its root, a not-Florio campaign.
Mr. Florio, too, has naturally cast the race in terms that suit him. For months, he described the primary as a choice between his 30 years of experience in government and Mr. Corzine's naivete.
More recently, Mr. Florio has seized upon Mr. Corzine's unprecedented campaign spending, asking voters whether they cared to let Mr. Corzine buy the election.
Voters can seize on a few issues on which the men hold opposing views. Mr. Corzine opposes the death penalty, and Mr. Florio favors it, for example. And Mr. Corzine supports a limited investment of the Social Security trust fund in the stock market, to extend the fund's solvency, a position Mr. Florio has vilified in the starkest terms. But the sharp line between the men on this subject was blurred when it was reported that Mr. Florio's and Mr. Corzine's positions were identical as recently as a year ago.
There are more subtle questions, too. A vote for Mr. Corzine's platform, for example -- with its hard-line support for abortion rights, gay rights, affirmative action, gun control and big government programs -- would seem to represent an embrace of the kind of liberalism that has been out of fashion for decades.
Mr. Florio, meanwhile, has in many ways made his own campaign a referendum on the nation's economic boom, warning voters that the fantastic wealth created by the new economy has momentarily obscured looming problems on issues like Social Security and pension financing. Mr. Florio has hammered away at Mr. Corzine on trade policy, corporate mergers and government borrowing. In doing so, he has employed the kind of class-based attacks Democrats often aim at Republicans.
If there is one watchword in the primary, however, it is electability. On the Republican side, voters must pick a contender for November from a field of four relatively unknown candidates: William L. Gormley, a veteran state senator from the south; Robert D. Franks, a four-term congressman from New Jersey's prosperous midsection; James W. Treffinger, a county executive in predominantly Democratic Essex County; and Murray Sabrin, a former Libertarian candidate for governor. In this race, where turnout is expected to be light, party endorsements are likely to play a heavy role.
On the Democratic side, every attack that Mr. Florio and Mr. Corzine employ can be reduced to the idea that only one of them has a reasonable chance to prevail in November. To Mr. Florio, his foe is too left-wing, too soft. To Mr. Corzine, Mr. Florio is too combative to win over even the most moderate Republicans.
"Democratic voters have to ask themselves whether they're selecting a candidate, be it Florio or Corzine, who can win," said Gerald M. Pomper, a political science professor at Rutgers University. "Primaries are about such practical calculations. After all, you're selecting somebody to carry the party's banner, not just somebody you like."

HEADLINE: CLINTON AND PUTIN MEET AT KREMLIN WITH WIDE AGENDA

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 3

 BODY:
In his final visit to Moscow as president, Bill Clinton arrived here today and dined tonight with Russia's new president, Vladimir V. Putin, at the Kremlin palace, where the two leaders made a "very serious and focused beginning" on a full range of issues, including the search for a compromise on antimissile defense.
During a nearly three-hour working dinner, the two men also discussed the American-Russian nuclear relationship, ongoing conflicts in the Balkans and the Caucasus, international trade and the state of the Russian economy, said a senior Administration official who sat in on the talks. 
 The official described the talks as "businesslike," "congenial" and "easygoing."
"Businesslike is good; businesslike is good," the official said, putting a positive cast on the talks, but declining to discuss them except in the vaguest terms. "Remember that the two presidents do know each other, and that was quite apparent from the beginning."
Mr. Clinton met Mr. Putin twice last year when he was prime minister, once at a tribute in Oslo to the late Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin and a second time at the annual economic summit of Pacific Rim countries, but the talks that started today and will continue through Sunday represent their first face-to-face encounter since Mr. Putin was elected president in March.
During their talks, Mr. Putin spoke some English and both leaders showed an enthusiasm to hear out the other's position on items of dispute, the administration official said. But he acknowledged that the initial exchanges lacked the first-name familiarity that characterized the relationship between Mr. Clinton and Russia's last president, Boris N. Yeltsin, where it was always Boris and Bill.
After a dinner of cold boiled boar, baked ham and cabbage and goose with berry sauce, Mr. Putin led Mr. Clinton on a tour of the residence, showing him a personal study, a small chapel, a gym and a massage room. The leaders settled into armchairs in an intimate wood-paneled theater for a jazz tribute to Louis Armstrong, conducted by one of Russia's best-known band leaders, Oleg Lundsrem.
Mr. Clinton has arrived to find Mr. Putin absorbed with domestic politics, a wrenching set of economic reforms just getting under way and an unresolved war in Chechnya.
At the same time, Mr. Clinton has come to a Russia that is relatively stable, poised for economic recovery and more politically united -- though disputes abound -- than at any time since the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991.
This is a sharp contrast with Mr. Clinton's most recent visits here -- in 1996 when former President Yeltsin was fighting for his political life against an entrenched Communist opposition, and in 1998 when the Russian ruble and much of the country's economy had collapsed.
Like a younger Bill Clinton eight years ago (Mr. Clinton was 46 when he entered office; Mr. Putin is 47), Mr. Putin has taken command of the Kremlin with an apparent determination to focus on his country's economic problems and other pressing domestic issues while keeping things quiet on the foreign policy front. There, America still looms as an enormous force in Russia's calculations on everything from financial assistance and debt restructuring to NATO expansion and arms control.
Mr. Clinton is seeking agreement to modify a 1972 treaty and thus go ahead with a national antimissile defense; Russia has so far refused.
Right after his inauguration last month, Mr. Putin, a former K.G.B. officer, stirred liberal fears about his commitment to democracy when heavily armed police raided the offices of a top news media organization. On Sunday, Mr. Clinton will sit for a radio interview -- with live questions from the audience over the Internet -- on the popular Ekho Moskvy station run by the media group in what is intended as a gesture of support for freedom of the press in Russia.
On Monday, Mr. Clinton will address the Russian Duma, or lower house of Parliament, which has formed a strong pro-reform, and pro-Putin majority since elections last December, though many battles over land ownership, regional autonomy and national investment lie ahead.
The economic reality that Russia faces was highlighted most glaringly by Mr. Putin himself after he was named acting president on New Year's Eve when Mr. Yeltsin resigned.
"To reach the production level of Portugal and Spain, two countries that are not known as leaders of the world economy," Mr. Putin said, "it will take Russia approximately 15 years" even under optimistic growth assumptions of 8 percent a year. Only twice in the 20th century, he said, had Russia been so weak, "after the October Revolution in 1917, and in the 1990's."
Mr. Putin, as a political unknown whose disposition to the Western eye is somewhat dour, seems unlikely to achieve with Mr. Clinton the easy-going "Boris and Bill" chemistry that dominated during Mr. Yeltsin's two terms.
Under Mr. Putin, still very much the man in the gray suit, a more pragmatic and businesslike style prevails these days in the Kremlin, though he has bonded in an openly friendly manner with Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain.
And Mr. Putin has betrayed a certain admiration for Mr. Clinton. When the two leaders met last fall in New Zealand at a meeting of Asian-Pacific leaders, Mr. Putin was still a novice prime minister, whose popularity among Russians was soaring due to his resolute prosecution of the war in Chechnya. Mr. Putin admitted to a group of interviewers from the newspaper Kommersant that he was charmed by Mr. Clinton.
"In that first meeting, he paid special attention to me," Mr. Putin said, referring to Mr. Clinton. "He made a point of coming up to me. We had been seated at different tables. We talked about something for a while, and then he said, 'Well, shall we go?' All the heads of state lined up. And he and I walked together along that corridor. We exited the hall to the sound of applause. I appreciated this sign of special regard," Mr. Putin said.
While clearly Mr. Putin has strong views, especially on NATO expansion and on the restoration of Russian power and national dignity in international affairs, he has shown great pragmatism in avoiding confrontation with the West, where he says he sees Russia's future as a European nation.
Mr. Clinton adopted that theme on Friday, when he used a speech accepting a prestigious European award to appeal to western Europeans to admit Russia, eventually, to both NATO and the European Union.
One of the problems facing Mr. Clinton is that both leaders know that history has assigned them different time slots in different decades. Mr. Clinton is almost at the end of his term and Mr. Putin is just embarking on his. And this difference in phase may do more to define the psychology at this summit meeting than any other factor.
Mr. Clinton has come here seeking to make progress on his proposal to build a system of national missile defense that requires an agreement to amend the treaty banning such nationwide systems signed by Moscow and Washington more than 30 years ago.
If accepted by Russia, the American proposal represents a profound turning point from offensive to defensive strategies by the world's two largest nuclear powers, one with the potential to reignite an arms race and alienate China, whose small nuclear arsenal would loose its deterrent credibility. Mr. Putin sent his foreign minister to New York last month to warn at the United Nations that America's missile defense plans could destabilize three decades of arms control agreements.
However, in an interview just before Mr. Clinton's arrival with "The NBC Nightly News," Mr. Putin hinted that the United States and Russia might collaborate on new ways to shoot down enemy missiles soon after they were launched, and thus address the problems posed by nuclear weapons being acquired by so-called rogue states. Mr. Clinton says the United States seeks an antimissile defense only to address that threat, although the Russians and Chinese are skeptical that this is the true purpose.
Although Mr. Putin will certainly engage Mr. Clinton's arguments, the Russian leader knows that he also has the luxury to wait for the next American president. That gives him an advantage over Mr. Clinton, who is in a hurry to improve the final cornice work of his presidency.
On the domestic front, Mr. Putin has opened his term with a strategy to strengthen federal power over Russia's vast region in preparation for slogging economic reforms. He has also has proposed legislation to gut and remake the upper house of Parliament and bolster the independence of the judiciary. His proposals appear so sweeping that his critics have attacked him for trying to recreate the vertical power structure of the Soviet Union.
The Russian leader's personal views on the subject have only deepened those concerns. "From the very beginning, Russia was created as a supercentralized state," he told interviewers this spring. "That's practically laid down in its genetic code, its traditions and the mentality of its people."

LENGTH: 857 words

HEADLINE: Third Parties Make Choices In Senate Race

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, June 3

 BODY:
With as much relief as enthusiasm, New York's Conservative and Liberal Parties reverted to type today, endorsing Rick A. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton for the Senate after both parties had endured a queasy several months that had left their nominations in doubt.
Less than two weeks into his campaign, Mr. Lazio, a congressman little known beyond his district in Long Island, has been working to establish himself in voters' minds as a centrist, but today his campaign veered to the right. Addressing the Conservative Party's nominating convention at a hotel a few blocks from the state Capitol, he promised "a crusade," offering up a list of favorite conservative causes, like tax cuts, the death penalty, longer prison terms and greater military spending. 
 He also spoke of the issue most identified with the Conservatives in recent years: what opponents call partial-birth abortion. "There is no place in our society for the gruesome procedure partial-birth abortion," he said to enthusiastic applause.
A few hours earlier, at the Hotel Inter-Continental in Manhattan, where Mrs. Clinton accepted the Liberal Party endorsement, she and the state party's leader, Raymond B. Harding, said Mr. Lazio was more conservative than the man he replaced as the Republican candidate, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York.
"In many ways my views are closer to those of the mayor than those of my opponent," Mrs. Clinton said. "He is out of step with the mainstream.
"My views are centrist views, positive views," she added at a news conference.
The day's events highlighted the danger to Mr. Lazio -- that the Conservative Party's backing can be both an aid and a burden -- as both candidates try to claim the political middle ground. Unlike the Liberals, the Conservatives still hew to an ideology in keeping with their name, taking strong stands against abortion, gay rights, affirmative action and big government. And the party's ready embrace of Mr. Lazio as a real conservative contrasts sharply with its rejection of Mr. Giuliani as too moderate.
Mr. Lazio said nothing to distance himself from the Conservative Party, even as he obliquely acknowledged that the affiliation could be used against him. "The other side is going to try to demonize me," he said. "They're going to try to demonize you, too."
He also peppered his speech with attacks on Mrs. Clinton, who barely mentioned him today. "You won't catch us trying to nationalize one-seventh of our economy," Mr. Lazio said, a reference to Mrs. Clinton's failed plan to restructure the nation's health care system. He reminded his audience several times that Mrs. Clinton was new to New York, saying, "I was able to jump into this race without a listening tour because I've been listening to New York all my life."
Of Mrs. Clinton, he said, "She comes to New York with the support of every left-wing special-interest group, from Washington insiders to the Hollywood elite."
As long as Mr. Giuliani was the presumptive Republican nominee, the race had both the Liberal and Conservative Parties in turmoil. The Liberals, whose longstanding support of Mr. Giuliani had alienated many Democrats, faced an internal battle over which side to take.
The state Conservative Party chairman, Michael L. Long, vowed that his party would not support the mayor because he was not conservative enough, especially on abortion. Party leaders said they would nominate someone to Mr. Giuliani's right, even if undermining him meant helping Mrs. Clinton and damaging the Conservatives' relationship with the Republican Party. But the Conservatives were having some trouble finding a candidate of their own.
But when Mr. Giuliani dropped out of the race last month, and the Republicans nominated Mr. Lazio, the battle lines became clear and the Liberals and Conservatives fell into their comfortable old roles as contentious allies of the major parties.
Conservative delegates said today that they were relieved to be able to unite with the Republicans, and, one after another, they said abortion was the key issue. "Abortion is the big difference between Lazio and Giuliani," said Viola Hunter of Syracuse, the party's vice chairwoman. "We're not a one-issue party, but it is a very vital, important issue."
Mr. Lazio supports legal abortion, but unlike Mrs. Clinton -- and Mr. Giuliani -- he opposes government financing for it, and would ban what he calls partial-birth abortion.
In nominating Mrs. Clinton, the Liberal Party went some distance toward mending its frayed relationship with the Democratic Party. The Liberals had alienated many Democrats by backing the mayor, and by refusing to support the Democratic nominee for governor in 1998, Peter F. Vallone, and instead nominating Lt. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross.
The Conservative Party has fewer than 2 percent of the state's registered voters, and the Liberal Party fewer than 1 percent, but they wield an influence beyond their size. In recent statewide elections, Republican candidates have pulled as many as 300,000 votes on the Conservative line, while Democrats often get well over 100,000 on the Liberal line.

HEADLINE: Merton H. Miller, 77, Nobel Winner in Economics

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Merton H. Miller, a professor of finance who won the 1990 Nobel in economic science for helping develop theories that were used to evaluate the risks of individual investments, died yesterday at his home in Chicago. He was 77 and had been suffering from lymphoma, said Allan Friedman, a spokesman for the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business.
Mr. Miller's ideas have been credited with changing Wall Street and the investment habits of millions of Americans. Until Mr. Miller and Franco Modigliani, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, developed the theories, it was generally assumed that companies could raise capital cheaply by borrowing or raise it safely by issuing more stock. 
 But the pivotal Miller-Modigliani theory, published in a 1958 paper, held what has become the most basic tenet of corporate financing: that the value of a company is determined by its investment decisions and not by its financing choices.
In a statement yesterday, Robert Hamada, the dean of the University of Chicago business school, said Mr. Miller was "the founder of modern finance and the person who fathered the discipline from an institutional field of study to one that is truly a legitimate and well-accepted part of economics and business."
Mr. Miller taught at the business school for 32 years.
His theory was based on the notion that while more corporate debt might make profits vary from year to year, the extra risk should not affect a stock's price because conservative investors could always "deleverage" their assets by holding more of a low-risk asset, like a bank deposit. Mr. Miller could be viewed as among "the intellectual fathers of the mutual fund" for this work, Robert Litan, an economist at the Brookings Institution, once said. Mr. Miller was also known for showing corporations the tax benefits of repurchasing their stock rather than paying dividends, now a common practice.
Merton Howard Miller was born in Boston. He received a bachelor's degree from Harvard University in 1943. He worked as an economist in the Treasury Department and at the Federal Reserve during World War II before earning a doctorate in economics in 1952 from Johns Hopkins University.
After appointments at the London School of Economics and Carnegie-Mellon University, Mr. Miller joined the University of Chicago faculty in 1961, and remained there until his retirement in 1993.
Mr. Miller's first wife, Eleanor, died in 1969. He is survived by his wife, Katherine; three daughters, Margot Horn, Pamela Chwedyk and Louise Lorber; and two grandsons.

HEADLINE: William E. Simon, Ex-Treasury Secretary And High-Profile Investor, Is Dead at 72

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
William E. Simon, who directed the nation's energy policy and served as treasury secretary in the dark economic days of the 1970's and then proved to have a golden touch as an investor in the boom days of the 1980's, died yesterday at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 72 and lived in Santa Barbara.
The cause of death was complications from pulmonary fibrosis, a lung disease that he had been fighting for more than a year, said James Piereson, executive director of the John M. Olin Foundation in New York, where Mr. Simon was president. . 
 A conservative Republican, Mr. Simon left a successful Wall Street career as a bond trader in 1973 to join Richard Nixon's administration as deputy treasury secretary. He went on to become director of the Federal Energy Office -- or "energy czar," as he was known -- later that year when the economy reeled in the wake of the Arab oil embargo, and in April 1974 he was named treasury secretary, a post he retained when Gerald R. Ford succeeded Nixon.
After leaving office at the end of the Ford administration, Mr. Simon returned to Wall Street, where he became emblematic of a breed of aggressive investor. In 1982, Mr. Simon and a partner, Raymond G. Chambers, paid $80.5 million, almost all of it borrowed, to purchase Gibson Greetings, a card maker, in one of the first high-profile leveraged buyouts.
Fourteen months later they sold the company in a public offering to shareholders for $290 million, yielding Mr. Simon and Mr. Chambers a profit of $70 million each and creating a mystique about Mr. Simon's investing prowess that was only partly tarnished in recent years by a string of disappointing deals.
Mr. Simon also served as the United States Olympic Committee's treasurer from 1977 to 1980, and as its president for the subsequent four years, playing important roles in the American decision to boycott the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow, and in planning the 1984 games in Los Angeles.
William Edward Simon was born on Nov. 27, 1927, in Paterson, N.J. His father was an insurance agent, and he lived a middle-class life through the Depression. After graduating from high school in 1946, he served in the Army and then enrolled at Lafayette College, in Easton, Pa., where he met Carol Girard. They were married in 1950.
After graduating from Lafayette in 1952, he got a $75-a-week job trading municipal bonds. By 1964, he was working at Salomon Brothers, where he was known as a quick-tempered, outspoken and very skilled bond trader. Within Salomon's aggressive culture, his sometimes-abrasive personality was no drawback. By the early 1970's, he was one of the firm's senior partners and was earning more than $2 million a year.
On the recommendation of Attorney General John Mitchell, a former Wall Street lawyer, Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz recruited Mr. Simon as his deputy at the beginning of Nixon's second term. Even as the Watergate scandal was beginning to envelop the White House, Mr. Simon was enmeshed in another national crisis, the embargo imposed by Arab oil producers on nations friendly to Israel.
By the end of 1973, Mr. Simon was coordinating the administration's efforts to encourage conservation and to allocate scarce supplies of oil -- favoring factory production and home heating oil over gasoline for motorists. It was a job that brought him criticism from all sides, not least from consumers, who resented gasoline shortages and high prices.
"I'm the guy that caused the lines at the gas stations," Mr. Simon once said.
But Mr. Simon seemed sufficiently thick skinned to cope and more than willing to fight back.
"We have become a nation of great energy wastrels," he said in 1973. He publicly chastised another administration official for crossing him, saying the official should "keep his cotton pickin' hands off energy policy." He labeled statements by the shah of Iran, then a key ally of the United States, "irresponsible and reckless."
By early 1974, the country was in a recession, and when Mr. Shultz resigned as treasury secretary, Nixon quickly named Mr. Simon to replace him. Mr. Simon spent much of his time on international policy, pressing Arab nations to reinvest the dollars they were reaping through oil sales in the United States and creating an international credit line for poor nations that had been hurt by soaring energy costs.
At home, with inflation rising, he counseled against deficit spending to stimulate the economy, in keeping with his fiscal conservatism. In 1975, he created a political firestorm when he helped persuade President Ford not to bail New York City out of its deep financial crisis. He argued that coming to New York's aid would encourage profligacy among other cities.
"Then came the New York fiscal crisis, and I was Genghis Khan," he recalled a dozen years later.
Under pressure from bankers, who countered that if New York City were to default on its debt, it could reverberate through markets around the world, Mr. Simon and Mr. Ford ultimately agreed to aid the city.
After Jimmy Carter was elected in 1976, Mr. Simon left Washington and became a consultant to investment firms and businesses, as well as becoming treasurer of the Olympic committee, for which he had raised funds before entering government service.
In 1980, when President Carter urged the committee to boycott the Moscow Olympics that summer to protest the Soviet presence in Afghanistan, most American amateur sports officials and athletes were opposed. Mr. Simon's impassioned speech to the committee's house of delegates in favor of the boycott swung the vote.
The next year, when Mr. Simon was elected president of the Olympic committee by acclamation, the organization was $9 million in debt and had to meet an $88 million budget for the next four years. The boycott had hurt fund-raising.
But Mr. Simon turned potential doom into a financial bonanza by having the Olympic committee become an equal partner with the Los Angeles Olympic organizers. Despite a retaliatory boycott by the Soviet Union and most of its allies, those Olympics earned $225 million.
The Olympic committee, with its 40 percent share and an additional $35 million from the Olympic coin program, created the United States Olympic Foundation as a permanent financial source for American amateur sports. That became the major legacy of Mr. Simon's era at the committee.
During the same period, Mr. Simon was building a fortune with his investments in leveraged buyouts, of which the Gibson Greetings deal was the best known. The company he operated in partnership with Mr. Chambers, Wesray, bought undervalued companies with borrowed money, whipped them into shape or waited until a willing buyer appeared, and then sold them, often for hefty profits. By the late 1980's, Forbes magazine was estimating Mr. Simon's wealth at $300 million.
But his partnership with Mr. Chambers came apart in 1986, as Mr. Simon turned to building a network of financial institutions on the West Coast and across the Pacific.
He had some success purchasing banks and failed savings and loan associations and reselling them, but he never approached his stated goal of building a trans-Pacific merchant banking empire. In 1993, federal regulators seized one of his properties, Western Federal Savings and Loan, when it sank into insolvency.
In recent years, Mr. Simon had dedicated more of his time to philanthropy and charitable work.
He gradually turned much of the responsibility for his business over to his two sons, William E. Simon Jr., and J. Peter Simon.
In 1996, Mr. Simon received the Blessed Hyacinth Cormier Award for outstanding Catholic leadership, and in 1999, he was honored by the Olympic committee.
Mr. Simon's first wife, Carol, died in 1995. He is survived by his second wife, Tonia Adams Donnelley, whom he married in 1996, and by seven children from his first marriage. In addition to his two sons, they are Mary Beth Simon Streep; Carol Leigh Simon Porges; Aimee Simon Bloom; Julie Ann Simon Munro and Johanna Katrina Simon.

HEADLINE: Fund-Raiser May Be Achilles' Heel for Gore

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
Fred Baron has perhaps the best party house for fund-raisers in the whole state of Texas, a 15,000-square-foot Dallas house designed by Robert A. M. Stern. And Mr. Baron, a wealthy plaintiffs' lawyer, has plenty of rich friends to fill it.
So when he agreed last year to work as a big fund-raiser for Vice President Al Gore, he had all the right tools. 
 In a few weeks, Mr. Baron, 52, will be the new president of the powerful Association of Trial Lawyers of America, which has vowed to do everything it can to defeat Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who has long made curbing civil litigation and limiting jury awards and lawyers' fees a centerpiece of his campaign.
But while Mr. Baron has given Mr. Gore a great fund-raising boost, he has also given the Republicans a ready target in their campaign to link Mr. Gore to the image of greedy trial lawyers.
Several years ago, asbestos defense lawyers seized on a memorandum written by a paralegal in Mr. Baron's law firm, and charged in court papers that it had been used to coach the testimony of witnesses in asbestos cases. The document received wide publicity at the time, and conservative columnists and politicians have used it to repeatedly pound Mr. Baron. Asbestos companies have used it to castigate him in advertisements.
The attacks on Mr. Baron come as the trial lawyers engage in what is probably their most critical and intensely fought presidential election. Beyond picking judges, the next president will shape federal policy on issues in which the trial lawyers have a big stake. The lawyers have taken the lead in major legal battles against big tobacco companies and, with help from the federal government, are seeking to make it easier to sue gun manufacturers and health maintenance organizations.
Mr. Bush has long cited tort reform -- laws that restrict civil litigation and limit jury awards -- as one of his greatest accomplishments as governor of Texas, and has said that if elected president he would take it to the federal level.
"This election goes right to where trial lawyers live," said Scott Harshbarger, the president of Common Cause and a former Democratic attorney general of Massachusetts.
Not surprisingly, lawyers like Mr. Baron are fighting back. In 1999, trial lawyers, who historically give the bulk of their contributions to Democrats, gave $4.4 million to Democratic candidates and political committees. That figure was two and a half times more than they gave in the same 12-month period during the previous presidential cycle, according to Common Cause. And many trial lawyers were among the big givers at a gala Democratic dinner on May 24 in Washington that raised $26 million.
It is against this backdrop that Mr. Baron, whose firm gave $135,000 in campaign contributions to Democrats in 1999, finds himself pushing the interests of trial lawyers, while defending his own reputation as a bruising litigator.
"I walk around with a bull's-eye on my head," said Mr. Baron, a short, trim man who wears expensive suits and wire-rim glasses.
Mr. Baron has long said that the controversial memorandum was written by an overzealous paralegal, who subsequently swore in court papers that she was its author. The document, which emerged in 1997, instructed claimants never to testify that they saw a warning label on asbestos packages or knew about its dangers. Some asbestos companies sought court-ordered sanctions against Mr. Baron's firm, and a Texas judge asked a state district attorney to investigate the memorandum. The United States attorney's office in Dallas also apparently made some preliminary inquiries into the matter, according to people who said they were interviewed by federal investigators.
Those inquiries, however, soon fizzled out. Also, several lower court findings by Texas state courts against Mr. Baron's firm were thrown out on appeal. Mr. Baron said he was also confident that the last legal dispute over the document, which is in an Ohio state court case, would be resolved in his favor.
As a result, Mr. Baron has declared himself and his firm exonerated. Still, even as he takes over a group that is a cornerstone of Mr. Gore's support, he remains haunted by the document and its implications of witness coaching.
It was cited earlier this year in newspaper advertisements paid for by the GAF Corporation, an asbestos producer, and others then pressing Congress for legislation limiting asbestos lawsuits. "You should be aware of the FACTS concerning Baron and his modus operandi," proclaimed one advertisement, which described the memorandum as one of his many "flagrant abuses" that make a "mockery of our legal system."
Walter Olsen, an adviser to Mr. Bush on tort reform, said he was surprised that the trial lawyers' group elected Mr. Baron president, given the document's controversy.
"The idea that he is going to be representative of a whole industry after the disclosure of the memo suggests a boldness on their part or an imperviousness to public criticism," said Mr. Olsen, a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute, a research group, who has written articles critical of Mr. Baron.
Mr. Baron said that tort-reform advocates like Mr. Olsen and conservative opinion shapers like the editorial page of The Wall Street Journal had kept the memorandum controversy alive as a way of smearing him. To defend himself he has hired legal troubleshooters like Abbe Lowell, the chief investigative counsel for the Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee during the impeachment proceedings against President Clinton.
But he has also struck back at his accusers with zeal. Some companies that filed legal challenges against Mr. Baron's firm over the legal document soon found themselves negotiating settlement deals favorable to him after he threatened to bring more asbestos claims against them. And he has intensified his pursuit of a former asbestos company executive who Mr. Baron contends spearheaded the assault against him, charging in court papers that the executive stole millions earmarked for asbestos claims.
"I learned early that it's best to let the other guy take the first shot," Mr. Baron said. "And then you come back at him."
It is a tactic Mr. Baron has used frequently in a career that has mirrored the transition of many trial lawyers from scrappy advocates for workers and consumers to wealthy businessmen eager to influence policies and politics.
These days, Mr. Baron, who was also a major contributor to President Clinton, plays golf with the president and dines several times a year at the White House. In recent years, he has been the host of a party for the Democratic National Committee at its annual retreat in Aspen, Colo., where he and his wife, Lisa Blue, a former prosecutor who is now a partner in his firm, have a second home.
A graduate of the University of Texas Law School, Mr. Baron went to work in the early 1970's for a Dallas law firm whose clients included the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union. He was asked to look at conditions at an asbestos insulation plant in Texas and said he found them appalling.
"It was disgusting," he said. "People were working in there shoveling up asbestos and they weren't even wearing masks."
He soon joined forces with a small group of lawyers around the country who had uncovered documents showing that asbestos producers like the Johns Manville Corporation long knew that asbestos, a mineral fiber that is now banned, could cause fatal diseases. By the 1980's, thousands of workers exposed to asbestos had filed lawsuits and Mr. Baron's firm, Baron & Budd, would eventually handle more claims than any other.
Before long, he was an extremely wealthy man whose political influence and contributions were felt in elections for Texas state judges, both Democrats and Republicans said in interviews.
"Fred is a very likable guy who throws a lot of parties," said Tom Pauken, who was chairman of the Texas Republican Party from 1994 to 1997. "He pays close attention to who is running and who isn't, and he has an ability to influence the process."
Mr. Baron also played a critical role in a 1997 United States Supreme Court decision that still hangs over asbestos cases today. At the time, some major lawyers representing asbestos claimants, including some of Mr. Baron's longtime colleagues, struck a deal with producers under which all current and future asbestos cases would be settled as part of a huge class-action lawsuit.
But Mr. Baron, who opposes the use of class-action lawsuits as a means of resolving legal disputes, led the fight against the plan. He poured $4 million into opposing it, hiring experts like Prof. Laurence H. Tribe of Harvard Law School to argue against it before the Supreme Court, which struck down the settlement as unconstitutional.
Some critics asserted that Mr. Baron's motive was profit, not legal principles, saying that his once pioneering firm had evolved into an asbestos "mill" that raked in a large fee for every claim it handled, and that the stream of cases would have been shut off under the settlement. But even some supporters of the plan disagreed.
"Opposing the case was in Baron's economic interest but he is a more complex person," said John Aldock, a lawyer for a consortium of asbestos companies involved in the failed plan.
By the late 1990's, Mr. Baron said, he decided it was crucial for him to get involved in the trial lawyers' lobbying group as its battles with advocates of tort reform intensified. One possible inspiration: Mr. Bush signed the sweeping tort reform bill in Texas in 1997, ending a legal mechanism that Mr. Baron had helped engineer.
Under it, asbestos claims from other states could be filed in Texas state courts. Ralph Wayne, the president of the Texas Civil Justice League, a tort reform group in Austin, said a 1996 study by his group found that Mr. Baron's firm had filed the majority of the roughly 56,000 out-of-state asbestos claims pending in Texas courts.
Mr. Wayne said that many of those cases had been filed in Texas jurisdictions with reputations for high jury awards.
"He knows courts in Texas and he knows where to file the cases," Mr. Wayne said of Mr. Baron.
It was also around that time that the memorandum controversy erupted. While a lawyer from Mr. Baron's firm turned over the document to defense lawyers in pretrial testimony in an asbestos case, the lawyer said that publicity about it was fueled by a former asbestos company executive who had been his longtime nemesis.
Over the past decade, Mr. Baron and that executive, Craig Smith, a former top official of the Raymark Corporation, have waged a lengthy court battle over the assets of the bankrupt concern. In 1988, a federal judge in Oregon found that Mr. Smith had engaged in a number of complex business transactions in a bid to escape Raymark's asbestos liabilities.
More recently, Mr. Baron and others said in court papers filed in United States District Court in Hartford that Mr. Smith and members of his family engaged in a scheme to illegally divert millions of dollars earmarked for asbestos claims for their own benefit.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Smith, who now runs a business in Wales, denied any wrongdoing in the bankruptcy proceeding. But he acknowledged meeting with Federal Bureau of Investigation officials in 1997 to encourage the agency to look at the controversial memorandum. He also said he hired lawyers who, among other things, filed lawsuits against Mr. Baron and other asbestos lawyers.
Mr. Smith insisted, however, that his actions were driven not by any animus toward Mr. Baron but by his belief that many of the asbestos claims filed by the Texas law firm were groundless.
"I believe they are undermining the industrial strength of this country," Mr. Smith said.
Mr. Baron's interpretation of Mr. Smith's motives is quite different. "He is absolutely a down-in-the-dirt crook," Mr. Baron said.
Some defense lawyers involved in asbestos litigation said that while Mr. Baron and his firm might have escaped sanctions in connection with the memorandum, they remained convinced that his firm had used questionable tactics to press dubious claims.
Elizabeth L. Phifer, an outside lawyer in Dallas for the Borg-Warner Corporation, which challenged Mr. Baron over the memorandum, said that asbestos claimants she had questioned in pretrial testimony over the past decade had repeatedly given the same answers to questions about events that happened decades earlier. "It is remarkable how similar the answers sound," Ms. Phifer said.
Mr. Baron is unmoved. After Borg-Warner challenged him, he brought two asbestos cases to trial, winning large judgments. The company soon withdrew its legal challenge and now settles claims with Mr. Baron's firm for more than it previously did, the Texas lawyer said.
"She is bitter," said Mr. Baron, referring to Ms. Phifer. "She lost."
