HEADLINE: A Magazine Giant Weighs In on Internet Business

BYLINE: By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
John Huey is a magazine editor known for his Southern charm and pit-bull mentality: when he has an idea between his teeth, he might be pleasant about it, but he will never let go.
Two years ago, Mr. Huey, managing editor of Fortune magazine, decided that Time Inc. ought to start or purchase a magazine about Internet business. He flew to San Francisco and met with editors and publishers at The Industry Standard, Red Herring and Business 2.0, deciding who or what or whether to buy. 
 No luck.
"We tried to see if there was a way that we each could satisfy the other's goals, and we basically decided we could not," Mr. Huey said.
Since he could not buy 'em, he joined 'em. The result is E-Company Now, a new monthly magazine from Time Inc. that Mr. Huey said cost less to start "than it would have ever cost to pay the Internet multiples everyone was asking for."
With the first issue, released three weeks ago, Mr. Huey and his editors jumped, some would say belatedly, into a fray of magazines that besides The Standard and Red Herring includes titles like Upside, Fast Company and -- take a deep breath -- the newly rechristened Ziff-Davis Smart Business for the New Economy.
And no one expects the dot-com advertising boom to last forever. What's more, Mr. Huey must keep E-Company Now from leeching content from Fortune, its inspirational parent.
But none of this daunts Mr. Huey. "I'm relatively confident this is going to work," he said in an interview last week from his home in Atlanta. (Mr. Huey prefers to commute to work from Georgia most weeks than to live in New York City.) "We figured out about two years ago that the whole Internet story was moving out of the realm of being a tech story alone. But we never wanted Fortune to drill down so deep into the subject that it became a magazine just about the Internet."
E-Company Now may soon have something else going for it that the other magazines do not, words that would make any Internet-magazine mogul's heart go pitter-pat: America Online and Time Warner.
Most of the other magazines in the field do not have the benefit of Time Inc.'s expertise in consumer magazines or the marketing clout of AOL, which has given the magazine special placement on choice CompuServe, AOL and Netscape sites. So far, those sites have generated more than 30,000 subscriptions, said Ned Desmond, editor in chief of E-Company Now.
Mr. Huey said the advantages of Time Inc.'s backing were obvious. "We are not running around trying to raise a new round of financing or preparing an I.P.O.," he said. "We're running around trying to get the best editors and writers we can."
Then again, most of the magazines about Internet business -- even those that are still raising financing and preparing initial public offerings -- are thriving and expanding.
Business 2.0, which is published by Imagine Media in San Francisco, shifted from a monthly to a twice-a-month publication three issues ago. Red Herring, published by Red Herring Communications, will do the same in November; its June issue is 628 pages. Ad pages for The Industry Standard, the weekly from IDG, are up almost 500 percent against last year and have almost surpassed those of People magazine. Its issues often reach 360 pages, including both advertising and editorial material.
Of course, the magazines have been buoyed by the fact that the market for advertising pages promoting dot-com companies has grown exponentially the last three years. Online, Internet and e-commerce companies spent $113.2 million on advertising in American magazines in 1997, according to Competitive Media Reporting. That climbed to $153.6 million in 1998 and then surged to $687.3 million last year.
But the tide has shifted in recent months, as some of the speculative excess in technology and Internet stocks has subsided; many of those advertisers can no longer afford to spend so freely and no longer need to reach the venture capitalists who thumb through the Internet magazines. Rich LeFurgy, chairman of the Internet Advertising Bureau, said the flow of dot-com advertising would soon abate and probably fall steeply.
"The shift is toward more moderated spending and more effective spending," Mr. LeFurgy said. "You were getting to absurd lengths with some of these magazines as it was. They were getting out of control in terms of the number of ad pages relative to editorial. That will change."
Mr. Huey said he had already thought of that.
"We're not naive about advertising," he said. "We have, along with the dot-com advertising, consumer advertising and business advertising, liquor, cars, fashion. Yes, we will take every dot-com ad that can pay for it, but our business plan is not built on soaking up an ever-growing pool of dot-com advertising."
The real battle among the Internet magazines may play out not in terms of advertising pages, but in the more mundane sphere of old-fashioned circulation. While some of the Internet business magazines have significant circulations, most remain fairly small. Ziff-Davis Smart Business for the New Economy has a circulation of 1,048,941, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, but that was all gained when the magazine was still known as PC Computing. (Ziff-Davis repositioned the magazine to a business-strategy magazine with the May issue.) And Fast Company's circulation is 402,603, according to the circulation bureau.
But the rest of the magazines have circulations closer to that of Model Railroader, and many give away the bulk of their subscriptions free.
Upside, which is not audited by the Audit Bureau of Circulations, reports circulation of 257,000, of which 15,000 are paid. Gini Talmadge, president of Upside Media, said that the subscriptions were given away to qualified readers, meaning readers who have filled out a survey.
"So our subscriber list reads like a Who's Who of the Internet," she said.
The Industry Standard, which also is not audited by the Audit Bureau of Circulations, gives away half of its weekly 150,000 circulation to qualified subscribers.
Mr. Huey said that competition like The Industry Standard, Business 2.0 or Red Herring was not a threat to his new magazine, which has guaranteed advertisers a circulation of 200,000 readers.
"The Industry Standard says they are a must-read for anybody doing business on the Internet," Mr. Huey said. "If that's true, why does it have a circulation of 150,000 and half of it they give away? They are the hot trade book. And that's a very good position to have. But look at us. We want to be a national business magazine that is informed by the Valley."
Jonathan Weber, editor in chief of The Industry Standard, does not dispute the circulation figures. But he said paid circulation was growing "at a healthy pace" and that "substantial increases" would be announced soon. He dismissed Mr. Huey's other criticisms.
There are potential pitfalls for Mr. Huey's and Mr. Desmond's magazine. Editors of competing magazines are quick to criticize Time Inc. for coming late to the game.
"They are two years late to the party," said James Daly, editor in chief of Business 2.0. "They have to do something that other magazines are not doing, and there's not a lot of space left."
Another potential problem is that E-Company Now is a monthly in a field now almost exclusively on weekly or twice-a-month schedules. But Mr. Huey said the magazine's Web site, with its daily columnists and a business-to-business component, would help keep readers plugged in. He suggested the shift to twice-a-month publication by Business 2.0 and Red Herring was part of a ploy to get more advertising.
"It seems pretty obvious to me what that's about," he said. "Our argument is that they are not doing the frequency thing for the reader."
About Mr. Huey's theory, Ted Gramkow, publisher of Red Herring, said, "I don't think so." He countered, "This is John Huey's way, and Fortune and Time Warner's way, of attracting dollars that have been beyond their high price in Fortune. This is a pure advertising play."
Of course, it would be hard for any publisher to argue that readers want even more Internet magazines. But the titles continue to proliferate. Business 2.0 will start an as-yet-unnamed offshoot in October, a business lifestyle magazine whose editor in chief is a former editor of Harper's Bazaar and In Style.
The former publisher of Office Products International is introducing line56, an Internet-business magazine whose title was inspired by the Shakespearian soliloquy that begins with the words "To be or not to be," which appear in line 56 of Act III of "Hamlet."
IDG, The Industry Standard's parent company, has just introduced Darwin: Business Evolving in the Information Age.
"It's getting to be way too much for me," Mr. LeFurgy of the Internet Advertising Bureau said. "I have total information anxiety. The magazines just stack up and stack up in my office now."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

British Airways Is Seen In Early Talks With KLM
Amid renewed pressure in the airline industry to consolidate, British Airways has held informal merger talks with KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, executives close to both companies said.
While the executives stressed that the discussions are preliminary, they underscore the frenzy among airline operators to seek partners hoping to increase profit in an industry that has seen its margins steadily erode. The informal talks take place amid the proposed acquisition of US Airways by UAL for $4.3 billion and overtures from AMR to Northwest about combining their businesses. Page C2. 

I.B.M. in Venture With Salesforce
I.B.M. and Salesforce.com, which offers software for managing sales data like contacts, leads and follow-ups, as a subscription service from its Web site, plan to announce a partnership intended to help small businesses transform themselves into e-businesses. C7.
 
Technology Deals That Went Wrong
In no sector of the technology business have more companies with less revenue been acquired for richer sums than in communications equipment. On the surface, many of these deals look good for everyone, and they often are. But not every deal can be a success, and as the pace of acquisitions grows, so may the number of bad deals. New Economy. C3.
 
Online Integration, Except for Taxes
Many traditional retailers have vowed that by integrating their Web operations into their physical stores, they will eventually bury Internet-only merchants. But even as these companies preach the gospel of Internet integration to the public, some of the best-known merchants are telling government regulators that their Internet and physical-world operations are distinct and separate businesses -- and therefore should enjoy the tax advantages of maintaining separate operations. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C10.
 
Movie to Be Transmitted Digitally
On Tuesday, for the first time ever, a movie will be digitally transmitted across the country over the Internet and then digitally projected to a cinema audience, going from the studio in Hollywood to a theater in Atlanta without ever touching film. The idea is to demonstrate the potential of digital distribution -- which many think will one day supplant traditional canisters of celluloid. C6.
 
Telewest in Talks for Chello Stake
Telewest Communications, Britain's second-biggest cable company, is in talks to acquire about 10 percent of Chello Broadband, a unit of United Pan-Europe Communications. C2.
 
Small Booksellers Take Fight to Web
Independent booksellers, which have fought a two-decades war against chains and, more recently, online booksellers, are seeking to gain ground on the Internet with two large-scale Web sites. On June 6, the American Booksellers Association will introduce Booksense.com, a "hub site" for hundreds of individual sites created and maintained by local stores. Next to come, in early July, is Contentville, in which about 40 of the most respected booksellers will provide editorial content. "Booksense.com and Contentville can all act to remind consumers that independent booksellers have a valuable voice," said Roxanne Coady of R. J. Julia Books in Madison, Conn., who is participating in both sites. C11.
 
A Rematch for Hit TV Shows
After uncertainty about the possible consequences, ABC will again pit the hottest show of the season, "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," against CBS's highly promising newcomer "Survivor" on Wednesday night. C11.
 
Salon's Redesign of Its Redesign
Hoping to soothe ruffled readers, the online magazine Salon pulled back its site redesign, which had elicited an immediate chorus of e-mail boos and hisses from readers, and introduced another new design. C3.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 394 words

HEADLINE: Ineffective Humanitarian Aid

 BODY:
Humanitarian disasters have emerged as the most complex challenges facing American foreign policy. There has been strenuous debate over whether America should get involved when there is famine in Somalia or Sudan, genocide in Rwanda, mass killings in East Timor or a refugee exodus in Kosovo. What gets less attention is the question of how to take effective action when we do get involved. An internal State Department report provides an unusually frank assessment of why American action has sometimes been slow or ineffective.
The study was directed by Morton Halperin, head of the policy planning staff at the State Department, and James Michel, counselor to the Agency for International Development. It examines how Washington responded to three man-made humanitarian disasters -- stemming from armed conflicts in Kosovo, Afghanistan and Sudan -- and one natural disaster, Hurricane Mitch in Central America. Although the report finds much to applaud, it is also a tale of poor coordination, missions being duplicated or falling through the cracks, and confusion inside the administration and the private humanitarian groups that sometimes cannot be sure with which agency to work. Confusion over which part of the government was leading the response to Hurricane Mitch, for example, led to delays in assessing the damage and getting aid to Central America. Most important, at many times when American policy was made, no one was present to remind officials of the humanitarian consequences. 
 The report can be read as a plea for establishing a single office to coordinate humanitarian assistance, with a chief who would participate in high-level meetings the next time we are faced with a Kosovo or Sudan. This is an eminently sensible recommendation for the next administration, which is sure to find itself wrestling with new famines, hurricanes and wars.
The authors of this unclassified assessment have stirred grumbling inside the State Department for their public bluntness, especially because their criticisms have received most of the attention. But they could have hoped for little impact if they had kept their views classified, and the issue is one that deserves airing. Mr. Halperin and Mr. Michel have performed a service by identifying the shortcomings in America's humanitarian programs, and by allowing the public to know. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Merton H. Miller, 77, Dies; Economist Who Won Nobel

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Merton H. Miller, a Nobel award winner in economics whose passionate belief in free markets helped him to develop what are now widely recognized guidelines for valuing corporations, died on Saturday at his home in Chicago. He was 77.
He died of lymphoma, from which he had suffered since 1997, said his wife, Katherine. While he did his pioneering work in the late 1950's as a young professor at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh, he spent most of his career, since 1961, on the faculty of the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business, where he taught until this school year. 
 Corporate finance in the 1950's was virtually untouched by academia, left mostly to the instincts and seat-of-the-pants judgments of the nation's executives and Wall Street. But as American companies grew and the stock and bond markets that served them became more complicated and faster moving, pioneers like Mr. Miller began to develop formal guidelines, and corporate finance soon became a new branch of economics.
The research that won Mr. Miller the Nobel in economic science in 1990 found in essence that the mix of stock and debt that a company used to finance its operations did not determine the value of the company in the financial markets. Too much debt might make a company's stock riskier because of the earnings that must be earmarked to pay interest on the debt. But investors could protect themselves through arbitrage, which is a process of buying and selling stocks and bonds to alter their mix of debt and equity.
Mr. Miller published these findings in a 1958 paper co-written with Franco Modigliani, who was then teaching at Carnegie Mellon but soon moved to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. During a lecture, Mr. Modigliani touched on views already taking shape in Mr. Miller's head. Mr. Miller then took the lead in carrying out the research, overcoming some early skepticism from Mr. Modigliani that markets could arbitrage so efficiently.
Recounting the story in his book "Capital Ideas: The Improbable Origins of Modern Wall Street" (The Free Press, 1992), Peter L. Bernstein reported that Mr. Miller stood his ground. He was "a passionate believer in the power of free markets to forge optimal and predictable outcomes," Mr. Bernstein wrote, and quoted Mr. Miller as saying: "I believed it. I felt from the very beginning that this is right."
The 1958 paper and one three years later elaborating on the theory raised enormous debate. The theory required too many unrealistic assumptions, some argued. Whatever their shortcomings, the findings that brought Mr. Miller a Nobel helped to lift inhibitions on corporate borrowing. The high-yield securities called junk bonds flourished later, as a result, as did arbitrage. And in later years, a friendship developed between Mr. Miller and Michael R. Milken, the investment banker who promoted junk bonds.
Throughout his life, Mr. Miller believed fervently in the power of free markets, unhindered by government -- an unusual stance for economists in his generation. Born in Boston on May 16, 1923, the only child of Joel and Sylvia Miller, he grew up during the Depression, an experience that won over others to the teachings of John Maynard Keynes, the British economist who gave government spending a key role in stimulating an economy.
After graduation from Harvard in 1943, where he had majored in economics, Mr. Miller worked in Washington for the Treasury Department and the Federal Reserve. A chance encounter that summer brought Mr. Miller into contact with George Stigler, a conservative economist who later became the first professor at the University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business to win a Nobel prize in economics. The two became fast friends.
A second mentor, Fritz Machlup, another free-market proponent, drew Mr. Miller to Johns Hopkins University, where he earned a doctorate in 1952, and after two semesters as a teacher at the London School of Economics, he joined Carnegie Mellon. He formally retired from the University of Chicago in 1993 but continued to teach and advise graduate students.
"He had his formative training when Keynesianism was at its height, in the 1940's and 1950's, and he evolved into a proponent of market solutions," said his wife, who was a graduate student in economics when Mr. Miller married her in 1970, a year after the death of his first wife, Eleanor. In addition to his wife, Mr. Miller is survived by three daughters from his first marriage: Margot Horn and Pamela Chwedyk of Chicago and Louise Lorber of Evanston, Ill., and two grandsons.
In his later years, Mr. Miller focused on regulatory issues and became involved in the private sector, serving on several corporate boards, as a director of the Chicago Board of Trade in the early 1980's and as a director of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange from 1990 until his death.
The Millers often spent weekends at a farm in Woodstock, Ill., which they had bought as a country retreat, and even there Mr. Miller thought in free-market terms. A neighboring farmer rented the land, and Mr. Miller proposed to the farmer that the rent vary with the price the farmer got for the corn he grew on the land.
"Luckily, the farmer turned down the variable rent proposal," Mrs. Miller said. "If he hadn't, we would have lost our shirts. Corn prices plunged that year."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
An African Ambassador Battles Terror and Indifference

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MANY of the worst photographs are kept in a red paper folder on the coffee table in the ambassador's office.
As some diplomats might want to share photographs of a sun-dappled tourist resort or a new business development in their homelands, Ambassador John E. Leigh asks visitors to the Sierra Leone Embassy to inspect the evidence of the nightmare that has descended on his West African nation. 
 He takes the first photograph from the folder. "Here, what has she done to deserve this?" he asks of the child in the photo, a girl not more than 3 or 4 years old. Her belly is covered with scars from blade cuts. Most of her right arm is missing, removed from above the elbow.
"They just put your arm on the ground and chop it off," he says of the grotesque tactics of the rebels who have mutilated whole villages of people, including infants, by hacking off their limbs, in an undeniably successful effort to spread terror. A second photograph shows a pretty young woman, perhaps 20, with two stumps where her hands had been.
Thousands of other civilians have been killed outright in almost a decade of fighting in Sierra Leone, a diamond-rich nation of five million whose history is bound up with that of the United States. Much of the population is descended from American slaves who fought their way off Southern plantations and returned to Africa.
The ambassador, an American-educated lawyer-turned-diplomat who has run the embassy since 1996, said he did not believe the first reports of the mutilations when they began to trickle out early that year. "I was stunned by it; I thought it was a made-up story," he said.
But quickly enough, the evidence became overwhelming. "When they chop off people's hands, they will say to the victims, 'Let's see how you're going to vote now,' " Mr. Leigh explained. "In Sierra Leone, people are in a state of shock. Nobody thought that fellow Africans could be this vicious."
The extreme violence, he said, is explained by the diamonds, which the rebels -- who have received support from Libya and neighboring Liberia -- seek to control. "The greedier you are, the more violent you are," he said.
Despite the scale of atrocities, the ambassador said, it has been difficult to get Americans, including officials of the Clinton administration, to listen and care. "It's just not important to them. Sierra Leone is small, the economy is tiny." As for the State Department, he said, "They listen to me but they do nothing."
Mr. Leigh said a possibly racist double standard became clear last year, when Sierra Leone continued its descent into chaos as the United States began its multibillion-dollar military campaign in Kosovo. "Here is a white nation getting all of these goodies, and here is Sierra Leone, where they are cutting off the arms of women and children, and they are not paying any attention."
Perhaps worse, he said, the United States joined with other nations last year in pressuring his government to negotiate, producing a cease-fire agreement in which the government pardoned the guerrillas who had been mutilating civilians. After the deal was signed, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright traveled to Sierra Leone and met with the rebel leader, Foday Sankoh. The agreement has collapsed.
"We were forced into it," Mr. Leigh said. "The United States went in and pushed it on us." Not surprisingly, he is unpopular across town at the State Department. "They give me dirty looks," he said with a throaty chuckle. "They don't like me there because I speak out."
Asked for a response, a department official said the United States had provided more than $300 million in humanitarian aid to Sierra Leone over the last decade.
"The notion that we haven't done very much is certainly erroneous," the official said, adding that the United States had not pressed the peace agreement on Sierra Leone but had instead been an honest broker at the request of the government there.
To the 61-year-old ambassador, the anger he arouses is simply proof that he is doing his job. His government asked Mr. Leigh to take over the embassy in the hope that after spending most of his adult life in the United States, he would know how to make his voice heard.
HIS family ties to the United States go back to the 18th century, when his ancestors escaped from Southern plantations and, according to family accounts, fled to Nova Scotia and eventually to Sierra Leone. "Sierra Leone was a place for the guys who were rebellious," he said.
Mr. Leigh grew up in Freetown, his country's capital, and was educated at American- and British-run missionary schools. His father worked for what was then the British colonial government. Like many from elite families, Mr. Leigh went to college in the West. He received an M.B.A. from New York University and a law degree from Suffolk University in Boston.
Over the years, he married an American, had three children, all of them American citizens, and worked for Chase Manhattan and Xerox. When he was tapped to become ambassador, he was a lawyer in private practice in Boston.
But Mr. Leigh says he has no desire for American citizenship. An American passport, he said, would dishonor the memory of relatives who had to risk their lives centuries ago to escape the United States.
"My wife has been on my case," he said. "But I didn't feel right doing that. My ancestors fought their way out of America's slave population. I didn't want to negate that heritage."

HEADLINE: In Brooklyn, New Insurgent Takes On an Old Challenger

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Twenty years ago, Roger L. Green was a 30-year-old upstart candidate, battling against a political Goliath for a seat in the State Assembly. In that campaign, Mr. Green waged and won a fight against not only against a 20-year incumbent, but against the might of the Democratic Party's political machine in Brooklyn as well.
After two decades in the Assembly, representing the Fort Greene and Clinton-Washington sections of Brooklyn, Mr. Green now finds himself in very much the same position as the man he defeated in that 1980 campaign, Harvey L. Strelzin. Mr. Green is being challenged by Hakeem S. Jeffries, a 29-year-old lawyer waging his first campaign for public office and brandishing many of the complaints made by Mr. Green in his first campaign. 
 Of course, defeating an incumbent, particularly one as steeped in the community's political landscape as Mr. Green, is always difficult. But the race in the 57th Assembly District is being watched for a number of reasons.
Mr. Jeffries, a lawyer at the firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, is marshaling a sizable group of young volunteers. And he is campaigning vigorously against an incumbent who has typically had little in the way of competition in this highly Democratic district.
Even if he turns back the challenge, how well Mr. Green does in the September primary will probably affect his prospects for higher office. Mr. Green undertook a brief campaign for public advocate in 1997 and has said he is considering running for Congress one day, when the seat held by Representative Edolphus Towns becomes vacant.
In the meantime, Mr. Jeffries says Mr. Green has become inattentive to the needs of his constituents. Whether it is giving assistance on economic development issues or simply returning a phone call, the assemblyman's performance has become abysmal, Mr. Jeffries asserts.
"The assemblyman has failed to put forth a vision for dealing with the educational needs of the district and developing the business corridor of the community," Mr. Jeffries said.
He complains that a large swath of Fulton Street, a major commercial corridor in the district, is filled with abandoned storefronts, and that "there is no plan coming from the assemblyman to revitalize our community."
Mr. Green acknowledges that he has had his lapses and that his office has not always been as efficient as he would have liked. But he is emphatic in his defense of his record, characterizing himself as a champion of economic development and issues affecting children.
"When I hear what Hakeem is saying, I actually can identify with some of it," he said. "Obviously, as his opponent, the only thing I would say is that you've got to check the record, because if anyone has done institution-building in this area, it's been me."
Specifically, Mr. Green takes great pride in the development of the Benjamin Banneker Academy, a charter school that specializes in math, science and technology, which was proposed and designed by his office.
He also points to his years of working with young people, citing his sponsorship of after-school programs in 18 public schools in Brooklyn. And he talks about his role in founding the Latimer-Woods Economic Development Association, which provides training and economic development opportunities in high technology for young people in Central Brooklyn.
"We have built institutions in this district that I will be reminding the voters of during the campaign," Mr. Green said. "We want folks to know what the real deal is."
In the 1990 census, the district was nearly three quarters black and 12 percent Hispanic. Since then, the district has attracted more higher-income black professionals.
While Mr. Jeffries may speak with vehemence about his view of his opponent's deficiencies, it is clear that Mr. Green sees something of himself in the young challenger, speaking of him almost as though he were Mr. Jeffries's mentor.
"Hakeem is the type of young man that we have struggled to support and, hopefully, to empower," Mr. Green said. "I don't think that we in the party have made a concerted enough effort to get people like Hakeem involved in the political process. When I look at his resume, I think that he could offer a lot."
Mr. Jeffries acknowledges the difficulty of unseating someone of Mr. Green's tenure. But he suggests that he is in part motivated by Mr. Green's history.
"I know that it's difficult to defeat a 20-year incumbent," Mr. Jeffries said. "He is a professional politician backed by the Democratic machine. But I believe that, as long as I can make the people aware that there is a credible alternate choice, there will be an opportunity to be successful. After all, that's exactly what he did 20 years ago."

HEADLINE: Divisiveness at Parade as Mrs. Clinton and Lazio Salute Israel

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton and Rick A. Lazio shook hands and stood side by side yesterday, both vowing to support the political and economic stability of Israel. But along the Fifth Avenue route of New York City's annual Salute to Israel Parade, the intense, even angry, division among Jews over the two United States Senate candidates was starkly on display.
The parade, like so many others in New York, typically draws a healthy contingent of vote-seeking politicians. But this year, the political jockeying was so pervasive and the crowd seemed so politically engaged that even some organizers said that campaigning was overshadowing the purpose of the event, to celebrate the 52 years of Israeli statehood. 
 Mr. Lazio marched yesterday with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, just ahead of the New York City Police Department marching band. Mrs. Clinton was farther back, beside Senator Charles E. Schumer and a collection of leaders of Jewish groups.
The first lady proved to be the biggest media attraction, drawing such a large pack of television cameras and photographers that her security team stretched out a rope to corral them. But she also inspired the most vociferous reaction from the crowd, with spectators sporadically booing, screaming and sometimes even crudely insulting her as she passed.
Also marching along the 22-block parade route, in addition to the groups of children, religious clubs and community associations, were three likely future candidates for mayor -- Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, Public Advocate Mark Green and the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone -- as well as many other state and local officials.
"Hillary brings out passions in people," said Mr. Green, who described the crowd as perhaps the most intense he had seen in his decade of marching in parades in the city.
Mr. Lazio and Mrs. Clinton went to great lengths to try to demonstrate their devotion to Israel, as both candidates, in what has quickly become a competitive race, clearly recognize the importance of the large number of Jewish voters in New York City.
But despite their competition for votes, the Senate candidates were quite cordial with each other. They shook hands and chatted briefly about Mr. Lazio's two daughters during a break in the parade while they stood at a reviewing stand on Fifth Avenue at 69th Street. It was Mr. Lazio's and Mrs. Clinton's first joint appearance since Mr. Giuliani last month dropped out of the nation's highest profile Senate race and Mr. Lazio replaced him as the Republican nominee.
Mr. Lazio repeatedly spoke yesterday about his support for moving the United States embassy in Israel from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem, to recognize the city that Israel claims as its capital. Mrs. Clinton, who also supports such a move, spoke more generally about what she called her longstanding respect for the country and its people.
"The United States has been and will be always there for Israel," she said, drawing applause from crowd, including the mayor and Mr. Lazio. "And we will always support the Israeli government and Israeli people as they struggle to find a safe and secure peace."
The two candidates stayed away from more controversial topics, such as whether there should be an independent Palestinian state. Mrs. Clinton angered many Jewish voters last year when she voiced support for such a state.
"I am going to take the lead of the state of Israel on this," Mr. Lazio said yesterday when asked by a reporter about the topic. "I have some serious questions about whether or not a Palestinian state is sustainable, considering the security concerns of the State of Israel."
But the animosity felt by some in the crowd toward Mrs. Clinton was evident on nearly every block, with some holding signs recalling her embrace last year of Yasir Arafat's wife, Suha, while others shouted, "Go back to Arkansas," mocking her move last year to New York State and her bid as a Democrat for the Senate seat.
Mira Hakak, a Queens statistician, held a torn-up Clinton campaign sign in her hands, just above an Israeli flag that was propped up in her pocketbook. "She did not do anything in her life and now she wants to be our senator," Mrs. Hakak said. "If she wants to be in Washington, she should get a job as a lawyer."
Emotions ran so high that brief scuffles at times broke out between the two camps, such as when one backer of Mrs. Clinton had her campaign sign pulled out of her hands and torn up. "There was just a lot of hate," said Resi Cooper, 29, of Nassau County, a supporter of Mrs. Clinton, who said she was nearly knocked over by supporters of Mr. Lazio at one point during the parade.
Also amid the crowd were many undecided voters, like Lisa Rosenzweig, 39, a lawyer from Brooklyn, who said she generally votes for Democrats, but has not made up her mind in the Senate race.
"How's your lip?" she yelled to Mr. Lazio, whose lip was still swollen from a fall he took in a Memorial Day parade on Long Island. She later told a reporter that she considered Mr. Lazio a worthy candidate and would not likely decide on her vote until November.
Mr. Giuliani, who was campaigning for his second time with Mr. Lazio, at times seemed to attract more attention than the Long Island congressman, with spectators chanting his name and some even holding his old Senate campaign signs. But the mayor appeared to make an effort to let Mr. Lazio take the lead, allowing him to decide when to break away from the parade and greet supporters.
Both Mr. Lazio and Mrs. Clinton dashed from the end of the Salute to Israel Parade to the smaller Philippine-American Friendship Day Parade on Madison Avenue in Midtown. Mrs. Clinton received a much warmer welcome from this crowd, some of her supporters so excited that they tried to climb over police officers to reach her. Asked about being booed at the Salute to Israel Parade, she responded: "I had a great time. I mean, that's democracy."

HEADLINE: William E. Simon, Ex-Treasury Secretary And High-Profile Investor, Is Dead at 72

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
William E. Simon, who directed the nation's energy policy and was treasury secretary in the dark economic days of the 1970's and then proved to have a golden touch as an investor in the boom days of the 1980's, died on Saturday at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 72 and lived in Santa Barbara.
The cause of death was complications from pulmonary fibrosis, a lung disease that he had been fighting for more than a year, said James Piereson, executive director of the John M. Olin Foundation in New York, where Mr. Simon was president. . 
 A conservative Republican, Mr. Simon left a successful Wall Street career as a bond trader in 1973 to join Richard Nixon's administration as deputy treasury secretary. He went on to become director of the Federal Energy Office -- or "energy czar," as he was known -- later that year when the economy reeled in the wake of the Arab oil embargo, and in April 1974 he was named treasury secretary, a post he retained when Gerald R. Ford succeeded Nixon.
After leaving office at the end of the Ford administration, Mr. Simon returned to Wall Street, where he became emblematic of a breed of aggressive investor. In 1982, Mr. Simon and a partner, Raymond G. Chambers, paid $80.5 million, almost all of it borrowed, to buy Gibson Greetings, a card maker, in one of the first high-profile leveraged buyouts.
Fourteen months later they sold the company in a public offering to shareholders for $290 million, yielding Mr. Simon and Mr. Chambers a profit of $70 million each and creating a mystique about Mr. Simon's investing prowess that was only partly tarnished in recent years by a string of disappointing deals.
Mr. Simon also was the United States Olympic Committee's treasurer from 1977 to 1980, and as its president for the subsequent four years, playing important roles in the American decision to boycott the 1980 Olympic Games in Moscow, and in planning the 1984 games in Los Angeles.
William Edward Simon was born on Nov. 27, 1927, in Paterson, N.J. His father was an insurance agent, and he lived a middle-class life through the Depression. After graduating from high school in 1946, he served in the Army and then enrolled at Lafayette College, in Easton, Pa., where he met Carol Girard. They were married in 1950.
After graduating from Lafayette in 1952, he got a $75-a-week job trading municipal bonds. By 1964, he was working at Salomon Brothers, where he was known as a quick-tempered, outspoken and very skilled bond trader. Within Salomon's aggressive culture, his sometimes-abrasive personality was no drawback. By the early 1970's, he was one of the firm's senior partners and was earning more than $2 million a year.
On the recommendation of Attorney General John Mitchell, a former Wall Street lawyer, Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz recruited Mr. Simon as his deputy at the beginning of Nixon's second term. Even as the Watergate scandal was beginning to envelop the White House, Mr. Simon was enmeshed in another national crisis, the embargo imposed by Arab oil producers on nations friendly to Israel.
By the end of 1973, Mr. Simon was coordinating the administration's efforts to encourage conservation and to allocate scarce supplies of oil -- favoring factory production and home heating oil over gasoline for motorists. It was a job that brought him criticism from all sides, not least from consumers, who resented gasoline shortages and high prices.
"I'm the guy that caused the lines at the gas stations," Mr. Simon once said.
But Mr. Simon seemed sufficiently thick skinned to cope and more than willing to fight back.
"We have become a nation of great energy wastrels," he said in 1973. He publicly chastised another administration official for crossing him, saying the official should "keep his cotton pickin' hands off energy policy." He labeled statements by the shah of Iran, then a key ally of the United States, "irresponsible and reckless."
By early 1974, the country was in a recession, and when Mr. Shultz resigned as treasury secretary, Nixon quickly named Mr. Simon to replace him. Mr. Simon spent much of his time on international policy, pressing Arab nations to reinvest the dollars they were reaping through oil sales in the United States and creating an international credit line for poor nations that had been hurt by soaring energy costs.
At home, with inflation rising, he counseled against deficit spending to stimulate the economy, in keeping with his fiscal conservatism. In 1975, he created a political firestorm when he helped persuade President Ford not to bail New York City out of its financial crisis. He argued that coming to New York's aid would encourage profligacy among other cities.
"Then came the New York fiscal crisis, and I was Genghis Khan," he recalled a dozen years later.
Under pressure from bankers, who countered that if New York City were to default on its debt, it could reverberate through markets around the world, Mr. Simon and Mr. Ford ultimately agreed to aid the city.
After Jimmy Carter was elected in 1976, Mr. Simon left Washington and became a consultant to investment firms and businesses, as well as becoming treasurer of the Olympic committee, for which he had raised funds before entering government service.
In 1980, when President Carter urged the committee to boycott the Moscow Olympics that summer to protest the Soviet presence in Afghanistan, most American amateur sports officials and athletes were opposed. Mr. Simon's impassioned speech to the committee's house of delegates in favor of the boycott swung the vote.
The next year, when Mr. Simon was elected president of the Olympic committee by acclamation, the organization was $9 million in debt and had to meet an $88 million budget for the next four years. The boycott had hurt fund-raising.
But Mr. Simon turned potential doom into a financial bonanza by having the Olympic committee become an equal partner with the Los Angeles Olympic organizers. Despite a retaliatory boycott by the Soviet Union and most of its allies, those Olympics earned $225 million.
The Olympic committee, with its 40 percent share and an additional $35 million from the Olympic coin program, created the United States Olympic Foundation as a permanent financial source for American amateur sports. That became the major legacy of Mr. Simon's era at the committee.
During the same period, Mr. Simon was building a fortune with his investments in leveraged buyouts, of which the Gibson Greetings deal was the best known. The company he operated in partnership with Mr. Chambers, Wesray, bought undervalued companies with borrowed money, whipped them into shape or waited until a willing buyer appeared, and then sold them, often for hefty profits. By the late 1980's, Forbes magazine was estimating Mr. Simon's wealth at $300 million.
But his partnership with Mr. Chambers came apart in 1986, as Mr. Simon turned to building a network of financial institutions on the West Coast and across the Pacific.
He had some success purchasing banks and failed savings and loan associations and reselling them, but he never approached his stated goal of building a trans-Pacific merchant banking empire. In 1993, federal regulators seized one of his properties, Western Federal Savings and Loan, when it sank into insolvency.
In recent years, Mr. Simon had dedicated more of his time to philanthropy and charitable work.
He gradually turned much of the responsibility for his business over to his two sons, William E. Simon Jr., and J. Peter Simon.
In 1996, Mr. Simon received the Blessed Hyacinth Cormier Award for outstanding Catholic leadership, and in 1999, he was honored by the Olympic committee.
Mr. Simon's first wife, Carol, died in 1995. He is survived by his second wife, Tonia Adams Donnelley, whom he married in 1996, and by seven children from his first marriage. In addition to his two sons, they are Mary Beth Simon Streep; Carol Leigh Simon Porges; Aimee Simon Bloom; Julie Ann Simon Munro and Johanna Katrina Simon.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN MOSCOW: THE OVERVIEW;
CLINTON AND PUTIN UNABLE TO AGREE ON MISSILE BARRIER

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 4

 BODY:
President Clinton and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia concluded two days of talks today with mutual praise, but without narrowing the differences over the national missile defense system the United States wants to build.
The summit meeting did produce two other narrow but significant agreements. One was an undertaking by the United States and Russia each to destroy 34 metric tons (about 75,000 pounds) of weapons-grade plutonium, enough to make tens of thousands of nuclear weapons. The other called for a joint center in Moscow to share early warnings about missile launching, a center that would be the first permanent American-Russia military operation. 
 Over all, senior administration officials described the atmosphere between the lame-duck American president and the new Russian president as correct and businesslike, though not necessarily warm. That was evident at their news conference.
Although the two presidents shook hands as they entered the hall, and Mr. Clinton gently nudged Mr. Putin to pose with him for the cameras afterward, they did not look or smile at each other during their opening statements or while answering questions.
The two men had met twice before, in 1999 when Mr. Putin was prime minister, but this was their first meeting since the Russian was elected president in March. And although they had a range of issues on their agenda -- including Russia's struggle to reform its economy and its unresolved war in Chechnya -- arms control dominated their talks.
Seeking to temper expectations, senior administration officials had said before the trip that there would not be a substantial breakthrough on the contentious question of a national missile defense.
But Mr. Clinton is committed to decide before the end of his administration whether to move forward with a limited missile defense system against the possibility that a "rogue state" like North Korea might develop a missile able to reach the United States. Russia says the project would undermine the Antiballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, a cornerstone of strategic arms controls, and unleash a new arms race. The proposed American system is also opposed by China, and the European allies have expressed concern.
Mr. Putin evidently felt no urgency to change his position.
He made that clear during the news conference, which was held in the grand, gilt-trimmed St. George's Hall in the recently renovated czarist-era Grand Palace of the Kremlin. While acknowledging that there was "a commonality" in foreseeing the possibility of unspecified new threats, Mr. Putin said, "We're against having a cure which is worse than the disease."
The two sides agreed to a joint statement pledging to continue talks on further cuts in strategic nuclear weapons and terming the ABM treaty the "cornerstone" of global strategic security. The statement called on experts from both sides to prepare a joint report on how to tackle new threats to strategic stability.
But briefing reporters after the press conference, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott stressed that Mr. Putin had not softened his position.
"President Putin made absolutely clear to President Clinton that Russia continues to oppose the changes to the ABM treaty that the United States has proposed since last September," Mr. Talbott said. He said Russia believed that the anti-missile plan "will undermine strategic stability, threaten Russia's strategic deterrent and provoke a new arms race."
At the news conference, Mr. Putin insisted that he was willing to continue working on the issue, if necessary, with the next American president. "We know that today, in the United States, there is a campaign ongoing," he said, adding that he was familiar with the programs of the two main candidates. "No matter who gets to be president, we're willing to go forward."
Though Mr. Clinton has only eight more months in office, that in itself does not necessarily preclude progress on arms control or United States-Russian relations. President Reagan spent a large part of 1988, his last year in office, pressing for improvements in Washington's relations with Moscow and pushing arms control agreements. And just two weeks before Mr. Clinton's inauguration, President Bush signed the Start II treaty, calling for the most significant rollback yet in the formidable nuclear arsenal of the cold war.
Officials said that during their eight hours of talks over two days, Mr. Putin spoke some English, and each leader displayed a readiness to hear the other out. But the exchanges lacked the first-name familiarity that characterized the relationship between Mr. Clinton and Boris N. Yeltsin, the former president, where it was always "Boris" and "Bill."
One American in the delegation said of Mr. Putin: "You can see he is not a warm person; he's a cold fish. People say he's a control freak." But the official pointed out that on arms control issues, that may not be bad.
Asked how they would describe each other's personalities and leadership styles, Mr. Putin said of Mr. Clinton, "He's a very experienced politician."
"In my mind, we've established now not only good business ties, but also personal relations," he said. "For me, President Clinton is a person who is a very comfortable and pleasant partner in negotiations."
"I think that if everyone behaves the way President Clinton has behaved, not trying to find dead ends and problems, but to seek ways of moving ahead, I think between us in the future our relations really will be successful."
Mr. Clinton was even more formal in his assessment of Mr. Putin, saying: "If you want to know what my personal assessment is, I think he is fully capable of building a prosperous and strong Russia while preserving freedom, pluralism and the rule of law. It's a big challenge. I think he's fully capable of doing it."
The agreement on the disposal of some 34 tons of plutonium would help prevent the material from being used for weapons, though the financing of the Russian effort remains uncertain. The joint military center is intended to help both nations avoid an accidental missile launching.
In the summit meeting, Mr. Clinton raised other areas of contention besides missile defense. He urged Mr. Putin to seek a political settlement to end Russia's eight-month-long military offensive against rebels in Chechnya and to allow international monitors to investigate charges of human rights violations in the region.
And he called on the Russian leader to protect the rights of a free press. Earlier this spring, Mr. Putin ordered an armed raid on Media-MOST, a major communications company that had been critical of the Kremlin. The invasion was officially described as a tax raid.
Mr. Clinton underscored his message by giving an interview to Echo Moskvy, a radio station owned by Media-MOST.
The joint Kremlin news conference was also an occasion to announce the agreements that had been reached. The two presidents sat at a long gilt-trimmed white table with two sets of pens as an overpowering, disembodied voice filled the vast 40-foot-ceilinged hall relating in both Russian and English each of the agreements and statements.
The voice was so powerful that Mr. Clinton and several members of his delegation -- including the national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger; Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, and Energy Secretary Bill Richardson -- could not stop themselves from smiling. Mr. Putin did not smile.
Mr. Clinton also indulged in a bit of sightseeing, visiting the imposing new Christ the Savior Cathedral on the Moscow River embankment near the Kremlin.

HEADLINE: The 00's Finale Of the 80's Tycoons

BYLINE: By Bryan Burrough; Bryan Burrough, a special correpondent for Vanity Fair, is co-author, with John Helyar, of "Barbarians at the Gate: The Fall of RJR Nabisco."

 BODY:
For those of us who remember a time before pimply dot-com billionaires and Gatesian wealth, the recent passing of Saul Steinberg's longtime investment company, Reliance Group Holdings, marks the end of an era.
Weighted down by debt, Mr. Steinberg sold Reliance to a competitor, the Leucadia National Corporation, for pennies on the dollar. Sold as well was Mr. Steinberg's palatial Park Avenue apartment, thought to be the largest in Manhattan, as well as its contents, including many of the fine paintings and draperies that once hung on its walls. And, let's not forget, a multimillion-dollar commode made of rococo-gilded bronze. The 80's, an era when financial alchemy brought jaw-dropping wealth to a generation of Wall Streeters, can now be safely said to be over. 
 For the last 15 years or so, Mr. Steinberg was an oversized symbol of a decade whose legacy will forever be debated by economists and historians. In fact, Mr. Steinberg's reputation was built largely through his groundbreaking but failed attempt to take over Chemical Bank in 1969, a precursor to 80's-style corporate raids. That run enshrined him in Wall Street lore, vividly illustrating to a generation of hungry young men what could be accomplished with a modest amount of cash and a large dose of moxie.
But in the 1980's, aside from collecting $60 million in greenmail, which Disney paid him to go away in 1984, Mr. Steinberg mostly stayed on the sidelines, watching as corporate raiders like Carl Icahn, T. Boone Pickens and Ron Perelman engaged in a financial fox hunt that sent hundreds of American companies scurrying for the woods, baying investment bankers on their heels.
It was what Mr. Steinberg did with his wealth that so aptly capsulized the era. It wasn't just the apartment, once owned by John D. Rockefeller, with its scarlet-and-gold dining room and seven-figure tchotchkes. His third wife, Gayfryd, was conspicuously young. His parties were legend: For his 50th birthday party in 1989, models were dressed as figures in Old Masters paintings. You get the picture.
His sad fate could be taken as yet another lesson on the hollow nature of 1980's wealth, especially when compared to the wealth of the 1990's. This new era has brought a good deal of speculative excess, of course, as is the nature of Wall Street -- raw capitalism is not pretty. But whatever one thinks of the current excesses in stock valuations, it's undeniable that the latest billionaires actually helped build something -- in this case the Internet and all its attendant new technology.
The same can't be said for the 1980's. The billions of dollars made from corporate raids and leveraged buyouts (in an L.B.O., a public company's shareholders are bought out using the company itself as collateral) were about nothing more than paper shuffling. When companies were cracked open like piggy banks, or split up like pizzas to reduce the debt, was anyone really surprised the parts were worth more than the whole?
In these exercises, no breakthrough products were created, no Edisons were uncovered. Is there some gee-whiz product out there that Mr. Steinberg's insurance company engineered? I doubt it. From the very first such deals, there was a sense it was all a shell game, that there was something patently wrong about wealth created by tearing apart companies rather than building them up, by firing, or downsizing, workers rather than hiring them.
Yet even the harshest critics of corporate raids would probably acknowledge that at the dawn of the 1980's too many American companies were overstuffed, overperked and none too sympathetic to the desires of their shareholders. Put aside all the envy, all the sniping about gold-plated cabinetry, and Mr. Steinberg and his ilk were agents of change, pure and simple. They were wolves clearing out the stragglers, forcing the other animals to get into fighting trim. True, they inflicted a great deal of pain, but financial Darwinism has never been for the squeamish.
For those who handle such unpleasant tasks, there is a classic American arc. In 1982, at the beginning of the raider era, the men who launched hostile takeover attempts were lauded as American folk heroes. When they first took to the floors of annual meetings, Gordon Gekko-style, to attack the bloated old boys' networks that ran too many large companies, people actually cheered. While Mr. Pickens and others stormed the ramparts, Henry Kravis and other buyout artists, were standing by in boardrooms, "rescuing" the raiders' frightened prey by taking them private with velvet gloves.
Of course the raiders finally went too far. In 1988, the unseemly free-for-all for control of RJR Nabisco triggered a backlash that killed the golden goose. Afterward it got ugly, as these things usually do, with a barrage of insider-trading and securities-fraud indictments and prison sentences for the untoward and the unlucky.
But many of the raiders, Mr. Steinberg included, now had publicly owned companies tucked under their arms to manage, and it's been informative to see how many of them proved unable to follow through on the promises they made at those bygone annual meetings. Mr. Pickens was unceremoniously ousted from control of his company, the former Mesa Petroleum, in a shareholder uprising. Mr. Perelman's company, Revlon, is a stock-market laggard. Mr. Steinberg's Reliance Group flirted with bankruptcy for years before the last air finally eased from its balloon.
The intriguing question is to what degree the winnowing and strengthening of the 80's set the stage for the explosive growth of the 90's. It's a matter best left to economists, but one suspects it is no accident that a slew of large non-Internet companies, from Wal-Mart to Gillette -- itself a target of hungry raiders during the 1980's -- embarked on rapid growth and stock-price rises in the 1990's. Would they have done so had raiders like Mr. Steinberg not frightened them into shaping up?
It would be the richest irony to argue that Saul Steinberg begat Bill Gates. I won't. But one should also not reach the facile conclusion that Mr. Steinberg's story is simply a fitting end for an era in which ruthless corporate raiders destroyed corporations and laid off tens of thousands of employees.
Then again, it is very, very difficult to envision a day when Mr. Gates would be forced to auction off his living-room drapes.

HEADLINE: PATH Fare Isn't Subsidy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Governors End Port Authority Rift That Blocked Billions in Projects" (front page, June 2):
It is welcome news that Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey will allow several important regional transportation projects to proceed. It is unfortunate that one of the outcomes of their agreement is the commissioning of a study that will likely recommend a PATH fare increase. 
 Rather than shortsightedly view the $1 PATH fare as a New Jersey subsidy, New York politicians should instead recognize it as an incentive for workers to contribute to New York City's economy without flooding the Hudson River crossings and city streets with more traffic.
 
WILLIAM O. YATES
New York, June 2, 2000

HEADLINE: End the Cuba Embargo

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your June 3 news article reporting that Cuban officials are receptive to negotiating settlements regarding claims about foreigners' seized assets is another indication that this is an opportune time to negotiate ending the United States embargo of Cuba.
In Cuba, religious groups are highly active, professionals are linked with colleagues throughout the world through the Internet, small private businesses are increasing, foreign investors are making profits, dollars are legal tender, farmers sell a proportion of their production in the open market, and Canadian and European tourists are enjoying the resorts. 
 The Congressional bill to end the food and medicine embargo should be speedily enacted and other issues negotiated so as to end the embargo. These actions will aid the changes already under way in Cuba and facilitate an orderly and just transformation of Cuban-American relations.
 
LOUIS KRIESBERG
Syracuse, June 4, 2000

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Commies and Demmies

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Now that the smoke has cleared from the debate over whether to grant China permanent normal trade with the U.S. and membership in the World Trade Organization, it's time for some wild and irresponsible predictions. I'd like to start the bidding.
My prediction is that in the wake of the China vote two parties in the world will never be the same again: the Communist Party in China and the Democratic Party in America. 
 Let's look at each. For years Deng Xiaoping, the architect of China's shift to a free market, described China's economic system as capitalism with socialist characteristics, or was it socialism with capitalist characteristics? I could never keep it straight -- and neither could they. But it no longer matters, because China is now committed to capitalism with W.T.O. characteristics. And that is going to be a huge challenge. If the Chinese Communist Party doesn't adapt, either it will implode or China will explode.
Here's the problem: By joining the W.T.O., China is basically agreeing to replace its current mixed economy -- part free market, part state controlled -- which is run by the arbitrary decisions of the Communist Party, with an increasingly free-market economy that will abide by international rules, on trade, tariffs and investments, set by the W.T.O.
This means the Chinese Communist Party is going to have to back off and shape up or ship out. You can't have a flourishing free enterprise system with party hacks interfering with businesses and distorting prices; you can't have W.T.O.-style foreign investment without moving toward an independent judiciary that is free of arbitrary party meddling and is capable of fairly enforcing contracts; and you can't live up to W.T.O. norms without government agencies ready to enforce W.T.O. rules, not Communist Party whims. All that means a different Communist Party.
"The ideal situation would be if the Communist Party would serve as the bridge and tutor for China's move toward a free-market, rule-of-law-based system," argued the Stanford University China scholar Michael Oksenberg. "If that doesn't happen voluntarily, I see three other possibilities: One is that there will be some catalytic event, like a downturn in the economy, that will force the party to adapt, or face losing power and legitimacy. Second, there will be a split in the party leadership, between those who want to move forward and those who refuse. And third, there could be a mass movement from below. The longer the Chinese Communist Party puts off the first two, the more likely becomes the last scenario."
As for the U.S., the China vote was not really a vote about China. It was a vote about how Americans feel about globalization. And it revealed a deeply fractured Democratic Party. The unions were opposed and advocated building walls; the new-economy types, led by President Clinton, favored further globalization; and a large group of old Democrats advocated some middle ground, but had no leader or program to offer.
"We are becoming the party of resentment and fear, and that is not who we were and that is not who we want to be," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, about the number of Democrats who voted against normal trade with China.
The challenge for the Democratic Party, if it is to remain united, is to articulate a new progressivism that addresses the worries of working Americans about globalization -- without resorting to trade barriers. There is obviously a strong feeling among the party's rank and file that Mr. Clinton's "progressivism-lite" is insufficient. Which is why a lot of Democrats are now groping for a new combination of tax policy, labor policy and social policy that could form a modern progressivism. (It would help if the unions got their heads out of the sand. Imagine if all the money and energy they wasted lobbying against China were applied to health or education funding?)
Without articulating a new progressivism, the Democrats will either become indistinguishable from Republicans, especially under George W. Bush, or, if the unions have their way, the Democrats will become just kinder, gentler Buchananites.
So in the wake of the China vote the key question is: Can the Chinese Communists become a real democratic party and can the real Democratic Party become a true progressive party? Nobody gets to stay the same.

HEADLINE: What Dahl-Wolfe's Eye Created in a Lens

BYLINE: By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
When Carmen Dell'Orefice was 15 and modeling to help her mother pay the rent on a Third Avenue walk-up, she made a visit to the 57th Street studio of Louise Dahl-Wolfe. At the time, 1946, Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe, 51, was in her 10th year as the reigning photographer at Harper's Bazaar and her umpteenth as a woman who looked like a home economics teacher at a girls' reform school.
"She seemed ancient," Ms. Dell'Orefice recalled a few weeks ago. "The first thing she said to me was, 'Your mother shouldn't let you wear makeup.' " When Ms. Dell'Orefice answered that she wasn't wearing any, the photographer dragged her to a window and pinched her eyelashes for proof. Finally, Ms. Dell'Orefice was sent home on the grounds that she was too young to stand in front of a tripod for money, or at least too young for Bazaar's older readers. Not long after, she appeared on the cover of Vogue. 
 Louise Dahl-Wolfe would see dozens of models rise and fall before she died 43 years later, in 1989, at 94. On June 12, the Museum of the Fashion Institute of Technology will present the first full-scale retrospective of her work, little of which points to the kind of benighted sensibility her behavior, and a hair bun slathered with beeswax, might have led one to expect.
Curated by Irving Solero and Nan Richardson, the exhibition will run through Aug. 12 and move to the Center for Creative Photography in Tucson in September. A companion book by Ms. Richardson, "Louise Dahl-Wolfe: A Retrospective," is due from Harry N. Abrams this summer. Some of Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe's black-and-white images are on view at the Staley-Wise gallery.
During her time at Bazaar, a 22-year tenure that ended when she quit in 1958, after the magazine's editor, Carmel Snow, and the legendary art director Alexey Brodovitch both resigned, Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe chronicled the birth of a looser, less pinched spirit in American fashion. With Diana Vreeland as her fashion editor, Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe traveled around the world, shooting that new concept, sportswear, out of doors where it comfortably breathed. Before the triumvirate of Mrs. Snow, Mrs. Vreeland and Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe, American style, as Richard Avedon has put it, did not exist.
"Louise has a pivotal role moving fashion photography out of formal studio work into a portrayal of the active, modern American woman," Amy Rule, an archivist at the Center for Creative Photography, said.
Other photographers, like Martin Munkacsi and Toni Frissell, were already capturing the new mood, but Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe distinguished herself with images that implied a languorous sexuality. She often photographed models on the beach, in repose, their eyes closed or averted, their bodies positioned -- trapped -- rigidly in the frame. Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe seemed to realize that new sportswear by Claire McCardell and Bonnie Cashin offered women the semblance of an unconstricted life, not the real freedom that only a challenge to accepted social arrangements could bring.
The daughter of a Norwegian marine engineer, Louise Dahl was born in San Francisco in 1895 and showed no tendencies during her young womanhood to live within the narrow corridor of risk laid out for her sex. After studying art in San Francisco, she moved to New York to take classes in architecture and design. In 1927, she embarked on a tour of Europe with her friend Consuela Kanaga, a news photographer. A year went by, and when the women were bored with the Continent they headed for North Africa.
It was on a train platform in Tunisia in 1928 that Miss Dahl, 32, spotted her future husband, a sculptor from Tennessee named Meyer Wolfe. "She saw him," Irving Solero, who befriended Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe in 1978, recalled, "and said, 'That's for me.' " The two married that same year.
Without fail, those who knew Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe remark on the intense bond she and her husband shared. "They lived together nonstop, 24 hours a day," said Mr. Solero, who spent time with the couple in their Frenchtown, N.J., home, known as the Creamery. "They fought all the time, but a fight would erupt for five seconds and then it was over." Mr. Wolfe would travel with his wife, typically picking her up for lunch during out-of-town shoots.
"When he died at 88 she was self-abandoned," Mary Jane Russell, a friend and favorite model of Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe's, said recently. "Her mourning was coupled with anger: 'How could he have left me? Why couldn't I be first?' "
While she was close to Mrs. Russell, her relationships with others in the Harper's Bazaar orbit were more complex. Well into the 70's and 80's, Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe would talk about her former colleague Mr. Avedon "as though he were a kid," Mr. Solero said, adding, "She'd say, 'He has a long way to go.' "
Lillian Bassman, whose impressionistic photographs began appearing in Bazaar around 1950, said that Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe repeatedly tried to have her fired. In the mid-40's, when Ms. Bassman was still working in the magazine's art department as an apprentice, Carmel Snow sent her to Paris to try to find photographers who had worked for Bazaar before the war. Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe was so irritated at the prospect of competition, Ms. Bassman said, that she complained to Mrs. Snow that the art-director-in-training had been maligning her. Mrs. Snow swiftly dispatched Ms. Bassman to the country and out of the way. "It was a testimony to Louise's stature at the magazine," Ms. Bassman said. After that, their relationship was "a mess," she added.
With underlings in the fashion department, Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe often played the taskmaster. Some 50 years ago, the fashion editor Polly Mellen traveled to Jamaica with Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe for a shoot and recalled waking up every morning at 4:30 to braid the hair that would eventually be cranked into the photographer's signature bun. "In my growing years, she was one of the few people who really formed me," Ms. Mellen said. "She taught me extreme discipline." And demonstrated a certain largesse as well. When Ms. Mellen left Bazaar to marry in 1952, Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe gave her a going-away party and took her wedding pictures. "If she was on your side, you were most fortunate," Ms. Mellen said.
After Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe left Bazaar, she worked briefly for Vogue before relinquishing photography in 1960, saying that advertisers had gained too much influence over magazines. But however frustrated she had become with what she saw as the commercialization of magazines, she was never the sort who demanded that some notion of artistic vision take precedence over the business of showing off clothes. One hallmark of her thousands of published images, 86 Bazaar covers among them, is that the gowns and bathing suits and ski clothes are always visible front and center. "She worked for the magazine because she showed the frocks," said Martin Harrison, a curator and historian of photography. "The models were good-looking, and it was a great time for American fashion."
Even Mr. Harrison, a detractor, admits that Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe had a talent for color. In her effort to show garments to their best advantage, she would typically go to the printing press where Bazaar was churned out and nudge engravers to change a blue backdrop to, say, a yellow one if it made a dress look better. "It was almost as if she were a set designer," said Christopher Greene, who produced prints from Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe's negatives late in her life.
While Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe might flinch at the sort of images that today fill the pages of avant-garde fashion magazines like Dazed and Confused, the striking, saturated colors that are their trademark hark back, in some sense, to her. Before the rise of digital technology, it was impossible to reproduce prints from Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe's Kodachromes that resembled what appeared on the printed page.
That is one reason, said Ms. Richardson, the Fashion Institute curator, that a coffee-table book of her work has never been published before.
Another is that Mrs. Dahl-Wolfe always thought the notion rather flashy and pretentious.

HEADLINE: Public Interests;
Panning For Gold in New Jersey

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
There's one heck of a lot of money sloshing around the political troughs these days. According to a report in yesterday's Times by William Glaberson, one race for the Ohio Supreme Court this year is going to cost up to $12 million. We have candidates spending a couple of million dollars to become state legislator, a job that generally carries less prestige than that of nightclub bouncer. At this rate, the next bunch of people stranded on a desert island with a TV crew is going to demand a whole lot more than a lousy million dollars for the effort. (Coming soon: "Who Wants to Be a Political Consultant?")
This brings us to the primary today in New Jersey, where a former Wall Street honcho named Jon Corzine has spent close to $35 million trying to win the Democratic nomination for U.S. Senate against former Gov. Jim Florio, whose entire budget is approximately what Mr. Corzine will be spending on fax machines and commemorative potholders. 
 Mr. Corzine is in many ways a fascinating story, although the fascinating part does not seem to follow him onto the campaign trail. Despite the very best coaching money can buy and a dramatically left-wing agenda, he makes Steve Forbes look like Franklin Delano Roosevelt. (In a recent debate, Mr. Corzine delivered this defense for his largess: "I have not been a politician and spent 30 million and over 30 years building name recognition and establishing the perspectives people might have. I needed to communicate.")
According to one of his associates, Mr. Corzine entered the race envisioning a $10 million primary, a plan that went awry somewhere between his decision to hire Robert Shrum, the man who gave us Al Checchi's failed $38 million campaign for governor of California, and the moment he started opening his checkbook for the local Democratic organizations. Mr. Corzine used to be famous for his munificent federal campaign contributions. But he assured New Jersey party officials that his newfound interest in state politics would naturally be reflected by a shift in his gift-giving. This had the approximate effect of tossing a chunk of hamburger into a tank of piranhas. "Word got out there was this pot there, and things got out of control," conceded one campaign official.
One of the comforting things about American election campaigns is the way the monetary playing field keeps leveling. You come into the game like George W. Bush with a big fat financial cushion and slurp, it vanishes. Nature may abhor a vacuum, but political campaigns can create one in a minute.
"There's always that pressure -- to donate to the local parties, hire the local potentates' daughters. You end up not saying no to anything," recalled John Weaver, who has run presidential campaigns for candidates with too little cash (John McCain) and too much (Phil Gramm). "Gramm went through the money pretty quickly," he recalled. "We had about 25 opposition research people. We probably needed one."
But there is no way that Mr. Corzine could go through his entire $400 million fortune running for Senate -- potentates have only just so many unemployed relatives and you can only run so many ads on TV before the viewer throws a shoe through the screen. Even as it is, Mr. Corzine may have overdone it. He seems to have made people feel a little sorry for Mr. Florio, a feat most New Jersey residents might have hitherto regarded as impossible. Mr. Corzine not only spent about 20 times as much as his opponent, he also managed to make Mr. Florio, whose household income last year was more than $500,000, look underprivileged.
Mr. Corzine has already broken the record for spending in a U.S. Senate race, set by Michael Huffington in California in 1994. But that was for the entire election, against an incumbent. It takes a lot of money to overcome those odds, especially when your candidate seems both shy and dimwitted. Mr. Corzine is running for a vacant seat, against a primary opponent who is best known for having raised taxes by $2.8 billion. He does not seem to lack aggression. His friends say he is smart, and they rave about his generosity.
In fact, if all the stories about his beneficence are true, every single person who put a Corzine sign on the front lawn this week should expect to be rewarded with a paid-off mortgage or, at minimum, a reshingled roof. When the money starts sloshing, the wise man goes for a pail.
