HEADLINE: Words of Clinton: Gains Despite Pains of Growth

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, June 5

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from President Clinton's address today to the Russian Parliament, as transcribed by eMediaMillWorks Inc.:
A great deal of the 21st century will be strongly influenced by the success of the Russian people in building a modern, strong, democratic nation that is part of the life of the rest of the world. 
 And so many people across the world have sought to support your efforts, sharing with you a sense of pride when democracy is advanced and sharing your disappointment when difficulties arose.
It is obviously not for me to tell the Russian people how to interpret the last few years. I know your progress has come with unfilled expectations and unexpected difficulties. I know there have been moments, especially during the financial crisis in 1998, when some wondered if the new Russia would end up as a grand social experiment gone wrong.
But when we look at Russia today, we do not see an experiment gone wrong.
We see an economy that is growing, producing goods and services people want. We see a nation of enterprising citizens who are beginning, despite all of the obstacles, to bring good jobs and a normal life to their communities. . . .
We see Russian citizens with no illusions about the road ahead, yet voting in extraordinary numbers against a return to the past. We see a Russia that has just completed a democratic transfer of executive power for the first time in 1,000 years.
I would not presume to tell the people you represent how to weigh the gains of freedom against the pain of economic hardship, corruption, crime. I know the people of Russia do not yet have the Russia they were promised in 1991. But I believe you, and they, now have a realistic chance to build that kind of Russia for yourselves in far greater measure than a decade ago, because of the democratic foundations that have been laid and the choices that have been made.
The world faces a very different Russia than it did in 1991. Like all countries, Russia also faces a very different world. Its defining feature is globalization, the tearing down of boundaries between people, nations and cultures, so that what happens anywhere can have an impact everywhere.
During the 1990's, the volume of international trade almost doubled. . . . Now Russia, America and all nations are subject to new rules of the global economy. One of those rules, to adapt a phrase from your history, is that it's no longer possible to build prosperity in one country alone. To prosper, our economies must be competitive in a global marketplace. And to compete, the most important resource we must develop is our own people, giving them the tools and freedom to reach their full potential.
This is the challenge we have tried to meet in America over the last few years. Indeed, the changes we have seen in the global economy pose hard questions that both our nations still must answer. A fundamental question is how do we define our strength and vitality as a nation today and what role should government play in building it? . . .
Another fundamental question is how shall countries define their strength in relation to the rest of the world today? Shall we define it as the power to dominate our neighbors or the confidence to be a good neighbor? Shall we define it by what we are against or simply in terms of what others are for? Do we join with others in common endeavors to advance common interests or do we try to bend others to our will?
This federal assembly's ratification of Start II and the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty suggests you are answering these questions in a way that will make for both a stronger Russia and a better world, defining your strength in terms of the achievements of your people and the power of your partnerships and your role in world affairs.
A related question for both Russia and America is how should we define our relationship today? Clearly, Russia has entered a phase when what it needs most is outside investment, not aid. What Americans must ask is not so much what can we do for Russia, but what can we do with Russia to advance our common interests and lift people in both nations?

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
As Rate Fears Ebb, Treasury Yields Fall

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Yields on Treasury securities fell to six-week lows yesterday on expectations that the Federal Reserve would not need to raise interest rates as much as forecast to slow the economy and curb inflationary pressure.
"A lot of economic data has suggested the economy is slowing in a broad-based way," said Steven Wood, a senior economist at Banc of America Securities in San Francisco, "and that takes pressure off the Fed to raise rates in June." He added that "the positive tone will be carried over" in the fixed-income markets. 
 The yield on the most-actively-traded 10-year Treasury note fell to 6.12 percent, the lowest level since April 24, from 6.16 percent on Friday. Its price, which moves in the opposite direction from the yield, rose 9/32, or $2.81 for each $1,000 face amount, to 102 23/32. The 30-year bond's yield dropped to 5.92 percent from 5.94 percent. Its price rose 12/32, to 104 21/32.
Some investors bought the higher-yielding debt of government-sponsored agencies like the mortgage financiers Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, said Steve Smith, head of government bond trading at Dain Rauscher Wessels in Minneapolis. The benchmark 10-year Fannie Mae notes currently yield 1.09 percentage points more than 10-year Treasuries.
Treasuries may also be sold this week to hedge against possible losses in a number of expected corporate bond sales, some analysts said. Companies including Ford and International Paper plan to sell investment-grade and high-yield bonds totaling more than $10 billion in the coming days to take advantage of lower rates.
The results of yesterday's Treasury auction of three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Hillary Clinton Wins Praise At U.N. Meeting on Women

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, June 5

 BODY:
Hillary Rodham Clinton took time off from state politics today to come back to feminism and the United Nations, where her audience has always been friendly, to deliver a spirited speech on women's rights.
Mrs. Clinton was not the main event. She spoke at one of many meetings on the margins of a weeklong special General Assembly session to assess the progress of women worldwide, five years after a groundbreaking conference in Beijing. 
 She is not part of the American delegation, as she was then. But the difference was lost on her audience of women from every continent, who greeted her with warmth and enthusiasm. They sang, clapped and grasped for her hand as they stormed the podium -- a display that no other speaker is likely to enjoy.
More than 10,000 women, and some men, from more than 180 countries are in New York for the session and dozens of related events.
Gita Sen, a development expert from India, said that Mrs. Clinton struck a responsive cord because of her unambiguous commitment to women's rights everywhere, a message many people gathered here say they want to hear more often from Americans, who seem to many to have withdrawn from the organization and the world in recent years.
"We are committed to making this journey together," Mrs. Clinton told a cheering audience invited by Unifem, the United Nations development program for women.
Her pledge came on a day when a group of independent organizations issued a call for help to forestall efforts they say the Vatican and some conservative Islamic and Catholic countries are making to reverse gains achieved five years ago at the Fourth International Conference on Women. At that meeting, a watershed event that brought grass-roots women's groups and governments together to form networks that continue to operate, most nations pledged to promote women's rights in areas as diverse as education, family planning and sexual relationships.
Richard C. Holbrooke, the United States ambassador to the United Nations, said Mrs. Clinton had laid out the administration's position forcefully. "It was Hillary saying, do not erode the gains of Beijing," he said.
Ms. Sen, a professor at the Indian Institute of Management in Bangalore and the leader of an organization for women from developing nations, said in an interview that this conference -- like the one in Beijing -- was in danger of sinking into arid debate over definitions and intentions. This meeting is intended to look for ways to move ahead, not to reopen debate on the issues, she said.
Women no longer want to debate the meaning of "family" or parse what "access to health care" means in relation to abortion, said Joana Foster, a Zimbabwean who is a leader of Women in Law and Development in Africa. "Africans think debates over nuances and language are a waste of time."
Ms. Foster represents a new generation of women in Africa, Latin America, the Caribbean and Asia who have worked hard through international conferences for improvements in women's rights and are determined to maintain the momentum. She said that international agreements like the Beijing "platform for action" have real effects in developing countries.
"Beijing was a catalyst for a whole lot of things," she said. "People are getting into Parliament. Look at somewhere like Namibia, which now has 44 percent women in the local government system. In South Africa, Mozambique, Kenya, Ghana people are now fighting for affirmative action to become part and parcel of the constitutions in their countries."
"F.G.M. was a big thing in Beijing for all of us," Ms. Foster said, using shorthand for the term female genital mutilation, or the ritual cutting of girls' genitals. "A lot of countries have passed laws against it. There is that sort of progress going on. For us, we don't want a document that future governments can use to stop the progress."
In Beijing five years ago, nations agreed to end laws that discriminate against women and to open more education to girls. They also called for closing income gaps between women and men.
Secretary General Kofi Annan opened the formal assembly session by reminding his audience of goals still to be met. "Most countries have yet to legislate in favor of women's rights to own land," he said. "Violence against women is still increasing -- both in the home and in the newer types of armed conflict which target civilian populations."
Of 110 million children not in school, he said, two-thirds are girls.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Share Prices Mixed as Investors Pause Over Recent Gains

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday, as investors paused to reassess their opportunities after last week's big advance.
Traders said they were encouraged by the price action. Yesterday's activity stood in stark contrast to the eruptions seen for much of the recent past. 
 "Back in April and May you would get a 150-point to 200-point rally and give it all back the next day," said Ned Collins, head trader at Daiwa Securities America.
"As far as I am concerned," he added, "it is good that we are treading water. We had such a big move last week that we need to consolidate some."
Led by Hewlett-Packard, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.54 points, or 0.2 percent, to 10,815.30. But the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 9.63 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,467.63, attributed in part to declines in General Electric, Cisco Systems and Wells Fargo.
The Nasdaq composite index, which rose a record 19 percent last week, rallied during the last hour of trading yesterday and closed at 3,821.76, up 8.38 points, or 0.2 percent.
And the Russell 2000 index of small- company stocks also managed to eke out a small gain, rising 0.27 point, to 513.30.
Stocks jumped last week on reports that showed the economy might be losing some of its momentum, an indication that efforts by the Federal Reserve Board to achieve that end might be working.
Since last June, the Fed has raised short-term interest rates six times to cool the economy and dampen inflationary pressures.
The only report of any note this week, however, is the Producer Price Index for May on Friday.
As a consequence, analysts said stock prices were expected to remain in a trading range for this week, and possibly a good deal longer.
"To stay in a trading range is probably the best thing that can happen to the market," said Kenneth M. Sheinberg, head of listed trading at SG Cowen.
"It gives the people the chance to get into stocks they want to get into, and to sell others at levels they want," he said. "There is no need to panic one way or the other. That is probably helpful, because the market needs to be a little calmer."
Trading volume was light, but not abnormally so for a Monday in what Wall Street considers the summer season.
Some 838 million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume on the Nasdaq stock market was 1.4 billion shares.
Hewlett-Packard was the Dow's biggest gainer, rising 9 3/8, to 120 3/8.
Microsoft and I.B.M. also helped to move the Dow higher.
Microsoft rose 9/16, to 66 7/8, after it said it would spend $2 billion to speed adoption of its new Internet-based software.
I.B.M. rose 4, to 112 7/16, after a Merrill Lynch analyst expressed optimism about its prospects for the second half of the year.
But Intel slumped 1 5/8, to 132 9/16, as investors took some profits after last week's big advance. Intel's shares gained 14 percent last week.
Bank stocks, which have rallied strongly in recent weeks on hopes that an end to interest rate increases by the Fed is near, retreated yesterday.
Wells Fargo, an S.& P. 500 component, lost 2 3/8, to 45 1/8. Bank of America slid 1 3/4, to 59 1/4. Chase Manhattan lost 13/16, to 79 3/8. And Bank of New York shed 1 3/4, to 46 7/8.
Biotechnology stocks, which posted very good gains last week, continued to advance.
Genentech was the biggest winner, rising 19 7/8, to 129, after the drugmaker won approval from the Food and Drug Administration for TNKase, a next-generation version of Activase, a clot-busting drug for heart attack patients.
Human Genome Sciences rose 7 9/16, to 113 1/2. And PE Corp Celera jumped 22 1/2, to 91.
"I was expecting some retrenchment in the biotech sector, and it didn't happen," said Mike Weiner, a managing director at BancOne Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio. "The follow-through in those stocks surprised me, and it probably masked some weakness in the Nasdaq."

HEADLINE: Doubts Rise on New Site for Big Board

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Eighteen months after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced plans to build a new trading complex for the New York Stock Exchange, the city has still not signed a formal agreement with the exchange for the heavily subsidized project, which includes a huge office tower in Lower Manhattan.
Nor have city and state officials signed a deal to buy the land for the project, an entire block bounded by Wall Street, Exchange Place, Broad Street and William Street. Even so, the estimated size of the public subsidy has grown to $640 million from $560 million, not including the cost of the land. 
 Despite the lengthy delays, the exchange says it is moving forward, and some public officials are optimistic that the deal to build the complex will ultimately fall into place.
Behind the scenes, however, there is bickering and widespread doubt that the project is necessary, given the advent of electronic networks that could replace the need for traditional trading floors. Although more than 680 million shares a day are traded on the New York Stock Exchange, critics contend that investors in the United States are increasingly buying and selling over the Internet, while the major stock exchanges in London, Frankfurt and elsewhere have already converted to electronic trading.
"There's a big question whether you need trading floors anymore," said Norman S. Poser, a former executive vice president of the American Stock Exchange and a professor of securities law at Brooklyn Law School. "In Europe, you don't have any more trading floors. It's electronic; all the trading's done at your desk."
But Richard A. Grasso, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, has insisted that there will always be a need for the trading floors that have made it the world's premier exchange. Electronic communications networks such as Instinet and Island now account for about 30 percent of the transaction volume on the Nasdaq but have failed to make much of a dent at the exchange, where institutional investors still prefer to trade. Mr. Grasso has said the exchange needs a new complex to grow beyond its cramped historic headquarters on Wall Street.
"We continue to work with the city and the state to move the project forward as expeditiously as possible," said Ray Pellecchia, a spokesman for the Big Board. "We have the same space needs we had earlier. Our plans haven't changed a bit."
Neither Deputy Mayor Robert R. Harding nor Michael Carey, president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, returned calls requesting comment.
City and state officials have completed a draft environmental impact statement for the project but have held off certifying the project for public review. Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said that he expected to submit the environmental statement for public review as soon as the exchange signed a letter of intent. "Everyone is still working together," Mr. Gargano said. "It has taken a very long time, but it's a very large project."
But according to several people involved in the negotiations, some public officials contend that the stock exchange has dragged its feet over signing a letter of intent with the city, possibly because of its own uncertainty. The letter was supposed to be signed over a year ago. Exchange executives have played down the importance of the document, countering that they would sign a binding lease for the trading complex if only the city would complete a deal to buy the land for the project.
The land deal is another thicket of recriminations. The city has been negotiating with J.P. Morgan, which controls four of the five buildings on the proposed site, and the Rockrose Development Corporation, which owns the fifth, an apartment house. Yet, Morgan has stopped moving employees out of the buildings and Rockrose is still renting apartments.
According to the officials involved in the negotiations, J.P. Morgan has grown tired of waiting for the city to complete its agreement with the exchange. The company wants the city to buy the land now or allow it to sell the property to a developer. The city, in turn, suspects that Morgan is trying to get a higher price for its property, according to the officials.
City officials expect that it will cost about $350 million to acquire all the property and relocate tenants, but it is loath to do so without a definitive deal with the exchange. The city has said that the projected rent from the trading complex and the office tower should more than offset the cost of buying the land.
The project has evolved since a mayoral news conference in December 1998. Mayor's Giuliani's offer to build a trading complex for the exchange came after Mr. Grasso threatened to move to New Jersey. The city did not want to risk losing the exchange and the possible dissolution of the financial district, although many real estate and financial executives doubted that the exchange would move.
Unlike the city, the state has been more skeptical of threats by the exchange and has tried to limit the state's financial stake in the project. As a result, the city has committed $255 million toward the $480 million cost of the trading complex, while the state has declined to go above $225 million.
In recent months, according to a copy of the draft environmental impact study obtained by The New York Times, the size of the trading complex has been cut 25 percent, to 600,000 square feet. The complex would contain a 50,000-square-foot trading floor, a smaller trading floor and administrative offices. The stock exchange has said it will spend $350 million to outfit the complex.
At the same time, the office tower, which is to sit atop the trading complex, has grown to 1.3 million square feet from 1.2 million.
Some critics said that the project was beginning to look more like a real estate deal than an effort to keep the stock exchange in Lower Manhattan.
"It certainly raises the question of whether the city is providing incentives to keep the stock exchange, or to build another office tower," said Jonathan Bowles, research director of the Center for an Urban Future.

HEADLINE: Putin Travels to Rome to Promote Russian Arms Control Alternative

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

DATELINE: ROME, June 5

 BODY:
Leaving President Clinton behind in Moscow, Vladimir V. Putin came to Rome today to sell Europe -- and the Vatican -- on a Russian alternative to the United States missile defense proposal.
The two-day trip was timed to follow his somewhat tense discussions with Mr. Clinton about altering the Antiballistic Missile Treaty. And it was choreographed to put Mr. Putin's heightened sense of Russian power on display. He left for Rome one hour before his American guest flew to Ukraine, kept John Paul II waiting 20 minutes and used his meeting with Italian officials as an opportunity to use Europe as a wedge in Russia's arms control negotiations with the United States. 
 The trip, which was to include meetings with business and energy industry leaders in Milan on Tuesday, is also an effort to attract European investment in Russia's economy. Italy is Russia's leading trade partner in Europe after Germany. Mr. Putin, a somber former K.G.B. officer rarely given to public displays of exuberance, tried to disarm his Mediterranean hosts by saying he came to Rome early in his term "because we love Italy." Soon after his election in April, he also paid a visit to Prime Minister Tony Blair in London.
Mr. Putin's public remarks here, made after a two-hour meeting with the Italian prime minister, Giuliano Amato, were aimed at swaying international opinion on arms control, and in particular at exploiting European fears that the United States is embarked on a risky course to refashion the ABM treaty to create a missile defense system aimed at protecting itself.
"Russia proposed working with Europe and NATO to create an anti-rocket defense system for Europe," Mr. Putin told reporters after meeting with Mr. Amato. "On one hand, it would avoid all the problems linked to the balance of force. On the other, it would permit in an absolute manner a 100 percent guarantee of the security of every European country."
The Russian proposal, which Mr. Putin made public in a NBC News interview last week on the eve of Mr. Clinton's arrival in Moscow, seems to offer the United States and Europe a joint missile defense program using short- and medium-range missiles to destroy rockets on their way up, instead of intercepting warheads on their way down. Mr. Putin's proposal resembles what advocates in the United States call a "boost phase defense." This could in theory ward off attacks from so-called "rogue" states, but would be of little use against the Russian nuclear force.
That would make it more acceptable to the Russian military, which fears that a solely American missile force could be used to gain a strategic advantage. But the United States military believes that the Russian approach cannot work, and wants to amend the ABM treaty to build a battle-management radar in Alaska and put 100 interceptors there to protect the 50 states.
In Italy, Mr. Putin emphasized the advantages of his plan to Europe's defense, seeking to exploit European fears that American efforts to rewrite the ABM treaty could destabilize relations with Russia and leave Europe unprotected.
"We know that many here in Europe and in the world and the United States are worried about whether the 1972 accord would be kept," Mr. Putin said, referring to the treaty. "We share the point of departure of this discussion," he said.
European leaders have warned of the dangers of any unilateral change in the treaty. Italy, current chairman of the Council of Europe, has often argued that Russia cannot be left out of any effort to limit the missile threat.
"There was nothing fundamentally new in what Putin proposed, but it seemed newly tailored to meet European needs," one Italian diplomat said. "Europeans are preoccupied with any decoupling of their own security, on one hand, and any unilateral change in international agreements that could lead to a weakening of security." He added: "But fear of unilateral actions works both ways -- vis-a-vis Russia as well as the United States."
Mr. Putin went to the Vatican for his first encounter with John Paul II. Arriving 20 minutes late, Mr. Putin was greeted warmly by the Polish pope, who told his visitor in Italian, "I am very happy to receive you at the Vatican at the beginning of your presidential mandate."
According to the Vatican spokesman, Joaquin Navarro-Valls, Mr. Putin spent most of the 30-minute meeting describing his vision of how Russia should be integrated into Western Europe and his views of how the Vatican could help the process. Calling Mr. Putin's proposal a "very ambitious approach," Dr. Navarro-Valls said that the Pope "mainly listened, then gave some remarks."
The pope, who turned 80 in May, has long yearned to visit Russia. But the Russian Patriarch, Aleksy II, has never agreed to a meeting with the pope, citing grievances like Roman Catholic proselytizing and its support of Eastern rite Catholic Churches in Ukraine.
 Mr. Putin did not directly renew a longstanding invitation, which Vatican officials noted is still active. But the fact that John Paul II listened attentively to Mr. Putin and refrained, at least publicly, from raising issues like Chechnya that could have embarrassed the president, suggested that the Vatican has some optimism for the future.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 485 words

HEADLINE: Peace Across the Hudson

 BODY:
The biggest network of airports, train lines, bus terminals and port facilities in the New York region is run by one giant agency, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Last week, Gov. George Pataki and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman reached an important agreement to end a fight over distribution of the authority's subsidies and projects. The accord, which ends 18 months of paralysis, grants Mr. Pataki's request for more resources spent in New York. It was a welcome step, but much more thinking is needed to revitalize the authority as an engine of economic growth.
The authority runs some operations that are profitable and others that lose money. Its stated goal has always been to mix burdens and benefits in a way that is fair to both sides. Since World War II, however, it has made sense for both states to allow shipping terminals to move to New Jersey, where there are better links to the continental United States and more room for container operations. 
 New York still gains from being the site of many businesses that serve the shipping industry.
Mr. Pataki has cried foul, however, as New Jersey also got the benefits of a new airport at Newark. In addition, the authority subsidizes the PATH lines and buses, enabling New Jersey commuters to pay lower fares than their counterparts on New York City's subways and buses.
The accord announced last week will restore some balance. For New Jersey, it approves a 30-year lease at Elizabeth Marine Terminal to the Maersk-Sealand container shipping company, which was threatening to go to Baltimore or Halifax. The authority will spend $575 million over 30 years to deepen the channel and make other improvements. But New Jersey commuters will also have to pay more in bus and subway fares.
New York is to gain by being able to sell or privatize the World Trade Center, sell air rights over the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan and embark on several beneficial projects. One could lead to a nonstop transit ride to Kennedy Airport, while another would help build a new Penn Station at the post office building on 34th Street.
New Yorkers should not give up on the Port Authority, as Mayor Rudolph Giuliani has with his effort to take over operations of Kennedy and La Guardia Airports. Instead of balkanizing the authority, its resources should be spread to benefit everyone. In the years ahead, the authority can do much to help commuters in New York. One positive step would be for the authority to help extend the No. 7 line from Grand Central to Pennsylvania Station and the Hudson River, where it could provide a link from Queens to the New Jersey transit lines and spur economic growth on Manhattan's West Side.
Nearly 80 years ago, the Port Authority's creation was hailed as a landmark in regional cooperation. It is time to look beyond the spoils and get back to a vision as valid today as it was back then.

HEADLINE: Port Authority Rift Revealed States' Competitive Instincts

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

 BODY:
Closing the deal took just a few hours of phone calls between Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and Gov. George E. Pataki of New York. Making it official took just two minutes' worth of votes by the board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
But the agreement that the two states reached last week, unleashing millions of dollars' worth of stalled projects, was the result of a roller coaster ride of negotiations and escalating demands that had stretched out for more than a year. 
 So on Friday, as the agency's 12-member board ratified the deal, which had been clinched the day before by the two governors, many of those involved in the talks could not forget that troubling history amid the governors' tableau of unity.
It is difficult to calculate whether one state got more out of the deal than the other. But it is clear that their jockeying for advantage allowed a dispute over a single issue -- a 30-year lease for the Maersk-Sealand shipping line to expand its operations at the Elizabeth Marine Terminal in New Jersey -- to snowball into an 18-month stalemate in which all of the Port Authority's long-term projects were kept in limbo.
The impasse took on a life of its own, said an adviser to Governor Whitman, until "everything was on the table" -- including otherwise routine expenditures, like the purchase of cranes and barges.
As the board met month after month, unable to agree on much, negotiators talked almost daily.
The turning point in the talks is difficult to identify. Some involved in the negotiations say key steps to compromise were an increase in the pool of money available for New York projects, New Jersey's willingness to consider fare increases on the PATH commuter rail line, and a realization on both sides that basic philosophical differences over the operations of the Port Authority were not going to be reconciled.
In addition, there was growing criticism from newspaper editorial boards and former governors in both states, who said the dispute was embarrassing the agency.
But even as the settlement was being finalized, some people close to the negotiations suggested that the dispute could have been settled earlier but for each state's determination to wring out greater concessions in the allocation of funds.
And even as they detailed the concessions that had made the settlement possible, officials on both sides of the Hudson privately pointed out ways in which their state had "won."
Some New York officials suggested that they had triumphed by negotiating an additional $287 million to cover unexpected increases in the cost of a terminal and rail link between Kennedy International Airport and subway and commuter lines in Queens, as well as $13 million for economic development in the neighborhood. But New Jersey officials pointed out that the Port Authority had already committed $1.6 billion toward the project, and was unlikely to leave it incomplete.
New Jersey, in turn, claimed victory in overcoming New York's objections to the Maersk-Sealand lease, which Mrs. Whitman said would guarantee the region's dominance among East Coast ports. But New York officials suggested that by temporarily withholding their support for a lease that they agree was necessary, they had prevented the Port Authority from handing a "blank check" to the shipping company.
Lewis Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority and New Jersey's chief negotiator throughout the stalemate, said last week that such comments on either side amounted to a kind of bean counting.
"It is what someone would say to stir the pot and continue the friction," he said. "But it is contrary to the spirit which I saw in the governors of New York and New Jersey as they worked this out."
Still, Mr. Eisenberg and his New York counterpart, Charles A. Gargano, vice chairman of the Port Authority and chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, concede that philosophical differences persist between the states on the direction and approach of the agency.
At the heart of the dispute was the Maersk-Sealand lease, which was first proposed in early 1999 and ran aground because New York officials believed that it provided too large a subsidy to the company.
In retaliation, Mrs. Whitman ordered Mr. Eisenberg and other New Jersey representatives on the board to block two projects New York favored: the leasing of air rights over the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan and efforts to sell or lease the World Trade Center.
Then, in February 1999, officials close to Mrs. Whitman said privately that the two sides had tentatively agreed to a compromise. It would have provided New York with $120 million in Port Authority funds for projects of the state's choosing, as well as $120 million for New York's plan to renovate the main post office in mid-Manhattan into a transportation and office complex that would include a new Pennsylvania Station.
But hopes of a settlement were dashed, some officials say, when Mr. Pataki was pressed by advisers and Port Authority officials to hold out for more. Mr. Gargano disputes this, saying that in early 1999 the Pataki administration was adamant that the Maersk-Sealand lease would unfairly benefit New Jersey by providing hundreds of millions of dollars in subsidies to the shipper.
New York said it should receive a pool of money for New York-based projects equal to the amount of that subsidy -- an amount calculated by New York at various times to be as much as $1.6 billion and as little as $250 million over the life of the lease. New York also called for the port agency to support its Manhattan transportation complex as a truly regional project. But New Jersey balked, Mr. Gargano said.
The next opportunity to resolve the dispute came last June, said Michael P. Torpey, Governor Whitman's chief of staff, when the states faced warnings from American Airlines at Kennedy Airport and Continental Airlines at Newark International Airport. The two airlines said their expansion projects at the airports were in jeopardy without Port Authority investments.
That led to an effort to reach a settlement that would include the airport projects, the Maersk-Sealand lease and the World Trade Center and Port Authority Bus Terminal plans. But the broader accord sank even as the airport projects were approved; both states believed that the airport projects were too important to risk, Mr. Torpey said.
Through much of last summer and into the fall, only minor progress was made in settling the dispute.
Meanwhile, the agency had a growing backlog of stalled spending proposals generally supported by the two states -- for new cranes, development of Howland Hook as a container port on Staten Island, and the lease or sale of the Port Authority-owned Newark Legal Center.
New York increasingly framed the dispute as a debate over fairness. New Jersey, it said, was disproportionately benefiting from Port Authority spending -- whether at Newark Airport, which had grown tremendously in the last decade, or in New Jersey's containerized-cargo operations. Easily reached by truck and rail, they had long ago supplanted New York's traffic-clogged port areas as prime berthing areas for the new, larger container ships.
So New York began pushing for an increase in fares on the PATH line, long a sore point. The Port Authority is subsidizing the line to the tune of $181 million this year, and New York sees that as a benefit mainly for New Jersey residents.
In last week's deal, New Jersey agreed to allow a study that is likely to lead to the first increase in the $1 PATH fare since 1987.
In the end, said Mr. Torpey, it was unclear exactly why the feud was resolved when it was. "It had gone on long enough," he said. "Maybe it was time. Maybe it was in the stars."

HEADLINE: Preferring Rochester to Silicon Valley

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER

 BODY:
On paper, at least, Christine B. Whitman looks like a slice of old Rochester. She grew up there, works at a company that was once part of Kodak, lives in a local landmark, and serves on the boards of all kinds of civic groups.
But how many members of the old guard long for "a nerd bird" -- nonstop jet service from Rochester to Silicon Valley? 
 And that is just one of the things that makes Chris Whitman a living symbol of the new, high-tech Rochester, many people here say. The company she runs, CVC, makes equipment for the computer industry. It sells these machines to Kodak and Xerox, yes, but also to I.B.M. and Sony and Seagate Technology.
CVC not only sells its products around the world, but it also has offices across the country and overseas. Ms. Whitman spends much of her time on the road, and keeps an apartment in California near her Silicon Valley office.
Why did she not move CVC out there, to where so many of her high-tech customers are? "I considered that," she said. "But my family is here, and we are committed to the Rochester area." Her husband, Steve, teaches advanced placement physics at Brighton High School; her son is in the eighth grade (and her daughter attends the University of Illinois).
"Years ago, Rochester was fairly self-contained, probably not as global and diverse," she said. But as the economy has shifted to smaller, high-tech firms, she added, "more of us are traveling through the world."
Getting potential employees to move to Rochester has been a challenge, Ms. Whitman concedes: "People think this is pretty close to Alaska, not a little bit west of Boston." But she has succeeded in attracting employees by concentrating on people with families who would be attracted to Rochester's cultural and recreational amenities, she said, and the fact that it is "a low-hassle place to live."
She has done things unimagined by most worker bees. After a dozen years at CVC, she raised money and bought out the previous owners in 1990 (the company was started as a division of Kodak in 1934).
In 1999, she took the company public by selling stock through a big Wall Street firm, Lehman Brothers. CVC had gone from about 100 employees and $10 million of sales to 400 employees and $100 million of sales.
And this year, she did a very un-Rochester thing -- she merged CVC with a company from Long Island, Veeco. She became president and chief operating officer of the merged company, and remains based in Rochester.
Not everything has gone smoothly, of course. Veeco CVC has announced the layoff of 180 people, most of them at a plant in Virginia.
In Rochester, "generations of people lived, their children stayed, there wasn't much movement," Ms. Whitman said. That, she said, is no longer true.
Does she expect her own children to stay in Rochester? "I'd say," she replies after a pause, "they're going to go where their careers take them."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

F.C.C. Approves Purchase Of Cable Giant by AT&T
The Federal Communications Commission approved AT&T's acquisition of MediaOne after ordering the companies to sell some of their assets, clearing the final obstacle to a merger that will create the nation's largest provider of cable television, long-distance telephone service and high-speed Internet access. 
 The F.C.C. gave the companies a choice of which programming and cable subsidiaries and investments to sell to comply with a rule that forbids a corporation from having interests in more than 30 percent of the nation's cable and satellite television market. Officials estimate that, without any divestitures, AT&T and MediaOne would control more than 40 percent of that market. Page A1.
 
Thomson to Purchase Primark
Thomson, which is selling most of its newspapers to focus on the electronic distribution of legal and financial information, agreed to buy Primark for $842 million. Thomson will pay $38 a share for Primark, a 31 percent premium to Primark's stock price of $29 on Friday. Shares of Primark, based in Waltham, Mass., rose $8.25, to $37.25, while Thomson fell 1.80 Canadian dollars, to 49.20. C4.
 
Merrill in Talks to Buy Market Maker
Merrill Lynch is in discussions to buy Herzog Heine Geduld for nearly $1 billion, according to people close to the companies. The deal, which could be announced as soon as today, would give Merrill a much larger role in trading on the Nasdaq stock market. C2.
 
Stocks Mixed in Lackluster Session
Stock prices were mixed as investors paused after last week's big advance. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 20.54 points, to 10,815.30, but the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 9.63 points, or 0.7 percent, to 1,467.63. The Nasdaq composite index, which rose a record 19 percent last week, rallied during the last hour of trading and closed at 3,821.76, up 8.38 points, or 0.2 percent. C12.
 
S.E.C. Tackles Variable Annuities
In the midst of a federal examination of the sale of variable annuities, a fast-growing and controversial combination of mutual funds and insurance, a senior Securities and Exchange Commission official issued a stern warning that misleading tactics and incomplete disclosure would not be tolerated. C6.
 
Start-Up Seeks Copyright Ruling
In a case experts say may have broad implications for whether automated Internet search engines can be held liable for linking to pirated material, an Internet start-up, MP3Board.com, has asked a federal judge to find that it is not abetting copyright infringement simply by linking to MP3 music files. C27.
 
I.M.F. Chief Advises Indonesia
The new managing director of the International Monetary Fund said that closing off Indonesian capital markets would hinder the nation's fragile economic recovery. The I.M.F.'s chief, Horst Kohler, left, emerged from a breakfast meeting with President Abdurrahman Wahid and briskly dispelled speculation that the I.M.F. would agree to an Indonesian effort to defend its faltering currency, the rupiah, by placing controls on the currency. C4.
 
Health and Safety Concerns in China
As China applies to join the World Trade Organization, international concern has been directed at the sometimes unpleasant or dangerous working conditions in the country's export industries, especially those owned by foreign companies. But health and safety conditions are generally far worse, Chinese and foreign experts say, in the many smaller factories and mines that have sprung up during the economic reforms of the last two decades, mainly producing goods for the domestic market. A12.
 
Pepsi Quietly Introduces Juice Drink
Pepsi-Cola, which is known for big-league marketing tactics, is introducing FruitWorks, a line of juice-based noncarbonated drinks that will compete with Snapple and Fruitopia, with comparatively -- but deliberately -- little fanfare. Advertising. C8.

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 5; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1416 words

HEADLINE: Cordial Talks Yield Accord On City Budget

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
After unusually amicable negotiations, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council speaker, Peter F. Vallone, announced a $37.6 billion budget accord yesterday that relies in part on this year's record surplus to cut business and income taxes and still expands government services.
The City Council had the most to boast about, given that the mayor, consistent with his "kinder, gentler" approach to governing in recent weeks, agreed to nearly all of the major bargaining points being pushed by Mr. Vallone and his colleagues. 
 The budget package for the 2001 fiscal year includes money to extend library hours, provide weekend meals for lower-income elderly citizens and to install about 75 of the city's long-planned street-side toilets. The mayor even surprised Council negotiators by accepting a Council plan to restructure the personal income tax rates so that a smaller share is paid by middle- and lower-income residents.
"It is an excellent budget," Mr. Giuliani said, standing amid two dozen Council members, whom he greeted with repeated handshakes, slaps on the back and even hugs. "It is one that achieves the objectives that the administration wants to achieve and the objectives the Council wants to achieve. It was done through compromise and agreement."
But the Council and mayor both warned that the deal could unravel since state legislators were likely to approve a change in the coming weeks in pension benefits for retired city employees that could cost the city as much as $1 billion in the 2001 fiscal year. If that happens, they said, the $414 million tax cut package, which involves nine items including a $329 million reduction in the personal income tax and a $23 million child-care tax credit, is the part of the budget the city is most likely to scale back.
"Forget the politics and just do the right thing," Mr. Vallone said, directing his comments to city legislators in Albany, asking that any new pension burden not be too great. "Don't let the air change that happens when you get to Exit 23" at Albany, he said, joking about the difference a little distance can make. He urged that they not "forget who you represent," adding, "This is still our town."
A $3.2 billion surplus is expected this fiscal year, beating last year's record largely as a result of the still booming city economy. About a third of the surplus would be set aside to help curtail budget deficits already projected to start surfacing in 2002. But Charles Brecher, research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, said the plan called for far too much of the surplus to be used to support basic city expenses in the coming year, a practice that could be dangerous if the economy goes sour.
"It is like getting a bonus in your paycheck and using it to rent a bigger apartment," Mr. Brecher said. "You can afford it at first, but then the money runs out."
The budget also relies in part on a one-time windfall of about $808 million that the city is getting over two years by taking credit for larger than expected profits gained through the investment of city pension funds. In order to get the unions to allow the city to tap those funds, the mayor agreed to sweeten their pension benefits, costing the city nearly $300 million a year, an expense that Mr. Brecher said would never go away.
Giuliani administration officials said the budget would be a prudent one, but added that they would start soon after the fiscal year begins on July 1 to look for ways to limit spending to reduce the possible deficits in later years. Those are projected to be about $2.7 billion by 2002.
The negotiations between the mayor and the Council focused in the last two weeks on competing tax cut plans and proposals for spending for city agencies. The biggest expense, as is always the case, is the school system, which would get $11.1 billion, the mayor said, a gain of 3.7 percent. The figures for other city agencies were not released yesterday, since budget officials were still adjusting the totals to take into account changes the mayor and Council had backed.
The spending adjustments ultimately agreed to as part of the settlement announced yesterday are tiny compared to the entire budget. They add up to $170 million, about $100 million of which restores cuts proposed by the mayor in April and about $70 million that actually increases city spending.
The mayor's more conciliatory approach to the budget this year surfaced in April, when he dropped his traditional push to cut spending for city libraries and cultural institutions. Now he has gone even further, agreeing to a Council request to increase spending in these areas by a total of $25 million. Even the Brooklyn Museum of Art, site of the "Sensation" exhibit the mayor had condemned, would get about 8 percent more city support, Council officials said.
"It was very hostile," the mayor joked yesterday at a news conference in describing this year's negotiations, arousing laughter from the Council members assembled, before one Council member joked about a "kinder, gentler" mayor.
Other new spending added at the Council's request includes $6 million for weekend meals for the elderly and an extra $5.2 million to provide health insurance for more of the city residents who now lack coverage. The mayor yesterday pointed proudly to some of his own initiatives included in the budget: $160 million to build new DNA laboratories to expand the genetic testing of suspects and other money to hire new school safety officers.
The Council and the mayor also agreed to use mostly federal funding to hire about 1,230 new police officers. And $12 million is being set aside for special school system initiatives, like charter schools, although the mayor dropped his insistence that some of it be used to finance a voucher program that would help parents send their children to private or parochial schools. There is also $1.7 million to offer women free breast cancer screening and to support educational programs related to ovarian and prostate cancer, an initiative that the mayor, who himself has prostate cancer, had originally proposed to cut.
The biggest piece of the tax cut package is a reduction in the personal income tax. Instead of just cutting the tax rate consistently across all income levels, the mayor agreed to a Council proposal to restructure the tax system. As a result, taxpayers earning less than $70,000 a year would pay about 12 percent less in city personal income tax, with a smaller reduction for the more affluent, dropping to less than 1 percent for those who earn $1 million or more. A taxpayer earning $60,000 to $70,000 a year would pay about $207 less.
The tax cut package includes a child-care tax credit, which varies depending on a family's income but would be worth $385 a year for a family with two children and an income of about $28,000. There is also a proposal to give a tax break to elderly residents who rent apartments on a moderate income.
The City Council could vote as soon as today to adopt the proposed budget. But the city needs the approval of the State Legislature before it can enact most of the tax cuts. And if the Legislature approves cost-of-living increases for more than 100,000 retired city workers -- increases tied to inflation year after year -- then pieces of the tax cut plan might be abandoned, Mr. Giuliani said.
Officials in Albany said the negotiations on the proposed pension program were still under way, and the city estimates that the program could cost the city $500 million to $1 billion. But Herman D. Farrell Jr., a New York City Democrat who is chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee, said the mayor and Council had their priorities wrong.
"The constant harping on tax cuts versus a cost-of-living increase for retirees is obscene," Mr. Farrell said, adding that retired workers need a pension that can allow them to afford basic expenses.
Estimates of overall city spending differed. The mayor said yesterday that city-supported spending would decline by 2.9 percent or $600 million compared with the current fiscal year. But the city's Independent Budget Office said that number did not take into account the city's habit of using the surplus to prepay some of the next year's expenses. Once these measures are considered, actual spending would be up by more than 6 percent, or more than twice the rate of inflation, said Ronnie Lowenstein, deputy director and chief economist at the Independent Budget Office.

Ukraine Promises to Close Chernobyl Plant This Year

HEADLINE: A City, Once Smug, Is Redefined;
Company Town Becomes a Town of Tiny Companies

SERIES: THE OTHER ECONOMY -- Remaking Jobs in Rochester

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER

 BODY:
You might think these are tough times in the city that George Eastman built.
His Eastman Kodak Company, for close to a century the city's reason for being, is now a shadow of its former self, and its future is cloudy. Xerox, which was founded here, is once more laying off thousands of people and struggling to regain some kind of financial footing. Bausch & Lomb, the third pillar of Rochester's economy, has been jettisoning businesses and people. 
 Yet you do not hear the blues much in this green city near Lake Ontario. Because against all odds, small companies have been filling the job gap.
Almost invisibly, in low-slung factories to the west of town and anonymous office parks to the east, tiny companies have been springing up all over Rochester: computer software companies, telecommunications companies, medical equipment companies, high-tech manufacturing companies, Internet companies. And they are hungry for workers.
In Rochester today, almost anyone suddenly unemployed "is getting gobbled up by existing technology businesses," said Brian E. Hickey, executive vice president of the M & T Bank.
The jobless rate in Rochester hovers around 4 percent, roughly where it has been since 1996, and the overall number of jobs just hit 555,000, surpassing the number in Buffalo for the first time. Every year for the last three, state economists have had to revise Rochester's job count upward by thousands of positions; big companies fill out surveys more readily than little ones, which often show up in state records only when they pay their unemployment insurance taxes.
Of course, the shift from a company town to a town full of little companies is by no means complete -- or assured. Total job growth in Rochester remains lower than the statewide average. And the Milken Institute, a high-tech research organization, ranks Rochester just 71st out of 315 metropolitan areas based on the concentration of high-tech business. Silicon Valley is not shaking in its expensive sneakers.
When you want to start a business, "Rochester is not the first place that comes to mind," said Christopher M. Campbell, who left a "comfy cozy corporate position" to found Clean Dry Air in 1998. "Hopefully, that's changing."
The change has not been easy, not for the people involved, not for the city government, not for the self-image of a place once so self-satisfied that it was called Smugtown.
There was, perhaps, a lot to be smug about. Even today, the area around Rochester remains extremely prosperous, full of grand houses and stately trees and glossy shopping centers. In May, every green spot is spangled with lilacs, and the city's suburban schools continue to rank as some of the best in the country.
There is not much need for networking in Rochester -- everyone turns up at Little League games or in line at Wegmans, the local grocery chain. Corpses do sometimes turn up in the Genesee River, to be sure, but they are more likely to be victims of canoe accidents than of criminal activity.
Rochester began to boom with the opening of the Erie Canal in 1825, but it was Eastman who really put the place on the map. It was not just that he pretty much invented film and brought photography to the masses. Eastman also had a hand in every aspect of Rochester's civic life. He founded the music school and the dental school, endowed the university, created the United Way.
And, of course, there were the Eastman Kodak jobs. The company "essentially guaranteed lifetime employment, not only for yourself but for your family members," said William A. Johnson Jr., Rochester's mayor. Paternalistic in the extreme, Kodak took care of its people with cushy positions, high salaries and great benefits. The work force was and is highly educated, with an emphasis on engineering.
In midcentury, the Haloid Company, soon to be known as Xerox, became the Microsoft of its day. By the early 1980's, "if you figured in the companies servicing Xerox and Kodak, they were responsible for three quarters of the economy, easily," said Kent Gardner, director of economic analysis for the Center for Governmental Research (which was founded by you-know-who).
A handful of business leaders ran the city. When the developer who had started building a Hyatt hotel downtown abandoned it in the late 1980's (he was not, locals note, from Rochester), it was a small group of businessmen who put up the money to finish the job.
In the early 1990's, things began to change. Kodak, facing fierce competition from overseas and suffering from disastrous forays into new businesses, had been maintaining what many called a bloated bureaucracy. George M. C. Fisher, the chief executive appointed in 1993, made it clear that he had to save the company, not run the city.
The company began laying off tens of thousands of people. In the early 1980's, more than 60,000 people worked at Kodak in Rochester; now, the company says, there are fewer than 25,000 workers. At its peak, Kodak accounted for almost a quarter of the city's payroll; today, that figure is just over 10 percent, according to the Center for Governmental Research.
What happened to all those people?
Some have obviously moved away to seek work; the population of metropolitan Rochester has been edging down since 1994 (it is now just over one million, though there has not been an exodus as from Buffalo).
Many others became "consultants," here as elsewhere a code word for "probably retired."
Thomas T. Mooney, president of the Greater Rochester Metro Chamber of Commerce, estimates that 20 percent were "outsourced," meaning that they continued to have almost the same jobs, just not under Kodak's name.
As for the rest, he said, "Our sense is that the majority stayed and found gainful employment."
They found it at places like the Sutherland Group, which was founded in 1986 by a refugee from Xerox. Sutherland, which is hired by other companies to handle their customer relations, now employs 2,400 people, including about 1,200 in Rochester.
They include people like Richard E. Clouser, director of sales operations, who spent 28 years at Kodak, and Ronald B. Knight, chief operating officer, who retired from Xerox after 30 years. Both men said the adjustment to a smaller company has been rewarding -- but not easy.
In his first few weeks at Sutherland, Mr. Knight recalled, he was asked to handle a customer's request. "By the time I figured it out, someone else did the job," he said, with chagrin still in his voice. "We move quickly here."
The adjustment is not always easy on the company side, either. Daniel J. Lang, Sutherland's president, said that not everyone he has brought in from a corporation has worked out. The sticking points, he said, are culture, status and money: like most of the small companies, Sutherland pays far more modest salaries than the big corporations, but offers large performance bonuses.
Chatting with some Sutherland employees in a conference room, it is easy to discover that many of them could easily have moved away, but chose not to. Life in Rochester, they said, is too cheap and too good.
Joseph J. Buggy, originally from Philadelphia, decided to stay in Rochester even after the engineering firm he worked for left, because his family loves the area; it does not hurt that the golf is great. He does allow that sometimes the city still feels a little insular, especially when he watches the evening news. ("Out of 30 minutes, 28 1/2 are about Monroe County.")
Similarly, Johnson Au-Yeung, the chief technology officer, says he sometimes "misses the big-city ambience."
"At 10 p.m. on a Friday night," he said, "there's nowhere to go unless you go to a bar." Nevertheless, he raved about the low cost of real estate and the easy commuting, all so different from his family's home in Jackson Heights, Queens.
Another striking thing about the Sutherland employees is that they appeared uninterested in joining a start-up company, the dream of so many Manhattanites. "I want to go to growth, to learn something new," said Barbara McManus, who until recently worked for Bausch & Lomb. But, she said, "I wanted something that was already started."
In fact, relatively few of the corporate refugees have actually started businesses of their own, said Mr. Gardner of the Center for Governmental Research.
Just ask Paul Wetenhall. Once an employee of Xerox, he runs a software company, and now spends four days a week as "venture coach" at the Lennox Tech Enterprise Center, a business incubator near the Rochester Institute of Technology.
Even if they once worked at a big company, most of his entrepreneurs have experience being on their own and understand what it takes, he said. Like Bruce P. Sidari, who in May was bolting together his own office furniture at the center. Mr. Sidari has worked at Kodak, it is true, but he has worked at a lot of places, including for himself, before starting an Internet employment company, Emp Tek Inc.
Entrepreneurs often find it hard to find time for their families, much less for the civic duties that consumed George Eastman and his heirs, Mr. Wetenhall said. Indeed, until he took the job at the incubator, which is affiliated with the Chamber of Commerce, it did not even occur to him to join that group. Entrepreneurs, he said, "tend not to be too plugged in to the community."
That is hard for Rochester to adjust to. Priding itself on its civic participation, this city is still wrestling with the effects of downsizing.
At the United Way, Kodak's corporate gift has fallen by more than $1 million since 1992, to $2.4 million this year. And as Kodak cuts back, so do other corporations.
Just as difficult are the layoffs of individual workers, often men who pledged $500 a year, said Joseph G. Calabrese, the charity's president. Meanwhile, the charity is lucky if new participants pledge $50 -- and it has to talk to two people for every pledge. So to replace one former donor, the United Way must contact 20 people.
"We have to make more and more calls and visits and presentations to more and more people," Mr. Calabrese said. For the first time, this year, the United Way raffled off cars to lure people to its presentations.
Business and civic leaders also complain of a leadership void -- that no one has stepped in to replace the old corporate chieftains who tackled the city's problems. And there are problems, including serious troubles in schools in poor downtown neighborhoods, high air fares that help isolate the city, and some sections of downtown that could use a lift.
And then, there is what could delicately be called the image problem. Companies are not moving to Rochester; neither, more ominously, are people, even those looking for high-tech jobs. Such people need to feel "that if you get a job in one company and it doesn't work out, you can go down the street and find another one," said Peter Holloran, a marketing executive.
He is helping Rochester to put together its first major sales campaign, long after cities from Atlanta to Cleveland have already done so. Why has it taken so long? "Rochester never sunk far enough," he said. "The Genesee River never went up in flames."
The mayor and other civic leaders are working on some other efforts, too. They hope somehow to encourage more of a night life in downtown Rochester, and also want to develop more housing in the center city for young people who do not long to live in the suburbs.
And they have talked to the presidents of the universities in and around Rochester, asking them to reach out to their alumni who might be willing to move back to Rochester to fill the new jobs that the smaller companies are creating.
"We've never had that in our job description; we never think about bringing them back," said Albert J. Simone, president of Rochester Institute of Technology. But, he says, he will. "If it weren't for downsizing, these employers would be all over me."
 
The Other Economy
Upstate New York, a vast, diverse landscape of old cities, small towns, farms and forests stretching from Buffalo to Albany and north to the Canadian border, was once one of the most populous and prosperous regions of the country. But the national economic boom that swept into New York City and its suburbs passed it by. This is the second in a series of articles examining the region's quest for prosperity. A previous article discussed the population drain in Buffalo.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Stellar Cast of Democrats Raises $3.7 Million in New York

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

 BODY:
High above Midtown Manhattan, Vice President Al Gore said last night that Representative Charles B. Rangel was "in the catbird seat." And the Harlem Democrat, grinning through his mustache, looked as if he was indeed in a position of power.
Mr. Rangel's possible future as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee has brought him many friends. 
 Last night, first at a reception at the Supper Club and then over dinner on the 33rd floor of the Service Employees International Union on 42nd Street, they raised $3.7 million for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, in the hope that the Democrats will recapture the House in November, an event that would automatically promote Mr. Rangel to the chairmanship of the powerful tax-writing panel.
The size of the cache came as a surprise to everyone. It was $1 million more than the committee had expected, and it was delivered in an envelope at the Supper Club by Dennis Rivera, president of the union local, to David Jones, the fund-raiser for Mr. Rangel.
The evening, built around Mr. Rangel's 70th birthday, which is days away, yielded the largest take for House Democrats since, oh, mid-March, when they raised $7.3 million at an event in Washington.
But tonight drew an all-star cast of Democrats, including Mr. Gore, Hillary Rodham Clinton, former Mayor David N. Dinkins, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, chairman of fund-raising for the House Democrats, assorted members of Congress from New York and Andrew M. Cuomo, the housing secretary.
Mr. Gore stood on a folding metal chair at the dinner and lavished praise on Mr. Rangel.
"Charlie Rangel is the heart and the soul of the Democratic caucus," Mr. Gore said. "He is the lion of Lenox Avenue. He is the man with the constant growl. He is the man responsible for the Rangel renaissance. He is part of all the budget policy, the health policy, Social Security, Medicare, education -- the Ways and Means Committee has it all. Let's make Charlie Rangel the next chairman!"
Mr. Gore, in his new mode of refraining from attacks on his Republican rival, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, made mention of only one Republican, Newt Gingrich, but otherwise only broadly referred to "the other side," which, he warned, would lead the nation into ruin.
Mr. Cuomo said later that Mr. Gore's previous "negative message" had been an effective and persuasive critique of the Republicans. "But he's more appealing when he's on the positive," Mr. Cuomo said.
A buoyant Mr. Rangel followed the vice president's lead, climbing up on a chair and assuring his listeners, "When we have the majority, one thing is going to be abundantly clear -- that we are going to move the Congress and the nation forward, that we are not going to pick fights with Republicans."
Mrs. Clinton, who appeared at the Supper Club, where Lionel Hampton led a dozen trumpets and saxophones in unending refrains of "Happy Days Are Here Again," also hailed Mr. Rangel in unusually laudatory language.
"Maybe earlier than many, I began to just do whatever Charlie told me to," she told the crowd. Alluding to the days when her Senate candidacy had seemed just an improbable rumor, she said: "And so when people said, 'Well, you know, gee, are you going to run for the Senate in New York?' I said, 'Well, Charlie told me I should,' so here I am, and I'm very happy I am because I'm having the time of my life."
Mrs. Clinton, like Mr. Gore, gave a nod to Mr. Kennedy and to his uncle, Robert F. Kennedy, who, both noted, was assassinated 32 years ago. Mrs. Clinton said she was honored to be seeking the same Senate seat that he once held, one that her supporters often invoke as having been won by a non-New Yorker.
She also lauded Mr. Gore and her husband, the president, saying that the nation elected them in 1992 on faith but now had the "evidence and results" of a thriving economy and that that was a big reason to elect Mr. Gore president.
At the dinner at the union headquarters, Mr. Gore spoke of the soaring economy but also cautioned, "There are a lot of people who are not yet being carried along."
It was in a similarly populist spirit that he began his day, proposing in a speech in North Carolina to put nearly all services of the federal government on line so that citizens would not have to wait in line or at their mail boxes to do things like receive their Social Security benefits, apply for a home loan with the federal government or report a crime.
Numerous activities are now possible on line, like applying for student loans, making reservations at the national parks and paying taxes. Mr. Gore would expand those services, so that, for example, people could pay their taxes directly over the Internet without having to go through a software intermediary.
Mr. Gore's plan, which aides said would cost $100 million but would quickly pay for itself by cutting paperwork and saving time, would be accomplished by 2003.
