SECTION: Section A; Page 10; Column 1; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1671 words

HEADLINE: Deprived Ukraine City Finds U.S. Help No Help

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: KHARKIV, Ukraine

 BODY:
There was a brief discussion among American diplomats very brief by all accounts -- about having President Clinton stop here during his visit to Ukraine, in this home of the American-sponsored Kharkiv Initiative.
But because people here are so unhappy with the initiative's results, his visit was limited to Kiev. 
 The initiative is a program to show off this city of heavy industries, power blackouts and high unemployment to American investors. This is being done as compensation for Ukraine's decision to give up multimillion-dollar contracts to help Russia build a nuclear power plant in Iran, which is proceeding anyway on Persian Gulf coast of Iran at Bushehr without Ukraine's participation.
In 1998, the Clinton administration persuaded the Ukrainian government to order Turboatom, a producer of giant steam turbines and one of this city's largest enterprises, to back out of the Iranian project. The move was regarded as a great success of American policy, and it was expected that it would seriously disrupt Russia's ability to complete the Iranian power station.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright traveled to Kiev in March 1998 and praised President Leonid Kuchma for "great statesmanship" in joining the struggle to "halt the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction."
But these days construction at the Bushehr power plant is well under way, and Russia's deputy minister for atomic energy, Bulat I. Nigmatulin, says it will be completed in 2002. Russia is expected to earn about $1 billion from the project.
Part of that will go to its largest turbine manufacturer, a St. Petersburg company, which has taken over Ukraine's contract to produce the turbine that will be delivered to Iran in September 2001, said Viktor S. Shevchenko, the factory's executive director.
In the end, the only party that was hurt by American intervention was Ukraine, which the United States has been trying to help become an economically independent nation.
"This was one of our biggest contracts, and losing it has been a very serious blow to the economy of our region," said Anatoly A. Bugaets, Turboatom's general director. "But of course we are law-abiding people, and when a decision is made at the highest level, we have to obey."
Here in Kharkiv, in retrospect, it is difficult to find anyone who thinks that it was a good thing for Turboatom to walk away from tens of millions of dollars in contracts with its industrial partners in Russia for the sake of a weapons-nonproliferation objective that -- here at least -- seems somewhat fuzzy.
The United States and Ukraine may have stood together, however unsuccessfully, to oppose the sale of civilian nuclear technology to Iran, but no one in Ukraine, and especially in this city, is taking a victory lap around the idle factories of Kharkiv.
Nearly a decade after independence, Ukraine's broken deal with Russia over the Iranian plant is emblematic of a lament often expressed here and in the capital, Kiev. It is that Ukraine's agenda for economic development in the post-Soviet era never seems to be as important as the strategic objectives of the United States and its Western allies.
Ukrainian officials point to a series of actions sought by the United States: closing Chernobyl, the site of the world's worst nuclear accident; destroying old missile silos, and putting up high-tech security barriers to keep nuclear physicists who are begging for work from sharing information with the wrong countries. The Ukrainian officials point out that the United States has achieved nearly all of its strategic objectives in this former Soviet republic -- eliminating nuclear weapons, making Ukraine an unofficial partner of NATO and, in the case of Turboatom, using Ukraine in an attempt to destabilize Russia's dealings with Iran.
Ukraine has been one of the leading recipients of American foreign aid in recent years, with about $200 million a year, much of which has gone to nuclear safety needs. But the nation remains mired in a kind of post-Soviet purgatory of economic and social lassitude as well as endemic corruption.
"A nation at risk" is how the Central Intelligence Agency described Ukraine in a mid-1990's report, warning that a seriously depressed economy, corruption and fiscal and monetary chaos were threatening its long-term survival.
Though there are signs that the Ukrainian economy is beginning a recovery after a decade of unceasing contraction, the Kharkiv Initiative, the payback for what Ukraine has sacrificed at Washington's insistence, has failed to generate a single contract for any industry in this city. Indeed, it has taken two years for the State Department to open an office here, which is now staffed by a single contract employee.
"Of course, we are disappointed," said the Kharkiv regional governor, Oleg Dyomin, who will travel as a guest of the State Department to New York, Cleveland and Chicago this summer in his continuing search for American corporations willing to invest in a country with serious corruption problems and an unstable electrical supply. Mr. Dyomin will bring color brochures of the Antonov jet transport produced here, of the Kharkiv tractor plant lineup, of the high-energy physics laboratories and of Turboatom, with its cavernous and nearly empty production lines.
"We haven't had any help yet," said Anatoly Myalitsa, general director of Kharkiv's aircraft plant. "We are not competitors. We only want a tiny piece of your market in the far north, where our aircraft is very capable of making short takeoffs in the snow. Why would America, a big country, not want to help small Ukraine?"
In an interview in May in Kiev, President Kuchma put on a pained expression when the subject of the Kharkiv Initiative came up. "I don't want to offer any comment on this," he said. "It hurts too much, and in fact, it is a strong point of criticism that I get from my opponents."
One Western businessman, who has observed Ukraine's painfully slow emergence as a state, tried to capture the mood here by saying, "Disillusionment is too strong a word, but disappointment may not be strong enough."
Any notion that Mr. Clinton might visit Kharkiv was overruled, Western diplomats say, by concerns that he might be jeered by unemployed workers from Turboatom, where the Iran contract was expected to provide 25 to 30 percent of the factory's total output over five years.
Ever since Russia signed a contract with Iran in 1995 to complete the Bushehr power station, abandoned by German constructors in 1979 with the onset of the Iranian revolution, the Clinton administration has opposed it and Congress has threatened sanctions against Russia. And for the last two years, Congress has reduced by half foreign aid payments to Russia's central government, specifically because of the refusal to abandon Bushehr.
United States intelligence agencies have long believed that Iran has a secret program to develop nuclear weapons, dating back even to the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, which ended with the 1979 revolution. Just the idea that Iran wanted to generate electricity with nuclear power instead of using its abundant oil and gas resources was suspicious, and still is for many experts.
American officials do not regard the Bushehr project as a source of nuclear material that could be diverted to an illicit bomb-making program. But the administration has taken the view that the Bushehr project will train an entire generation of Iranian physicists and engineers in nuclear technologies, and thus enhance Iran's scientific base, including any program to develop nuclear weapons. Israel, whose leaders also see their security threatened by Iran's nuclear program, joined in the diplomatic offensive to kill the project, but to no avail.
Russian and Iranian officials point out that Iran has placed the Bushehr plant under the rigid safeguards and inspection regime of the International Atomic Energy Agency.
In the last five years, when Boris N. Yeltsin was president of Russia, Dr. Albright and Vice President Al Gore undertook a number of missions to try to persuade him to cancel the Bushehr contract. But Mr. Yeltsin would not relent, promising instead not to expand Russia's nuclear cooperation with Iran beyond Bushehr, where as many as four reactor and turbine units are planned.
The project has suffered some setbacks. The original contract envisioned a four-and-a-half-year construction schedule. But Iranian construction companies were not able to repair the German foundation work -- bombed during the Iran-Iraq war of 1980-88 -- in accordance with Russian specifications. Under a revised contract, Russia's Ministry of Atomic Energy has assumed overall management of the project.
"Bushehr is a very interesting and profitable contract for us," said Mr. Nigmatulin, the Russian atomic energy official. "And at the same time it is helping us to restore our industrial capacity."
Having failed to persuade Russia to pull out of Bushehr, Mr. Clinton's senior national security advisers in late 1997 began a campaign to force Ukraine out of the deal. Ukraine's ambassador to Washington at the time, Yuri Shcherbak, was told that the administration would prevent Ukraine from purchasing fuel for its aging nuclear reactors from American companies unless Turboatom gave up the Iran project.
There were carrots as well sticks, the Kharkiv Initiative among the carrots, along with promises of Ukrainian participation in space exploration.
But Turboatom's departure has brought little cheer to Ukraine's industries, which still have connections with Russia's industrial structure. And as a consequence of Turboatom's withdrawal, it seems less likely that Ukraine will be invited to take part in Russian projects to build nuclear power stations in China and India.
"Kharkiv lost a very good order, and that is a shame," said Mr. Nigmatulin, the Russian official. "An order like this represents the revival of the turbine business."
But not for Ukraine.

HEADLINE: $3.5 Billion Africa Pipeline Expected to Pass

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 5

 BODY:
With American support, the World Bank is expected to approve on Tuesday a $3.5 billion project to develop an oil pipeline in Chad and Cameroon in West Africa, despite widespread concerns about the potential for corruption and environmental damage.
The Clinton administration will vote in favor of World Bank sponsorship after specifying an unusually detailed list of safeguards that officials hope will earmark the oil revenues for development projects and ward off abuse, a senior American official said today. 
 Although the project does not have united European support, the United States, as the major shareholder in World Bank, is confident that there will be enough votes for a loan to pass, the official said. Exxon Mobil is the lead company that is seeking the loan. The World Bank is generally expected to contribute $90 million to $200 million.
The proposed 663-mile pipeline, which would link oil fields in landlocked Chad to the Atlantic Coast of Cameroon, has stirred an outcry among environmentalists and antipoverty crusaders. They say the project will provide a boon to corrupt African officials, dislocate indigenous peoples and harm ecologically sensitive areas.
The senior American official said critics had "very legitimate concerns." But after more than two years working with the oil companies, officials and independent figures in both countries, he said, planners have come "a very long way" in addressing them.
"This is a project with substantial development potential," the official said. "I'm confident that it will be approved."
Environmental groups contend that the companies have failed to set aside adequate money to clean up an oil spill, allocating less than $1 million, despite Dutch researchers' citing a need for $28 million.
The pipeline, the critics add, will threaten the livelihoods of hundreds of Bagueli people, or pygmies, and endanger the habitats of endangered black rhinos, gorillas and chimpanzees.
"Any time you lay a pipeline, you're basically building a road for loggers and poachers," said Alejandro Queral, associate Washington representative of the Sierra Club.
Other critics say the World Bank will effectively be lining the pockets of a corrupt government in Chad that the State Department says brutally persecutes its enemies. Nearly every region of Chad, a nation two and a half times the size of France, has erupted in ethnically based unrest.
Providing oil revenues to the central government is "like adding more fuel to the fire," asserted Korrina Horta, a senior economist at Environmental Defense in Washington.
"It's a very dangerous situation," Ms. Horta added.
Exxon Mobil has insisted on World Bank participation as a hedge against instability, Ms. Horta said. She referred to the bank's role, which represents less than 10 percent of the project, as "political risk insurance" for investors.
"You make the World Bank a shareholder in the project, and no government is ever going to nationalize it," Ms. Horta said.
In addition, the support clears the way for Exxon Mobil, Chevron and Petronas to seek additional financing before investing $3 billion of their own, she said, adding, "It's the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval."
In tandem with its support for the loan, the administration has insisted on a framework to be monitored by the World Bank that would reduce the risk of corruption or mismanagement. That structure would include an escrow account for oil revenues that would set aside most of the income for health, education and development and allow for monitoring by nongovernmental groups in Chad.
The American-backed strictures also require that money be set aside to create national parks, compensate displaced people and respond to oil spills.
The pipeline would be one of the largest that involves direct foreign investment in Africa in decades, officials said. Experts expect it to generate $80 million to $100 million a year for Chad and $20 million in transfer fees for Cameroon.
American officials acknowledged that the project would be something of a test for the World Bank. Last week, the bank released a report in which it faulted itself and the International Monetary Fund for making Africa poorer through failed lending policies over 40 years.

But the contention that the two organizations had made the continent poorer through failed lending policies came from recent Washington demonstrators, not from the study.

HEADLINE: UKRAINE CONSENTS TO SHUT CHERNOBYL BEFORE YEAR'S END

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO with MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine, June 5

 BODY:
President Leonid Kuchma of Ukraine used the occasion of a brief visit by President Clinton today to announce that the Chernobyl nuclear power station, site of the worst radiation accident in history, would be closed by Dec. 15.
Mr. Kuchma made the announcement after the two leaders met in the white-and-gilded splendor of the Mariinsky presidential palace. "This is a hopeful moment," Mr. Clinton said. "It is also a moment when we remember those who suffered as a result of the accident there." 
 For Mr. Clinton, the six-hour visit to Ukraine was the last stop on his last scheduled trip to Europe as president.
He began the day in Moscow with an address to both chambers of the Russian Parliament, in which he acknowledged that "Americans have to overcome the temptation to think that we have all the answers." He then urged the Russians not to reject Washington's proposal for a limited national missile defense and to make the changes needed to achieve full participation in global trade. Excerpts, Page A10.
In earlier conversations with President Vladimir V. Putin, Mr. Clinton failed to shake the Kremlin's staunch opposition to Washington's proposal for a new missile defense plan -- an opposition shared by China and much of Europe on the ground that it could spur a new arms race. The United States argues that it would construct defenses only against the chance of missiles being launched by "rogue states."
Ukraine has been under pressure from the United States and Europe to shut down the last working reactor at the Chernobyl plant, where a fire in 1986 spewed radiation over vast stretches of northeastern Europe and caused untold thousands of deaths and illnesses. Mr. Kuchma had previously said he was prepared to shut down the plant if major industrialized nations would contribute toward the $1.2 billion Ukraine needs to build two new nuclear power plants.
In his announcement today, Mr. Kuchma said Mr. Clinton had agreed to solicit the Group of Seven industrialized nations and Russia for help in shouldering the costs. Mr. Clinton also pledged $78 million in new American aid to help Ukraine repair and strengthen the concrete "sarcophagus" over the damaged reactor, $2 million to improve security at other Ukrainian nuclear plants, and an unspecified amount to assist the tens of thousands whose livelihood comes from Chernobyl.
"The aim of this decision is to reduce nuclear risks in the world," Mr. Kuchma said, adding that it "was not easy."
In addition to the Ukrainians who depend on the plant for jobs, Ukraine faces an energy crisis. The country also needs to spend an estimated $750 million to reconstruct and stabilize the hastily built concrete and steel structure that encases the shattered No. 4 reactor hall and the nearly 200 tons of radioactive fuel inside; the structure is riddled with leaks and threatening to crack open.
Besides his talks with Mr. Kuchma, Mr. Clinton went outdoors to address tens of thousands of people packed into St. Michael's Square.
"Today, the oppressors are gone," he said. "Stalin is gone. The Nazis are gone. But you, the people of Ukraine, you are still here, stronger than ever! You must build a free and prosperous Ukraine. Do not give up. Keep on fighting."
The purpose of the speech, administration officials said, was to give a strong show of support for Ukraine's independence, which came with the collapse of Communism nine years ago after three centuries of rule by Moscow, but has run up against severe economic hardship and rampant corruption. Ukraine is one of the largest recipients of American aid.
It was also a photo opportunity that Mr. Clinton seized to the fullest. He stood atop a dais and waved to the crowd against a backdrop of the gold-domed, Wedgwood-blue Monastery of St. Michael and a city square decked with huge Ukrainian and American flags.
Earlier in the day, concluding his two-day visit to Moscow, Mr. Clinton took a defensive line in the speech to Parliament. "Many Russians still suspect that America does not wish you well," he said. "The United States wants a strong Russia."
The reception, however, was muted. Some deputies skipped the session, partly because they were confused about when it was to start. For many of them, NATO's expansion, the alliance's war with Yugoslavia and the administration's plans to build a limited missile defense have created the impression here that Washington revels in its role as the world's only superpower and is determined to thwart the emergence of new powers, including Russia.
"Russia's future is very important to others because it is among the most important journeys the world will witness in my lifetime," Mr. Clinton declared from the lectern.
On security issues, he insisted that his administration's plan for a limited missile defense was not a drive for military superiority. On the economy, Mr. Clinton backed Russia's bid to join the World Trade Organization, a bid that still requires Moscow to change some of its economic policies.
"Russia should not be the only major industrialized country standing outside this global trading system," he said. "We will support you, but you must know the decision to join the W.T.O. requires difficult choices that only you can make."
On the political front, he criticized the Russian prosecution of its war in Chechnya. "My question on Chechnya was an honest one, the question of a friend," he said. "And that is whether any war can be won that requires large numbers of civilian casualties and has no political component bringing about a solution."
More generally, Mr. Clinton insisted that he had not come to Moscow to preach to Russians, saying, "You will choose what your interests clearly demand and what your people democratically embrace."
The reviews after the speech were generally positive.
"It was a clever lecture," said Andrei Kokoshin, a legislator in the Fatherland - All Russia party and a national security adviser when Boris N. Yeltsin was president. "I think Clinton is still important."
"It was not a full hall," said Nikolai Kharitonov, the leader of an agrarian faction that generally supports President Putin. "But it was not a bad speech. Let's hope it is realized constructively."
Communists and nationalists in Parliament were predictably critical. Communists held up signs saying, "Clinton Go Home" and "Defense Missile System Is a Threat to the World." They chanted, "Soviet Union! Soviet Union!" over and over.
Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, who plays the part of an ardent nationalist but who is seen by many Russians as a kind of clown on the political fringe, created a row during Mr. Clinton's speech, screaming "Shame! Shame!"
"Who is he teaching how to live?" Mr. Zhirinovsky yelled. "It's profane! We are not going to do what America commands!"
After addressing Parliament, Mr. Clinton received the warmer welcome he was more accustomed to during his previous four trips here as president when he called on Mr. Yeltsin at his residence outside Moscow.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin had a sense of camaraderie that is clearly lacking in the president's businesslike meetings with Mr. Putin. And Mr. Clinton seemed to look back on the old meetings wistfully.
"We all just had a nice visit, just like old days," Mr. Clinton said. "He's got a beautiful place."

Valuable, Bush Aide Says
By The New York Times
WASHINGTON, June 5
 Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Gov. George W. Bush, said that the Clinton-Putin meeting had been valuable in advancing relations between the United States and Russia. Mr. Bush welcomed agreements on disposal of nuclear materials and establishment of a joint center to monitor missile launchings, he said.
More importantly, Mr. Fleischer said, the two leaders did not sign any binding pledges that would limit action by the next president.
"The governor is pleased the agreements they reached do not tie the hands of President Clinton's successor so that we can have a defense policy that reflects post-cold war thinking," Mr. Fleischer said.

HEADLINE: What Conservatives, Liberals, Stores and States Share

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
WHILE e-commerce is remaking how business gets done, it is also remaking traditional alliances on tax policy, creating a deep rift within the Republican Party and building common ground between some antitax Republicans and some Democrats who have opposed the antitax agenda.
The unpredictability of the matter extends much further. Efforts to make the Internet a permanent tax-free zone obviously pose problems for off-line businesses. But the most direct impact might be felt by state and local governments, which now receive almost half their revenue from sales taxes. As more transactions move online, falling revenue would have to be made up either through higher taxes on property, income and off-line sales or through cuts in services. 
 In 1998, at the behest of e-commerce companies seeking a tax break, Congress passed the Internet Tax Freedom Act, which prohibited multiple and discriminatory taxes on the Internet and effectively prohibited sales taxes on e-commerce that crosses state lines until 2001.
Last month, the antitax Republicans in the House leadership pushed for a vote to extend the moratorium for five years, to 2006, even though the current moratorium had 18 months left and even though hearings on the extension were not scheduled until a week after the vote.
The House Republican leadership pushed through the vote in the face of solid opposition by a traditional Republican constituency, the nation's retailers, from mighty Wal-Mart to local federations of mom-and-pop stores. They all want a level playing field in which there would be no distinctions for sales tax purposes among bricks-and-mortar, clicks-and-mortar and pure cyberspace businesses.
The moratorium extension is very likely to face a much tougher time in the Senate as retailers step up their lobbying. President Clinton has not said whether he will sign the bill, but the administration's representatives on the Internet tax commission have opposed extending the moratorium.
The rush to extend the moratorium has brought together Representative Ernest J. Istook Jr. of Oklahoma, one of the most far-right Republicans in Congress, and John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, one of the most far-left Democrats. They made similar arguments against the extension. As Steve Pfister, a senior vice president of the National Retail Federation, which represents merchants with more than 1.5 million stores, observed, "Internet tax issues are creating really strange bedfellows."
Both Mr. Istook and Mr. Conyers expressed concern that the moratorium would take power from state and local governments, which provide the bulk of government services, like police protection and education.
Mr. Istook wrote to his colleagues that his fellow antitax Republicans have lost sight of the 10th Amendment, which reserves to the states and the people those powers not expressly authorized or denied to the federal government.
THE argument that opposing an extension of the moratorium means favoring higher taxes, which was promoted by the House leadership, was called bunk by Mr. Istook.
"Washington politicians," he wrote, "are scrambling to show who can be 'friendliest' to the Internet community -- and win their political support -- even if it means turning a deaf ear to other business and ignoring common sense." He also asked whether extending the moratorium was "a federal power grab, a back-door approach to consolidating all power firmly and finally in Washington?"
He urged his colleagues to fight high levels of taxes, rather than give a break to one industry. "Tax justice is not achieved by promoting injustice; tax justice must be based on fairness," Mr. Istook wrote.
Mr. Conyers, while not agreeing that taxes are too high, said the state and local tax system was a mess and that by extending the moratorium to 2006, Congress would remove an incentive for the states to streamline sales taxes.
As much as Americans complain about the complexity of the income tax, the sales tax regimes of 45 states, plus the District of Columbia, are vastly more complex. A can of soda is untaxed as a grocery item in Ohio, for example, but is taxed as a convenience in New York.
The two congressmen, and many retailers, want to use the rise of e-commerce as a cudgel to force the states to simplify the sales tax, creating standard definitions of items and eliminating picayune rules.
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, a Republican who has signed 31 tax cuts into law, is the political leader of those seeking a level playing field; he thinks the issue is both philosophical and economic.
"The issue is whether local government will be allowed to function independently of the national government and Congress," Governor Leavitt said, adding that blocking the states from applying sales taxes to e-commerce is the most significant issue of federalism since the Civil War.
Grover Norquist, the president of Americans for Tax Reform and a leading Republican antitax strategist, sees the same federalism issues from a different perspective.
"The principle is no taxation without representation," Mr. Norquist said. "You cannot allow Alabama politicians to impose taxes on businesses in Maine and New Hampshire because there is no limit to the abuses that can follow. They can go kick your door in and levy sales taxes on things you bought over the Internet."
Governor Leavitt and his allies, however, take strong issue with this view because, they say, they have agreed that collecting sales taxes should not draw a company into other tax, regulatory and litigation issues.
One idea that Mr. Norquist finds palatable would be to tax all items at the point of sale. Under this theory, Washington State would collect taxes on every book sold by Amazon.com, based in Seattle, not just those bought by Washington residents.
Such a policy would encourage e-commerce companies to move to the five states that have no sales tax -- Alaska, Delaware, Oregon, Montana and New Hampshire -- and encourage the other states to reduce sales-tax rates, which Mr. Norquist favors.
Mr. Norquist added: "The cost of government should be radically falling with all the new technologies. That politicians don't reduce the cost of government is a criticism of the politicians."
Mayor Ron Kirk of Dallas, a leader in the level-playing-field camp, said he regarded these comments as nonsense. Computer technologies will reduce many government costs, but Mayor Kirk said: "The Internet can't replace a fire truck. Cities still have to buy pumpers and ladder trucks and hire firefighters and train them, and we have to have the means to pay for all that."
Mr. Kirk also fears that exempting the Internet from sales taxes will mean more power for Washington, the opposite of the devolution arguments put forth by antitax Republicans, who say that they favor state and local governments. "I don't think Grover and his people have thought this through," Mr. Kirk said.
But Mr. Norquist said that he and other antitax Republicans had indeed thought through the consequences of their position. Exempting e-commerce from sales taxes eliminates a potential source of revenue and furthers the underyling cause, Mr. Norquist said, adding, "We want less government."

LENGTH: 1159 words

HEADLINE: SHOPPING;
Creating Ways to Cut the Delivery Time From Mouse to House

BYLINE: By JONATHAN BURTON; Jonathan Burton covers technology and business from San Francisco.

 BODY:
THE ordering may be express, but the delivery often seems Pony Express. That is shaping up as a central issue in the highly competitive world of online shopping, and it is spawning creative solutions for getting the goods to customers more quickly.
 "I can order a book on my lunch break, but if I have to wait a week to get something, it becomes less valuable," said Stacey McCullough, a senior analyst at Forrester Research, in Cambridge, Mass., explaining the frustration that sends many potential online shoppers to the mall. 
 Delivery delays are often attributed to the parcel carrier, but mishaps frequently occur before an order leaves the warehouse. Not that this matters to the customer, who knows only that the order did not arrive on time.
 The cost for such delays can be high. In a recent Boston Consulting Group study 19 percent of online customers said the delivery of their orders either took longer than they expected or never occurred. As a result, many stopped shopping online, while others simply refused to do more business with the offending e-tailer.
Internet merchants hoping to build brand loyalty need to give customers much more than point-and-click ordering convenience, said George Shaheen, the chief executive of the online grocer Webvan, based in Foster City, Calif. "Everybody thought that ordering was the secret sauce," he said. "But if you're going to win over a large group to Internet shopping, you have to provide them a full shopping experience."
 Theresia Gouw Ranzetta, a partner at Accel Partners, a venture capital firm in Palo Alto, Calif., added: "We haven't figured out how to beam things, but that's sort of what people expect. The Internet has trained consumers that they should be able to access information anytime, anywhere."
 To cope with customers' expectations in this fiercely competitive climate, many online retailers are redoubling their efforts to assure shoppers that every step is covered, from mouse to house. While they aren't yet zapping books and videos via modem directly to your computer, they are devising ways to deliver goods faster, better and more cheaply.
 Same-day service is already becoming a fixture in large metropolitan areas. For example, Barnesandnoble.com guarantees same-day delivery in Manhattan by 7 p.m. for Internet orders placed by 11 a.m. In Los Angeles and San Francisco, electronic items and toys ordered by 2 p.m. from the aptly named Sameday.com will arrive by 8 p.m. Other couriers with catchy monikers like Kozmo.com, Urbanfetch.com and Pinkdot.com deliver videos, ice cream and other convenience items store-to-door within an hour in large cities.
 Many sites are also providing precise information about when an order will ship and when it will arrive. Amazon.com has a feature on its site called "Where's My Stuff?" that allows customers to follow their orders in transit. Information is a powerful tool, and a customer who feels in charge is frequently a satisfied one. A high degree of personal communication and care seems especially important to shoppers in the cyber world, where orders and service lack face-to-face interaction.
 Behind the scenes, many e-tailers are taking control of crucial inventory and warehouse functions, trying to avoid delays. Filling orders quickly -- using sophisticated technology to get a shipment out of the warehouse and on the road -- has become an imperative for astute Internet merchants.
 "You have to have fresh information and the ability to track that information and keep abreast of the order," said Dennis Spina, the chief executive of SubmitOrder .com in Dublin, Ohio. The company is an online order-fulfillment provider for e-tailers that monitors inventory, processes orders and handles shipping, delivery and customer service.
 Most online merchants contract these back-office operations to independent providers like SubmitOrder, whose clients include BlueLight.com, the nascent Web venture of Kmart, and the toy seller Zany Brainy. Shippers like Federal Express and United Parcel Service are also billing themselves as one-stop e-commerce solutions. "We know how to run a warehouse," said Harvey Rickles, the general manager of e-logistics for U.P.S. "We have inventory management systems and tracking systems already in place."
Still, many of the more popular Internet retailers, including Amazon, Webvan and eToys, handle their own logistics. Webvan, for example, raised $275 million in a private placement of stock last year to build new distribution and fulfillment centers and expand its fleet of delivery trucks. Webvan operates two giant warehouses in or near each of its metropolitan markets -- the San Francisco Bay Area and Atlanta, -- that are stocked with perishables, dry goods, household products, beauty items, clothing, books, portable electronics, music CD's, and even pet supplies. Employees select and pack the orders and load the merchandise onto the company's small, distinctive delivery trucks.
 Many Webvan vehicles use Global Positioning Systems to guide drivers, a high-technology technique that ensures delivery within a 30-minute window of the customer's choosing. By the end of the year, Webvan expects to do business in Chicago, Seattle, Baltimore and Bergen County, N.J. "You have to keep in mind what the consumer wants," Mr. Shaheen said.
 Amazon is trying to enhance its seven merchandise-distribution centers. The company, based in Seattle, has been criticized for building such capital-intensive structures, but Jeff Wilke, the general manager for operations, said that Amazon's size required massive internal controls on inventory and orders. "We could not deliver the same performance if we cobbled together some outsourced partners," he said.
 Amazon also intends to furnish same-day delivery for some top-selling products -- books, CD's and toys -- to customers through a partnership with Kozmo. (Last December, Amazon invested $60 million in Kozmo, which uses bicycle messengers in 10 cities to whisk movies, snacks and other easily carried items to urban dwellers.)
CITY couriers like Kozmo and Urbanfetch store products close to their customers, much as Amazon or Webvan does, but on a reduced scale.
 Urbanfetch, which offers one-hour delivery in New York and will do so soon in London, taps a network of sites that stock its electronics, beauty products, food, movies and CD's. And because couriers arrive at their destinations within minutes, customers do not need to juggle schedules or ask a neighbor for a favor.
 "The ability to schedule a delivery when you know you're going to be home becomes a real asset," said Ross Stevens, the chief executive of Urbanfetch, which is based in New York.
 Same-day delivery, or same hour? That choice will depend increasingly on the customer. And anyone who thinks that only city folk will relish these perks, take heart: Urbanfetch also owns the Internet name Suburbanfetch.com.

HEADLINE: ONLINE OVERSEAS;
Familiar Start-Up Story, With a Romantic Twist

BYLINE: By SALLY McGRANE; Sally McGrane is a technology writer living in San Francisco.

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
TORSTEN SCHMALE and Christian Wessel started Inubit, their Berlin-based business-to-business software and services company, in December after their respective girlfriends decided that they had had enough of listening to them complain about their jobs.
The women, who work together at another company, persuaded Dr. Schmale, who was bored with his job as a software developer for Siemens, and Mr. Wessel, who was sick of his job as a consultant with Roland Berger & Partners, a management consulting firm, to meet. They did, and quickly hit upon an idea for a technology platform that would enable business-to-business marketplaces. In doing so, they joined a wave of business-to-business start-ups in Germany. (After the business idea was hatched, the couples got married.) 
 The beginnings of Germany's Internet start-up revolution can be traced to June 1999, when eBay purchased Alando.de, a German online auction company, for $43 million. Since then, the start-up scene has accelerated, causing investor interest to shift from businesses selling to consumers to those servicing other businesses. The emerging business-to-business climate is healthy and likely to continue growing. Indeed, Forrester Research, a market research firm in Cambridge, Mass., predicts that by 2004, Germany will lead Europe with 26 percent of all e-commerce activity, followed by Britain, with 18 percent.
The business-to-business landscape in Germany, however, will look different from its early-stage counterpart in the United States. A crucial difference is that in Germany, corporate players are recognizing the importance of the business-to-business market almost in tandem with start-ups. DaimlerChrysler, Bayer, Volkswagen and Siemens are creating e-commerce marketplaces to procure goods or have plans to do so, and both SAP and Intershop Communications are also interested in expanding into such commerce.
"Big companies were faster in realizing the potential of business-to-business e-commerce in Germany than in the U.S.," said Reinhard Edelmann, an investment manager with Technologieholding, a Berlin venture-capital firm. One result, said Thorsten Wichmann, the chief executive of Berlecon Research, a research and analysis firm also in Berlin, is that "niche markets are where start-ups are coming in."
Inubit is focusing on European niche markets, along with other start-ups, including Newtron.de, Surplex.de and Portum.de. (The "de" stands for Deutschland.) Inubit has built a business-to-business technology platform and is planning to join with established companies to create industry-specific marketplaces. So far, Inubit has one partner, the Floramedia Group, a horticulture company with a pan-European presence.
Even if big companies are quicker on the draw in Germany, enough business-to-business start-ups have taken root in the last six months to spawn more than 100 online marketplaces, according to Berlecon's research.
Inubit, as is typical for a German business-to-business company, is fashioning itself as a European company -- one that needs to adapt to multiple countries, cultures and languages from the get-go. "We're looking at the European market, which is like the worldwide market -- from an organizational perspective, it's the same," Mr. Wessel explained. "If you're a B-to-B start-up in Germany, it doesn't make sense to stay in the German market. We programmed our technology so that if someone comes in and says he's from Spain, he gets Spanish content."
This approach, according to Mr. Edelmann, of Technologieholding, is what distinguishes European e-commerce ventures from American ones. "We're used to dealing with other cultures," he said, "and Americans are not." Many American companies add multiple language abilities to their technology only after they stake a claim in the United States market, Mr. Edelmann said, rather than integrating them from the start.
Multiple languages are just the beginning. "The European market is not homogenous like the U.S. market," said Patrick Sheehan, the managing director for the United States division of 3i Group, a venture capital firm in London. "There are quite different market conditions in each country."
European companies have to take into account the different business processes, tax systems, cultures, market structures, labor laws and governments from country to country. "To address your market you have to have a whole different set of business approaches," Mr. Wessel said. Even the level of technological adoption -- which varies widely from southern to northern Europe -- is an issue: a European technology company must have different strategies for, say, wired Sweden and analog Spain.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS;
Assessing the Online Exchanges: From One Expert, a Mixed Grade

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
THE bull market has not just been on the stock exchange but in exchanges themselves. The frenzy to find business-to-business uses of the Internet is prompting people to create online exchanges where companies will be able to trade everything from sheet steel to hotel sheets.
To Eric K. Clemons, a professor in the Information Strategy, Systems and Economics group at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, this boom is reminiscent of the late 1980's, when a whole crop of online exchanges started to compete with the existing face-to-face stock exchanges and futures markets. Mr. Clemons has studied why as many of these markets failed as succeeded, and he has consulted for many of them, too. 
 Now he's turning his attention to the new industrial markets and says that many of them are doomed to repeat the mistakes of their financial predecessors.
He discussed the lessons from the financial markets in a series of e-mail messages last month.
 
Q. Electronic trading exchanges first began opening in financial markets 15 years ago, amid great skepticism by traditional traders that they would work. Remind us, what happened?
 
A. Many markets moved partially to electronic form faster than people had expected. Back in September of 1986, just before London's Big Bang the deregulation of its financial markets , you will remember, many of the large houses expected the floor to continue to hold a dominant share of equities trading. Five minutes into the first day's trading, the floor was empty.
London still uses intermediaries -- market makers who buy from every seller and sell to every buyer. Like most markets, London has been unwilling to take the next step, in which computers match buyers and sellers directly.
On the other hand, stock and futures markets in France and Germany have moved more completely to fully electronic systems without intermediaries and have been enormously successful.
In the United States, the New York Stock Exchange has continued to rely on an active face-to-face trading floor. And Globex and other electronic futures exchanges have had very little impact.
 
Q. So why did some electronic exchanges work and others not?
 
A. I guess the biggest difference between success and failure continues to be liquidity. When there are enough buyers and sellers to determine an effective price, then online trading can occur. If buyers and sellers are widely separated in time, and if there is little information on "comparables" to help buyers or sellers determine fair prices, then intermediaries will continue to serve an essential function. Thus, I would not expect to see real estate agents disappear anytime soon.
Similarly, exchanges didn't help instruments that no one understands, or no one wants to trade, such as contracts tied to hurricanes in Florida or the cost of cellular air time in August in Midtown Manhattan or other forms of catastrophic risk.
 
Q. But online exchanges also failed in the United States in some very liquid markets like futures.
 
A. It's hard to get market participants to leave a structure that's liquid and working well, even if it is not working perfectly. Thus, online trading has captured markets abroad where there had been no previous exchange or where the existing stock market had been less efficient and more expensive than its U.S. equivalents. Online trading in the U.S. continues principally to provide lower-cost access to existing exchanges, rather than replacing these existing exchanges, in general because they have been doing such a good job.
 
Q. So what sort of industrial markets will be most suited to online exchanges?
 
A. The invisible hand of the marketplace does the best job when buyers and sellers are fragmented and thousands of small orders interact simultaneously. This is true whether I want to buy 1,000 shares of I.B.M. at the current price on a stock exchange or if I want to buy 1,000 standard memory chips in one of the emerging industrial exchanges. The guiding principle here is that the random flow of small orders is sufficient to assure that the market finds the right price.
 
Q. What's an example of an industry that meets the test to find the right price?
 
A. Game fish, like sashimi-grade toro or hamachi. They are not farmed, and production cannot be fully predicted or matched to current demand. Likewise it cannot be stored for long. An exchange that found regional market clearing prices, let buyers throughout Asia bid on fish available in Tokyo or allowed buyers throughout the East Coast to bid on the regional catch would allow supply and demand to determine a market clearing price. Sellers would get a better price, through aggregation of demand. Buyers would have access to greater supply, again through aggregation. There would be less waste.
 
Q. So what about the proposed exchanges in industries like auto parts, where there are a handful of buyers and not all that many sellers of each type of item?
 
A. If the order flow is heavily concentrated in a small number of buyers or a small number of sellers, or if delivery must be carefully coordinated and scheduled between buyer and seller, then an exchange is likely to be less effective.
If I need several million fuel injectors or pistons, an exchange-based market will not be my best alternative. If my pistons arrive too late, my production line will shut down. In business environments such as these, I will want to carefully negotiate order quantities and delivery schedules, quality levels and purchase prices.
 
Q. Even in those industries, proponents say, online exchanges are a great way to unload excess inventory.
 
A. I'm not so sure excess inventory is still such a great idea. I recently studied exchanges in the glass industry. Excess production is indeed sold through exchanges, but at prices only slightly better than the pre-exchange mechanism for liquidating overproduction, which was to grind glass down and remelt and reuse it.
But the new exchange causes a secondary problem: it floods the market with cheap glass, and thus depresses the prices of primary production runs.
Selling overproduction through an exchange is seldom as cost-effective as properly planning production.
 
Q. A lot of people say the real value of the exchanges in the long run won't be the lower transaction costs or even the lower prices, but the efficiencies throughout the production stream that would flow from the instant -- universal, transparent demand information being shared. I take it you don't completely agree.
 
A. That's right. For some industries full transparency will indeed produce allocative efficiency -- by setting the right prices, based on aggregating supply and demand, the product will end up in the hands of the customers who value it most highly. In industries with rapidly evolving products -- personal computers -- this might indeed be a new and optimal design.
In these cases the key issue is not determining the right price, but scheduling delivery of the right quantity at the right time. Ford or G.M. might be more concerned with assuring that spark plugs and fuel injectors arrive in the right-sized batches at precisely the right times to avoid disrupting their assembly lines; getting the right quantity of products at the right time is closer to traditional supply-chain optimization than it is to the design of trading mechanisms.
 
Q. Some people argue that one benefit of these new exchanges is that they open up world markets, allowing a small steel maker in Thailand to find a buyer in Peru. Does that make sense?
 
A. Globalization of markets and exchanges, likewise, will be important only if buyers and sellers have a real need for global access. But when they do, geographical separation appears to be no longer relevant as a barrier to trading, as long as the item's description is clear enough to be described online without too much ambiguity, and its value is sufficient to justify shipping costs. I will admit that the online trading of Beanie Babies through eBay caught me pretty much by surprise.
 
Q. Will we see these industrial exchanges come to resemble the futures pits in Chicago where investors could hedge piston prices or speculate in spark plugs?
 
A. Actually, I am quite convinced that they will. You will see forwards, for physical delivery, tradeable commodity-style physical-settlement futures contracts to lock in supply, and cash-settlement contracts to lock in a price. You will see speculators, regulators and all the infrastructure you currently see in futures markets.

HEADLINE: ONLINE OVERSEAS;
High-Tech Boom Near Santa's House

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: OULU, Finland

 BODY:
SITUATED on the jagged coast of Finland nearly 400 miles north of Helsinki, this remote city must rank as one of the world's most improbable technology boomtowns.
There is no daylight from December through mid-February. Parking lots provide electric warmers to keep car engines from freezing. 
 Except for forests and lakes, there isn't much within 100 miles of Oulu. The most notable town to the north is Rovaniemi, which has built its economy on the assertion that it is the true home of Santa Claus. "It is easy to come to Oulu," wrote Ilpo Okkonen, the author of a picture book about the city. "All you have to do is set out from somewhere else."
Yet as unlikely as it may seem, this town of 100,000 people is home to hundreds of electronics companies. Driven in part by Nokia, the Helsinki company that is the world's biggest manufacturer of mobile telephones, Oulu thrives as a center for research on wireless data communications.
Nokia employs nearly 5,000 people here, most of them working on third-generation mobile services that offer high-speed electronic commerce and even full-color video communications.
But the city has also become a hotbed for start-ups. There are companies here that make wireless networks for underground mines; wireless tickets for buses and ski lifts; wireless automation systems for factories; and wireless encryption systems to protect data sent over the airwaves.
No one is quite sure how all this "mobile commerce" will develop, but the phenomenal success of ordinary mobile phones has attracted a flood of venture capital. Finnair now makes 15 daily round-trip flights between Oulu and Helsinki, and most are packed with business travelers.
The city's half-dozen hotels are routinely booked solid, but rarely with tourists. A handful of American technology companies, like Tellabs and Mentor Graphics, have offices here as well.
"Right now, all of us venture funds are loaded with money," said Juha Mikkola, a partner in Eqvitec Partners, a venture capital firm in Helsinki that has invested in several Oulu companies. "All we need is more good entrepreneurs."
Until about 10 years ago, Oulu was best known as a former trading center for black tar. Those days are long gone: the demand for tar, used in waterproofing, collapsed with the demise of big wooden ships in the 19th century. (Local shops still honor the heritage by selling tar liquor and tar candy, which taste about as good as they sound.)
Much of the city's rebirth stems from its large pool of skilled technical people. The University of Oulu, financed mainly by the Finnish government, draws 13,000 students and has programs in electronics, engineering and information technology. Most of the students come from northern Finland, and about two-thirds stay in the area.
The government also set up the Technical Research Center, which now employs about 2,900 researchers who work on advanced wireless technologies and optical electronics. About half of the center's revenue comes from work for private companies.
In the early 1970's, long before the boom in cellular telephones, Nokia set up a small branch here. Then Nokia was a conglomerate that dabbled in a variety of electronics as it searched for new opportunities. Researchers in Oulu provided some of the company's early work in wireless military equipment for the Finnish government, which gave it a base for jumping into mobile telephones in the late 80's.
Oulu's abundant technical talent has also made it a haven for local entrepreneurs. One was Lauri Kuokkanen, who was posted here by Nokia and then quit in 1976 to start LK Products, a company that made radio-frequency filters.
A self-described "serial entrepreneur," Mr. Kuokkanen went on to start at least three other companies, including a company called Solitra. The man he recruited to run Solitra, Juha Sipila, recently sold it to an American company called ADC, reaping tens of millions of dollars. Today, he is an investor in at least 15 other local start-ups.
"People ask how Oulu suddenly became such a big success," said Mr. Kuokkanen, who is 68. "We just did our daily work and it gradually grew bigger and bigger. It's been happening for the last 25 years."
Much of that work happens at Technopolis, an industrial park that is home to about 130 companies. Researchers and ideas shuttle between business and academia, much as Stanford University fueled the growth of Silicon Valley.
"There is quite a strong internal network of people there who all studied in the same area about 20 years ago," said Vesa Sadeharju, a partner at SFK Finance, a venture capital firm in Helsinki that has invested in about 10 Oulu start-ups. Last month SFK was bought for an undisclosed amount by one of Europe's biggest venture capital firms, 3i Group, which is based in London.
Companies based at Technopolis employ more than 10,000 people, but thousands more work off campus at companies like Sonera, Finland's biggest telephone company, and Polar Electro Oy, which makes electronic heart-measurement products.
MANY are start-ups that rent as little as a single room but obtain access to high-speed phone lines, administrative services and expertise at the university and the Technical Research Center. CCC Oy, for example, a small company started in 1985, developed software under contract for Nokia and then developed its own products. Today, it has about $20 million a year in sales.
Researchers are digging into more exotic areas as well. At the Wireless Internet Laboratory, part of the Technical Research Center, Petri Mahonen is experimenting with virtual-reality glasses that would allow mobile-phone users to browse the Internet in color.
His team has also installed miniature wireless-computer servers into devices like coffeepots and toy race cars. "The main idea is not that people want to run their coffeepots over the Internet," Mr. Mahonen said. "The point here is to think about using the Internet for unusual new purposes and to see how small and how cheap you can produce a wireless Internet server. It turns out they can be quite small and cheap."
Compared with Silicon Valley, Oulu remains a rustic outpost. There are few shopping malls or movie complexes, and the streets are filled with creaky old cars. The city's main attraction is bicycle paths and footbridges, which crisscross the waterways and lakes.
When spring arrives in mid-May, nights gradually disappear into a two-month-long stretch of daylight, and the region becomes a haven for outdoor sports and recreation. One evening early last month, in-line skaters and bicyclists stayed out until 11 while salmon fishermen drifted in the golden rays of the late-night sun. By July, people are playing midnight golf and tennis.
"The other day, I left work at 3 p.m. and drove about 150 kilometers to go fishing," Pertti Huuskanen, the president of Technopolis, said last month.
"I fished for several hours and I used my mobile telephone to read and answer my e-mail," he said. "I got back by about 11:30, before it was completely dark."

LENGTH: 1349 words

HEADLINE: Ratings That Know What You're Looking at, and When

BYLINE: By HILARY APPELMAN; Hilary Appelman is a freelance writer living in Clinton, N.Y.

 BODY:
TELEVISION has its Nielsens. Radio has its Arbitrons. Now the audience ratings business has moved to the Internet. This time, it just about knows when you are in the bathroom.
Billions of dollars in advertising are spent each year on the basis of audience ratings that profess to tell what Americans are watching and when. Yet advertisers have no way of knowing if you are glued to the TV, or if you head for the kitchen every time there is a commercial. 
 Things are different on the Internet.
The computer's ability to track a user's every online move makes it possible to collect far more information about Internet users than has been the case with traditional media audiences. Internet ratings companies can track every link followed by their thousands of volunteer panelists as they surf the Web, recording how long they spend at a given site, when they stop interacting with the computer, even for a moment, and whether they click on banner ads.
"It's not simply that a person is at the other end," said Chris Charron, the director of media and entertainment at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. "It's 'Is that person engaged? Are they responding to content? Are they responding to advertising?' All of those things are becoming much more important to measure."
Although the bottom line of audience ratings is commerce, the abundance of data, or metrics, as the audience-tracking numbers are known, should in theory translate into Web sites better tailored to users' interests and needs and even better suited to the capacities of users' computers. It should, again in theory, mean research less crude than divining that Americans like to watch women fight to marry rich strangers. That is, if the numbers are accurate, which remains to be seen.
The battle to become the household name in Internet ratings is being fought by four-year-old Media Metrix Inc. and Nielsen/Net Ratings, a joint venture of Nielsen Media Research, the television-ratings giant, and Net Ratings Inc. of Milpitas, Calif.
Media Metrix and Nielsen/Net Ratings each have about 50,000 American panelists and are rapidly expanding overseas. The panels, made up of randomly selected volunteers, are 10 times the size of the Nielsen television panel; they have to be bigger because the numbers are spread across thousands of Web sites in a constantly changing online universe.
Other players in the market include PC Data of Reston, Va.; the French company NetValue, which entered the United States market in April; and online advertising and marketing networks like DoubleClick and MatchLogic.
Privacy concerns raised by companies like DoubleClick, which collects data without the user's knowing, are not an issue for Media Metrix or Nielsen/Net Ratings, whose panel members have agreed to have their Internet use monitored. Panelists receive small cash incentives -- $25 every six months -- or coffee mugs and beach towels.
Unlike Nielsen television ratings, which rely partly on weekly diaries and are subject to the vagaries of memory and wishful thinking, Internet ratings data is collected by software that tracks panelists' computer activity and automatically sends the collected information.
"We're blessed on the Internet because there's no survey component," said Tim Meadows, a senior vice president for marketing at Net Ratings. "Everything that we track is what actually happens, not what people want to tell you happens."
The numbers are being used not only by advertisers but also by investment companies and venture capitalists to evaluate Web companies' stock prices and potential investment values, in lieu of traditional measures like earnings and profits.
"Online companies use the data to track the competition and appraise potential acquisitions," said Doug McFarland, a senior vice president and general manager at Media Metrix. "It's a combination of media and market research. There are billion-dollar decisions being made with this data."
Despite the high stakes, the ratings numbers have little outside verification.
Bruce MacEvoy, the director of advertising research at the portal site Yahoo.com, said the ratings companies needed to be able to validate their projections by matching them against actual user counts kept by the Web sites.
"It's an evolving art," he said. "We're building an industry here; we're not flying on something that's been around 20 years."
Many large clients are subscribing to more than one ratings service, which can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars a year, as they wait to see which becomes the industry standard.
The ratings, while similar, do not always match. In March, for example, both companies reported Yahoo.com as the top-visited Web site. Nielsen/Net Ratings said about 39.2 million home-computer users came to the site, while Media Metrix put the number at 40.5 million. The next most popular site, according to Media Metrix, was MSN.com, with 32 million visitors, while Nielsen/Net Ratings said it was AOL.com, with 35.3 million visitors.
The companies are highly critical of each other's panel- and data-selection methods, which they cite for the differences.
Still more vexing are the sometimes large discrepancies between the rating companies' numbers and the logs kept by Web sites. "Because the Internet is so measurable, there's a high expectation on numbers and measurability, but also a lot of different ways to measure simple things," said Mr. Meadows, of Net Ratings.
Both Media Metrix and Net Ratings are working with Internet sites to try to reconcile any discrepancies.
Shane Ankeney, the director of media strategy at the Los Angeles advertising agency TBWA/Chiat/Day, said that advertisers used the panel-based ratings more for strategy and planning and less for actual advertisement pricing.
Pricing itself is based on the number of times an advertisement is seen, which is counted by the site or the advertising network that displays it, Mr. Ankeney said.
"On television, I can't tell you how many people were watching 'E.R.' when my Apple commercial ran," he said. "Nielsen will tell you on average how many people are watching that show, and anyone watching the show at that time probably saw my ad as well." But referring to online exposure, Mr. Ankeney noted: "I don't care about Yahoo over all. I want to know how many people saw my ad."
THE panel-based information is invaluable to advertisers who want to identify which sites can help them reach certain segments of the population, said Mr. MacEvoy of Yahoo. In addition, the ratings provide a consistent measurement standard, making comparisons possible. A Web retailer deciding where to advertise might look at ratings data on sites that were popular with the retailer's own visitors, Mr. Ankeney said. Or the retailer might look for sites frequented by people who matched its demographics but who had not visited the site.
The ability to measure actual responses to online advertisements is changing the Internet business model, said Mr. Charron of Forrester Research.
Sites will no longer attract advertisers simply by pulling in high traffic numbers; they will have to prove that those visitors are looking at the advertisements and acting, he said.
Fifteen percent of Internet advertising is priced on performance criteria already, and Forrester estimated that 50 percent would be by 2004, Mr. Charron noted.
"Advertisers are starting to demand that they pay for advertising on the basis of action," he said. That could spell trouble for some popular sites -- like gaming, news and chat sites -- whose users are less likely to interact with advertising.
"The Internet shows us that reach and frequency, in and of themselves, do not indicate value," Mr. Charron said.
"The media ratings services will have to become much more advertising- and commerce-focused, not just simply traffic-focused," he added.
But Mr. McFarland said that perspective provided a limited view of the advertising and the audience-ratings business.
"It's about more than data," he said, "it's about understanding consumer behavior."

HEADLINE: ONLINE OVERSEAS;
Taking a Warlord's Advice to Shake Up the Marketplace

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOYKO

 BODY:
MORE than 400 years ago, a warlord named Nobunaga Oda revolutionized the Japanese marketplace by taking control of the powerful trade associations and throwing it open to all would-be merchants for a nominal flat fee.
The rules of the open market were so radical and so popular that central Japan, Oda's stronghold, became the dominant center of commerce in Japan for a while, and the name of his revolutionary policy, "rakuichi to rakuza," which means "free markets and free guilds," still resonates with Japanese. 
 Hiroshi Mikitani certainly had Oda-San in mind when he named Rakuten, now Japan's largest e-commerce site. Operating an online bazaar under virtually the same principles that underpinned Oda's marketplace, www.rakuten.co.jp draws about 95 million hits a month as a gateway to about 2,800 merchants around the country selling everything from eggs to kimonos.
"I want Rakuten to be the best place to sell anything," said Mr. Mikitani, who founded the site three years ago. "The marketplace is what we focus on, the exchange between buyers and sellers, while most others focus on being a shop or a collection of shops."
Merchants pay 50,000 yen a month, or about $469, to link their Web sites to Rakuten. In exchange, they receive tips on jazzing up those sites and access to Rakuten's database and software, which contain information about customers and their predilections. Rakuten also offers them low-cost advertising. "We are basically a bricks-and-mortar business because all of our stores are real bricks-and-mortar stores," Mr. Mikitani said, although most of Rakuten's customers never set foot in those shops.
Many of the vendors on Rakuten are established companies looking to pare stale inventory without undercutting sales of their merchandise that is sold at full price. They can put their old inventory online at bargain-basement prices without much risk that the news will reach customers who frequent their stores.
Other Rakuten vendors are merely trying to overcome Japan's notoriously layered distribution system, or to sell their customers the freshest fish and produce.
Rakuten has also created a sense of community among its users, who chat online about the virtues and transgressions of Rakuten vendors and can participate in online auctions. The site's Rakuten's Free Market, a sort of mini-eBay, where sellers list items for sale for a fee of 100 yen, or 94 cents, plus 5 percent of the eventual sale price, is often a lively window onto customer preferences.
The communities that Rakuten creates are important in Japan, where the Internet has taken off largely as a means of social interaction. "E-commerce here has a much greater social component than in the United States," said Jiro Kokuryo, a professor who specializes in the study of information technology and systems at Keio University's business school in Yokohama.
But it is Rakuten's business model that has made it a darling of investors in the six weeks since it went public, smack in the middle of a sharp decline in global demand for Internet-related investments. The stock trades on Jasdaq, Japan's over-the-counter market. The decline for Internet stocks was as sharp here as it was in the United States when Rakuten went public; Japanese markets reflect movements in the American markets.
For one thing, Rakuten has been profitable, earning $1 million on sales of $5.6 million last year. That's an impressive 17.8 percent profit margin, largely unheard of in e-commerce. Mr. Mikitani had the advantage of studying the business models of Amazon.com and eBay, and quickly decided that Rakuten would be much better off as a hybrid, leaning more toward the eBay model than toward Amazon.com.
Not that he is unimpressed with Amazon .com. He just wants to avoid the costs and liabilities of inventory and distribution. And Rakuten has never advertised. "We're not really a retail company," Mr. Mikitani said. "We sell retailers the use of our servers, and there's a big difference." (In addition to the monthly membership fees, which provide 80 percent of Rakuten's revenue, 10 percent of the revenue comes from advertising and the rest comes from auction.)
Mr. Mikitani has limited Rakuten's risk by assuming the least liability possible for the business conducted on the site, but he pays attention to customer service. Shops are carefully monitored, and a few have been asked to leave Rakuten for business practices that were considered shady.
Mr. Mikitani contends that Japan will be a better market for e-commerce than the United States, mostly because of the medium's ability to spark a consumer revolution in a country known for its high prices. In short, the Internet allows merchants to circumvent the many layers of middlemen who clog this country's distribution system, adding costs every time merchandise changes hands.
For example, if you buy an obi, the sash worn with a kimono, at the retailer Kyoto Kimono Ichiba, it will cost 138,000 yen, or about $1,300. Buy it from Kyoto Kimono's shop on Rakuten, and it costs 13,800 yen, or an affordable $130.
Or think of it this way, which is Mr. Mikitani's favorite illustration of the power of the Internet here: Buy a share of Rakuten through a traditional Japanese stockbroker, and pay commissions equal to 3 percent of the share's value, which is about 1,065,000 yen at current prices, or $10,000. Buy it online from Monex, a securities broker here, and pay a $10 commission.
"In the U.S., you use Schwab's online brokerage and you get a price break for sure," Mr. Mikitani said. "But it's not anything like the savings you get in Japan."
As a result, Mr. Mikitani predicted, the Internet "is going to completely rebuild the Japanese economic system, much more so than in the United States."
He also thinks that Japan's more homogeneous population, with its flatter distribution of wealth and stronger sense of community than in the United States, provides the country with e-commerce advantages. "Japanese people like to communicate with each other, and it's much easier to do that on the Net," he said.
After graduating from Hitotsubashi University in Tokyo, Mr. Mikitani became a banker at the Industrial Bank of Japan, one of the country's most blue-blooded financial institutions.
He took a break from banking to go to Harvard Business School, returning to the bank in 1993 with a master's of business administration and a newfound respect for entrepreneurship. "Before I went to business school, I thought my choices were to either work my way up Japanese style to become a director of the bank, or to go into investment banking at a Western firm and make a lot of money," Mr. Mikitani said.
But he opted for a third approach, striking out on his own to become a consultant, which led to his foray into e-commerce.
Mr. Mikitani toyed with selling educational services, financial advisory services and other things online but chose Rakuten "because it was scalable," which he defined as requiring lots of technology and relatively little human input. "I knew I could service 2,800 customers with Rakuten," he said. "Giving 2,800 people financial advice would have been impossible."
Rakuten has had no marketing costs so far, although it plans to use some of the $430 million it raised in its stock offering to do advertising. "We were lucky," Mr. Mikitani said. "We got famous fast. The first mover always has an advantage, and we were the first mover."
That is not to say that others are not moving fast. Curio City, another virtual mall that Mitsui & Company started about the same time that Rakuten opened, has said it plans to increase the number of stores affiliated with its site to 10,000 from the current 800 by the end of this year.
But out-Rakutening Rakuten is not easy. WomenJapan.com, which offers a forum in which Japanese women can seek out and exchange information and advice about careers, finance, health, entertainment and family issues, experimented with the online bazaar concept at Christmastime.
The site featured two shops, one selling pashmina wraps and other items, and the other selling wine. Neither vendor was an actual store, and WomenJapan.com found the logistics of distribution and inventory management cumbersome.
The result? "E-commerce in Japan is still a big question mark in my mind," said Grace Fromm, the chief marketing officer at WomenJapan.com. But WomenJapan .com has not given up on e-commerce. Rather, it took a page from Rakuten's book, signing up two vendors for Mother's Day -- Tower Records and Hibiya Kadan, a well-known Tokyo florist -- that could handle orders on their own.
Mr. Mikitani's success has made him something of a celebrity, and government officials and politicians seek his advice about e-commerce, although some people worry that the government is more interested in regulating the Internet than in encouraging it. It is worth remembering that free and unfettered markets have been the exception in Japan, not the rule. Nobunaga Oda, after all, committed ritual suicide under threat of assassination by a vassal turned enemy.
But Mr. Mikitani is not afraid. "What can they do? Shut down a server?" he asked. "All you have to do is move the server to the U.S., and you're back in business."

HEADLINE: The Web's User Profile Undergoes a Broad Transformation

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
FOR a long time, the image of the typical Internet user was a heterosexual white male younger than 40. Although this characterization was mostly true, the Web is now becoming a thriving marketplace for a wider range of people.
As the economic and political influence of Asian-Americans, Hispanics, African-Americans and gay men and lesbians increases, so does their presence on the Web. Technology is also allowing millions of people with disabilities to go online. Not surprisingly, a growing number of sites are serving these communities as they contour the Web to their own needs. 
 The Asian-American community is wired, with a full 69 percent of Asian-American households connected to the Internet. This is reflected in the many sites aimed at this community, including www.aonline.com, a site focusing on culture and lifestyle for Asian-Americans, produced by A Magazine. Another site, www.Click2Asia.com, links to shopping, business and travel in the United States, Japan, Taiwan and Korea.
For the Hispanic market, the site www.zonafinanciera.com provides banking, insurance, auto and real-estate services in English, Spanish and Portuguese in 21 countries. "Many Hispanics are looking for convenient ways to send money home, secure a loan for a family member in Latin America or buy stock or property there," said Greg Keough, a co-founder of the site.
The site www.starmedia.com is a huge portal that includes shopping in Spanish, travel services, news from the Americas, classified advertising and chat rooms.
African-Americans are the fastest-growing group online. "Blacks are always on the tail end of technology, and we need to get on the front end," said Harry Alford, the president and chief executive of the National Black Chamber of Commerce. Its site, www.nationalbcc.com, offers members discounts from major corporations and other benefits. Other sites, like www.blackplanet .com, will soon offer college databases, financial tools and technology classes, said Omar Wasow, the executive director.
For people with disabilities, the Internet offers perhaps the greatest promise. With www.wemedia.com, "for the first time, a homebound individual can visit the grocery store, stop at the bank and pick up a new shirt," said Mikki Lam, a senior vice president of WEmedia Inc. The site also offers health assistance and information about finances, education and sports.
For gay men and lesbians, two large portals, www.gay.com and www.planetout .com, offer chat; personal ads; shopping; information on living with H.I.V.; investment tools; news; and links to gay-owned companies. "Gay commerce takes a different angle online," said Megan Smith, Planetout's chief executive. "We're a large community with specific needs. It's a completely underserved market."
