HEADLINE: PERSONAL FINANCE;
Banks Are Slow to Move Online, but So Are Their Customers

BYLINE: By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
IN the early rounds of the online banking competition, the surprising outcome is that the big commercial banks have not been beaten to the punch by nimbler young challengers. 
 Unlike the brokerage titans of Wall Street that steadfastly refused to recognize the threat posed by Internet-based stock trading competitors, commercial banks have been wrestling with the Web for years. But the results of those efforts, many of which were primarily defensive, have ranged from modest success to spectacular failure.
It turns out that, unlike online stock trading, online banking has not, so far, been a killer app. Consumers have been just as slow as the banks to accept the Internet as a medium for managing everyday money matters.
Less than 10 percent of American consumers bank online. Last year, about 8.3 million people shopped the Internet for mortgages and other loans, but only one in eight even started the loan application process online, said Robert Sterling, an analyst with Jupiter Communications in New York.
The real challenge to established banks may just be arriving, in the form of companies that combine banking with other services online. Control of consumers' financial information is so critical to establishing bonds with them that it has attracted a host of competitors, including purely electronic banks, brokerage firms and software companies that operate Internet portals.
For example, E*Trade Group, the electronic brokerage firm, is making a big push for its E*Trade Bank, which was known as Telebank before E*Trade bought it earlier this year. E*Trade also bought a network of more than 8,800 automated teller machines to establish its first physical presence across the country. The company eventually hopes to link those A.T.M.'s with its Web sites so that customers can withdraw cash from bank or brokerage accounts.
Traditional banks take some comfort in E*Trade's moves because they reinforce the belief that Internet-only banks have limited appeal. When it comes to their savings, most people demand that there be some there there, as the saying goes.
"The advent of Net-only banks seems so exciting," said Bruce Zimmerman, a senior vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank. "The reality is, there aren't many customers who want to do everything only over the Net. That's why you've seen that Net-only models haven't been successful."
To build business quickly, most Internet banks have taken advantage of their slim cost structures by paying higher interest rates on checking accounts and certificates of deposit. E*Trade Bank started early this year with a one-year C.D. that yielded 7.27 percent on an investment of as little as $1,000, compared with 5.7 percent at Citibank in New York and 5.15 percent at Chase Manhattan Bank.
But, analysts say, paying above-market rates to attract deposits has never been a path to profits. Indeed, that tactic contributed to the failure of many savings and loans in the 1980's.
"The bad idea of the decade for online bank marketing is competitive C.D. rates online," Mr. Sterling said. The people most likely to shop for the best rates are retirees, and they are unlikely to shop online, he said.
Among Internet banks, the most visible disappointment has been WingspanBank .com, the electronic bank created by the Bank One Corporation. After spending about $35 million on advertising for Wingspan, Bank One put it up for sale.
Citigroup's Citibank has also struggled with its Internet strategy. Even with its latest electronic offering, called Citi f/i, Citibank, the nation's largest bank, trails Wells Fargo and Bank of America in the number of online accounts.
After the initial trials of the all-electronic bank model, Mr. Sterling said, "There's one verdict in, and it ain't the next E*Trade."
There are several reasons for the slower migration online for bank customers compared with investors, according to analysts and industry executives. One of the most important is that electronic discount brokerages opened up a simple, affordable route for millions of people to invest. Another is that investors were not accustomed to visiting brokerage offices with any regularity, while many bank customers still stop at their neighborhood branch at least once a week.
Electronic banks can offer better interest rates on deposits and loans because they have virtually no overhead compared with traditional banks. But banks' costly clusters of branches are still valuable assets, analysts say.
"The fact that a bank has a physical branch in the vicinity of a prospect is an enormous advantage and will remain an enormous advantage," Mr. Sterling said. "A local presence implies solidity, whereas anybody can set up a Web site."
BIG banks are following a trail that was blazed in the brokerage business by Charles Schwab: they are working toward making their services available online, over the phone and in person.
"We believe people will want a choice of how they access the bank," Mr. Zimmerman said. "And we believe customers will value a seamless financial relationship."
Things are not so smooth just yet. Traditional banks are ahead of the game if they have made all account information accessible to customers online, said Matt Cone, senior vice president of marketing for the Corillian Corporation, a provider of Internet banking software in Portland, Ore. "There are a number of financial institutions that still have yet to get to first base," Mr. Cone said. Many banks had put off their Internet ambitions until they had updated their computer systems for the Year 2000, he said.
Mr. Cone said that making account information available electronically was a step toward offering what customers really want: a single, online source of up-to-date information about their finances, including savings and checking accounts, credit cards, mutual funds and other investments.
On that score, banks are facing new challengers: upstarts that want to give people one place on the Web where they can check on accounts scattered among several companies, from savings at a bank to brokerage accounts to frequent-flier mileage.
Several companies, like Yodlee.com and X.com, are offering to gather account information from disparate sources and compile it for a quick survey. The technology that these companies use is known as "screen scraping" because it requires them to use customers' account numbers and passwords to collect confidential data posted by other companies.
Banks are hoping that most consumers will not trust any other company, especially new dot-com ventures, with access to such important personal information.
The buzzwords at Chase Manhattan these days are "real-time," "connected" and "personalized," Mr. Zimmerman said. Chase Manhattan is working toward immediate recognition of deposits, withdrawals and transfers between accounts, he said, because "one of the expectations of the Internet is that everything be real time. The Internet enables, and therefore the customer expects, everything to be connected." But like most banks, even E*Trade Bank, Chase Manhattan still uses batch processing every evening to process the daily transactions and update balances in customer accounts.
The faith that most consumers place in traditional banks is a powerful competitive advantage, Mr. Cone said. "The problem banks have had historically is that they rely on that and so they could take their sweet time to get there."

HEADLINE: SHOPPING;
Ordering Brides on the Web: Old Business, New Source

BYLINE: By JULIE CHECKOWAY; Julie Checkoway is director of the Creative Writing Program at the University of Georgia.

 BODY:
MEN with fantasies and women with hopes have always managed to connect. Now, sites that draw on those dreams have exploded across the Web.
The fastest growth appears to be in sites that promote international marriages, Internet versions of the 19th-century mail-order-bride business. More than 200 such sites are in the United States, with earnings for some estimated as high as $2 million a year, although other operators cite a much lower figure. 
 According to a report by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, the number of marriages between American men and foreign women they met through online matchmakers has doubled in the last decade, totaling 4,000 to 6,000 a year.
The international online matchmaking services are thriving largely because of increased Internet access worldwide, low overhead and start-up costs and an abundance of eligible foreign women: 100,000 to 150,000 advertise themselves on e-matchmaking sites each year.
In the mid-1970's, most mail-order brides came from the Philippines, whose economy was in shambles. Today, more than half of the 200 mail-order bride businesses online cater to men seeking mates from Russia and Ukraine, countries in steep economic decline and in which, not coincidentally, women make up more than 80 percent of those unemployed.
Which is why most such sites are heavy on postings like this one, from Nataliya, a 29-year-old divorced nonsmoker from Russia who reports (spelling and grammar intact): "I am tender, caressing dantist with unusual sense of humor. I have daughter with appearance and character of angel. . . . I am looking for man . . . not greedy, tender, not tedious."
Nataliya has been "viewed" 655 times since November on www.cherry-blossoms.com, the site operated by by Cherry Blossoms Inc., in Hawaii, which has been in the mail-order-bride business for 26 years. Cherry Blossoms used to rely solely on regular mail for the delivery of its expensively printed catalogs. Today, said Mike Krosky, the president of Cherry Blossoms, the company owes 50 percent of its business to the Internet, compared with 15 percent to 20 percent in 1997.
Choosing a mate from another culture is not unusual; the United States is home to millions of cross-cultural marriages. What is new are the numbers involved and the increasing sophistication of international e-matchmakers in their delivery of services. Many companies duplicate features found on other e-commerce sites, like electronic shopping carts. Critics of the services contend that this approach underscores the suggestion, always present in the bride business, that the woman is being bought -- a fantasy that they contend contributes to high rates of divorce or abuse after reality sets in.
Whatever lies at the heart of the transaction, the competitive advantages -- and the profits -- for site owners arise from their ability to provide clients with more than just a woman's address. The Cherry Blossoms site, for example, boasts a database of more than 16,000 women, which can be sorted by country of origin, education, age, eye color, race, height, weight, religion, number of children and whether she is a smoker or a drinker. A visitor types in his criteria, and head shots of women who fit that profile appear on the screen. Double-click on a head shot, and a client will see a full-body shot, a biography and vital statistics. But at Cherry Blossoms and other leading sites, the address database is merely a portal to a menu of services that are intended to extract money from a client at nearly every step he takes toward the altar.
Cherry Blossoms, like other established sites, begins charging a client when he requests an address. Starting at $75, Mr. Krosky's company offers a membership fee that provides a client with 15 addresses. At the high end is the "Premier Guaranteed Membership," which, at $595, includes 100 addresses; two "individualized searches" of the database, which Mr. Krosky conducts on the client's behalf; one-to-one coaching with Mr. Krosky -- himself married three times, most recently to a woman from the Philippines he met through his own business; and an online photograph and biography which, Mr. Krosky says, guarantees a client "60-plus letters" from women.
Other innovations include e-mail forwarding. A client can request that his photograph or a love letter be hand delivered in three to five days rather than in two to three weeks by international mail.
One of Mr. Krosky's competitors, Scanna International (www.scanna .com), adds a link to Flower and Gift International (www.smartlink.net /ais/flower). There, the delivery of roses, a box of chocolates and a card costs a customer at least $155 and can also include, at additional cost, a snapshot of the woman receiving her gift. Another rival, Euroladies (www.euroladies.com), offers three-way conference calling with an interpreter. Both Euroladies and Scanna offer the fiancee a visa preparation kit. At the top of the price scale are organized tours to Russia and Ukraine, offered by Euroladies and Scanna. Euroladies guarantees that men will meet more than 800 women in 10 days for $3,000 to $5,000, including hotel and airfare. Scanna offers a referral to Anastasia Tours, which offers tours for the same price as Euroladies. Anastasia's tours include introductions to 600 to 1,000 women and a 10 percent discount "when you bring a friend."
Even if true love does not last, the e-matchmaking sites are ready to help: some men are repeat customers, returning to the same Internet site on which they had found a previous, now-ex, wife.

SECTION: Section H; Page 25; Column 1; E-Commerce 

LENGTH: 1291 words

HEADLINE: What's That Noise on the Internet? The Sound of Alliances Being Forged

BYLINE: By BOB TEDESCHI; Bob Tedeschi writes the E-Commerce Report each Monday.

 BODY:
EVERYONE'S a cousin in e-commerce.
Scan a week's worth of dot-com headlines, and chances are good that you will find at least a dozen, if not scores, of partnership agreements or corporate alliances between Internet companies or traditional companies doing business on the Web. 
 Sometimes the partnerships involve industry behemoths, like Sun Microsystems and Netscape. Most other times, they are more modest, as in the recent alliance between Phone.com, a provider of wireless Internet technology, and MyWay.com, which builds custom business portals.
Taken as a whole, however, e-commerce partnership announcements have come so often recently that they have become the white noise of Internet business, the hum of the industry's hard drive.
Analysts and e-commerce executives say that alliances are far more prevalent in the Internet industry than in the off-line world, for cultural, practical and technical reasons. The opportunity for publicity also plays a role. "Some of these are really good," said Steven Johnson, a partner with Andersen Consulting, "but some are just companies breathing their own exhaust -- more hype than reality."
Consumer sites have been among the most aggressive in their partnership efforts, analysts say, because they are under pressure to broaden the products they offer. Amazon.com, for instance, has joined Drugstore.com, Ashford.com and, more recently, Wineshopper.com to sell as wide a variety of goods on its site as possible.
With these partnerships, sites achieve two critical e-commerce objectives: first, they increase the chances of shoppers' spending more on each order; second, they prevent customers from straying to other retailers. And portal sites join with companies that provide bill payment or group buying technologies to give users more reasons to stay -- "stickiness," in industry terms.
But stickiness is only part of the story. Industry analysts say that 20 years ago, companies were more inclined to build their own divisions or buy other companies. "In the 70's and 80's, people bought into diversification," said William Battino, who heads the e-business division of PricewaterhouseCoopers. "Now they don't want to be the jack-of-all-trades."
That notion is particularly relevant within the context of Internet business, Mr. Battino and others say, because Web start-ups often spring from a shred of technology or involve a marketplace niche that simply cannot serve customers without plugging in pieces of other businesses.
"With partnerships," Mr. Battino said, "it makes your speed to evolve and radically reinvent much higher," he said.
In an industry where an idea can turn into an initial public offering in months, and where first-mover advantage is the holy grail, Internet executives say that stopping to develop expertise in any given area is tantamount to suicide.
"In a crowd of start-ups, no one can do everything," said Cornelius Willis, vice president for marketing at QPass, which allows shoppers to buy lower-priced goods on several Web sites and have the purchases put on one bill. "So companies like mine are trying to string together a value proposition by creating a coalition of value."
Mr. Willis said that QPass recently made an alliance with American Express, whereby American Express customers would be able to redeem their awards points or shop at Web sites that use the QPass payment system. "We don't have that Amex customer list of 27 million people," Mr. Willis said. "And they don't have the partnerships with digital publishers and others that we have. It makes sense for everyone."
While such a loosely woven corporate structure may at first appear too feeble to sustain a business over the long haul, executives predict it will become a mainstay of the new economy.
"This won't slow down," said Warren V. Musser, the chief executive of Safeguard Scientifics Inc., an incubator of Internet companies. "Collaboration makes things work. There's no one group that can have all the perspective, so the trick is to collaborate, to make sure you don't miss anything."
Another reason why partnerships, especially among technology-savvy companies, are so plentiful is that "the new information technologies allow for better coordination between firms," said Charles Conn, the chairman of Ticketmaster Online-CitySearch Inc., which sells tickets and has more than 40 city sites.
Mr. Conn said that in the past, companies like ITT, the conglomerate, "just acquired everything because it was difficult to coordinate partnerships through the phone" or other means. "But now we can communicate fluidly," he said, "even with companies that have a completely different structure."
Small Internet companies, he added, are also much happier to pursue partnerships because that allows them to maintain a small workforce "where people can feel the impact of their labor, and frankly feel their impact on the company's stock price."
Mr. Conn said that Internet companies also choose partnerships over deeper equity relationships because of the uncertain nature of the industry. "When you look at a firm you might want to own, but they have a cash burn rate that's very high," he said, "you might make less than a controlling investment to get a seat on the board, and get some insight from the company without having to consolidate their losses."
For instance, he said, Ticketmaster Online recently formed a partnership with Active.com, which helps users find sporting events they can participate in, rather than buy the company. "They're still losing a significant amount of money, so it wouldn't make sense to own them now," Mr. Conn said. "But this way, we still develop a strong relationship with them."
ONE way to track the Internet's infatuation with alliances is to watch the fad du jour within e-commerce. When business-to-consumer e-commerce held the public's -- and Wall Street's -- attention, the pace of alliances matched the investor frenzy. When the focus shifted to the business-to-business category, partnerships involving online industry marketplaces and software providers proliferated.
Lately, wireless e-commerce, sometimes referred to as "m-commerce" (the m stands for mobile), is emerging as another battlefront; for wireless providers, that means it is time to find partners. Kathy Simpson, the director of developer marketing for Phone.com, said the company had created alliances with about 200 companies who wanted to put their Web content into a format that could be viewed by people with cellular phones and other hand-held devices.
Phone.com earns money by signing up large long-distance carriers like AT&T to offer the service to cellular customers, so it behooves Phone.com to get as many Internet companies as possible to develop wireless versions of their sites. Meanwhile, these companies have little time to devote to wireless technology -- particularly because many are scrambling to remain in business -- so they rely on Phone.com to help.
When asked how Phone.com helps such a vast list of partners develop wireless programs, Ms. Simpson laughed. "We have other partners to help with that," she said. "None of us can exist alone. It's like people are supplying various pieces of the puzzle."
E-commerce executives said that in cobbling together that puzzle, not every piece fit nicely, especially when the partnerships are thrown together for the publicity.
Mr. Conn, of Ticketmaster Online, said that he had seen that happen. "We've been fortunate with our own alliances," he said. "But it's absolutely true that many of the ones you read about are ill-thought-through, and are done for the P.R. value. If there's one great thing about alliances, though, it's that they can be undone quickly."

SECTION: Section H; Page 1; Column 2; E-Commerce 

LENGTH: 3086 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TO BUSINESS;
It's Just the Beginning

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: DANBURY, Conn.

 BODY:
THINK of the Internet. The imagery that comes to mind is romantic and exciting: dot-com billionaires barely out of school and colorful Web sites offering all sorts of wares and intriguing ways to shop. What definitely does not come to mind are Sherrell Coppedge and Kara Sylvia, seated recently at two ordinary desktop computers in a plain, windowless room at Honeywell Inc.
For eight weeks, four hours a day, Ms. Coppedge and Ms. Sylvia have been trying to trip up the new Internet ordering system that Honeywell's consumer products group, based here, is installing. Soon 2,000 customers -- auto dealers, parts distributors, lube centers, retail chains -- will be logging on to Web sites to place orders for Autolite spark plugs, Fram oil filters and Prestone antifreeze. No more orders by telephone or by fax, and much less paperwork. But first, the speedy new system has to function. 
 Working from thick loose-leaf notebooks, Ms. Coppedge, 34, and Ms. Sylvia, 26, carefully type in complicated, quirky orders, each a probe for shortcomings in the system's software. When a flaw appears, Jon Nehlsen, a 25-year-old Internet specialist, takes charge of the fix. All three are salaried employees earning less than six figures, the two women much less. None of the windfalls from wildly lucrative dot-com stock offerings come their way. And yet they and thousands like them are laboriously making the Internet a backbone of the national economy.
The Internet, with its endless Web sites, is already a miraculous storehouse of information, an instant communicator, a new medium, a vast electronic shopping mall, a link to Wall Street. But for all the excitement over the prospect of an Internet connection in every home, this is not where the big money is. What companies spend buying and selling goods and services to one another dwarfs consumer spending. The score last year was $14 trillion to $3 trillion. Like Honeywell, brick-and-mortar companies are just beginning to shift these intercompany sales to the Internet. Until they make the full transition, the Internet age will not truly have arrived.
And it is slow in coming. A lot more is involved than just logging on. Honeywell's consumer products group, for example, has three disparate, aging computer systems that track 17 factories and more than $1 billion in annual sales. Getting those computers to talk to other companies through the Internet is not easy. When Ms. Coppedge and Ms. Sylvia -- simulating outsiders -- hit a trouble spot, it is often because one of their orders placed through a Web site failed to enter the company's internal computers. Some version of Honeywell's painful progress is popping up everywhere in corporate America.
"The lion's share of American companies are in the throes of this conversion," said Clyde R. Moore, chief executive of the Thomas & Betts Corporation in Memphis, which makes electrical switches and connectors. A multi-million computer investment is just being completed. The more sophisticated system updates the company's inventories more quickly than before, for example, thus reducing the risk of selling a connector over the Internet that is not in stock.
Web sites for consumers are easier to create, and many companies now have them. They put these sites on computers dedicated to the Internet. A car buff, for example, can pull up a Honeywell site and find the filter he needs to change the oil in his car himself. Punch in a ZIP code and the site lists the nearest retail outlets selling the filter -- along with maps and directions on how to get there. The entire database is maintained separately from Honeywell's internal computer system.
The consumer is clearly the hare in this race. Still, the tortoise, even in this difficult early stage, has already moved out front. Intercompany transactions over the Internet totaled $90 billion last year, a drop in the bucket given the potential but nevertheless more than five times the $16.7 billion that consumers spent over the Internet, according to the Gartner Group, a consulting firm that tracks such data. The $16.7 billion included brokerage fees to trade stocks online.
But what route the tortoise will take to the finish line is still unclear. Business-to-business commerce over the Internet means that companies will have access to the data in one another's computers, like access to a stranger's bedroom. "What the Internet does is make the boundaries between companies much more fuzzy," said Paul Osterman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management. With boundaries fading, mergers, and challenges to antitrust law, may multiply.
The Internet is also giving fresh impetus to trends already well under way. American companies, for example, find that the Internet gives them easier access to suppliers overseas. Competitive Internet auctions are forcing suppliers, here and abroad, to cut prices more than in the past. And stockpiles of unsold goods -- a burden in hard times -- are likely to shrink; the Internet helps companies place smaller orders more frequently.
There is one unambiguous benefit: labor productivity. The Internet should make possible more output, or at least the same output, from fewer hours of work. The 28 employees in Honeywell's consumer products group who now take orders by fax and phone will eventually be reassigned, their tasks automated as corporate customers shift to ordering online -- 2,000 this year and the remaining 2,000 thereafter. Some of the 28 might be reassigned as traveling sales reps to sign up more customers. Business would then grow without having to hire more workers, another gain in labor output.
"The potential exists for the nation to achieve real productivity gains," said Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist. The gains are just beginning to kick in, Mr. Blinder noted, as business-to-business commerce over the Internet -- almost nonexistent in 1997 -- finally takes hold and spreads.
More noticeably, the incipient Internet age is breeding a new type of electronic marketplace. Beyond one company selling goods or services to another, companies in the same industry are offering their products jointly on a common Web site, inviting buyers to choose from among their joint offerings. A new marketplace, to sell plywood or chemicals or steel or accounting services, is announced almost weekly. Honeywell's avionics division is participating in one, to sell aircraft parts and repair services. The main customers are airlines and the owners of corporate jets.
Buyers are also setting up joint marketplaces, the best known being one announced earlier this year by General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler. Most of the $240 billion a year in parts and materials that the Big Three purchase to make vehicles are to be listed on common Web sites, and thousands of suppliers will bid online for the business, almost certainly pushing down their prices.
There is a catch, however. Lacking expertise, the brick-and-mortar companies are relying on outside contractors to design and maintain their electronic marketplaces. Often the contractors are young, profitless dot-coms scrambling for a permanent foothold. Whether they will share in the control of these marketplaces, and the revenue they generate, or simply collect fees as technical agents is anyone's guess.
Honeywell, for example, took the lead in setting up the marketplace for aircraft parts and repair services but offered shares to the United Technologies Corporation, another big maker of aircraft parts. "To attract the likes of United Technologies, we had to be willing to share ownership," said Michael R. Bonsignore, Honeywell's chief executive. The necessary expertise in Internet technology -- to set up and run the marketplace -- comes from a start-up, i2 Technology, which also has an ownership stake but not much leverage. It lacks any merchandise to sell on the exchange.
Still, a few dot-coms are trying to mimic the New York Stock Exchange, which owns and runs the principal trading house for corporate stocks. FreeMarkets Inc. in Pittsburgh is in hot pursuit of this goal. Big manufacturers like Emerson Electric, Honeywell and United Technologies now turn regularly to FreeMarkets to round up suppliers, who then bid against one another on auction-style Web sites set up by FreeMarkets.
"Our FreeMarkets is going to be a major node, and we are now a major business-to-business marketplace," said Glen Meakem, the 35-year-old founder and chief executive, whose four-year-old company, for all its success, is losing money. "We are too far along for that to be taken away from us."
 
The Inventory Revolution
Making What's Needed Only When It's Needed
From the early days of the Industrial Revolution, business has struggled with the problem of unwanted inventories, which are the stockpiling of goods that later cannot be sold. Computers have helped to keep inventories in check, and now business-to-business commerce over the Internet offers corporate America, particularly manufacturers, a new and perhaps powerful tool in this struggle. That is because the Internet is turning out to be the least expensive system developed, so far, in which companies can talk to one another through their computers.
But to hold down inventories, the hookup has to go in two directions: to customers at one end, as Honeywell's consumer products group is doing with its new order system, and to suppliers at the other end. Then when one of Honeywell's customers -- the Jiffy Lube chain, for example -- orders a thousand oil filters, the suppliers at the other end will instantly know this and begin to make the metal casings, filter elements and tops, shipping them to Honeywell factories for final assembly.
The broad goal is to manufacture only what is needed, when it is needed. In good economic times, companies everywhere have tended to overproduce and stockpile, fearful -- for lack of timely information -- that they could not meet a flood of orders. These are good times, and Honeywell still has "$3.5 billion in working capital tied up in inventory," Mr. Bonsignore said.
Stockpiles, although smaller than in the past, are still a shadow over the economy. When slowdowns inevitably arrive, production is cut back abruptly, exacerbating the hard times until inventories are reduced. The great hope is that production swings in the Internet age will be less abrupt.
But the Internet hookups that link customers to their suppliers are still in their infancy. Only a few companies have completed the process: I.B.M., for example, and Wal-Mart. A decade ago, before the Internet, Wal-Mart connected the cash registers in its stores to its thousands of suppliers so that a shirt sold in Omaha registered with the company that made it in South Carolina. That pioneering system, however, required a huge investment in special computers and dedicated phone lines. Few other companies matched Wal-Mart's achievement, and in 1998 Wal-Mart itself switched its network entirely to the less expensive, more flexible Internet.
Most American companies are more like Honeywell than Wal-Mart. Honeywell's consumer products group is only now about to go online with its order system for business customers, and its avionics group in Olathe, Kan., only recently hooked into the computers at Cessna, a big customer for the cockpit controls and navigational devices that Honeywell makes.
Far more quickly than in the past, Honeywell is now privy to Cessna's shifting production schedule -- not only how many planes Cessna will make in the months ahead, but also how many of each model and their delivery dates. "Honeywell takes this data, runs it through its computers and explodes it down to parts numbers for its suppliers," said David Oppenheim, Cessna's supply chain manager and chief of its e-business.
Not quite. The explosion down to Honeywell's suppliers has not happened yet. But it will soon, the company promises. Links through the Internet to 12 of its 800 suppliers are about to go live. In a conference room at the avionics group's headquarters in Olathe, Jeffrey C. Small, manager of supply chain infrastructure, recently demonstrated the new system, flashing Web sites from his laptop on to a big white screen.
"Every day when a supplier logs on, he will see his situation with us," Mr. Small said, displaying a dummy supplier Web site filled with hyphenated parts numbers, new and old orders, parts needed quickly, others needed not so quickly. "It has taken 18 months to develop this system and it seems like it has taken forever."
 
The Global Auction Block
From Sealed Bids To Online Competition
More visible is the Internet auction house operated by FreeMarkets. The auctions are a novelty even for a technology full of novelties. Suppliers worldwide bid over Web sites on their laptop computers. Giant mother versions of these Web sites, several feet high, cover most of a wall at FreeMarkets' headquarters in Pittsburgh.
As the bidding proceeds from the laptops, the numbers change on the mother Web sites, which have bluish backgrounds that glow in a slightly darkened room the size and shape of a small college lecture hall. As the auction proceeds, sometimes for three hours, young people (average age 31) counsel the bidders by telephone. They have designed the Web sites to call attention to the big justification for Internet auctions.
One prominent column of numbers tells the big corporate buyer how much money the company is saving from the last time it bought this particular item. More often than not, that last purchase was pre-Internet style, through sealed bids. Opening these envelopes, the buyer then chose the lowest one. In the Internet auction, the competing suppliers see one another's bids. And if the falling numbers are not prod enough to keep shaving bids, separate graphs on the glowing Web sites plot the action downward.
Honeywell's avionics group, in this new world, saved $400,000, or 19.5 percent, in the purchase last month of various parts for $1.7 million. Owens Corning bought $24 million worth of corrugated packaging through an online auction, saving 7 percent. And the Carrier Corporation saved 16 percent on the purchase of air-conditioner motors, mostly from Asian suppliers for the company's Asian factories.
Carrier's parent, United Technologies, has bought a stake in FreeMarkets, which has frequently issued new stock to raise much needed capital. That may help to explain the enthusiasm of Edward Williams, Carrier's vice president for purchasing. "We spend $3 billion a year on suppliers, and we are running $100 million of this through FreeMarkets," he said. "I would like to keep that number growing."
What is less talked about are two changes in American business practices that the Internet auctions encourage. One is the tendency to ignore long-term relationships with suppliers and award the business to the qualified bidder offering the lowest price, or to the long-term supplier if it cuts its bid. Japanese companies had favored long-term relationships with suppliers, without forcing them to discount, and in the 1980's, when corporate Japan seemed so successful, American companies went that way, too. Now the pendulum is swinging back, thanks in part to the Internet.
"Japanese companies tried to partner a lot," Mr. Meakem of FreeMarkets said, "and the Asian crisis proved that noneconomic cozy relationships don't work."
The other change is the new encouragement to seek less expensive suppliers overseas, a trend well under way before the Internet. The Internet makes worldwide bidding feasible and dramatic, although the recruiting of overseas suppliers remains a rather old-fashioned task. Half of FreeMarkets' 497 employees spend their time not running electronic auctions but searching for suppliers in trade-association directories and trips abroad, painstakingly building up a huge database of potential bidders.
In preparation for last month's auction, Honeywell's avionics group received from FreeMarkets a list of 600 possible bidders from this database. By auction day, the list had been trimmed to 22 that met Honeywell's standards, some from as far away as Israel and China. That was still far more than the three or four suppliers that traditionally mailed in sealed bids.
"There was no reason why we could not have recruited many more suppliers in the past if we had made the effort," said Doug McCambridge, e-business project manager at Honeywell's avionics group. "The Internet is now pushing us to make the effort."
 
Small Changes Start to Add Up
THE Internet, with its easy accessibility, is generating various small corporate efficiencies.
The Chubb Corporation, the big insurer, for example, provides workers' compensation insurance to multinational corporations at their sites worldwide. Before the Internet, the executives in charge of workers' compensation at Chubb's client corporations gathered information about accidents by telephone, fax, e-mail, even floppy disks mailed to the home office.
Reports from Chubb's claims adjusters arrived by similar routes. With the data finally entered in a central computer, the executives could pinpoint the most frequent types of accidents, where they occurred most often and other trends that, if reversed, might reduce accidents and thus the company's insurance premiums. Now Web sites set up by Chubb provide all this information more quickly, in greater detail and with new analytical tools for spotting trends.
"What we are doing is leveraging a public infrastructure just as truckers leverage public highways," said Doug Nordstrom, Chubb's manager of business technology planning. "And our customers are demanding that we use the Internet to give them information in real time. If you don't give it, you are at a disadvantage. Someone else will and take away the business."
Johnson Controls Inc. in Milwaukee, which makes temperature controls and other products, uses Web sites to help its field representatives repair controls installed in commercial buildings nationwide.
The field representative logs on to a company Web site and "accesses our huge database until he finds a similar problem and solution," said James H. Keyes, chairman of Johnson Controls. There is much less need for costly experts at the other end of a phone line to answer a representative's questions, Mr. Keyes added, "and the repair job is faster." LOUIS UCHITELLE

HEADLINE: LETTER FROM...PHILACON VALLEY;
Brotherly Love It's Got, and Now There's a Touch of Envy, Too

BYLINE: By DAVID J. WALLACE; David J. Wallace, a business and technology writer, has moved to Boston from the Philadelphia area.

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA

 BODY:
LIKE a character actor who takes roles as a serial killer after years of playing the kindly uncle, civic boosters here are trying to shed the cardigan sweater and the sensible shoes. There is a palpable desire to be a technology hot spot.
But how? Over the last couple of years, Technophilly, SiliconPhilly, Silicon ValleyForge, @Philly and Philacon Valley have been floated in efforts to raise the region's brand awareness, on the theory that recognition and corporate dollars would follow. Some names have Web sites or printed materials behind them, but not one of the monikers has stuck. 
 As any athlete knows, nicknames are given, not manufactured. Philadelphia is not as complacent and dowdy as its critics say. It has its power lunchers, its venture capitalists who chat casually about jaw-dropping sums. But it is not the technology mecca envisioned by its boosters. And when the city was omitted from a Wall Street Journal list of the top 20 technology areas last November, the slight touched off a quest for attention that would have made the region's Quaker settlers twitch uncomfortably.
Civic leaders want an e-business scene, just as earlier civic efforts tried to recognize the city's movie, restaurant and film notables. The actor Will Smith, Ben Vaughn, a rocker, and the rap group The Roots are hometown heroes, but the enduring reputation is "The Sound of Philadelphia," soul and pop music created by Kenny Gamble and Leon Huff two decades ago. Movies recently filmed here include the creepy "Twelve Monkeys" and "The Sixth Sense," hardly the stuff shown by the chamber of commerce to foster corporate relocation.
Philadelphia has long had an identity crisis, flanked on the north by New York's financial and media capital and on the south by the political capital, Washington.
Defining the region is exasperating because of its diversity, said David Thornburgh, the executive director of the Pennsylvania Economy League, a public policy and research organization. The region encompasses some of the former steel towns of Pennsylvania and the shore resorts of New Jersey. Unlike Las Vegas or Detroit, where tourism or automotive industries serve as bellwethers, Philadelphia companies enjoy a strong reputation in credit, finance, insurance, medical education and care, biotechnology and pharmaceutical research, among other industries.
"There's been no image defined in the public psyche since 'Rocky,' " Mr. Thornburgh said. "But we could become the buckle on the East Coast's money belt because of our location. And our strength is in putting things together as an integrator."
Indeed, as in San Francisco or Boston, there is no single technology epicenter in the city. Philadelphia's downtown lofts and 19th-century storefronts now house computer graphics or e-business start-ups and electronic-art galleries.
That streetscape contrasts with acres of suburban office parks where companies vie for room to grow alongside countless consultants, training firms and support service providers. Devon Consulting, in the Main Line borough of Wayne, uses the parking lot for advertising. A Plymouth Prowler sporting the company's logo reminds clients that a successful referral may bring a week's use of the car.
Many argue that the region's reputation as a technology center will grow as more companies migrate to the Internet. There are now companies that excel in particular applications, among them SEI Investments in Oaks, Pa., which provides technology services and asset management for banks and investment companies.
"Unfortunately, we've never been able to birth a megacompany like AOL, Microsoft or Sun Microsystems," said Howard Ross, an adviser to emerging companies since the 1980's and a principal in LLR Equity Partners, a new venture fund. "But this area could wake up and surprise itself."
ONE reason for Mr. Ross's optimism is his argument that Boston and San Jose, Calif., had the first significant concentrations of venture capital, but the capital that creates companies is now flowing into other areas. In just the last three years, more than $50 billion in wealth was created on paper by three local companies. The charge has been led by the Safeguard Scientifics Corporation of Wayne, Pa, a publicly traded venture-capital investor, which backed two of the most successful public offerings in 1999, Internet Capital Group and VerticalNet.
Much of the e-commerce activity is in the business-to-business market, where less glamorous companies make the consumer dot-coms look good by providing the systems and fulfillment processes that power consumer Web sites.
Major corporations based here include QVC Network Inc., the Comcast Corporation, SAP Americas Inc. and Aetna U.S. Healthcare. Yet there are several obstacles to growth, said Stephen Mullin, a former commerce director for the City of Philadelphia who teaches college courses on e-commerce and is a consultant.
He points to a city tax structure that punishes companies by taxing both wages and net profits as one explanation as to why most of the expansion has been in the suburbs instead of downtown.
Looking to distinguish itself, a study found that Philadelphia's cost of living, relative to a technology professional's salary, ranked third lowest, behind Dallas and Chicago, among 15 cities. Robert Hollebeek, a data-mining expert, found the region was in a top spot in the number and density of colleges and universities. The residents of those 88 institutions, however, are transient, with one-quarter of the population coming and going each year, many taking business plans with them.
Innovative start-up ideas are being exported from Temple, Villanova and Drexel universities and the University of Pennsylvania, where the first electronic computer was created, in 1946.
Last month, it was announced that eTechtransfer.com, a business-to-business marketplace for the life-sciences industry, won the 2000 Wharton Business Plan competition. The prize was $15,000 cash and a $10,000 investment from Safeguard Scientifics. The 1999 winner, Paymybills.com, got snapped up by a California incubator, which disappointed local technology leaders.
To help stem the talent flight, the Eastern Technology Council, a regional industry group, has supported a program of scholarships, financing assistance for start-ups and using mentoring efforts to keep students here after graduation.
"Philadelphia's business plans are farther along than other cities', but the ideas that emerge here are going other places," said George Boyajian, a managing director of RoundTable Partners, which advises emerging companies. "As more 'smart money' comes into the area, more deals are getting done. But the traditional Quaker banking, insurance and real estate money is remarkably risk averse."
Still, the buzz of entrepreneurship is growing louder. At a student-entrepreneur forum organized by Mr. Boyajian at the University of Pennsylvania, 40 of the 60 undergraduates there said they had started a company.
Meanwhile, the search for a glamour tag continues. One local entrepreneur has tried out the idea that the area could be billed as being twice as important as Silicon Valley, whose technology companies are clustered around Route 101. Philadelphia's straddle Route 202.

HEADLINE: ONLINE OVERSEAS;
The Net Is Calling Them Home, but Many More Are Needed

BYLINE: By GRACE FAN; Grace Fan writes about business and the Internet in Shanghai.

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
WHEN Xin Ye returned to Beijing after a 14-year absence to take a senior position at one of China's most popular Internet portals, Sohu, he left behind his wife, two daughters, a California lifestyle and a job prospect at a Silicon Valley start-up.
"My heart at this point is still in Silicon Valley," said Mr. Ye, 36, a former senior technical manager at Marimba, as he emerged from a meeting on his first day of work early last month. "The ocean was five minutes away. The mountains were half an hour's drive away. But how many times does an opportunity come up to build a leading portal in China? Just once, right?" 
 Mr. Ye is not alone among overseas Chinese who have given up the advantages of life abroad, for the time being, to chase Internet gold in a nation he no longer calls home. In growing numbers, first- and second-generation Chinese from Hong Kong, Taiwan, Singapore and the United States are returning to China, many recruited to feed a hunger for bilingual senior managers in the country's infant Internet industry.
"It's like a reverse brain drain," said Jay Kuo, a lawyer who left his job as a marketing manager at BSEM, an agricultural equipment manufacturer, in January to co-found Fudao.net, a finance site for families that is going online next month. "A lot of my friends have come back for the singular opportunity to write the next Internet chapter. Many mainland friends who have the opportunity to go overseas now haven't gone for this reason."
Beijing has tried for years, without much success, to lure natives with technical and managerial skills back to China. But the explosion of the Internet in China is finally "bringing them back in droves," said Charles Zhang, chairman of Sohu.
Still, while Web entrepreneurs like Tang Haisong of Etang, an online portal, and Joseph Chen of Chinaren, a community Web site, are coming back waving their Harvard and Stanford M.B.A.'s -- and flush with millions of dollars in venture capital -- what start-ups really need are senior executives with hands-on management experience and technical talent, analysts said.
Norman Liu, co-founder of 51job.com, a job site, said, "Once companies pass their first three- to six-month periods, human resources inevitably becomes the most important and most difficult problem for them."
They will particularly have to to fill certain upper-echelon spots. "They need key senior people with the vision and capability to lead them to an I.P.O.," Mr. Liu said. "The Chinese are good at execution, but weak on problem-solving, and lack a keen knowledge of the business as well."
Though established multinational companies have lamented that there is a scarcity of executive talent in China, the rash of new dot-com companies is fast turning this shortage into a cross-industry regional drought.
"The Internet industry is a big, sore open wound right now," said Steve Chiu, chief sales officer of Zhaopin, another job site. "We have over 500 companies advertising on our site now, many of them looking for the same people. It's a really really crazy scene."
A chief technical officer, with five to eight years of management experience, tops the wish lists of more than 100 start-up companies. A talented vice president for marketing is another highly coveted yet hard-to-find executive. Longer-established dot-coms, including the popular portal Netease, are beginning to recruit older executives, who can offer a depth of experience that their brash young founders lack.
Though well-known sites like Sohu and Sina have the money and name recognition to lure talent from Silicon Valley, many start-ups without these advantages are settling for employees with less experience, including managers from state-owned enterprises and graduates with master's degree in engineering. Salaries for even less-qualified chief technical officers can be as much as as $100,000, plus stock options.
"It's not the most rational hiring decision," Mr. Liu said, "because they'll hit a wall in six months. But companies nowadays are getting more and more desperate."
With demand up and supply down, it is no surprise that recruiting firms like Wang & Li Asia Resources, which culls talent from greater China and San Francisco, has seen its Net business explode 80 percent over the last six months. About 300 competing job- search dot-coms have also crowded into the recruiting field, Mr. Chiu said, all trying to capitalize on the expanding market.
For example, Sinobit, a site for technology entrepreneurs, prominently features a "Western returnee" center, hoping to lure overseas talent. The site was co-founded in January by Zhang Lei, who hastily packed his bags three months before finishing his M.B.A. from Yale University to return to China and join the Internet rush "before it was too late."
Others scoff at the perception that returnees are a sure-fire bet, saying that some people come back with a superior attitude that offends their staff members, or have been away too long to immediately grasp the complexities of a business environment literally changing by the month.
Still, for now, many smaller start-ups -- from Web development design firms to city guides -- are not worrying about an industry-wide scarcity of senior managers. Competent junior-level and midlevel managers are plentiful, thanks in part to multinational firms that started promoting local employees five years ago.
Though more than a few executives are disappointed by the lack of creative graphic designers or talented and self-motivated editors, which they attribute largely to an education system that does not foster creativity, many have devised innovative ways to deal with the problem.
An American executive at Menkou, a lifestyle and entertainment site, routinely does pull-ups in his hallway or plays his stereo loudly to encourage his employees to do wacky things. Fudao.net has built a jungle gym in its office to give its 27 employees a way to "keep their creative juices flowing," as Mr. Kuo puts it. Other Internet start-ups, unhappy with local programmers and graphic designers, have contracted the work out to people in other countries.
Employees have also realized that they are in demand. With bidding wars and raiding on the rise, salaries have increased in some companies as much as 50 percent for writers and 80 percent for junior-level programmers since a year ago. Across the industry, wages have generally risen a more modest 20 percent to 30 percent, but sudden promotions are also in vogue. One Internet company lured a sales clerk from another start-up by offering her a salary 12 times higher than her previous one, and the position of chief executive.
"We couldn't even find good-quality secretaries at average salaries," Mr. Kuo said. "Some even asked us for stock options. And we gave it to them."

HEADLINE: Matchmakers for Services That Really Mean Business

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
THEY have been designing and building Web sites since 1994, the proverbial dawn of the Internet age. But even though they have more potential business than ever before, work has become more complicated in recent years for the people at Choice One OnLine, Inc. a Buffalo, N.Y., Web host and Web design services company.
"Sure, there are lots of potential customers out there now," said Kyle Kraus, director of sales for Choice One, which was known as Edgenet until it was acquired in February by Choice One Communications of Rochester, N.Y., a local and long-distance phone company. "But in our industry, it's still hard to find a qualified lead -- someone who is willing to attach a budget to the project and who believes that there's going to be a return on his investment."
 Enter IT-Radar (www.it-radar .com, a Minneapolis company that links companies like Choice One with those that want to buy a range of information technology services. A so-called e-marketplace, IT-Radar's New York pages made their Web debut in late January. As Edgenet, Choice One was among the first to sign on; by mid-May, the company had received at least a dozen leads. 
 "What IT-Radar has done is to hook us up to people who are serious about what they're looking for," Mr. Kraus said.
Although business-to-business sales of goods on the Internet are exploding, the selling of business services online is in its infancy and amounted to a relatively meager $22 billion last year, according to Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. That number is expected to rise to $44 billion this year, compared with $406 billion in total business-to-business transactions. Most of those services were sold one-to-one by companies with an established relationship; very few transactions were, in fact, made at e-marketplaces, where service offerings have just begun.
The reasons are obvious. Buying a service often requires a chemistry between buyer and seller, which is especially true of complex and subjective services, like legal advice or creative design. Such services are less than ideal to sell at arm's length, notably between people who share only an Internet connection.
Still, those who use e-marketplaces to buy tangible goods say they like what they find, which is a system that encourages shopping around and finding substantial savings over traditional catalog prices. Given that, are e-marketplaces for services catching up?
Bruce D. Temkin, a Forrester analyst, thinks so. "Over the next three to four years we expect services to take hold," he said. "Even the most complex, human-intensive services will have an Internet component." As a result, Forrester predicts that business-to-business sales of services should rise tenfold over the next few years.
The field is wide open, Mr. Temkin said, "with no industry leader or model having yet emerged." E-marketplaces that are taking a crack at services are doing so in several different ways.
FreeMarkets, which arranges auctions of industrial materials and is one of the oldest business-to-business marketplaces, began offering services in 1997. But they make up less than 5 percent of the company's business -- $123.8 million of the $2.7 billion in sales made through the site, Mr. Meakem said. Services bought and sold included temporary help, corporate car-rental contracts and a $3.1 million contract for telecommunications services recently fulfilled for the state of Pennsylvania. Mr. Meakem thinks that these impersonal services will continue to dominate e-marketplaces.
"To make an auction market, a buyer has to be able to specify exactly what he or she needs and be willing to take it from any supplier," Mr. Meakem said. "You can't do that with corporate legal advice, but you can do it with services that are conducive to the bidding process."
Must an e-marketplace relegate customers to formal auction bidding in their service transactions? No, said Alexander Straub, the United States chief executive of Mondus (www.mondus.com), an e-marketplace that operates in the United States, Britain, Germany and France. Instead, the site offers goods and services to small and midsize companies through a system in which bids are presented to prospective buyers who can make their decisions at leisure. The process lets buyers make purchases using considerations other than price, and buyers often negotiate directly with sellers after receiving their bids. Sellers pay Mondus.com a commission if a sale is made.
That means that a buyer can get to know a seller before making a purchase. "With services, you often want to talk to the vendor, and with our system you can do that," Mr. Straub said.
According to Mr. Straub, customers who originally came to Mondus for products are beginning to use it to shop for services as well, mostly standardized ones like courier services and translation. More personalized things like human resources, legal services and public relations remain a harder sell.
And that is precisely the kind of resistance that IT-Radar is determined to overcome. Unlike most e-marketplaces, where the sale of services has a secondary role, IT-Radar deals in nothing else.
"In this market -- information technology services -- there is a lot of subjectivity on both sides," said Don Peterson, the chairman. Providers and buyers are selective, he said, adding, "Like a law firm, they decide whether to take a client." Moreover, although buyers and sellers of goods and raw materials often benefit from the national or international scope of an e-marketplace, the market for services is far more fragmented, with a "unique mix in each town," Mr. Peterson said.
So IT-Radar operates locally, with businesses in 11 markets thus far, including Denver, Atlanta, New York, Chicago and Los Angeles.
Although the places differ, the process is the same. Service providers prepare profiles of themselves that the company keeps on file. Then, as prospective purchasers require services, they prepare lists of their needs, which are sent to providers, who file their responses. The process continues, often with negotiations and direct contact, until the client makes a selection. Meanwhile, service providers pay IT-Radar a fee depending on how many leads they accept.
Mr. Kraus, of Choice One OnLine, is pleased with the service so far. "We've closed a couple of deals already," he said.

HEADLINE: LIFE'S WORK;
It's a Whole New Lexicon

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN; This column about the intersection of jobs and personal lives appears every other week. Lisa Belkin's e-mail address is Belkin@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
A FORMER professor of mine called the other day and asked if I'd speak to a group of graduating students about juggling life and work. It's been nearly 20 years since I was a graduating senior myself, and I certainly don't remember anyone talking to me then about life in the same sentence as work.
Back when I was their age (back when I swore I would never say things like "back when I was their age"), a job search was all about whom we could persuade to hire us, not whom we would deign to work for. I have vague memories of my mother suggesting that "international law requires a lot of time away from home, dear," but I wasn't really listening, and I did not for a moment consider choosing a career because it would provide something as complex as flextime-in-preparation-for-the-day-when-I-had-children. Back then the vocabulary with which to articulate that idea didn't even exist. 
 Today's students, I'm learning, are fluent in this new language. They have watched their parents (gulp, my peers) try to give 100 percent of themselves twice over, and, because this is a mathematical impossibility, they have watched them fail. "They have mothers and fathers who were never around," says Dan Golden, a dean at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., where students are counseled, beginning as freshmen, about the "triangle" of life-work, significant relationships and community service. "They saw their parents get sliced apart trying to balance everything," he says, "and they are determined to do things differently."
Schools, in turn, are determined to help them. Just look at the name of Mr. Golden's department. No longer "career services," his office of "Work and Service Learning" holds seminars throughout the year, with recent graduates returning to tell students about the real world. "We don't want them to come back in 20 years," he explains, "and say, 'Why didn't you tell us how hard it was going to be?' "
Instead, armed with knowledge and bouyed by a microscopic unemployment rate, they march into today's job interviews and ask for what they want. "Dress code is a big one," says Dr. Larry Salters, director of the University of South Carolina's Career Center. "They want to know, 'What are the dress expectations? How flexible is my schedule? Can I set my own hours? Can I do some of my work from home or in my car? How involved will I be in making the important decisions?' "
Some of them do their asking on the Web, at job-search sites like Careercreations .com. Founded by 22-year-old Todd Gitlin, who is barely one year out of California State University at Chico, the site proclaims: "Forget about searching for job openings. Search for employers by the things that matter to you -- signing bonus, car allowance, stock options, on-site massages, flexible schedules and more."
One afternoon a few weeks ago I did just that. I logged on as the me I was my senior year, a confused Ivy League political science major who thought she might want to go to law school but figured journalism might be fun, too. Under "fields of interest" I entered advertising, publishing, consulting and the Internet. That last one didn't exist when I graduated, but if it had I don't imagine I could have resisted that which lures this whole generation.
Then I scrolled through Mr. Gitlin's ingredients for a balanced life. I clicked "yes" to all the insurance benefits, to the stock-option plan, to paid personal days, paid sick days, paid vacation days, paid holidays. I clicked 'not essential" to the commuting allowance and auto allowance because my 22-year-old self expected to live in the middle of a city. My only "no" was to paternity leave, for obvious biological reasons.
I said I needed a flexible schedule and a smoke-free environment, but I could live without a casual dress code and the right to bring my (nonexistent) dog. On-site food facilities were on my list of requirements and, as a result, so was an on-site gym. Wanting to appear reasonable, I said that an on-site hairdresser, dry cleaner, car wash and massage therapist were "nonessential." I was, I admit, sorely tempted to check "yes" to the massage.
After agreeing to move anywhere in the country, I hit the send button. A list of more than a dozen companies appeared, and most were technology-related. Not one had all the features I had checked, but a few had most.
Would I have been happy with a life spent writing banner ads for Internet sites? Perhaps. Would all this advance warning really have prepared my 22-year-old self for the cataclysmic changes brought to that life by adding children? Probably not. No class nor Web site can prepare you for that. But I would have been well served to have paid some attention. The biggest change since I was "their age" is not that they have all the answers, but that they know enough to ask the questions.
