HEADLINE: Chartered Wings: Less Time Going, More Time There;
Growing Numbers of Travelers Bypass the Scheduled Airlines

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
Americans are flying more in this booming economy, but also griping more: about longer lines at airports, longer takeoff delays and tighter limits on carry-on bags. Not to mention the perennial beef about how long it takes just to get to the airport.
But growing numbers of travelers, particularly in the New York region, are doing more than complaining about tiring business flights or arduous vacation travel. They are bypassing regularly scheduled airlines altogether and finding alternative wings on charter flights or in part ownership of small jets. 
 For companies that do not own their own planes, charter flights and so-called fractional ownership of aircraft permit executives to make more efficient use of their traveling time, conducting in-flight meetings and often traveling to small, less-crowded airports much closer to their destinations.
The appeal is particularly great at a time when travel budgets are fat and a charter seat, in some cases, costs only marginally more than a first-class or business-class ticket on a scheduled airline.
And while figures vary on the increase in chartering, estimates from industry specialists and individual charter companies suggest a growth range in the last year from 7 percent over all to several times that for some individual operators. This growth comes even as scheduled carriers have reported a 37 percent rise in passengers over the last decade.
"We're at the epicenter of the charter world," said Carole Helms, vice president for marketing at TAG Aviation, a major charter company whose half-dozen bases in the region include Westchester County Airport in Harrison, N.Y., and Teterboro Airport in New Jersey, not far from Manhattan.
New York's investment banking houses and companies making initial public stock offerings are "great users of charter," she said, adding that business is also brisk in California's Silicon Valley, where software and dot-com denizens are also big on buzzing about in "air taxis," as charters are called in the airline industry.
Ms. Helms and others in the business say that while most charter flights and partial plane ownerships involve business travel, a growing number are for personal travel.
One such traveler is James W. Kinnear, the retired president and chief executive of Texaco and now the chairman of the Metropolitan Opera.
When he and his wife journey once or twice a month from their home in Connecticut to their farm in southern Virginia, they do not drive for an hour to La Guardia Airport, check in themselves, their baggage and their three dogs an hour before the 90-minute flight and arrive at the Raleigh-Durham International Airport in North Carolina, the nearest to their farm that the airliners from New York land.
Instead, they drive just 20 minutes to the Westchester County Airport and immediately board a sleek, seven-passenger Cessna Citation light jet that carries them to an airfield closer to the farm.
"It adds up to three hours door to door," Mr. Kinnear said in a recent interview, two hours less than the trip by scheduled carrier, and without the worry about the dogs' riding in a cargo hold. Harnessed securely and sleeping on the floor, they, too, ride in the cabin of the Cessna, in which Mr. Kinnear has a one-eighth share, or fractional ownership.
Such arrangements were pioneered in the 1980's by the company that sold him his share, Executive Jet Inc., of Woodbridge, N.J., but most of the growth in such ownership has come in the last three or four years.
Then there is Bill Rosenthal, the president of KaplanCollege.com, an online school that offers courses for career advancement. He flies two or three times a week on business, using scheduled airlines, usually riding in coach class. But recently, he had his first chew of charter flying, and the taste was great, he said of the single-day trip between his New York base and Atlanta.
He said it emphasized for him two big advantages of chartering: more time for work in the city he was visiting and less time getting there and back.
"I knew I could be with my customer till the last minute," Mr. Rosenthal said, noting that he did not have to arrive at the airport 45 minutes before his flight's departure and had a quicker drive to the charter plane's field. No less satisfying was the fact that the time saved in ground travel and airport waiting totaled three hours round trip.
But Mr. Rosenthal also said that despite these advantages, he did not know whether charter flying could be more than a rarity in his regimen. He did it on the Atlanta trip, he said, because he found a bargain $998 round trip being offered at the time by a new company that is seeking to build an Internet business arranging individual seats on charter flights.
The fare, which was being offered by flightserv.com to attract customers, brought the cost close to that for a business-class ticket on a trip arranged on short notice on an airline, Mr. Rosenthal said.
He said that in working for a business on a tight budget, he would fly charter again "in a heartbeat" if the price were within 10 or 15 percent of an airline's fare for the same trip, but "above 15 percent, I'd have to give it a a lot of thought, and over 25, 30 percent, I can't justify it."
While hard-and-fast figures on charter flying are difficult to come by -- the Federal Aviation Administration lumps charter flights with commuter airline flights -- charter operators and those who follow the business say chartering in the United States has been on the upswing in the last few years.
"It's grown about 7 percent in revenues and flights in the last year or so," said Fred Gevalt, publisher of the Air Charter Guide, a listing of charter operators and their planes and prices. He said charter flying in the country had shown no growth for years before that.
Susan Bopp, the owner of Air Charters Inc., a six-plane fleet based at Teterboro Airport, said that after being down earlier in the 1990's, her business was "about 20 percent up over two years ago."
Ms. Helms of TAG Aviation, whose Geneva-based international operations include nearly 150 planes in the United States, said that the company's business in this country had not been caught in any downdrafts over the last decade, its charter hours flown having steadily risen.
Clifton Stroud, a spokesman for the National Air Transportation Association, which represents hundreds of the approximately 3,000 charter companies that he estimates exist in the country, said that many manufacturing companies with plants far from big airports found it "more direct and efficient" to charter flights for visiting executives than to have them connect to commuter flights or drive from the big airfields.
Mr. Gevalt said that while chartering "has been typically 80 to 85 percent business trips," personal-travel charters were becoming more visible. "It's a lot easier to see people get off with golf clubs, skis and a couple of kids and the family dog, more so than in the past," he said.
Ms. Helms said that personal travel had gone from 10 to 25 percent of TAG Aviation's charters in the last decade.
Generalizing about the comparative costs of chartering and using airlines is difficult because of a number of variables: the differing aircraft and prices charter companies offer, the size of charter groups, which affect the cost per person, and the airlines' intricate fare schedules.
Mr. Gevalt, for example, said a typical business trip -- "out and back in a day, two and a half hours flying each way" -- could cost $1,200 to $1,500 an hour for craft and crew, or $6,000 to $7,500 for the day.
With a group of five, that would be $1,200 to $1,500 a person, which he said was not far from what they might pay on a scheduled line in first or business class, or even in coach "if it's a last-minute trip."
Delta Airlines, asked recently for the round-trip fare for a roughly comparable single-day trip that would be made the next day -- New York to Atlanta, about four and a half hours in the air round trip -- quoted a $1,499 first-class fare and a $931 coach cost, though a return later at night dropped the round-trip coach ticket to $569.
In some examples, a large enough charter group brought the cost per traveler below an airline's first-class price.
Clearly, however, many who charter are not concerned with comparison shopping.
"The average we charter costs $2,600 to $3,000 an hour," said Ms. Helms of TAG Aviation. At $3,000, the cost of a five-and-half-hour round trip on a one-day journey to Miami would total about $18,000, with taxes and fees, or $3,600 a person for a group of five.
If they returned the next day, there would be a total of $500 more to put up the crew for the night, and a more extended stay would add much heftier minimum daily fees -- indicating, Ms. Helms said, that charters are most economical for short trips.
The May 21 crash of a charter plane near Wilkes-Barre, Pa., in which 19 people died, has focused attention on the safety of charter flights. The accident rate for such flights has consistently been higher than that for flights on scheduled airlines, according to National Transportation Safety Board records going back to 1982. Accidents that year involving charters totaled 4.39 per 100,000 flight hours, compared with 0.22 for the airlines; in 1999, the rate was 2.71 for the charters and 0.29 for the airlines.
Charter business groups said the higher charter rates were mainly attributable to crashes involving piston-powered propeller planes, whose engines they said were probably less reliable than the turbine engines that power jets and turboprops. They held this to be true even though the plane in the Pennsylvania crash, operated by Executive Airlines of Farmingdale, N.Y., was a turboprop.
According to David Almy, a vice president of the National Business Aviation Association, there are more than 2,700 fractional-share owners in the country. Executive Jet, whose chairman, Richard T. Santulli, came up with the concept, says nearly 1,800 of them are in its program.
It currently costs $835,000 under the Executive Jet program to buy a one-eighth share in a seven-passenger Cessna Citation V Ultra, the kind of jet in which Mr. Kinnear, the retired Texaco chief, has a share. That plus $7,900 a month in management fees and $1,275 for each hour the owner flies buys 100 hours a year in the air, said Kevin Russell, an Executive Jet spokesman.
But there really is no need for jaw-dropping, Mr. Russell said. An owner can always sell the share and recoup as much of the purchase cost as the market affords, he said. Of the other costs, he said, "We tell people that if you fly less than 50 hours a year but want access to a private jet, you should probably charter, but if you fly more than 50 hours a year and your trips are extended beyond two or three days, you should investigate fractional ownership."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
With a Torch and a People's Pride

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY 

DATELINE: MELBOURNE, Australia

 BODY:
Walk through the modest front door of Nova Peris-Kneebone's Victorian home and you soon come face to frame with a picture of Muhammad Ali standing on a stage next to Peris-Kneebone's young daughter Jessica.
"Melbourne 1998 just after the Commonwealth Games," Peris-Kneebone explains proudly. "He was in a boxing ring here for an appearance, and the people who brought him here, they introduced us to Muhammad and brought Jessie up on stage, and you know he has this affiliation with children. So he went straight up to Jessie and held her hand and would not let it go. It was unbelievable, a very special moment." 
 But there is more linking Ali and Peris-Kneebone than a small child's grasp. In 1996, when the Summer Olympics were last held, Ali was the last person to carry the torch. Trembling from disease, he lit the Olympic flame during the opening ceremony in Atlanta, sending goose bumps down Peris-Kneebone's and a lot of other spines.
Now, nearly four years later, it is her turn to play a leading role, and on June 8 in Australia, when the flame arrives at the sacred Aboriginal site of Uluru to begin a 100-day tour of the sprawling continent before reaching Sydney, Peris-Kneebone will be the first Australian to carry it when it is unloaded from the plane.
She will do so with the massive and magnificent red monolith -- dubbed Ayers Rock by the white European settlers but long called Uluru by the Aboriginals -- looming telegenically in the background. She will do so because Sydney Olympic organizers, eager to project an inclusive and updated vision of Australia, found her multifaceted, multicultural background irresistible even though other Australian athletes have accomplished more.
Peris-Kneebone is confident that this moment, her moment, will have resonance. "To have an Aboriginal person carrying that flame is going to make a hell of a lot of people very proud," Peris-Kneebone said earlier this year.
But there is more to it than her rich brown skin; there is the content of her character and of her resume. At 29, Peris-Kneebone is a mother, an artist and a world-class sportswoman in the midst of a career change. In 1996 in Atlanta, she became the first athlete of Aboriginal descent (she also has Filipino and European ancestors) to win an Olympic gold medal, as a member of the Australian women's field hockey team. Several months later, she retired from hockey and decided to train to become an elite sprinter.
"If I was to show you my scrapbook as a kid, track and field was my first love," she said. "And that's what I'm going after this year: my first childhood love."
After surprising the field and herself to win the gold medal in the 200 meters at the 1998 Commonwealth Games, she is now focusing her energies on the 200 and the 400 in the lead-up to the much more competitive races in Sydney. Though her chances of an individual gold medal are extremely slim -- her goal is to reach a final -- she and an even more prominent Aboriginal runner, Cathy Freeman, could win a medal together if Peris-Kneebone manages to qualify for the 4 x 400 relay.
"I think she can do it," said Freeman, who won a silver medal in the 400 in Atlanta and has won the last two world titles over the distance. "No matter what happens, I have a lot of respect for Nova, because she's very courageous. She chases her dreams."
The chase has sometimes resembled an obstacle course. Born in 1971, Peris- Kneebone and her younger sister were raised by their mother, a single parent, in a two-bedroom house in Darwin in Australia's Northern Territory. When Peris-Kneebone was 10, her mother remarried and, according to Peris-Kneebone, the atmosphere changed dramatically.
"My stepfather was a policeman, a very hard, strict man," she said. "I was really stubborn as a kid and him coming into our lives at such a late stage, he was stubborn and I was stubborn and he had to sort of chase me down to grab hold of me. There was none of that sit in the corner and face the wall kind of thing. I was always being chased across the road with a strap. But he was fair. He hated lying, so as a kid, if you ever told a fib, you got the belt. If you told the truth, it was fine."
At 13, largely because of a dearth of track and field programs in Darwin, Peris-Kneebone focused her energies on field hockey, a popular sport throughout Australia, and was soon one of the best prospects in the country. But at 19, she gave birth to Jessica in 1990.
"The whole 12 months after Jessie was born, I was just happy being a mum," she said. "It wasn't until 1991 that I thought, 'The dream is still there: if you want, you can go after it.' "
The following year, she moved with Jessica to the western city of Perth, where the national hockey team trains. She took a job with the Australian telephone company and juggled day care, practice and part-time employment while Jessica's father and Peris-Kneebone's future husband, Sean Kneebone, remained in Darwin attempting to build a career of his own in case her hockey career foundered.
"I'd put Jessie up in the stands with her coloring books or dolls and a little lunch box and drinks," Peris-Kneebone said. "There were times on Tuesday evenings, I'd have psychology meetings and she'd come and sit underneath the table with a coloring book and the other girls in the room wouldn't even know she was there. She was just so quiet and did her own thing. She'll be one of those people when she gets older who will love sport or hate it, because she's seen the hard work that goes into me achieving, seen all the highs and lows."
For now, the Kneebones divide their time between their rented house full of photographs in Melbourne and their family and spiritual base in Darwin. Aboriginal people represent approximately 2 percent of Australia's population of about 19 million but they make up approximately 20 percent of the population in the Northern Territory and own about one-fourth of the property because of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act passed in 1976.
Aboriginal landowners are called "traditional owners" in Australia, and Peris-Kneebone is a traditional owner in Kakadu National Park, where she often fishes, camps and hunts with her family. As a custodian of the land, Peris-Kneebone is in regular contact with tribal elders, including her biological father, with whom she had virtually no contact until he went to visit her after Jessica's birth. Her father lives a traditional, seminomadic aboriginal life style.
"It's funny, I spent 18 years apart from him and yet we are so much alike in so many ways," she said. "I never see him with a watch on his wrist because time doesn't matter. He's lived out in really harsh places on the Coburg Peninsula, living off the land for eight months at a time."
It is on her people's land and with her father that Peris-Kneebone has worked through her problems in the last two years. First came her post-Commonwealth Games depression in late 1998, when she quickly grew weary of the interest in her private life that accompanied her increased celebrity. It was all very petty to Peris-Kneebone -- complaints that she wore too much gold jewelry or that she had grown too arrogant for a society that values egalitarianism. Irritated, she considered returning to the more anonymous existence of a hockey team member.
"I have no problem getting criticized for my performances, but when they start to get into my personal life, I have a problem," she said. "I have a daughter who goes to school and has to face the music and people saying, 'Is this true about your mum?' And she gets really upset about it, and I'd had a gut-full, an absolute gut-full of the stuff."
"She was all ready to go back to hockey," Sean said. "It was all done and then about a week before it was announced, she was watching video of the Commonwealth Games final and just turned around and said, 'I can't do this. I'd be quitting, leaving the sport for the wrong reasons.' "
There have been calls from many Aboriginal leaders to use the Games as a platform for increasing international awareness of the intense discrimination Aboriginals faced after European settlement in the 18th and 19th centuries. Aboriginals were only granted full citizenship in 1967, and even now, their life spans are nearly 20 years lower on average than the rest of the Australian population, while unemployment, child mortality and criminality rates are significantly higher.
Australia's attitudes and policies toward Aboriginals have evolved considerably, but Peris-Kneebone knows there is more progress to be made. Yet she often feels divided: eager to capitalize on a unique opportunity and spread the word; worried about spreading herself thin and missing out on her athletic goal.
"There has been some discussion of a boycott, but the grass roots people tell us to run, tell us, 'You're the one that inspires our children and gives hope to our race.' " Peris-Kneebone said.
Nonetheless, there will certainly be Aboriginal protests of some type at the Games in September, and there could also be some form of protest at Uluru when Peris-Kneebone becomes the first of 10,000 Australians, including the golfer Greg Norman, to run with the torch. Peris-Kneebone understands there is anger out there, but for now she is more interested in carrying flames than fanning them. And when she's asked what message she wants to convey to the world 100 days before the Olympics begin, she harkens back to a conversation she and Sean had not long ago with one of the grizzled elders from Kakadu known as Old Man Bill. The conversation started out being about Peris-Kneebone's gold medals but it ended up being about something more universal.
"All of the sudden he sort of looked at Sean and said, 'Do you want to learn?' " Peris-Kneebone said. "And Sean told him, 'Yeah I want to learn, and Old Man Bill told him, 'No matter what color skin you got, we all got the same color blood.' "

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
More Than a Bit Player

BYLINE: By Terry Pristin 

 BODY:
New York may be second banana to Los Angeles when it comes to the film and television industry, but the city's supporting role is larger than New York officials had realized, according to a study released yesterday.
Feature film, commercials and television production contributes about $5 billion a year to the city's economy -- twice as much as previous estimates -- and provides about 70,000 jobs, said the report, which was commissioned by the city comptroller's office and the New York City Investment Fund, a private company whose investors include several media companies. 
 The Boston Consulting Group, which prepared the study, said that the industry's economic value had been underestimated because earlier figures were based solely on permits and did not include pre- and post-production. (But, of course, New York does not come close to Los Angeles County, where film and television are a $31.7 billion industry employing 250,000 people.)
The study also noted that in New York, there is often overlap between the traditional media and the Internet industry, which generates another $5 billion a year. A study released earlier this year by the New York New Media Association showed that about 100,000 people in New York have Internet-related jobs.
The comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said the report showed that more soundstages are needed to accommodate the explosive growth in film and television work. But Arnon A. Mishkin, a vice president of the Boston Consulting Group, said the question of whether there is demand for additional sound stages -- like those proposed for the Brooklyn Navy Yard -- was not specifically addressed in the study. Terry Pristin (NYT)

Peter Simon, Mary Beth Simon Streep, Carol Leigh Simon Porges, Aimee Simon Bloom, Julie Ann Simon Munro and Johanna Katrina Simon Morris. Loving brother of Mary Ellen Simon White and Madeline Simon Becker. His wife of 45 years, Carol G. Simon, predeceased him. Also survived by three step-children, Mark T. Mayo, Sean S. Mr. Simon's passing coincided with the 25th Reunion of the Lafayette College Class of 1975, two of whose graduates, Peter Simon, and Dana Streep, husband of Mary Simon, were sadly missed at the gathering. At the William E. Simon Center for Business and Economics and at many other campus sites, Bill Simon, Class of 1952, was remembered and the good works and charity of he and his family warmly acknowledged. HEADLINE: Council Adopts Budget Package Cutting Taxes $400 Million and Raising Spending

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
The City Council moved quickly yesterday to adopt a $37.6 billion budget package that would cut city taxes by more than $400 million, while increasing city spending at a rate that far exceeds inflation.
The 2001 fiscal year plan, endorsed Monday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, included a companion capital budget that authorizes $7.59 billion in spending on new or renovated schools, bridges and other projects, a nearly 15 percent jump. It is the largest capital budget in at least a decade, city officials said. 
 The flurry of votes came with almost no dissent: the final package passed 48 to 0 with three members absent. The only delay occurred while city aides feverishly printed copies of the just compiled budget resolutions, and then Council members, including some of the most fiscally conservative Republicans, took turns to praise the budget staff and one another for their work.
"This is a budget I am proud of and that the city should be proud of," said Stephen J. Fiala, a conservative Republican from Staten Island.
But as the details of the agreement filtered out yesterday, former city officials and leaders of independent budget groups expressed growing concern that the budget package might leave the city vulnerable to future changes in the economy, even if it merely slows down.
"Spending is growing faster than revenues," said Ronnie Lowenstein, deputy director and chief economist at the city's Independent Budget Office. "It is simply not sustainable."
Defining just how much spending would grow in the coming year remains difficult because of the multiple ways that the city counts its spending.
The Council finance staff reported late yesterday that the $27.7 billion portion of the budget that is paid for directly with city taxpayer funds would be up about 9 percent over the current fiscal year, which ends June 30. But that percentage increase may decline, the Council staff added, if more federal and state financing surfaces.
Council officials and analysts from the Independent Budget Office said that even if there are adjustments for extra federal and state funds, increases in city spending in 2001 would far exceed inflation, which has been about 2 percent.
The surge in spending is possible in part because of the record surpluses the supercharged city economy has generated in the last two years; the fiscal year is expected to end with an extra $3.2 billion. About $1 billion of that money is being set aside to help balance the budget in 2002 and 2003, but the rest is being spent to support programs in the coming year, city officials said.
The problem, fiscal watchdogs said yesterday, is that if tax revenue dips or even does not continue to grow at the same rate, the programs the city is creating would have to be cut back, or taxes would have to be increased to sustain them.
"It is hard to be prudent in good times," said Eugene J. Keilin, chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission and former chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, the state agency that helped rescue the city during its financial crisis of the 1970's. "But that is the only time you can put aside money for a rainy day, and they are plainly spending too much of the surplus and saving too little."
Adam L. Barsky, the director of the Giuliani administration's Office of Management and Budget, said the city's approach was prudent. "We are not spending our surplus on unnecessary expenses," he said. "And we will have adequate resources to react to any changes in the economy or other fiscal uncertainties."
The mayor has yet to sign the budget plan, and approval by the State Legislature is needed before the tax cuts can go into effect, the largest piece of which would be a reduction in the personal income tax. The changes vary, but the average tax cut for a taxpayer earning $60,000 to $70,000 a year would be $207, or 11.7 percent.
The Council and mayor have warned that the tax cut plan may need to be scaled back if the State Legislature approves changes in pension benefits for more than 100,000 retired city employees, which could cost the city an extra $500 million to $1 billion that is not now included in the budget. 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: June 8, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the City Council's adoption of a budget misstated the amount of money the city plans to spend in the 2001 fiscal year that would come from city tax revenue. It is $25.4 billion, a 3 percent decline in spending from the current fiscal year, not $27.7 billion. That figure, provided by the City Council staff, was higher because it includes payments the city will make before the end of this fiscal year on June 30, to cover debt service costs that come due in the next fiscal year.

HEADLINE: 10 Months, 10 Minutes, $10 Million

BYLINE: By COURTNEY BARRY; Courtney Barry, a writer in Austin, Tex., has just finished her first novel.

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex.

 BODY:
EIGHT a.m. Thursday, May 4. Nervous, bleary-eyed, already highly caffeinated, 21 finalists in the Texas Venture Capitalist Conference wait for the lineup at the Four Seasons Hotel. Today they will pitch their business plans, each in a span of 10 minutes, each hoping to secure the start-up money to become an overnight Internet success, complete with initial public offering and a listing on Nasdaq.
The partners in WebTaggers.com -- Rudy Rouhana, 24, Sean McCullough, 25, and his twin brother, Craig -- have been working nonstop toward this moment since last July, when Mr. Rouhana and Sean McCullough, graduates of New Mexico Tech University, ran into each other in Austin, had a beer and tossed around ideas for a new company. 
 The original idea had to do with posting messages on Web pages, but that has evolved. Now the company's business plan describes WebTaggers as "an application service provider that delivers highly targeted content for e-merchants," enabling retailers from Barnes & Noble way down to Bob's Books to learn the preferences of potential customers who surf their Web sites.
WebTaggers had to clear high hurdles to get here. Two-hundred twenty companies across the nation applied for a place at this morning's conference, according to David Gerhardt, the president of Capital Network, the nonprofit economic development firm in Austin that organized it. Capital Network's team of early-stage investors winnowed that number to 21.
On this warm and humid May morning, WebTaggers' three principals, along with David Chevalier, their 45-year-old chief executive, are putting the finishing touches on Mr. Chevalier's 10-minute pitch. For the last 18 hours they have allowed me to observe their last-minute preparations, and between cups of lukewarm coffee and frantic phone calls, they have been filling me in on their short, eventful history.
The three young partners made their first official move last August, hiring a law firm -- Gray Cary Ware & Freidenrich of San Diego -- and working on patent issues. By fall, they had raised their first million dollars in venture capital, from an Austin company called AVLabs. From that experience, Mr. Rouhana said, he and his partners learned an interesting business principle: "Once you have a venture capitalist, everyone wants to start dating you."
AVLabs took the partners through a "think and drink" conference, at which potential investors and chief executives meet entrepreneurs over a cocktail to see whether they are a good match. (As Sean McCullough later noted, "We were asked if we were old enough to drink.")
At that meeting, they met Mr. Chevalier. They needed a leader, said Rob Adams, the founder of AVLabs, adding, "They were optimistically naive -- they didn't know what they didn't know."
Mr. Chevalier, a tall, dapper former vice president at Dell Computers who has led six other start-ups to success, stepped on board Dec. 1. His job was to develop the company's structure, hire people and, most important, get financing. "At certain stages," he said, "C.E.O.'s of dot-coms spend 90 percent of their time raising money." And that is his job today, at what he calls the "beauty pageant."
"In that 10-minute pitch I've got to give the whole story," Mr. Chevalier said. "And ask for $10 million."
4 P.M. WEDNESDAY, MAY 3 -- Seventeen hours to go. Craig McCullough, tired, head in hands, sits in WebTaggers' office in north Austin in front of a computer, barely keeping his eyes open. Computers are everywhere; desks are strewn with papers.
Sean McCullough, slim, quiet, with a goatee and a nose stud, is reviewing resumes for the six positions they must fill. Mr. Rouhana, tall, confident, eager and sharp-witted, is on the phone talking to potential investors who are not part of the venture capital conference.
8 P.M. -- Craig McCullough takes the business plan to a printing shop downtown to make copies. Mr. Chevalier is rehearsing his pitch on his trip back to Austin from San Francisco, where he has just met with another start-up company. Sean McCullough and Joe Gorman, the company's marketing director, are writing final code and planning screen shots for the company demos.
9:30 P.M. -- Tomorrow's audience, the venture capitalists, are in the lounge of the Four Seasons. They are well groomed and prosperous looking: casually dressed but exuding confidence. They are here to have a good time, drinking in the lounge, but are restless, as though ready and eager for the hunt.
Mr. Rouhana is here, working the venture capitalists. He talks shop with Bryan Steffen, of the Berthel Fisher Company. A round of drinks arrives. Nobody seems daunted by Mr. Rouhana's clothing, which is pure grunge: T-shirt and baggy, faded olive-drab military pants. (At the pitch the next morning, he will be wearing the same outfit.)
11 P.M. -- Throughout the night, phone calls have been flying back and forth. At 11, Mr. Rouhana learns there is a problem with the printing job for the business plan: the shop, backlogged, does not have the right binders. Craig McCullough and WebTaggers' network administrator, Vance Shtraikh, roll up their sleeves and head over to help with the print job. Back at the hotel suite, Sean McCullough is trying to open a port on WebTaggers' server: they must be able to connect from the hotel to show the demos. Sometime after midnight, Sean succeeds.
2 A.M. THURSDAY -- The partners have connected with Mr. Chevalier, whose flight from Dallas was delayed and who has just made the four-hour drive to Austin in a rental car. He had been told by the event's sponsors that on the night before the pitch, there would be a dress rehearsal of sorts.
"They said, 'No problem, you guys come in any time -- we'll be there,' " Mr. Chevalier said. "Well, with all my flight delays and having to drive from Dallas, I ended up at the Four Seasons at midnight or 1 in the morning, and nobody was there in the hotel ballroom. Basically it was just me and all the hotel employees, setting up the chairs and tables. And so I said the hell with it. I just got up and rehearsed my pitch on my own to the hotel employees."
At 3, after debating whether to try to get some sleep, the partners and Mr. Chevalier decide to get breakfast at an all-night diner.
7 A.M. -- The conference kicks off with a buffet breakfast. A Nasdaq representative, Chris Santiago, tells the audience how the exchange has added 228 companies just since January. Impressive, but is anyone paying attention? People look up, acknowledge that he is talking, turn back to their tablemates and sip their coffee. Eyes skirt the room; the venture capitalists seem to be wondering, "Who should I be talking to here?"
The room is awash in business cards floating from hand to hand. In the lobby during the presentations, there is a friendly competition among the service providers, and perhaps a biting envy lurking beneath. Lawyers and accountants have booths with slick slogans ("Winning Matters"). They smell money and are dying to land these new companies as clients. At one law firm booth, representatives, friendly at first, offer me a book on Silicon Valley; when they realize I am not a presenter, they dismiss me with a curt "Enjoy your book."
8:01 A.M. -- One hour until showtime. Craig McCullough calls Mr. Rouhana from the print shop. The business- plan copies are done at last. Mr. Chevalier is suited up and ready for the pitch, so ready that he sits in on the four other company pitches before his.
9:18 A.M. -- Mr. Chevalier speaks before an audience of more than 600 investors, developers, service providers, lawyers, accountants and others. He opens with a joke about an incident involving his family, but it is his delivery that is crucial. Unlike some of the presenters, who cling to the lectern, he uses the front of the room as a stage, walking confidently around as he speaks. He seems to know intuitively what the venture capitalists want to hear. "Very smooth," one says.
Was it a success? The WebTaggers guys say they will not know until the wire transfer date, Aug. 15, when WebTaggers anticipates that funds from investors will have traded hands. After that? Jan. 1, 2001, the "fume date," which no one really wants to think about -- the point at which, if no venture capital is coming in, the partners must admit defeat.
"But that's not going to happen," Mr. Chevalier said, and there was reason to hope that he was right. Though the recent skid in technology stocks has made venture capitalists want to "look for deals only with bulletproof economic models," as he put it in an interview in late May, the company is showing a profit. And any day now, it is expecting to receive its first formal proposals from a short list of potential investors.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Wising Up, Though He Ain't No Bigger Than a Poot

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:

JIM THE BOY
By Tony Earley
227 pages. Little, Brown. $23.95.
Accurate as it would be to call Tony Earley's first novel a radiant, knowing, pitch-perfect parable of childhood, it seems wrong to say things that would make his characters blush. Mr. Earley's book is set during the Depression in the modest, folksy North Carolina town of Aliceville, where "Shoot!" and "Daggummit" and "You knothead" are the cuss words in common parlance and a ghostly story still resonates about the little girl for whom the place was named. In this simple setting, which Mr. Earley renders with a wonderful blend of nostalgia and sophistication, the verities discovered by 10-year-old Jim have a way of seeming particularly eternal. 
 The expert and irony-free minimalism of "Jim the Boy" gives it the plain, wholehearted sound of a book for young readers. But the forthright and sweetly humorous way in which Jim's story unfolds is anything but naive. This book's rural characters seem as carefully chosen as figures in a Greek myth, like the widowed mother who sounds as if she stepped out of a folk song ("Mama was tall and pale and handsome; her neck was long and white") to watch over her son. The other deities in Jim's universe are the three uncles who during the course of this quick and unexpectedly elegant fable teach Jim everything he needs to know.
"Y'all know who I am," Jim insists on the morning of his 10th birthday when Uncles Al, Coran and Zeno teasingly pretend not to recognize him. "Can't say that we do," Uncle Coran remarks, in a book that, while not without seriousness, seldom sounds any less good-natured than that. It turns out that the twins Al and Coran and their older brother ("His age was considerable, up in the 40's somewhere," Jim thinks about Zeno), mean to surprise Jim with a baseball glove and bat, which they present with the characteristically wry understatement that serves as local color.
"Never seen them before," says Uncle Coran, when the glove and Louisville slugger turn up in the middle of the dining room table. "What are they?"
Jim's Mama urges the uncles to quit kidding. ("Oh, stop it. Sometimes I could just strangle y'all.") In the end, it is Zeno, the book's foremost source of wisdom, who ends the birthday celebration on a suitably sweeping note. "He ain't no bigger than a poot," says Zeno, "but I guess we'll keep him." It wouldn't take many poots to tip a book this slender into the realm of sugary down-home charm. But Mr. Earley, whose first book was a collection of short stories, retains the economy and purposefulness that that form demands, as he leads Jim through a series of exploratory ventures beyond the loving shelter of his Aliceville home. The book's landscape and cast of characters are so selectively delineated that each of these forays has the mythic quality of a major undertaking, even on the journey about which "Uncle Al would say only that they were going to see a man about a dog."
This is the trip on which Jim visits a town big enough to have a courthouse, a place that affords a tempting sight. ("Jim could no longer imagine sitting inside a soda shop than in the house of a king, and did not ask Uncle Al to stop."). It's the time he first sets foot in another state. ("South Carolina," said Uncle Al. "Not much to it, huh?") And provides Jim with his first experience of the Atlantic Ocean, where he steps into the water ("A fish no bigger than a thought swam by his feet") and tries to imagine where else that water has been. The beauty of "Jim the Boy" lies in its graceful way of describing a boy who is in every way thus poised on the verge of discovery, thrilled and fearful to find new wisdom flooding into his familiar world.
The course of the book leads Jim to make peace with thoughts of his father, who fell dead in a cotton field the week before Jim was born. It leads him to understand his mother's loneliness, especially when a genial traveling feed salesman named Whitey Whiteside begins to court her. (Wondering about Whitey's presence around his mother made other questions begin "pulling into his head like trains into a station.")
It brings Jim into friendly rivalry with a schoolmate named Penn who fights with him about baseball and makes him see the contrast between Penn's life on a nearby mountain and Jim's life in town. It seems no coincidence that Penn's mother, glimpsed briefly at home, is in a sky-blue dress and a white apron, as if this symbolic setting were indeed part of the clouds. The whole book has the sharp, clean, inviting hyperreality of a detail like that.
The most daunting figure in Jim's world is the grandfather who will have nothing to do with him and who can also be found somewhere up the mountain. And while it's true that Jim comes to know about pride, competition, racial tension and disabling illness during the course of the story, nothing looms larger for him than the terrifying specter of that mean old man. It is some measure of Mr. Earley's storytelling mettle that he uses Jim's grandfather to generate the book's closing epiphany without remotely reaching for the literary equivalent of a big grandfatherly hug.
The novel's matter-of-fact-looking cover illustration ably conveys the meaning of this last episode. Yet this picture, like the story itself, has the stealth aspect of something intended for young readers in an innocent, less cynical time. In fact, "Jim the Boy" is anything but quaint. Mr. Earley may not have invented the coming-of-age novel, but he streamlines and reawakens the genre with this swift, lovely book.

HEADLINE: Growth Rate Of Borrowing Fell in April, Fed Reports

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Americans increased their borrowing at a less feverish pace in April, ringing up the smallest rise in consumer credit in six months, the Federal Reserve said today.
Total consumer credit rose a seasonally adjusted $9.3 billion in April for an annual growth rate of 7.8 percent. That was the smallest gain since October, when Americans increased their borrowing by $5.3 billion. 
 Still, the increase in borrowing was larger than the $8 billion many analysts were expecting.
Consumer credit in March grew by $10.7 billion, stronger than the Fed estimated one month ago. That translates into an annual growth rate of 9 percent.
In April, demand for revolving credit, like that of credit cards, rose $5.9 billion, an 11.4 percent annual rate. That was down from $7 billion and an 13.8 percent rate in March.
The total amount of nonrevolving credit, like loans for new cars, vacations and other big-ticket items, advanced by $3.4 billion at an annual rate of 5 percent in April. That also was down from $3.7 billion and a 5.5 percent rate in March.
The Fed has raised interest rates six times since June 1999, including a more aggressive half-point increase in May to slow the economy and keep inflation from becoming a problem.
Consumer spending accounts for two-thirds of all economic activity and has been the engine behind the supercharged economy.
Last month, the Commerce Department reported that retail sales in April fell for the first time since August 1998.
Since then, some economic data -- including home sales, factory orders and the unemployment report, which showed that the jobless rate rose to 4.1 percent in May and that employers had cut jobs -- offered signs that the economy might be slowing.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The trade deficit may seem harmless, but it could be what trips up growth.

BYLINE: By Jeff Madrick; This column appears here every Thursday. Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and adjunct professor of social sciences at Cooper Union. Four economic analysts -- Mr. Madrick, Virginia Postrel, Alan B. Krueger and Hal R. Varian -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
IT has become one of the most familiar refrains in economic circles. Every time the trade deficit reaches yet another record, as it did again this March, economists generally assure us that there is little, perhaps nothing, to worry about.
We've dealt with high trade deficits for 20 years, the argument goes, and we're still the leading economy in the world. But in recent years, the deficit has actually been growing considerably faster than has the economy itself. And when Americans buy more from abroad than at home, someone in the United States must borrow those dollars from foreigners. As a result, the nation's foreign debt is rising faster than its income. And as the economy begins to slow at last, the question becomes more urgent because slower growth may persuade global investors to put their money elsewhere. The rising level of debt is not sustainable indefinitely. 
 Why are we so complacent? One reason is that a couple of misleading half-truths have become conventional wisdom.
The first of these is that, contrary to what you may have thought, the trade deficit really reflects America's economic strength, not any inability to compete on the part of companies in the United States. This year, Americans are buying in excess of $300 billion more from foreigners than they will buy from the United States, so the argument goes, because this nation is so much better off than the rest of the world. If only foreign economies were as strong as America's. Then their companies and consumers would buy more American goods.
But, in truth, if foreign consumers and investors suddenly bought another $300 billion from the United States, Americans companies could not handle it. Labor markets are tight and business is already running full out, so an increase in production of roughly 3 percent of the nation's economic output would be inflationary.
"People often seem to forget that because we are approaching the limits to capacity," says Wynne Godley, senior economist at the Jerome Levy Institute at Bard College, "an increase in foreign demand would have to be matched by a comparable decrease in consumption by Americans."
Secondly, we are invariably told that the trade deficit merely reflects America's record low savings rate. This is true as far as it goes. When Americans save so little, the nation must attract enormous sums of capital from overseas to fuel investment.
Fortunately, right now foreigners are willing to lend a lot of money to the United States, as well as buy American stocks. This helps keep the value of the dollar high, which stimulates imports by pushing prices down and restrains exports by driving their prices up. According to this reasoning, the trade deficit is simply a trivial side effect.
But it does not follow from this that all the United States needs to do is to raise its savings rate and everything would be fine. If the savings rates were to sharply improve, consumers would spend much less. The lower spending, in turn, would substantially reduce output and employment in the economy, running the risk of outright recession.
Unfortunately, these half-truths drown out more useful discussions about ways to improve America's ability to produce what Americans themselves want to buy. Low savings rate or high, Americans like to buy imports more than foreigners like to buy American products. So the trade deficit does to some extent reflect how internationally competitive American companies are.
In her comprehensive book "Is the U.S. Trade Deficit Sustainable?" Catherine L. Mann of the Institute for International Economics shows clearly that as Americans make more money, a higher proportion of their purchases is from abroad.
How to correct this? An unusually high dollar, which the Clinton administration has favored because it simultaneously restrains inflation and attracts foreign investment, only makes these matters worse. It reduces incentives to invest in export-producing companies by keeping prices for these goods unduly high to foreigners. It also reduces incentives to invest in American companies that compete with imports by keeping those prices low.
America's inherent competitive advantages would also be better served, especially in the new economy, if the nation invested more effectively in its human capital, in research and development and in infrastructure. At least in part, this will require the efforts of government.
But those who believe that trade deficits merely reflect the low savings rate insist that any budget surpluses be used to pay down Treasury debt. In the short run, this would raise the nation's total savings, they argue, but what they ignore is that it would also forgo the best opportunity in decades to improve the nation's competitive potential through needed public investment.
Because Americans have lived for so long with a high trade deficit, many seem to believe we have plenty of time to correct the problem. Aside from a new commission established by Congress to review the trade deficit, there is little serious policy discussion of the issue among Democrats or Republicans, or even among prominent economists.
The current hope -- and it is no more than that -- is for a soft landing. Foreign economies will grow a little faster and gradually increase America's exports. The American economy will slow down moderately, and American consumers will buy fewer imports. The dollar may also fall slightly, thus stimulating more exports.
In sum, the trade deficit will not be eliminated, but at least it will be dented. America's relentless borrowing from abroad will be tempered, and, well, the problem will be postponed if not solved.
But the situation is more delicate than that. The debt Americans now owe overseas investors, Mr. Godley figures, has risen to more than 20 percent of the nation's gross domestic product, easily a record. Even Ms. Mann, a gradualist, believes America may have only a few years to reverse the current trends.
If the economy does indeed begin to slow even moderately, Ms. Mann and Mr. Godley -- no ideological bedfellows -- both agree that foreign investors may want to rebalance their portfolios (as might domestic investors) in favor of the securities of other countries. This would place downward pressure on the dollar and stock prices, and there is no telling when a small outflow of funds could turn into a run, especially given the stock market's anxious condition.
The complacent attitude among economists about the trade deficit was originally a response to exaggerated fears in the past when America was a creditor. But now that it is a debtor, the nation no longer enjoys such a luxury.

HEADLINE: Software Makers Ask for Protection From Internet Piracy

BYLINE: By JERI CLAUSING 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
If copyright laws are not more broadly and aggressively enforced on the Internet, software developers will be forced to resort to cumbersome technological protections that consumers will not like, an industry leader warned today.
"You're going to have a piece of music that will only play on one Walkman," said John E. Warnock, the chairman and chief executive of Adobe Systems, during a panel discussion on Capitol Hill involving 10 key software executives. "You're going to have a piece of software that will only work on one machine. It will provide enormous inconvenience." 
 The industry officials were in Washington as part of an annual lobbying trip organized by the Business Software Alliance. They said they were not asking for new copyright laws, just better prosecution of the fast-growing number of digital piracy cases.
"We need more cases brought to the court system," said Carol Bartz, chairman and chief executive of Autodesk Inc.
Mr. Warnock also urged the government to educate young people who think piracy and computer intrusions are no big deal.
"We would like government to set an example, to send a message that this is breaking the law and the law will be enforced," he said.
In a survey released by the alliance in conjunction with the visit, software executives estimated that by 2005, 66 percent of software will be distributed over the Internet, compared with 12 percent today.
"The increase in Internet distribution and the growing number of users raises the possibility of even greater losses due to piracy in the coming years," said the study, which cited an estimate that 36 percent of software in use last year had been pirated.
Ms. Bartz said she would urge that Congress become involved in encouraging more copyright enforcement efforts by federal authorities.
In addition to meeting with administration officials and Congressional leaders over the last two days, the executives sent letters to the presidential candidates asking for their dedication to three top policy goals outlined in the survey.
In addition to broader copyright enforcement, they are urging continued adoption of free trade policies. The House recently voted to establish free trade with China and a vote is pending in the Senate.
The executives are also pushing for more visas for skilled foreign workers, saying that without the visas, 9 percent of America's high-skill, high-wage jobs will go unfilled.
"How you respond to these issues will have a vital impact on the next phase of the Internet economy, with tremendous consequences for American jobs, standard of living and competitiveness," the executives wrote. "We ask for your full support and your commitment to make these an integral part of your policy agenda."
Among the other software executives in Washington on Wednesday were Andrew S. Grove of Intel, Eric E. Schmidt of Novell and Stephen M. Bennett of Intuit. William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, was in Washington on Tuesday for meetings and a Congressional hearing, but returned to Seattle on Tuesday night.

HEADLINE: C. D. Atkins, 86, Inventor of Orange Juice Process

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE 

 BODY:
C. D. Atkins, an inventor of frozen concentrated orange juice, which revolutionized the Florida citrus industry, died last Saturday at his home in Winter Haven, Fla. He was 86.
Mr. Atkins, Edwin L. Moore and L. G. MacDowell, who died in July 1986, were the research team that the Florida Citrus Commission asked in the 1940's to improve the quality of processed orange products. The purpose was to provide better juice for the armed forces and make more efficient use of Florida's orange crop. The work was done at a laboratory provided by the United States Department of Agriculture in Lakeland, Fla., and began in 1942. 
 The concentration process, which involves heating the juice so that the water evaporates, was already well known. But the three invented the process in which the flavor of orange juice could be retained by adding a bit of fresh juice to the concentrate and then freezing it. Called the cutback process, it led to the expansion of the Florida citrus economy as well as surrounding industries for transporting and warehousing the juice.
The cutback process also created a more nutritious product by restoring some of the Vitamin C that was lost in heating.
Cedric Donald Atkins was born on Sept. 7, 1913, in Winter Haven. He was the only child of James H. Atkins, a railroad telegraph operator, and his wife, Christina, an elementary-school teacher. The Atkinses had inherited a couple of hundred acres of land in 1887, and they planted orange groves, from which they earned a second income, according to Mr. Atkins's son, Robert.
C. D. Atkins attended the University of Florida for three years, planning to be a doctor. But when his parents ran out of money, he transferred to Florida Southern College near his parents' home in Lakeland, where he could help finance his tuition by teaching chemistry, biology and physics at the college. He graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in 1937.
After college, he taught high school and coached football in the Florida towns of Plant City, Fort Meade and Winter Haven. In 1942, he became a research scientist with the federal Department of Agriculture.
Mr. Atkins had seven patents in all, including one for a sports drink containing orange juice, a pulp-free syrup for carbonated beverages and a process for extracting the aroma from fresh juice, then adding it to concentrate, which enhances its flavor.
The process for frozen orange juice was patented in 1946 under an agreement in which the patent belonged to the federal government.
"He never mentioned regretting it," Mr. Atkins's son said. "He always had enough money to be comfortable."
Mr. Atkins is survived by his wife, the former Martha Kathryn Marsh; a daughter, Barbara Atkins Smith, and his son, Robert, both of Winter Haven; nine grandchildren, and six great-grandchildren.

HEADLINE: With Only Their Wits, Part II

BYLINE: By David Martin; David Martin is a lawyer.

DATELINE: OTTAWA

 BODY:
With the success of CBS's series "Survivor," we can expect the other networks to play catch-up with copycat versions like these:
 
Big Apple Survivor (Fox)
Two eight-member teams of Midwestern tourists are dropped off in Bensonhurst with nothing but the clothes on their backs. Over the next 39 days, relying on their wits, they compete to see which player will be first to reach Midtown and claim the million-dollar prize. Every three nights, the teams are pitted in competitions like ticket scalping and taxicab hailing in hopes of winning precious prizes like subway tokens. The losing team must vote to remove a member, who is left in the new Times Square to wander alone. 

Silicon Valley Survivor (ABC)
Ten technophobes, deposited in Silicon Valley, use their rudimentary skills to see who will be first to contact family and be taken home. Watch as they tackle coinless pay phones, cashless supermarkets and Palm Pilot banking. Each week, the survivors are given a new device, like an e-mail pager or Global Positioning System receiver, with just an instruction manual to guide them.
 
White House Survivor (NBC)
Fifteen males and one female are split into teams, the Democrats and the Republicans. Using only their natural gifts to raise soft money, each team slowly narrows itself down to one presidential candidate. The two finalists compete in a late fall 900-number telephone contest for a four-year term.
 
E.U. Survivor (CNN)
Each week, representatives of the 15 countries of the European Union compete to see which will emerge as the economic ruler of Europe. Contestants can artificially inflate or deflate their currencies to undermine the euro. Smaller countries can band together to reinstate tariff barriers. The show will end when Germany wins.
 
Solar System Survivor (PBS)
Nine planets, nine orbits. Watch as each of the planets tries to avoid the effects of climatic change, deteriorating orbits and random asteroids. See who survives into the next millennium and who ends up as a sunspot.

HEADLINE: Jobs With Links To Internet Soar

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
The Internet accounted for one job in 50 in the American economy last year as the number of workers who depend on the Internet for their jobs surged, according to a study released this week.
The study, commissioned by Cisco Systems Inc., the maker of network equipment, reported that nearly 2.5 million people made a living directly from the Internet in 1999. 
 That was a jump of 36 percent from 1998, up from about 1.8 million, according to the report by the Center for Research in Electronic Commerce at the University of Texas in Austin.
Figures on Internet employment are not available from the government. Its Bureau of Labor Statistics compiles detailed data on various occupations but lacks a special category for the Internet.
The Texas study showed the inroads being made by the Internet are broad.
"It is important to point out that the Internet economy is not just a collection of high-tech companies," said the report. "It includes any company that generates revenue from the Internet." But even in the most intensive Internet companies, not all employees may be counted as Internet workers, the report said.
Although workers were spread throughout industry, the biggest rate of growth was among people who make and service the basic infrastructure of the Web -- the fiber backbones, routers, software and Internet Service providers.

HEADLINE: PRIMARY IN NEW JERSEY: THE OVERVIEW;
Campaigns Quickly Stake Their Ground

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, June 7

 BODY:
Robert D. Franks was not halfway through his victory speech early this morning when he began ripping into Jon S. Corzine, his opponent in the New Jersey Senate race, as a dangerously out-of-touch spendthrift.
The race to control the wide middle of New Jersey politics began even before all the votes were counted in Tuesday's primary, which left Mr. Franks as the apparent Republican nominee. And Mr. Franks's swift attack raised a question that he clearly hoped would define the race: Can he succeed in turning the liberal proposals and record-setting spending that won Mr. Corzine the Democratic nomination into liabilities big enough to keep Mr. Corzine from winning the general election? 
 "What's dangerous about Jon Corzine isn't the fact that he has spent tens of millions of his own money," Mr. Franks said. "What's really dangerous is the prospect of Jon Corzine sitting in the United States Senate where he will have the power to spend your money."
In giving his own acceptance speech, Mr. Corzine, emotional and exhausted after his overwhelming but hard-won victory over former Gov. Jim Florio, seemed to be thinking more about how soon he would be able to take a vacation than about his next opponent. But his advisers suggested today that Mr. Corzine, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company, would soon begin pointing to his Wall Street background as evidence that, for all his expansive ideas, he would understand as well as any lawmaker the importance of fiscal moderation.
"Jon Corzine is a can-do, pro-jobs Democrat who understands the new economy," said Steven Goldstein, a top official in the Corzine campaign. "He's running against a lifelong politician who's never had any real- world experience. And New Jersey, whether it's Frank Lautenberg or Bill Bradley, likes real-world experience in its leaders."
Moreover, aides to Mr. Corzine outlined a plan to depict Mr. Franks, who was elected to Congress in 1992, as an ideological soul mate of former Speaker Newt Gingrich, a strategy used most successfully by President Clinton in his 1996 campaign against Senator Bob Dole, and by Senator Robert G. Torricelli in his race the same year against Representative Richard A. Zimmer.
"The Franks-Gingrich agenda is hopelessly out of touch with New Jersey," Mr. Goldstein said. "Bob Franks can't possibly be moderate when he voted for the Contract With America."
Mr. Corzine is by no means the only candidate still using this ploy. In the Senate race in New York, Hillary Rodham Clinton has also tried to link her Republican rival, Representative Rick A. Lazio, to Mr. Gingrich. But it remains unclear how potent a weapon that will be more than a year after Mr. Gingrich's exit from the political stage.
Charlie Smith, an aide to Mr. Franks, made clear that he would not be intimidated by Mr. Corzine's stated willingness to spend whatever it takes to win the Senate race, which he demonstrated by spending close to $35 million in the primary.
"We believe we'll have the financial wherewithal to compete, with a message that's much more in tune with New Jersey's voters than Jon Corzine is with his immense wealth," Mr. Smith said. "And others, around New Jersey and in Washington, will come to the same conclusion."
He added that $10 million was a decent rule-of-thumb estimate for what an effective fall campaign could cost.
Indeed, Republican officials in Washington, whose help Mr. Franks will sorely need, expressed glee today at the prospect of helping him take on Mr. Corzine, whose advocacy for ambitious government programs, against the death penalty, and for affirmative action, gun control and gay rights made his campaign as left-leaning as any successful Senate primary bid in memory.
"Congressman Franks is an accomplished legislator and an outstanding candidate, while all Corzine has is rich liberal guilt," said Steven Law, executive director of the National Republican Senatorial Committee. "We believe in this race because Bob Franks has New Jersey common-sense values, while on the other hand, if Corzine goes any more to the left, he'll be in Pennsylvania."
Just how much more Mr. Corzine will spend in the fall campaign was the subject of much speculation today. His advisers have said they long believed that a primary campaign against Mr. Florio would be much more difficult and costly than a general election. And after an unprecedented 12-week saturation of the New York and Philadelphia television stations with Mr. Corzine's image in gauzy commercials, he enters the race with Mr. Franks, who is little known outside of his district except among Republican stalwarts, holding an incumbent's name-recognition advantage.
But Mr. Franks's decision to focus on Mr. Corzine's spending was striking not only because he picked right up where Mr. Florio left off, vowing to make campaign finance reform a central issue, but because Mr. Florio's efforts in that regard had won him newspaper endorsements but failed to sway most Democratic voters. Mr. Goldstein also said that Mr. Franks was vulnerable to attack for his own acceptance of special-interest contributions.
The demand among Democrats for Mr. Corzine to add to his spending record was sure to heighten with his victory Tuesday, however. After donating hundreds of thousands of dollars to county party organizations in the months leading up to the primary, Democratic officials said, Mr. Corzine now may be pressed similarly to help bankroll the party's coordinated campaign -- the grass-roots organizing efforts in which the party's presidential, Senate and Congressional candidates pool their resources and avoid putting out conflicting messages.
Meanwhile, Vice President Al Gore, who has called New Jersey a must-win state for his presidential campaign, is expected to visit Trenton on Monday for a town hall meeting-type television show. And an official in Mr. Gore's New Jersey campaign said today that Mr. Gore also hoped to meet during his trip with Mr. Florio, Mr. Corzine and other Democratic leaders in an effort to halt the divisive infighting between Mr. Florio's followers in South Jersey and Mr. Corzine's backers in the north.

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT: POLITICS;
Muted Comments Avoid Criticizing the Defendant

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas and Vice President Al Gore, the presumptive presidential nominees, declined to comment today on the court order to break Microsoft into two companies, but Congressional Republicans condemned the ruling.
Scott McClellan, a spokesman for Mr. Bush, who in February had expressed concerns that a breakup would threaten economic growth, said tonight that "Governor Bush has said all along that it would not be appropriate for him to discuss the specifics of the case while it is still before the courts and Microsoft has indicated that they intend to appeal." 
 Doug Hattaway, a spokesman for Mr. Gore, said that "since it's an ongoing legal matter, it would be inappropriate to comment." Mr. Hattaway declined to explain why silence was indicated in this case when Mr. Gore freely commented last month on the case involving political asylum for Elian Gonzalez, as has Mr. Bush.
Their reluctance to comment reflected a sense among political professionals that the decision was unlikely to have much impact on the presidential election, except perhaps in Microsoft's home state, Washington, where it could hurt Mr. Gore.
Moreover, both supporters and foes of Microsoft have contributed heavily to all sorts of candidates this year. As one Washington lobbyist put it, "It's obvious why no one is getting too far out front -- there's too much money to be raised from both sides."
But that did not stop Republicans on Capitol Hill.
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant majority leader, said the decision marked "a sad day for the American consumer." Mr. Nickles said the Clinton administration apparently wanted a "federal department of software regulation," but said Congress should decide "whether we need federal bureaucrats and federal judges writing our computer software and deciding how we surf the Internet."
Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, denounced the decision even before it was issued. In a statement released at 3:56 p.m., 34 minutes before the ruling was made public, Mr. Armey said: "Judge Jackson's ruling will divert innovative companies from creating better products. Worse, it will send the message to innovators around the world that in America we punish success."
Democrats were more hesitant in their comments. Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the senior Democrat on the Judiciary Committee, said the implications of the ruling "are anything but clear right now." Mr. Leahy urged the government and Microsoft to "invest new urgency" in trying to reach a settlement.
Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said the penalty was too severe. "Obviously," Mr. Schumer said, "if Microsoft broke the law, they should be punished, But not all legal roads lead to a breakup," which he said should be used only as a "last resort."
Lawmakers from Washington State were vehement in their complaints, regardless of party. Senator Patty Murray, a Democrat, called the decision disappointing, saying it would "hobble Microsoft at a critical time in the development of our information-based economy" and "cripple a major technology innovator."
That was mild compared with the comments of Senator Slade Gorton, a Republican running for re-election. Calling the result a sham, Mr. Gorton said: "Today is truly a sad day in our nation's history. Never before has our government so viciously pursued a company that has done so much good for not only Americans, but for people worldwide. Microsoft, the driving force behind the booming U.S. economy, has revolutionized how we communicate, how we educate our children and how we live."
The absence of any immediate denunciation of Microsoft, even from members of Congress who have been critical of its activities, reflected not only a desire to study the decision by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson and weigh the politics of attacking a generally popular company, but perhaps also represented a bow to the corporation's increasing role as a campaign contributor.
A study by the Center for Responsive Politics showed that while Microsoft, and individuals and political action committees connected to it, gave candidates and parties about $1.8 million from 1993 to 1998, in just the first 17 months of the current election cycle they gave $2.2 million.
And while almost three-fifths of the earlier giving went to Republicans, the donations between Jan. 1, 1999, and June 1 of this year were divided with almost surgically exactness. Democrats received 50.2 percent, or $1,118,014; Republicans took in 49.8 percent, or $1,083,723.
Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, has made strenuous efforts to cater to Democrats as well as Republicans. During his visit to Capitol Hill on Tuesday, he met at length with the all-Democratic Congressional Black Caucus and the heavily Democratic Hispanic Caucus.
Still, many Microsoft officials are known to hope that if Mr. Bush is elected, his administration might be willing to settle the case on terms more generous to the company than the Clinton administration.
Mr. Bush's spokesman, Mr. McClellan, avoided that issue, saying, "As president, Governor Bush will fully enforce our antitrust laws to foster competition and innovation and protect consumers," but he declined to say whether that meant Mr. Bush would have supported government action against Microsoft.
In the meantime, the case seems to have little national political impact. Last month, an NBC News/ Wall Street Journal poll did find the public opposed to a breakup, by 52 percent to 35 percent. And many polls have found the company and Mr. Gates popular with the public.
But there was no indication either in those surveys or elsewhere that the subject was one that could change votes. Charles Cook, editor of a highly regarded political survey, The Cook Political Report, said he had seen no impact anywhere.

HEADLINE: Ellery Chun, 91, Popularizer Of the Shirt That Won Hawaii

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
Ellery J. Chun, who might not have exactly invented the Hawaiian shirt but who surely gave it a powerful push toward prominence, died in Honolulu on May 16. He was 91.
Once there were no shirts in Hawaii, much less pink ones with ukuleles, but shocked missionaries hastened to introduce a plain, solid-color work shirt called a palaka to men. Women got long, shapeless dresses called muumuus. These early garments were made of native tapa, or bark cloth. Soon patterns were added. 
 As American tourists began to arrive on cruise ships in the 1920's, small tailor shops began making custom prints on the shirts for the visitors. Hawaiians, in turn, started using them for weddings and other special occasions.
Enter Mr. Chun, a native Hawaiian who graduated from Yale as an economics major in 1931. He turned a Chinese dry goods shop, King-Smith Clothiers at 36 North King Street, into the first mass producer of Hawaiian shirts. Most important, he gave them the name by which they are called on the Hawaiian Islands, aloha shirts.
His wife, Mildred, said the shirts were a way to keep his clothing business going during the Depression. She told The Honolulu Star-Bulletin that he started with a few dozen bright printed Hawaiian patterns with palm trees, hula girls and pineapples. She said his tailor sewed three or four dozen at a time.
By 1933, he was producing ready-to-wear models from cloth imported from the United States mainland, Japan and Tahiti. Surfers and beach boys snapped them up, and before long the shirts had become symbolic of easy, casual masculinity. To be sure, the cheap imitations, particularly those featuring pink flamingos, became gaudy badges for tourists.
Aiming higher, marketers let it be known that each color on the more expensive styles carried ancient significance: Yellow meant victor, red valor and white holiness. Montgomery Clift wore the Diamond Head pattern in "From Here to Eternity"; Elvis Presley wore the Blue Hawaii pattern in the 1963 movie of the same name, and Tom Selleck's Bird Airbrush shirt from his "Magnum P.I." television series ended up in the Smithsonian Institution.
Frank Sinatra, Arthur Godfrey and Bing Crosby wore aloha shirts. Presidents Harry S. Truman and Dwight D. Eisenhower equated them with weekends.
In Hawaii, at least on Fridays, the shirts became acceptable as business garb. And the older shirts became collector's items. The most expensive command prices of up to $5,000. In 1997, the Honolulu Academy of the Arts mounted an exhibition of the most iconic aloha shirts.
To Mr. Chun, the shirts were good business. His store embellished its easygoing reputation by sponsoring a radio talent show in the late 1930's, which originated from the stretch of Waikiki Beach fronting the Moana Hotel.
In 1945, Mr. Chun became a director of American Security Bank. He closed his clothing outlet and remained with the bank until retiring in 1966. In 1991, the Hawaii Senate honored him for his shirt-making achievement.
In addition to his wife, he is survived by two daughters, Colleen Hirano and Christine Chung; a son, Damon; a sister, Wai-Chee Yee; and four grandchildren.
"It turned out well," his wife said.
