HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT: THE LAW;
If Microsoft Is Sawed in Half

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
"Possession of unchallenged economic power deadens initiative, discourages thrift and depresses energy."
"Immunity from competition is a narcotic, and rivalry a stimulant, to industrial progress." 
 Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in June 2000 ordering the breakup of Microsoft? No, Judge Learned Hand declaring in 1945 that the Aluminum Company of America had illegally monopolized the market for a type of aluminum ingot.
A lot has changed since 1945, the exact midpoint between the passage of the Sherman Antitrust Act in 1890 and the Microsoft ruling today.
An economy based on heavy industry and capital investment has transformed itself into one based more and more on human capital and information technology where "it's pretty hard to figure out what the markets are and what really competes with what," as Thomas E. Kauper, a former government antitrust chief who now teaches antitrust law at the University of Michigan, noted today.
Nonetheless, as today's ruling demonstrates, the old factories may be obsolete, but the legal principles that led to the breakup of the Standard Oil trust in 1911 and the American Telephone & Telegraph Company in 1984 are not.
Perceptions and priorities have changed, naturally enough. When oil and tobacco trusts loomed over the economic landscape, the perceived enemy was price-fixing, while in the government's theory of Microsoft, adopted by Judge Jackson, the enemy is the ability of a predatory monopolist to strangle innovation.
But from a broader perspective, these are just different ways to measure a monopolist's threat to consumers, the protection of whom was the ultimate goal of antitrust enforcement in the old economy and remains so in the new. There is no reason the old rules should not apply in the software-driven economy, Joel I. Klein, the assistant attorney general for antitrust, has insisted throughout the case.
Simply attaining monopoly status in a given market, by being quicker out of the starting gate, or more creative or diligent than the competition, does not itself violate antitrust law. As Judge Hand said in the Alcoa case, "The successful competitor, having been urged to compete, must not be turned upon when he wins."
Microsoft, portraying itself as a victim of antitrust policy run amok, has long argued that the government was turning on it in exactly that way. Judge Jackson disagreed. Microsoft's offense, he held, lay not in the fact that its Windows operating system runs 90 percent of the world's personal computers, but in the methods the company used to maintain and try to extend its monopoly.
"Judge Jackson found that Microsoft mounted a campaign of dirty tricks, and the dirty tricks are old tricks," said Robert E. Litan, director of economic studies at the Brookings Institution who served in the Justice Department's antitrust division earlier in the Clinton administration. In an interview, he continued: "John D. Rockefeller used them all: exclusive contracting, throwing your weight around, scaring off the competition."
Antitrust cases have two dimensions: liability and, if liability is found, a remedy. While on the liability side, there is a straight line leading from the earliest antitrust cases to today's ruling, Judge Jackson's approved remedy -- breaking Microsoft in two -- arguably moves the case toward uncharted territory.
Monopolies have been broken up before, of course, either by court order, as in the Standard Oil case, or by negotiated settlement, as with AT&T. But the earlier breakups were along fairly obvious lines.
AT&T's own corporate structure reflected the division between long-distance service, which it kept in the breakup, and local telephone service, which was spun off. Microsoft's chairman, William H. Gates, repeated today, as he has in the past, that there was no precedent for breaking up a "unitary" company such as his.
To assess the wisdom of the remedy in the Microsoft case, which the government sought and which Microsoft strenuously resisted, requires a set of subtle judgments and just plain guesses about the environment for Internet-based information and a technology market that even during the two years of the Microsoft trial has evolved with surprising speed away from the desktop and toward wireless hand-held devices.
It also involves, to a degree that no other antitrust case has, questions about maintaining the country's leadership in the global economy. Of all the earlier antitrust cases, only the AT&T case came close to having such global implications. "If we had left AT&T where it was, we'd have a stodgy, nondynamic telecommunications world today, and we'd never even know what we were missing," said Harvey J. Goldschmid, an antitrust professor at Columbia Law School, in an interview.
Nearly 20 years further into the information revolution, the implications of a wrong bet on the Microsoft remedy are even greater, given the dominance that Microsoft's success has meant for the United States. While the government's economic experts have dismissed the warnings of Mr. Gates, that efficiency and synergy will be lost by cleaving the Windows operating system from the software applications, the fact is nobody knows for sure.
Indeed, Charles D. Weller, an antitrust specialist at the Cleveland law firm of Baker & Hostetler, commented today that under the Supreme Court's current skeptical view of expert testimony -- a view the justices have applied in negligence cases but not yet directly to antitrust cases -- the economists who testified on both sides should have been disqualified.
Breaking up Microsoft "is not like breaking up two factories," Professor Goldschmid said. "A breakup may well be the appropriate remedy," he said, "but the tough part is that there is a heavy investment in human capital, and breaking up Microsoft means changing things for a lot of people."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Attorney General Janet Reno and Joel I. Klein, the assistant attorney general for antitrust, answer questions about the Microsoft case at a news conference yesterday. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)(pg. C13)
 
Graphs: "And Then There Were Two"
If yesterday's order by Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson is held up on appeal, Microsoft would be split into two separate companies that would be required to operate independently. And it would not be just an illusion.
 
On One Side . . .
Includes Windows 95, Windows 98, Windows 2000, Windows NT and Windows NT Server, a business server operating system.
 
Graph tracks windows operating system revenue.
 
. . . and the Other
Includes Microsoft Office, which has Word, Excel and Outlook. Also has the MSN portal, WebTV, Expedia.com and hardware sales.
 
Graph tracks computer applications and other revenue.
 
(Source: Company report)(pg. C1)
 
Chart: "Landmarks in Antitrust History"
The Microsoft case marks the latest major test of antitrust law. Here are some of the biggest and most important earlier battles.
 
Defendant (Decided)
Standard Oil of New Jersey (1911)
 
Complaint
Monopolizing oil business by buying rivals, forcing railroads to discriminate against other rivals and buying up pipelines so competitors could not use them.
 
Outcome
Found in violation
 
Result
Standard Oil was split into 34 companies, many of which are now among the world's largest oil companies, including Exxon, Mobil, Chevron and Amoco.
 
Defendant (Decided)
American Tobacco (1911)
 
Complaint
Monopolizing the cigarette trade through practices like predatory pricing and excluding rivals from access to wholesalers.
 
Outcome
Found in violation
 
Result
Split into 16 pieces, including American Tobacco, Reynolds, Liggett & Myers and P. Lorillard.
 
Defendant (Decided)
U.S. Steel (1920)
 
Complaint
Monopolizing the steel business by its sheer size. The company controlled about two-thirds of the market and met regularly with rivals to set prices.
 
Outcome
Cleared
 
Result
The Supreme Court ruled that sheer size alone did not constitute a monopoly. The decision brought a halt to big antitrust cases for almost 20 years.
 
Defendant (Decided)
Alcoa (1945)
 
Complaint
Monopolizing aluminum production by its sheer size and by its ability to anticipate and satisfy demand for aluminum faster and at a lower cost than rivals could.
 
Outcome
Found in violation
 
Result
An appeals court found that the company was anticompetitive. To remedy this, the government auctioned off some wartime plants operated by Alcoa to smaller aluminum companies.
 
Defendant (Decided)
AT&T (1982)
 
Complaint
Using its monopoly of local phone service to keep competitors out of the long-distance and telephone equipment markets.
 
Outcome
Settled
 
Result
AT&T agreed to spin off its local phone companies.
 
Defendant (Decided)
Aspen Skiing (1985)
 
Complaint
Exerting monopoly power, the owner of three of the four major ski runs in Aspen, Colo., ended a joint program with the owner of Aspen Highlands under which they both sold tickets allowing skiers on any of the mountains.
 
Outcome
Found in violation
 
Result
The Supreme Court ruled that Aspen Skiing had discontinued the program solely to injure its competitor. The company was ordered to pay damages. Later, it resumed its partnership with Aspen Highlands.
 
(Sources: David Ross, associate professor of economics, Bryn Mawr College; Industrial Market Structure and Economic Performanceby F.M. Scherer and David Ross)(pg. C13)

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
No Level Field For Athletes In Schools

BYLINE: By JOYCE PURNICK 

 BODY:
IT'S not that Martin Jacobson is a patient man. He is not. But Mr. Jacobson, the soccer coach at Martin Luther King High School, is a realist: "Come on. This is New York. You put up with it."
What he and his team tolerate is hard to believe, even in New York. Changing clothes on the subway because of inadequate locker rooms in the school on Manhattan's West Side. Spending 90 minutes taking two trains and a bus to a playing field on Randalls Island. Lugging 40 pounds of nets to practice. Raising money to buy uniforms. 
 All of this when New York City has a budget surplus and is committing generous capital dollars to building two minor-league baseball stadiums: for the Yankees in the St. George section of Staten Island and for the Mets in Coney Island.
"Let them have their stadiums, that's O.K.," Mr. Jacobson said. "But they are neglecting teenagers in high school. We need more cooperation." And more money.
It's not school athletic facilities vs. professional sports stadiums. There can be both. There are both. But look at the relative numbers:
For public school ball fields, in the new city operating budget: $10 million.
For minor-league stadiums, in the new city capital budget: $142 million. That's $71 million for the Yankees complex on Staten Island (which includes local improvements like a new esplanade); $61 million for the Mets ballpark, including $30 million to spruce up the boardwalk area; and $10 million for temporary ballparks. Plus plans down the road to contribute $30 million to an amateur sports complex for southern Brooklyn, subject to future budget votes.
All this spending, while Mr. Jacobson and his team -- ranked among the top five in the country -- have to finagle just to get playing time at Randalls Island or at Riverbank State Park. And they are hardly the only ones with such problems.
Only a third of the city's high schools have their own playing fields, and many are in bad shape. Finding playing space anywhere is a challenge. Not only are athletic fields in this vertical city scarce, but public schools have to compete with private schools and adult teams that can pay higher users' fees.
The Board of Education has a new physical fitness initiative, but the city is still spending almost a third less on sports equipment and supplies than it did on the eve of its fiscal crisis in 1974.
This has to make one wonder about priorities. Especially since none of this is new. The problems were documented in a series of New York Times articles last year, portrayed on "60 Minutes," and cited just last week by Mark Green, the public advocate.
The bad publicity did get attention. A new private group, Take the Field, was begun in February and is raising money; it is already adding about $3 million to the city's $10 million for athletic fields -- enough to build at least one major track and field facility in each borough.
BUT school officials estimate that they need $300 million to upgrade fields and playgrounds, not to mention pools and gyms.
"It's hard to justify spending over $100 million on minor-league stadiums when not even 40 percent of our high schools have outdoor playing fields," Mr. Green said, adding that the Staten Island project "seems more like patronage than investment," because the borough has been such a stronghold for Mr. Giuliani, until recently a Senate candidate in pursuit of votes.
The mayor says that economic development, not politics, was his motive, and contends that the stadiums will act as catalysts. Michael G. Carey, president of his Economic Development Corporation, expressed confidence yesterday that "improving barren areas will bring private investments."
But many an economist disputes that theory. Building a stadium "doesn't create development, doesn't generate jobs, raise per capita income -- it does just about nothing," said Andrew S. Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College who consults with governments about sports facilities. "Just take a drive up to Yankee Stadium and see all the activity it's spawned. There isn't any."
But City Hall is betting that investing in St. George and Coney Island will be different. And the City Council did what legislatures generally do when voting on spending money in their own communities: approve.
So the Yankees and the Mets will have their farm teams, if litigation does not get in the way. And Mr. Jacobson and his players will continue to scramble. "Nothing's changed," he said. "I've learned to accept deplorable conditions. Hey. This is New York."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
At Meeting of Tribal Leaders, Gore Taps a New Font of Cash

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., June 7

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore, ever on the prowl for money, has found a new source: American Indians.
Beginning a three-day West Coast campaign swing, Mr. Gore raised nearly $1 million at three events today, including $400,000 from a group of Indians at a luncheon in Palm Springs at the Hilton Hotel. 
 Edward G. Rendell, general chairman of the Democratic National Committee, which organized the events, said that although many Indians had attended fund-raisers for the party in the past, these were the first events held exclusively with Indians. Representatives of 16 tribes from the region -- there are more than 400 tribes across the country -- were in Palm Springs attending a tribal council meeting, and about 40 of them ate lunch with Mr. Gore.
Mr. Rendell, who noted the emerging economic power among Indians from casinos and shopping malls, said that at least 80 percent of those Indians who voted traditionally voted Democratic, and there seemed to be considerable support for the vice president among this group.
"Al Gore has made a commitment to who we are as a people," Mary Ann Martin Andreas, chairwoman of the Morongo Band of Mission Indians from Banning, Calif., said in introducing the vice president.
Barbara Gonzales Lyons of the Agua Caliente Band of Cahulla Indians, and vice chairwoman of the council, said, "Vice President Al Gore has taken the time to meet and speak with us and candidate Bush has not," referring to Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, Mr. Gore's Republican rival.
Other officials said that Indians looked more favorably on Mr. Gore than on Mr. Bush because Mr. Bush had suggested that states be allowed to determine whether gambling could occur on Indian reservations. Without directly endorsing gambling, Chris Lehane, Mr. Gore's spokesman, said of the Indians, "We support their right to do what they want to do on their land."
In a brief and solemn speech, Mr. Gore said that he recognized that the tribes' agenda -- including better health care and more economic opportunities -- had received too little attention. "I don't wear rose-colored glasses," he said, "but I think that it's important to take stock of the fact that we have made success in the direction of progress."
He cited his support for tribal sovereignty, tribal hunting and fishing rights and economic empowerment zones, but said more needed to be done to attract investments and jobs to Indian reservations.
"I know -- I say that I know, but I don't know in the same way that you know -- the burden of history on Indian people," Mr. Gore said. He said he understood how "travails as well as opportunities can cascade down through the generations, parents to children to grandchildren and on and on, to the seventh generation and then beyond." Indians traditionally refer to the seventh generation as a symbol of the future. But, he said, "we have the ability to interrupt the cycle."
Although Mr. Gore was collecting money from this group, he lamented doing so. "I accept that there's a great irony in this process," he said, adding that he was determined to overhaul the campaign finance system. "We need sweeping reforms to end the money chase," he said.
Mr. Gore then flew here to a fund-raising reception at the home of Brad Krevoy, chief executive officer of the Motion Picture Corporation of America, where 100 people gave $1,000 each to the Democratic Party.
He then had a date at the Conga Room in Los Angeles, where 65 people were paying $5,000 each to have dinner with him.

HEADLINE: Budget Offers Perks to Boroughs Other Than Manhattan

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and City Council leaders joked this week about what to call them: the "outer boroughs" or the "other boroughs"? But the reason for the bantering was no joke: the $37.6 billion budget approved this week includes an unusually large share of money and other perks for sections of the city outside Manhattan.
The 2001 budget package includes $30 million in extra money to renovate or expand parks and cultural institutions in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island. It also sweetens incentives for businesses to relocate to certain parts of the boroughs in an effort to broaden the city's recent economic boom. 
 "The Manhattan economic renaissance has become somewhat self- sustaining," said Councilman Kenneth K. Fisher, a Brooklyn Democrat whose district would benefit from the economic development program. "We have the opportunity and obligation to open up the winner's circle so other parts of the city can participate."
The borough-based extras are among the handful of special initiatives included in next year's budget, along with other items like the first significant increase in many years in funds for cultural institutions and an intensified pitch to stimulate biomedical research at teaching hospitals.
The economic development program would, among other things, offer a tax credit to companies that relocate businesses from central Manhattan or from outside the city to Long Island City in Queens, Red Hook and parts of downtown Brooklyn, St. George in Staten Island and the Fordham Road section of the Bronx. The tax credit would be worth $3,000 a year for 12 years for each new employee.
Even if the companies make no profits -- and therefore pay no business taxes -- they would get a $3,000 payment from the city for each relocated employee in the first two years. The city would also offer grants to help companies demolish buildings to prepare sites for new construction. And the relocating companies would be offered abatements on part of their property tax bill, all part of an effort to make it more affordable to move to the other boroughs, instead of, perhaps, New Jersey, city officials said.
Some of the incentives already exist, but the new program offers enhancements, and it is intended to bring high-technology jobs to the other boroughs and prevent manufacturing jobs from leaving the city.
"We need this; the city needs this," said Paul Bader, the owner of City Imprint Inc., a Manhattan-based printing company, who said he had seen too many other printing companies move out of the city because of rising costs in Manhattan and too few alternatives for relocation within the city. "It is vital to the maintenance of manufacturing businesses."
The extra money for construction projects at parks and cultural institutions in the other boroughs -- the term that Mr. Giuliani told the Council members he preferred -- was added to the budget shortly before it was adopted this week.
It includes $3 million to build soccer fields at Flushing Meadows in Queens, $3 million to renovate the fountain at Grand Army Plaza and Litchfield Villa in Prospect Park in Brooklyn and $1 million to renovate tennis courts at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, all in the coming year. These projects are in addition to other major capital projects in the other boroughs like a new courthouse on Jay Street in Brooklyn and a new Willis Avenue Bridge.
Among other initiatives in the new budget is an increase of $7 million, amounting to $10 million, in grants that the city intends to offer hospitals and universities to further biomedical research. Another $2 million would be invested over the next two years to help build a biology research center at the City University of New York in upper Manhattan.
Dr. Jeremiah A. Barondess, the president of the New York Academy of Medicine, said that the city's share of federal biomedical research funds had dropped in recent years, making it harder for universities and hospitals to attract top researchers. The city grant fund, which he said he thought would be the only one of its kind in the country, should help reverse that trend.
The budget also contains good news for cultural groups. An extra $7 million was put into the budget for institutions like the Brooklyn Museum, the Museum of Natural History, the Queens Botanical Garden, Wave Hill in the Bronx and Snug Harbor Cultural Center in Staten Island.
"This is a much needed increase and the first substantive increase in more than a decade," said Arnold L. Lehman, director of the Brooklyn Museum. In 1990, the museum closed its doors for a second day each week. Officials would not say if they were considering returning to a six-day-a-week schedule.
The budget also has $176,000 for each Council member to spend on programs for youths, senior citizens and other purposes. The amount is $20,000 more than what was allotted in the current fiscal year.. That money is going to dozens of groups, among them the Alzheimer's Association of Staten Island and the Astoria Youth League.
City officials said they could accommodate the new initiatives in the 2001 budget while cutting taxes by more than $400 million and reducing overall city-taxpayer-financed spending by about 3 percent.
But officials in the Independent Budget Office said yesterday that Mr. Giuliani's accounting method understated the actual increase in city spending, which they put at 8 percent.

HEADLINE: Foreign Investment in U.S. Climbs to Record

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
Foreign investment in the United States climbed to a record $282.9 billion in 1999, the government said today. It was the second consecutive year that heavy merger activity pushed foreign purchases of American companies to record levels.
The Commerce Department said today that last year's total represented a 31.4 percent increase from the record of $215.3 billion set in 1998. 
 Foreign investment in both years was far above any previous year. The 1998 figure was triple the $69.7 billion in foreign investment recorded in 1997.
Much of the activity over the last two years represents a boom in telecommunications takeovers as global giants jockey for position in the emerging technologies of wireless telephone and Internet services.
Of the $282.9 billion spent by foreign companies or their United States subsidiaries to purchase or start United States companies, $93.5 billion, the single largest amount, came in information concerns. That category includes telecommunications and broadcasting companies, which accounted for $80.1 billion of the total. Movie, record and publishing companies are also included in the information category.
By country, Britain outranked all other nations with $110.1 billion in spending last year in the United States, over half of the $205.2 billion in purchases that came from companies based in Europe.

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MICROSOFT: THE COMPANY;
Gates Says the Court Fight Has Just Begun

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., June 7

 BODY:
From the perspective of the Microsoft Corporation, the nation's largest software company, the fat lady hasn't sung.
Arguing that his legal battle with the federal government is far from over, William H. Gates, Microsoft's chairman and chief software architect, said today that he was looking forward to the next round of the antitrust trial, which will soon move to a higher court. 
 "I'm reminded of the old saying that, 'Today is the first day of the rest of your life,' " Mr. Gates said during a news conference here on the sprawling campus of his company. "I believe very strongly that today is the first day of the rest of this case."
Mr. Gates appeared calm today, briefly stumbling over his words at the outset of his prepared remarks but then warming to his theme that during the appeals, Microsoft would continue to do what he believed the company does best: design software.
He reiterated his belief that Microsoft had done nothing wrong. And when asked if he felt he might have done anything differently, he responded that his only regret was not articulating Microsoft's story earlier and more clearly to the American public.
"Microsoft and the whole story of the PC was missed here," he said. "I should have taken the opportunity to go and talk about this industry and what it has meant in terms of empowering people."
Although Mr. Gates did not go so far as to assert that what was good for Microsoft was good for America, he generally outlined a view that his company has been an engine of progress, which is now in peril.
"Today's ruling represents an unwarranted intrusion into the software marketplace that has been an engine of growth for the economy," he said.
Mr. Gates argued that the company's principal contribution was in transforming what was once a low-volume and high-cost computer industry into a fast-paced, mass market business, in which Microsoft's Windows operating system allowed consumers to benefit from new features that enhanced the power of desktop computing.
Speaking in front of seven of his top executives -- including Robert J. Herbold, Microsoft's chief operating officer; William H. Neukom, its chief lawyer; Jeff Raikes, a veteran marketing executive; and Mitch Matthews, the current marketing chief -- Mr. Gates said that his most important challenge today was to pursue developments in technologies like speech recognition and computing on tablets.
He also sought to define the substance of the antitrust case narrowly, saying that at its heart the case was about nothing more than whether his company had the right to add Internet browsing capabilities to its operating systems.
At one point, while a cluster of more than 30 reporters and television cameramen gathered in front of a large-screen television in the lobby of the Microsoft television studio, glued to a CNN news report on the judge's ruling, Mr. Gates, clad in a sweater and khakis, strolled past the press corps and was virtually unnoticed.
At today's news conference, Mr. Gates answered questions for several minutes before he then turned the meeting over to Microsoft's chief counsel, Mr. Neukom, who proceeded to give a preview of the company's strategy for its appeal, which he said would be filed in a matter of days.
"I think both the substance of the case and the lack of any process during the remedy phases make a compelling case for our appeal," Mr. Neukom said.
Mr. Neukom, who led the company's defense before federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson in the 20-month-long trial, also pointedly attacked the many state attorneys general -- without mentioning them by name -- for foiling the company's attempts to reach a negotiated settlement with the Justice Department during a mediation attempt by Judge Richard A. Posner of the United States Court of Appeals in Chicago several months ago.
The feelings Mr. Gates expressed today about how his company has been treated unfairly by government prosecutors are echoed among Microsoft's 34,000 employees.
On the Redmond campus, there has been a palpable sense in recent months of a closing of ranks, according to a number of Microsoft employees.
The view here is that Microsoft is the victim of a small Silicon Valley cabal. This group of industry chieftains were fairly vanquished in the market, Microsoft employees often say, but decided to carry on their war in the courts.
Moreover, there is a sense in Redmond that the situation was exacerbated by what many here view as the media circus that surrounded the antitrust trial.
"We've become the designated whipping boy for corporate misbehavior," said one of the company's top executives. "It leaves other companies free to merge and engage in all kinds of behaviors without being noticed."
Other employees said that there were no surprises for them in today's ruling, even as they insisted that Judge Jackson's decision to endorse the government's proposed breakup was clearly wrongheaded.
"Given all the media coverage of this, I'm not surprised," said George Bullock, a programmer who works for the company's MSDN group, which creates tools for software developers. "But I wholeheartedly disagree with the government's case."
But while there was widespread disappointment over the outcome so far of the case, many employees took issue with Microsoft's contention, made in its last court filing in the case on Tuesday, that a breakup could lead to mass defections among the company's work force.
"I still believe in Microsoft and I still like what I do here," said Franc Camara, a program manager in the company's Windows Division. "As long as I'm doing something interesting, I don't care if it is broken into two, or three, or four companies."
Mr. Gates clearly remains a revered figure in the Seattle area. The case has been closely watched by many of the region's residents, who can discuss the detailed legal turns and twists in the case with little trouble.
At the Seattle airport today, Mr. Gates had many fans on his side. "I think that if the company is split up, it will harm consumers and raise costs," said an employee at a rental car counter. "Tell Bill Gates that Jenny at Avis said 'Hi' and is supporting him."
She noted that she owned a small amount of Microsoft stock. When asked about its recent performance, she frowned slightly and turned her thumb down.

HEADLINE: Albright Tells Syrians an Accord for Palestinians Is First Goal

BYLINE: By WILLIAM A. ORME Jr. 

DATELINE: CAIRO, June 7

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright told Syrian and Egyptian officials today that the Clinton administration was willing to push once more for peace talks between Damascus and Israel, but that its main goal in its remaining months in office was a settlement between Israel and the Palestinians.
"There is no higher foreign policy priority for the Clinton administration than an Israeli-Palestinian peace," Dr. Albright said between meetings with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Foreign Minister Farouk Shara of Syria. 
 Capping a hastily scheduled three-day swing through the Middle East, Dr. Albright appeared to be trying to clear the rubble off both tracks of the peace effort. Arriving this morning from Israel, where she secured an agreement to resume talks with the Palestinians next week in Washington, Dr. Albright reiterated President Clinton's hopes for conclusive negotiations there this summer with Prime Minister Ehud Barak of Israel and the president of the Palestinian Authority, Yasir Arafat.
Asked whether the troubles of Mr. Barak's coalition might disrupt the plans, Dr. Albright said Washington was sticking to "its own timetable" for a peace pact.
"This is a rare opportunity to reach an accord, and we cannot let it slip away," she said.
In an hourlong meeting with Mr. Shara, she stressed that "the door is still open" to a renewal of American-sponsored talks between Syria and Israel, a senior American official said. This was the first high-level Syrian-American encounter since Mr. Clinton's meeting with President Hafez al-Assad in Geneva in March, when the Syrians effectively ended the talks by insisting that Israel would have to surrender not just the entire Golan Heights, but also the northeastern shore of the Sea of Galilee.
"We are beyond Geneva," a senior American official said after the meeting. "We are looking forward. We are not looking backward."
Dr. Albright made it clear that the administration was aiming for a comprehensive pact between Israel and the Palestinians, not Syria. She said she believed that Israel and the Palestinian Authority could negotiate compromises on core issues like refugees and the status of Jerusalem before Sept. 13, the date that Mr. Arafat has pledged to move toward the establishment of an independent state with or without an agreement.
"Sometimes deadlines focus the mind," Dr. Albright said. "I would just like to announce, for those who care, we are not having a summer vacation."
Washington is also keeping a wary eye on the still volatile situation in southern Lebanon. Dr. Albright said she expected the United Nations to certify soon that Israel has fully withdrawn, following the terms of United Nations resolutions adopted after Israel occupied the zone 22 years ago. But Lebanon and Israel continue to wrangle over fragments of territory along the hilly border line, which has never been definitively negotiated or even surveyed.
Israel pulled back today from two small outposts north of a provisional boundary newly demarcated by United Nations cartographers. But the United Nations mission that is supervising the pullout contends that Israel continues to violate withdrawal requirements in another pocket, of pastures, near a border kibbutz. The disagreement, though minor, may further delay official certification of the withdrawal, which is required before United nations forces can be deployed in the region.
Dr. Albright's discussions with Mr. Shara dealt as much with the Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon as with prospects for new bilateral talks, United States officials said. American and Israeli officials have voiced concern that violence in southern Lebanon could disrupt talks with the Palestinians, because of its political effects in Israel and the fear that it could spark outbreaks by dissidents in the West Bank and Gaza.
Syria has more than 30,000 troops in Lebanon and maintains effective political and economic control over the country. Dr. Albright urged Beirut and Damascus to do more to pacify the frontier zone, Hezbollah guerrillas now largely govern.
In her talks with Mr. Shara, Dr. Albright did not reiterate the demand for a Syrian withdrawal, concentrating on Syrian acceptance of the United Nations verification of Israel's withdrawal, United States officials said. Damascus and Washington are now "pretty much in agreement" about the certification terms, an American official said.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: AROUND THE NATION;
Montana Voters Pick Candidates for Governor and Senate

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, June 7

 BODY:
With Gov. Marc Racicot of Montana barred by law from seeking a third consecutive term, his lieutenant governor, Judy Martz, and State Auditor Mark O'Keefe had little trouble winning their gubernatorial primaries on Tuesday to face each other in the November general election.
Democrats regard Montana as one of their best hopes for picking up a governorship, as well as seats in Congress. 
 In the Democratic primary, Mr. O'Keefe won 48 percent of the vote to defeat two other state officials, Attorney General Joseph P. Mazurek, with 36 percent, and Secretary of State Mike Cooney, with 16 percent.
Ms. Martz, a Republican who has served with Mr. Racicot since 1996, had 57 percent of the vote to 43 percent for Rob Natelson, a law professor who fared better this time than four years ago, when he won only 24 percent in a challenge to Mr. Racicot.
Montana was also one of several states that held Congressional primaries on Tuesday. In winning the state's Democratic Senate primary, Brian Schweitzer, a farmer who made the high cost of prescription drugs a campaign focus, easily defeated John Driscoll, a former state public service commissioner. He now faces Senator Conrad Burns, the two-term Republican incumbent, who had no primary opponent.
Ms. Martz and Mr. O'Keefe both said they would make economic development a priority. Montana ranks lowest among the states in average wages, 47th in per capita income and, Mr. O'Keefe said, first in the percentage of families in which the chief wage earner holds at least two jobs.
Mr. O'Keefe said those rankings reflected how poorly the Racicot administration had performed, but Ms. Martz said the situation had been far worse when Mr. Racicot took office in 1993, when the state was $200 million in debt.
In New Mexico, Democrats held primaries in all three of the state's Congressional districts. Seeking the right to oppose Representative Joe Skeen, a 10-term Republican from the Second Congressional District, State Treasurer Michael A. Montoya narrowly defeated Mike Runnels, a district attorney, despite a recent investigation by the New Mexico state police into accusations that Mr. Montoya's brother, Orlando Montoya, diverted money from his construction business into the campaign.
Michael Montoya won 52 percent of the vote to 48 percent for Mr. Runnels, a showing that Mr. Montoya said might have been helped by a sympathetic backlash against the police investigation, which, so far, has produced no charges.
In the First Congressional District, John J. Kelly, a former United States attorney, won 43 percent of the vote in a three-way race to face Representative Heather A. Wilson, a first-term Republican whom Democrats view as one of the most vulnerable members of the House majority. Mr. Kelly defeated Sam Bregman, a former Albuquerque City Council member, who won 33 percent of the vote, and John V. Wertheim, the party's nominee four years ago, who had 24 percent.
Both Mr. Skeen and Ms. Wilson ran unopposed, but not so New Mexico's other incumbent representative, Tom Udall, a freshman Democrat, who soundly defeated Francesca Lobato, a tax lawyer from Santa Fe, with 83 percent of the vote.
Lisa L. Lutz, a state representative, ran unopposed to win the Republican nomination.
In the Republican Senate primary, former Representative Bill Redmond breezed to victory in a three-way race, with 60 percent of the vote, to oppose Senator Jeff Bingaman, a Democrat seeking his fourth term. State Representative Stevan E. Pearce had 22 percent and State Senator William F. Davis had 18 percent.
In South Dakota, Curt Hohn, general manager of the Water Development Association, beat two other Democrats for the right to oppose Representative John Thune, a two-term Republican who was expected to win in November no matter who prevailed among the Democrats. With the turnout extremely light, Mr. Hohn won 56 percent of the vote, to 36 percent for Steve Sandven and 7 percent for Raymond Osloond .
In Iowa, each party had two primaries. In the First Congressional District, Democrats chose Bob Simpson over Gregory Guy by almost 2 to 1, although Mr. Simpson is given only a slim chance against Representative Jim Leach, the 12-term Republican incumbent. In the Third Congressional District, Jay Marcus narrowly defeated Phil Ferren to oppose Iowa's only Democratic House member, Leonard L. Boswell, who is seeking a third term.
Both parties held primaries in the Fifth Congressional District. Mike Palecek defeated Conrad Lawlor for the Democratic nomination, and Representative Tom Latham, a Republican seeking a fourth term, easily turned back Thomas Hall.
In the only Alabama Congressional contest, Representative Earl F. Hilliard, a four-term Democrat from a solidly Democratic district, the Seventh, won 58 percent of the vote to defeat two challengers, Arthur Davis and Wayne Sowell. Ed Martin won the right to oppose him for the Republicans.

PUB-DATE: June 8, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1697 words

HEADLINE: U.S. VS. MIRCROSOFT: THE OVERVIEW;
MICROSOFT BREAKUP IS ORDERED FOR ANTITRUST LAW VIOLATIONS

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, June 7

 BODY:
A federal judge ordered the breakup of the Microsoft Corporation today, saying the severe remedy was necessary because Microsoft "has proved untrustworthy in the past" and did not appear to have accepted his ruling that it had broadly violated the nation's antitrust laws.
"There is credible evidence in the record to suggest that Microsoft, convinced of its innocence, continues to do business as it has in the past and may yet do to other markets what it has already done" to dominate operating systems and Internet software, Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said in his final ruling in the long-running trial. Text, Page C12. 
 Under his order, Microsoft would be broken into separate and competing companies, one for its Windows operating system and one for its other computer programs and Internet businesses. It would also be forced to comply with a long list of restrictions on its conduct lasting three years if the breakup order withstands appeal, and 10 years if it does not.
Microsoft said it would appeal the case to the Court of Appeals, filing the papers within a few days, while the government said this evening that it would try to bypass that court and ask immediate review by the Supreme Court.
While an appeal proceeds, Judge Jackson's order stays the breakup plan, but not the restrictions on the company's conduct. Microsoft intends, however, to ask that the entire order be stayed.
The government charged, and the judge agreed, that Microsoft had used its monopoly in operating systems to put competitors at a disadvantage and stifle innovation.
In surprisingly assertive language, Judge Jackson accepted the government's remedy proposal in its entirety, attaching it to his ruling -- utterly rejecting Microsoft's repeated assertions that the breakup plan was "Draconian," "unwarranted" and "bad for consumers, the high-tech industry and our economy."
William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, called the judge's ruling "an unwarranted and unjustified intrusion into the software marketplace, a marketplace that has been an engine of economic growth for America."
"The idea that someone would say that a breakup is a reasonable thing comes as quite a surprise to us," Mr. Gates added. "We have a very strong case on appeal, and we look forward to resolving these issues through the appeals process and putting this case behind us once and for all."
Mr. Gates was in Washington on Tuesday, planning to meet with lawmakers today. Anticipating the ruling, though, he canceled the meetings and hurriedly flew back to Seattle overnight.
Attorney General Janet Reno, smiling broadly, said this afternoon that the ruling "will have a profound impact, not only by promoting competition in the software industry, but also by reaffirming the importance of antitrust law enforcement in the 21st century." And Joel I. Klein, head of the department's antitrust division, said, "Microsoft itself is responsible for where things stand today."
If the judge's order withstands appeal and Microsoft is eventually broken up, it would join a handful of major national monopolies that have been taken apart over the last 90 years as a result of antitrust violations, including Standard Oil, American Tobacco and the Aluminum Company of America.
Tom Miller, the attorney general of Iowa, speaking on behalf of the 19 states that are partners with the Justice Department in the Microsoft case, said the ruling "sends a strong message that no company is above the law." (Two of the 19 states, Illinois and Ohio, declined to support the breakup plan.)
If Microsoft's request for a stay of Judge Jackson's order is rejected, the company must begin complying with the conduct restrictions by Sept. 7 and submit a detailed plan for dividing the company by Oct. 7.
With Judge Jackson's encouragement, the Justice Department announced that it would take the case directly to the Supreme Court, under a 1974 revision to the federal antitrust laws allowing fast-track consideration of significant antitrust cases.
Microsoft opposes the direct appeal to the Supreme Court, preferring to take its case first to the Court of Appeals, which ruled in its favor in a related lawsuit two years ago and reversed a decision by Judge Jackson.
Whether the Supreme Court would even take the case is at best uncertain. Microsoft argued this evening that the suit filed by the states would not be eligible for expedited appeal because the states have no similar law. In that case, the states' appeal would be taken to the Court of Appeals. But state and federal officials said that because the cases were joined for trial, it would make no sense to separate them for differing legal appeals.
The officials acknowledged that the point of law was ambiguous. But Richard Blumenthal, attorney general of Connecticut, said, "Today's victory vindicates and soundly validates our decisions as state law enforcement officers to join this historic action."
If the conduct restrictions are allowed to take effect, computer manufacturers will be allowed to offer customized versions of Windows on their computers in ways they never could before. And future versions of Windows will be offered in a form that allows buyers to accept certain new software features Microsoft chooses to offer -- or to decide they do not want them and use a competing product.
It was Microsoft's decision four years ago to tie a Web browser to Windows that prompted the investigation and lawsuits that led to the breakup order today.
Years from now, if the government's remedy plan works as intended, consumers might also begin to see alternate operating systems on sale that are competitive with Windows. If that occurs, the broad compatibility among personal computers that exists today might begin to erode.
Judge Jackson issued his ruling at 4:30 this afternoon, just after the stock markets had closed. His decision had been widely expected, and investors appeared to have already taken the breakup plan into account. Microsoft stock was up 87.5 cents today, to close at $70.50.
Asked at a news conference today if he had any regrets, Mr. Gates said: "If I look back at anything, I think, perhaps I should have taken the opportunity to go in person and talk about this industry."
Whether Mr. Gates might be called as a witness was a continuing question during the antitrust trial. His halting, obdurate performance in a videotaped deposition proved to be a powerful tool for the government in court.
Though Judge Jackson accepted the remedy plan put together by the federal and state governments, his endorsement was not unequivocal.
He noted that the plan was the collective work of senior state and federal officials "in conjunction with multiple consultants." And, he said, the remedy "appears to the court to address the principal objectives of relief in such cases, namely to terminate the unlawful conduct, to prevent its repetition in the future and to revive competition in the relevant markets."
But even though several experts provided "some insight as to how the provisions" of the remedy might work, "for the most part they are merely the predictions of purportedly knowledgeable people as to effects which may or may not ensue if the proposed final judgment is entered," he added. "In its experience, the court has found testimonial predictions of future events generally less reliable even than testimony as to historical fact."
Microsoft severely criticized the judge this evening for his decision to hold no substantive hearings on the government's remedy proposal. Microsoft said it had been surprised by the scope of the plan and had been unable to respond to it adequately in the six weeks since it was offered.
But in his order today, Judge Jackson retorted: "Microsoft's profession of surprise is not credible. From the inception of this case Microsoft knew, from well-established Supreme Court precedents dating from the beginning of the last century, that a mandated divestiture was a possibility, if not a probability, in the event of an adverse result at trial."
In fact, the government first made plain to Microsoft during settlement negotiations a year ago that it planned to ask for a so-called structural remedy. That was repeated during mediation efforts by a federal judge early this year, though the government offered terms short of a breakup after Microsoft said it would not discuss structural remedies.
The judge also explained why he moved through the remedy phase so quickly, saying that he wanted to pass the case to a higher court as soon as possible for validation, revision or rejection of his decision, "to abort any remedial measures before they become irreversible as a practical matter."
If necessary, the judge said he could hold hearings later or "modify the judgment as necessary in accordance with instructions from an appellate court."
Judge Jackson noted, with some apparent irritation, that after he ruled on April 3 that Microsoft was in wide violation of the nation's antitrust laws, Microsoft's leaders continued to assert that "the company has done 'nothing wrong' and that it will be vindicated on appeal."
"The court is well aware," he added, "that there is a substantial body of public opinion, some of it rational, that holds a similar view. If true, then an appellate tribunal should be given an opportunity to confirm it as promptly as possible."
Microsoft's continued assertions of innocence were one reason for his ruling, he said. Another was that "Microsoft has shown no disposition to voluntarily alter its business protocols in any significant respect."
A third reason, he said, was that Microsoft "has proved untrustworthy in the past." As an example, he referred to the precedent case he tried in late 1997, after the government accused Microsoft of illegally tying a Web browser to Windows.
In December 1997, Judge Jackson issued a preliminary injunction ordering Microsoft to separate the two products. That was the ruling later overturned by the Court of Appeals.
But "Microsoft's purported compliance while it was on appeal," the judge said today, "was illusory and its explanation disingenuous."
